HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Vertex Buys Biotechnology Rival for $592 Million

BYLINE:  By ANDREW POLLACK 

 BODY:
Vertex Pharmaceuticals Inc. announced yesterday that it would acquire the Aurora Biosciences Corporation for about $592 million in stock, combining two biotechnology companies with expertise in different aspects of developing drugs.
 The deal could presage additional biotechnology mergers, analysts said, as stock prices have sunk and it has become difficult for companies to raise money by selling shares. 
 In addition, many biotechnology companies specialize in one technology out of many needed to develop drugs, making it hard to build a business without merging. Companies might seek to merge to take advantage of the potential gold mine of information made available by the sequencing of the human genetic code -- one factor behind yesterday's deal. 
"We are going to seize as much of this ground as we can," Joshua Boger, chairman and chief executive of Vertex, said in an interview. "This is not something we can come back to in 20 years. The fun will all be over."
Aurora shareholders will get 0.62 share of newly issued Vertex stock for each Aurora share held. Based on Friday's closing price, that would mean a price of $24.34 per Aurora share, a 44 percent premium.
Yesterday, Aurora's shares shot up $6.35, or nearly 38 percent, to $23.20. Vertex's shares slipped 69 cents, or about 1.8 percent, to $38.56.
Executives at the two companies said they hoped to create a drug discovery powerhouse combining complementary technologies. 
"It's almost as if we met on a road at an intersection," Dr. Boger said, "and were going in the same direction." 
Aurora, based in San Diego, has technology for studying the effects of drugs on living cells and is working with companies like Merck, Bristol-Myers Squibb and Pfizer. Vertex, based in Cambridge, Mass., has experience in the chemistry of designing drugs.
By becoming a part of Vertex, Aurora will gain expertise in developing drugs from start to finish. Vertex already has one drug on the market, an AIDS treatment called Agenerase that it helps GlaxoSmithKline sell. It also has 12 drugs in or close to starting clinical trials.
The deal could be perceived as a step back for Vertex, toward becoming a technology company rather than a drug company. But Dr. Boger said Aurora's technology would speed Vertex's drug development and its efforts in genomics. Rather than focusing on genes for particular diseases, Vertex is studying families of genes and associated proteins that might play a role in numerous diseases, an approach that it believes offers economies of scale. 
With financing from Novartis, Vertex has focused on a family of more than 500 proteins known as kinases, which are involved in transferring signals within cells. Now it will gain access to a similar program at Aurora that is concentrating on two other families of proteins involved in cell signaling.
Aurora will become a subsidiary of Vertex but will keep its name. The unit will be led by Harry Stylli, currently senior vice president for commercial development. Stuart J. M. Collinson, Aurora's chairman, chief executive and president, will join Vertex's board but will not have a day-to-day role in the company.
Scott Greenstone, an analyst at Thomas Weisel Partners in New York, said Vertex "got a good price" for Aurora, whose shares sold for more than $100 last August. Mr. Greenstone also said the deal was good for both companies. "The sum of the parts will be better than each one alone," he said.
Aurora, which was founded in 1995, was profitable last year but is now operating at break even as it has shifted from supplying technology to trying to develop drugs. Vertex, begun in 1989, is not profitable.

HEADLINE: More Care, More Resources 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The article "As Technology Improves, More People Breathe With Machines" (April 24) details the economic pressures that health care institutions and clinicians labor under when caring for patients on ventilators.
As a physician observing the treatment of my own father since August, I know that many such patients risk developing complications and need a high level of care best provided in hospitals. 
 The current reimbursement system demoralizes all concerned and creates situations in which such care for patients can be rationalized as meaningless. 
 But even people who are severely debilitated and on ventilators can have meaningful lives with hospital-level care. As America ages, we run the risk of becoming a society that treats some lives as more equal than others unless the reimbursement system is changed to provide more resources rather than less.

DR. HAROLD J. BURSZTAJN
Cambridge, Mass.

HEADLINE: Packed Alabama Jails Draw Ire of Courts Again 

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: DECATUR, Ala., April 26 

 BODY:
A few weeks ago, a federal judge walked through the doors of the Morgan County Jail in this tidy riverfront city and observed firsthand what happens when 256 inmates are crammed into a jail built for 96.
 He stepped around scores of inmates that the state prisons had refused to take. Most were sleeping on the floor next to toilets and on top of shower drains, because they had no beds. He saw the cells that no one cleaned and the linens that no one washed. He breathed the fetid air that the prisoners breathed and saw the small portions of unsanitary food that they ate. 
 Last week the judge, U. W. Clemon, wrote a blistering ruling ordering the state prisoners removed by mid-May and the jail cleaned. Judge Clemon's strong language has shaken up one of the country's most overburdened corrections systems. 
"To say the Morgan County Jail is overcrowded is an understatement," he wrote. "The sardine-can appearance of its cell units more nearly resemble the holding units of slave ships during the Middle Passage of the 18th century than anything in the 21st century."
More than 11 percent of the state's 27,000 prisoners are in county jails. Though it costs Alabama $26 a day to keep an inmate in a state prison, the state pays counties only $1.75 per meal to house its prisoners, the judge noted. Holding inmates in county jails saves the state more than $70,000 a day. 
The Department of Corrections "thus has a substantial financial incentive to leave its state prisoners on the barren concrete floors of the Morgan County Jail," Judge Clemon wrote.
His ruling was the latest in a series of federal court orders going back 30 years that have tried to improve conditions in the prisons and jails of Alabama, which has one of the highest incarceration rates in the country, 571 per 100,000 people. . The pattern has become familiar: a court orders prisoners freed; the state grudgingly builds more prison beds; the problem recedes until the inmate population builds again and a new court has to step in.
But this time, lawmakers and prison experts say, the problem may have reached its most serious level. Alabama's rate of incarceration has risen unabated as the Legislature has increased drug penalties and reduced parole. The number of state prisoners -- most of them nonviolent drug offenders -- has grown sevenfold since 1970, and the prison population has been rising by 130 prisoners a month.
Only four states -- Texas, Louisiana, Oklahoma and Mississippi -- and the District of Columbia have higher rates of incarceration, but though county jails in other states also have been crowded, few of the states have had a problem as widespread or as long-running as Alabama's. The low-tax state has always been among the nation's poorest, and a decline in revenue has made it hard to find money for new prisons or alternative programs.
Judges are getting angry, and even county sheriffs are threatening legal action if their jail populations are not reduced. In Birmingham on Wednesday, Sheriff Jim Woodward of Jefferson County said he would try to have the state corrections commissioner, Michael W. Haley, cited for contempt for leaving state prisoners in his jail.
In December, four judges in Houston County threatened to order 118 state prisoners taken from the jail and chained to the fence of the state prison if the state did not accept them. When other judges around Alabama started praising the idea, the state quickly found room for 1,000 prisoners.
But as unventilated county jails continue to fill up, some people in corrections say they fear violence or other hazards as the summer's heat approaches.
"It's becoming a dangerous situation," said Allen L. Tapley, executive director of the Sentencing Institute, a private research group in Montgomery that is a paid consultant to state government on justice issues.
Tamara Serwer, a lawyer for the Southern Center for Human Rights, an Atlanta legal center that took the Morgan County case to Judge Clemon, said the group would continue its work in other counties with crowded jails.
Inmates are supposed to be transferred from a jail to a state prison within 30 days of being sentenced, but often that transfer never happens. Ms. Serwer said many prisoners were kept for months in the small jails, which were not built for long-term incarceration.
Morgan County's 25-year-old jail was all but condemned in September by the state fire marshal, who found in an inspection that the fire alarm and smoke detectors were not working, that there was no sprinkler system and that the building was so crowded that inmates and guards were in danger. There have been several small fires in the jail in the last year, the marshal noted.
Sheriff Stephen L. Crabbe, who is responsible for the jail, refused to discuss the issue or let a reporter inside, citing the advice of his lawyer. But several inmates working outside the jail this week said the reports did not go far enough in describing conditions inside.
"It's a hellhole in there," said one inmate, who would not give his name. "You can't move, and you don't want to breathe."
Inmates said the mattresses that the judge saw were provided a few days before his tour. Before that, many inmates had to sleep on concrete, they said.
Judge Clemon spent several pages detailing the violations of the constitutional protection against cruel and unusual punishment that he found, including inattention to medical needs. Finally, he accused the State Department of Corrections of being "deliberately indifferent" to conditions in the jail because it was so eager to save money.
In his opinion, the judge said the state prison system had unused beds, despite the department's insistence that it was full. The most recent statistics issued by the department showed that its prisons were operating at 97.9 percent of capacity in February, meaning 412 beds were empty. The judge also noted that no inmates in state prisons slept on the floor, and he suggested that they would be better off sleeping on floors in prisons -- or in trailers or tents in prisons -- than in jails.
Commissioner Haley would not agree to be interviewed, but his spokesman, Jack Hamm, said the prison system simply could not take as many inmates as the judge suggested.
"It's not just a matter of putting beds in," Mr. Hamm said. "People need to understand that you have to feed them; you have to launder their clothes and linens; and you have to have the wastewater facilities to handle their showers and needs. The old facilities we have just don't have the physical plants to handle everyone."
The department also has a serious shortage of corrections officers, because of the job's low pay and unattractive image, Mr. Hamm said. (The system has one officer for every 12 inmates, compared with a national average of one for four inmates, and the shortage has been blamed for the escape of six prisoners from a maximum-security prison in January.) Although the commissioner has repeatedly asked the Legislature for money for new prisons, Mr. Hamm said, none has been forthcoming. This year's budget does include an increase for more corrections officers.
Legislators said they wanted to build more prisons but lacked the money. In February, Gov. Donald Siegelman, a Democrat, cut the state education budget 6.2 percent, citing the economic downturn.
It is hard politically to vote for prisons when schools are crumbling. Education advocates have turned to the courts to force spending for schools, just as prisoner advocates have done to force spending for prisons.
"Yes, we are really in trouble in Alabama," said Senator Jack Biddle III, a Republican who is chairman of the Legislature's Joint Prison Oversight Committee. "Everyone wants all the prisoners locked up forever, but they don't want to spend the money for it or have the prisons in their neighborhood. We're just doing the best we can without any money."
Alabama has the country's lowest per capita state and local tax burden, and it relies heavily on the volatile sales tax. Church groups have repeatedly asked the state to consider changing tax laws to bring in more revenue. In February the Episcopal Diocese of Alabama said the state's property tax rates were "unconscionably low."
Governor Siegelman has often said he would not consider a tax increase, but legislators said there had been informal talks recently about increasing property taxes. One legislator said privately that if judges started releasing prisoners to ease crowding, the public could awaken to the situation.
The state has not used the alternative sentencing methods that many other states use to reduce prison populations. Mr. Tapley of the Sentencing Institute, noting that three-fourths of Alabama's prisoners had been convicted of nonviolent offenses like burglary, said the state needed to build diversion centers and halfway houses like the ones other states had used successfully. Those programs would ultimately cost much less than building prisons, he said.
"This is a solvable problem, once people decide to attack it," Mr. Tapley said. "We can't be the scourge of the nation forever."

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing/Americas: Canada: Economy Stalls 

BYLINE:  By Timothy Pritchard (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Canada's economy stalled in February, as output dropped 0.1 percent after a 0.3 percent rise in January, but the decline was only half as bad as economists had predicted. 
Manufacturing led gross domestic product down, with a 0.9 percent drop, and production of electrical and electronic equipment fell 9.1 percent, the worst reversal in 40 years. "Major customers, primarily from the United States, continued to curtail spending, sparking significant production cutbacks and layoffs by key Canadian producers," said Statistics Canada, the government's reporting agency. Gains in construction, mining and forestry partly offset the decline in manufacturing. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

HEADLINE: London Journal; 
To Get the Underground Up to Par, Call on a Yank

BYLINE:  By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: LONDON, April 28 

 BODY:
Even the British caricature that portrays Americans as boorish, loud, blind to nuance, deaf to irony or just plain weird usually includes a grudging good word for their native ability to go out and get the job done.
 While a number of can-do Yanks have ended up in high-profile management jobs in Britain, none have attracted quite so much attention as Robert R. Kiley, 65, the transportation expert brought in to repair London's crumbling bus and subway system. 
 Mr. Kiley is credited by many with rescuing rapid transit networks in Boston and New York, and he was invited here by the city's new mayor, Ken Livingstone, to take on the problem that tops the list of Londoners' complaints about their congested city.
"You are the most important American to come to Britain since Dwight Eisenhower," a British diplomat told Mr. Kiley in a toast at a recent gathering. 
If extravagant, the comparison with the commander in chief of Allied forces in Europe was apt. Like General Eisenhower, Mr. Kiley has also found himself at war.
He is in pitched battle with the government of Prime Minister Tony Blair, which eyed him suspiciously on his arrival last fall because he was sponsored by Mr. Livingstone, public enemy No. 1 at No. 10 Downing Street. Mr. Livingstone was evicted from Labor last year after he ran against the party's official mayoral candidate and beat him 3 to 1.
Now it is Mr. Kiley himself who is being demonized, with unidentified ministers leaking quotes to the British press like "those Yanks think they can boss us around," and John Prescott, the deputy prime minister who doubles as the government's transportation chief, deriding his past accomplishments.
In New York on a visit 10 days ago, Mr. Prescott cast a disapproving look at an R train he was boarding at 60th Street and Third Avenue and told British reporters accompanying him that "Kiley should come back to New York and raise it to London standards."
Those standards do not impress Londoners, whose only frame of reference is the sorry state of their once-proud system, the world's oldest. It has suffered from decades of neglect and underfunding and is now dirty, unreliable and subject to maddeningly frequent service breakdowns.
"When I got into this business in the mid-70's the London Underground was thought to be the best transit organization in the world," Mr. Kiley said. "Now I would give top honors to the Paris Metro." 
In Britain, being called less efficient than the Americans is one thing; being called less efficient than the French is something else again.
Mr. Kiley incurred the government's wrath by exposing its London Underground improvement plan as an arrangement that had more to do with satisfying competing bureaucratic interests than running trains safely and on time. 
He called it "fatally flawed" and added, "It has no basis in reality or common sense. It is a dumb proposal, and we are trying to get it back into the land of the sane."
That proved to be a more difficult journey than he imagined. The Blair government enjoys an enormous majority in Parliament, is considered sure to win a new term in the election expected this June and is impatient with criticism. Officials pressed ahead with the disputed plan while Mr. Kiley and a team of past associates from New York and Boston devised an alternative.
The government plan would transfer tracks, signals and stations to three privately owned companies on 30-year contracts while leaving operation of the trains to the publicly run London Underground. 
Mr. Kiley was quick to point out that the fragmented arrangement was remarkably like the one resorted to in the privatization of Britain's railway system, which today is the most expensive and hazardous and least efficient of any in Europe.
When a suburban train crash killed four people last fall, Mr. Kiley suggested that similar accidents would happen under the government's subway plan. And he added that the consequences below ground would be much worse, given the tighter spaces, the larger tonnage of the cars and the smaller headways between trains.
The train crash was the fourth fatal one in the last four years on British trains, and safety on the rails has become a priority issue with the riding public. Mr. Livingstone seized on that, saying of the government plan for the London Underground, "People will die." 
Mr. Kiley commented: "Ken's more flamboyant than me. What I say is you never want to design a scheme that elevates the risk profile as substantially as this one does."
Newspapers have all editorially backed Mr. Kiley -- a rare outbreak of unanimity for the disputatious British press -- and the London public has rallied to his cause, with people on the street stopping him to tell him to keep up the fight. 
On a recent trip through Heathrow Airport, he was surprised by a woman yelling at him from the other side of the terminal. "What you're doing is so important," she shouted. "Why are you going back to the U.S.?" He assured her it was just a quick trip.
There were months of desultory talks through the winter, with Mr. Kiley and his mass transit experts seated across the negotiating table from a group of Treasury officials led by an aide whose expertise is third world debt.
Mr. Kiley argued that without unified management by London Underground, the system would be chaotic and dangerous. The Treasury officials ruled out any change in their formula of divided responsibilities.
The plan, they said, upheld the non-negotiable wish of their chief, Gordon Brown, the powerful chancellor of the Exchequer, to transfer the risk of any cost overruns away from the public purse and onto the private sector.
This month, the pace of the dispute has quickened, and another showdown looms in days. Stymied by the government's refusal to agree to unified management, Mr. Kiley appealed to the High Court, arguing that the government plan denied Mr. Livingstone the means to meet his statutory responsibility to give London a safe, efficient and economic subway. The High Court agreed to a full judicial review of the plan starting on June 12.
The government reacted by announcing that it would pre-emptively name the three operating companies next week. Mr. Prescott issued a statement last Wednesday listing the benefits of the government plan as face lifts for all stations in the near term and new trains on all lines by 2019. 
Mr. Kiley countered the next day, saying that under his plan 85 percent of the trains would be replaced or refurbished by 2009 and new signals and tracks would guarantee safety.
Looking out of his 14th-story office windows at Parliament Square and the government buildings of Whitehall, Mr. Kiley recalled his first trip on the Underground, in October. 
The train he was on stalled for 11 sweltering minutes in a tunnel, and he ended up in a glass-front control booth at the next station watching uniformed workers form a human chain to hold back crowds swarming onto the platform when no trains were arriving to lessen the load.
"I'm saying to the guy who's taking me around: 'Do these people know who we are over here? Do they ever come and start pounding on these windows? Has anyone ever tried to kill you? You know, we wouldn't last very long if this were Times Square.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert R. Kiley, London's new director of transport, riding a train in the Underground. Though hailed by many Londoners, he is caught up in a political battle with the government of Prime Minister Tony Blair. (Carlos Lopez-Barillas for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New Jersey High School Is Winner of Fed Contest 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30 

 BODY:
A team of students from Montclair High School in New Jersey won first prize and $40,000 today in the sixth annual Fed Challenge, a national competition that tests economic wits.
 The contest, sponsored by the Federal Reserve, required the students to consider economic data, analyze daily financial figures and then argue for a specific monetary policy. The four final teams of five members each were judged on their knowledge of monetary policy and the Federal Reserve and on the quality of their presentations, research and analysis. 
 The $40,000 prize, provided by Citibank, consisted of: a $5,000 scholarship for each team member; $10,000 for their school (to develop an in-school economics lab); and $5,000 for their faculty advisers: Jack Weber, Tom Clifford and Tom Manos. Each of the other three teams received $15,000. 
Although most of the students took economics courses, and some of their schools offered college credits for courses that prepared students for the competition, the Fed Challenge is mainly an extracurricular activity, said Lloyd Bromberg, director of educational programs for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. 
In some schools, Mr. Bromberg added, the Fed Challenge is treated like an interscholastic sport, with tryouts and weekly practices, research sessions and lectures. 
The Montclair team prepared about four hours each weekday and a few hours each weekend, said Ted Chestnut, a 16-year-old junior on the team. The students said they had relied on newspapers, 24-hour cable networks and the Internet for information and daily financial statistics.
"We got together on snow days, and we prepared through spring break," Mr. Chestnut said.
Another member of the team, Michael Rey, a 17-year-old senior, compared preparations for the Fed Challenge to those required for his baseball team. This year, 10 people competed for three open spots on the team. Mr. Chestnut and Mr. Rey were members of last year's Montclair team, which reached the finals.
Mr. Clifford, an English teacher, said the team members received academic credit for the competition. Prize money for the faculty advisers will be used to support the program at the high school, he said.
In welcoming the students, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, dryly offered some advice.
"Remember," Mr. Greenspan said, "if you are practicing to be a central banker -- you do not smile."
The Fed Challenge was created in 1995 by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, and became a national competition in 1996. Federal Reserve Banks conduct regional competitions, sending the district winners to the final competition. This year, more than 250 schools took part, with 6 of the 12 Federal Reserve districts represented in Washington. 
Judges for the competition were Laurence H. Meyer, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board; J. Alfred Broaddus Jr., the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, Va.; Donald L. Kohn, director of monetary affairs for the Federal Reserve's board of governors; and Arthur J. Rolnick, director of research for the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis.

HEADLINE: Rent Board Chief Resigns With Attack on the Mayor 

BYLINE:  By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
Facing ouster by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the chairman of the New York City Rent Guidelines Board quit yesterday and unleashed a scathing attack on the mayor.
 The departing chairman, Edward S. Hochman, accused Mr. Giuliani of being "a control freak" who "brow-beat" and "dictated to" the board, treating its members like "messenger boys" and "puppets," all to "advance his political career." 
 Mr. Hochman also said the mayor and his aides had "manipulated the numbers," "tried to get around the law," "bastardized" the rent-setting process and turned it into "a charade," Pausing for a breath, he added: "I hope I'm not mincing words." 
Mr. Giuliani declined to respond to the charges, but he repeated his displeasure at the board for having raised rents last year by one percentage point more than he wanted, granting 4 percent increases for one-year leases and 6 percent for two-year renewals.
"Frankly, we weren't happy," he said. "We had asked that the rent increase not be as high as it was. For some reason, the board passed a higher increase than we thought the economy or the numbers really indicated, which we think did harm to tenants. I would rather have someone that is somewhat more sensitive to all sides."
One reason Mr. Hochman is being replaced is that he expressed a desire not to do the job any longer, Mr. Giuliani said. Mr. Hochman said he had simply sent an annual year-end letter offering to stay or leave, at the mayor's will, and urging that if any replacement were made, it be done quickly. 
The rent board had gathered in Brooklyn yesterday for what was supposed to be a daylong hearing on what increases it should adopt this year for the city's one million rent-stabilized apartments.
Instead, Mr. Hochman began by announcing his resignation and denouncing Mr. Giuliani. He said that after The New York Times reported earlier in the day that the mayor planned to appoint Steven Sinacori as the new chairman, he had called City Hall but could not get a straight answer.
"It gives me no small amount of pleasure to resign," he said.
Stunned, the board adjourned, abandoning the hearing. Tenant and landlord leaders who had come to testify packed up their speeches. Mr. Hochman continued his criticisms in a chain of news interviews lasting two hours.
The events had a surreal feel.
"I can't recall anything like that before," said Kenneth Schaeffer, vice chairman of the Metropolitan Council on Housing, a tenant group. A landlord representative on the board, Vincent Castellano, praised Mr. Hochman and said, "It's bizarre."
Although the board's initial vote on this year's rents is scheduled for next week, the process is now more clouded. Mr. Sinacori is not yet in office -- he is awaiting a background check -- and the mayor is still filling two other board vacancies.
Tenant groups, who often opposed Mr. Hochman during his seven-year tenure, were cautious.
"I'm hoping the new chairman will be less pro-landlord, but this new guy could be just as bad," said Michael McKee, associate director of the New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition.
As an appointed chairman, Mr. Hochman said, he had tried to reflect the mayor's view.
"I introduced his proposal for 3 percent and 5 percent," he said. "But nobody voted for it -- so why did he replace me?"
The rent board is supposed to be independent, but Mr. Hochman said Mr. Giuliani had exerted growing pressure, especially when he was preparing to run for the Senate. 
"Last year was outrageous, unconscionable," Mr. Hochman said. "The mayor's deputy chief of staff took us into a back room and tried to browbeat us with: 'the mayor wants this,' 'the mayor wants that,' 'we don't care what your reports say, this is what we want,' blah, blah.
"For us to go through all this and have the mayor's office attempt to dictate the outcome for political purposes is outrageous. The pretense of having an objective process is out the window."
Of the new board members, Mr. Hochman said: "They don't need to come up to speed; they'll just call Robert Harding, and he'll tell them how to vote." Mr. Harding is a deputy mayor.

HEADLINE: CHENEY PROMOTES INCREASING SUPPLY AS ENERGY POLICY 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30 

 BODY:
Vice President Dick Cheney said today that oil, coal and natural gas would remain the United States' primary energy resources for "years down the road" and that the Bush administration's energy strategy would aim mainly to increase supply of fossil fuels, rather than limit demand. 
 In his most comprehensive comments to date on the energy task force he is heading on behalf of President Bush, Mr. Cheney dismissed as 1970's-era thinking the notion that "we could simply conserve or ration our way out" of what he called an energy crisis. 
 The only solution, he said, is a government-backed push to find new domestic sources of oil and gas, including in protected areas of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, and an all-out drive to build power plants -- a need that he says will require one new electricity-generating plant a week for 20 years. 
"America's reliance on energy, and fossil fuels in particular, has lately taken on an urgency not felt since the late 1970's," Mr. Cheney said. "Without a clear, coherent energy strategy, all Americans could one day go through what Californians are experiencing now, or worse."
Mr. Cheney, who ran the oil-services company Halliburton Inc. before becoming vice president, offered a supply-oriented energy philosophy that seems likely to dominate the report the cabinet-level task force is expected to issue as early as mid-May. The report is expected to recommend legislation, executive actions and incentives for the private sector.
The vice president's comments, delivered to the annual meeting of The Associated Press in Toronto, seemed partly a combative response to Democrats and environmentalists who argue that the Bush administration has used California's electricity shortages as a pretext to enact energy policies that have been favored by industry executives for many years. 
In discussing their energy plans recently, administration officials have put the most emphasis on opening protected lands to oil and gas exploration, while rolling back environmental rules that inhibit the burning of coal and the construction of pipelines and refineries. They have also strongly advocated the use of nuclear power.
Critics have faulted the administration for moving quickly to abandon a treaty on global warming and rejecting controls on carbon dioxide emissions from power plants, steps Mr. Bush said were vital because of energy shortages. The administration has also come under withering criticism for delaying stricter standards on arsenic in drinking water.
Mr. Cheney said today that environmentalists had taken things too far. He said a recent television advertisement showing a child asking for more arsenic in her water was a "cheap shot."
Drastic measures to increase energy supplies are justified, he said, because the geometry of supply and demand curves are so alarming. He estimated that the country needed 38,000 miles of new pipelines to carry natural gas, covering the distance of Maine to California more than 12 times over.
Coal, Mr. Cheney said, has been neglected. It is the United States' "most plentiful source of affordable energy." He said people who sought to phase out its use, largely because they considered it a major source of air pollution, "deny reality."
He said the most environmentally friendly way to increase energy supplies was to extend the life of existing nuclear plants and grant permits to build new ones, because they had no emissions of greenhouse gases. 
"We can safeguard the environment by making greater use of the cleanest methods of power generation we know," he said, speaking of nuclear power. "If we are serious about environmental protection, then we must seriously question the wisdom of backing away from what is, as a matter of record, a safe, clean and very plentiful energy source."
Utility industry executives have applauded the administration's support of nuclear power, but questioned the economic viability of building new nuclear power plants anytime soon. Environmentalists dispute Mr. Cheney's contention that nuclear power is the cleanest source of energy because they say the mining and enriching of uranium and the storage of nuclear waste are hazards.
Mr. Cheney indicated that the administration would put some emphasis on energy efficiency. New technology -- like computer screens that use far less power and energy-efficient light bulbs -- have an important role because they can save energy without reducing living standards, he said. But he said he would oppose any measure based on the premise that Americans now "live too well" or that people should "do more with less."
"The aim here is efficiency, not austerity," he said. "Conservation may be a sign of personal virtue, but it is not a sufficient basis for a sound, comprehensive energy policy."
Some people who have talked with administration officials about the energy plan expect that the policy will include some tax-related measures to promote efficiency. Among those considered most likely are tax credits for people who buy fuel-efficient automobiles and for power companies that produce electricity using renewable energy sources.
But the budget Mr. Bush submitted to Congress in early April sharply reduced spending by the Department of Energy on research and development for energy efficiency and renewable energy technologies. 
"They give lip service to efficiency, but their whole emphasis is on supply," said Senator Jeff Bingaman, a New Mexico Democrat who has introduced energy legislation that he says strikes a finer balance between increasing supply and controlling demand.
In a report to be released later this week, the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy estimates that raising the fuel efficiency of cars and light trucks by what it calls a modest amount could do far more to reduce reliance on imported oil than drilling for oil in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.
Fuel economy standards reached their peak in 1988, when the average passenger vehicle covered 26 miles on a gallon of gas. The average fell to 24 miles per gallon last year, because more Americans drive light trucks, which have lower mandated efficiency standards than cars.
Raising average fuel use by cars and light trucks to 35 miles per gallon by 2010 would result in oil savings of 1.5 million barrels a day by that time, the report says. The United States Geological Survey estimates that the Alaskan refuge would probably produce 580,000 barrels a day later this decade.
Mr. Cheney did not discuss the merits of raising government-mandated Corporate Average Fuel Economy standards in his address today. But he strongly defended the administration's proposal to allow drilling for oil and gas in the Alaskan refuge. 
The administration has sent mixed signals recently on how hard it intends to push to open the refuge. Christie Whitman, the Environmental Protection Agency administrator, said earlier this month that the energy plan would not emphasize drilling in the Alaskan wilderness, but other officials contradicted her.
Mr. Cheney left little doubt of his support. He said new oil-drilling technologies meant that exploration could take place in the 19-million-acre refuge without disturbing wildlife. The affected area totals no more than 2,000 acres, he said, "one-fifth the size of Dulles Airport."

HEADLINE: Sales and Unease Ahead, Auction Houses Seek Buyers 

BYLINE:  By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
With their sleek new headquarters, glossy catalogs and aggressive advertising campaigns, Sotheby's, Christie's and Phillips appear to be pillars of strength and prosperity. But as their twice-yearly evening sales of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art begin in Manhattan next week, the mood within could best be described as jittery. 
 Among them these three auction houses are to offer more than $600 million worth of art, a considerable sum given the rocky economy and the auction business's dependence on the mood of buyers whose split-second decision -- whether to bid as high as $30 million on a Picasso portrait of his first wife, Olga, or $45 million on a Cezanne or $10 million on a self-portrait by Max Beckmann -- determines the stability of the market. 
 Heightening their unease is the knowledge that Sotheby's is for sale, and Christie's may well be, too. Sotheby's main shareholder and former chairman, A. Alfred Taubman, has made a public declaration of his intent to sell his controlling interest in the company, while Francois Pinault, the French investor who bought Christie's in 1998, has been quietly approaching investors to try to unload what has become a highly expensive asset. 
Christie's is also in the process of consolidating its operations both in New York and in London. This is a sign that it may be trying to make itself more financially attractive to a potential buyer. To make matters worse for them, both companies are embroiled in a four-year antitrust investigation by the Justice Department involving collusion by the companies' former chairmen and chief executive officers. Legal fees and civil lawsuits have already cost them millions of dollars in civil lawsuits and legal fees.
Compounding this is a new threat to Christie's and Sotheby's revenues: Phillips. When LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton bought Phillips more than two years ago, the LVMH chairman, Bernard Arnault, began investing large sums of money, either buying works outright and putting them at auction or offering seller's guarantees (an undisclosed sum promised to a seller regardless of a sale's outcome) to compete with Sotheby's and Christie's. Every work of art that Phillips sells hits the bottom line of Sotheby's and Christie's from the most profitable part of the market: Impressionist and modern art. 
Luring sellers with cash is hardly a new idea; Sotheby's and Christie's did it regularly in the 1980's boom years. But when the market began to nose dive in the early 1990's and a few guarantees went sour, leaving both auction houses with unsold material that they suddenly found themselves owning, Sotheby's and Christie's became more cautious about the guarantees they were prepared to offer.
Besides its deep pockets, Phillips's position was greatly strengthened in January when the company merged with de Pury & Luxembourg, Geneva dealers. Its founders, Simon de Pury, the former chairman of Sotheby's in Europe, became chairman of Phillips, and Daniella Luxembourg, the former deputy chairman of Sotheby's Switzerland, became its president.
Having a pair of well-connected officers running the third-place auction house has made a difference in just a few months. While all three companies have some impressive works for sale as well as their share of mediocre material, it was Phillips that snagged the most coveted collection -- a group of 19th-century paintings and drawings owned by Heinz Berggruen, the Berlin dealer. It is thought that the collection will bring more than $80 million when it is offered on Monday. 
Mr. Berggruen's artworks include two van Goghs as well as five Cezannes, the star among them "Montagne Ste. Victoire," which he bought in 1982 from the Greek shipping magnate George Embiricos. It is expected to sell for $35 million to $45 million. The collection came at a price. Phillips gave Mr. Berggruen a guarantee. While no one at the auction house will say just how big its investment is, and officials there deny any figures suggested to them, experts say the guarantee is believed to be $120 million.
Complying with regulations of the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs, Phillips (along with Sotheby's and Christie's) has designated the property it has guaranteed. In its Impressionist and modern art evening sale, 15 of 41 works, have been guaranteed. They include a Matisse sculpture being sold by Mr. Embiricos and two Renoirs belonging to the financier and Sotheby's board member Henry Kravis.
When Sotheby's and Christie's experts began competing for artworks to sell this spring, some collectors expected them to match offers made by Phillips. In some areas of the market there is more financing than in past seasons, but less than experts said they expected considering the the competition for prized works. 
Surprisingly, some clients went straight to Sotheby's or Christie's simply out of loyalty, with no interest in financing. For instance, there's Sotheby's single-owner sale on next Tuesday and May 9 featuring 130 works by masters like Bacon, Schiele and Miro. The collection belongs to Stanley J. Seeger, the reclusive American heir to a family fortune from lumber and petroleum who lives in London. Eight years ago, during a downturn in the market, Mr. Seeger boldly sold 88 Picassos at Sotheby's in New York for an impressive $32 million. One of his secrets was that he allowed auction house experts to put reasonable estimates on all the works, heightening the excitement of eager bidders. The same may be true next week.
"There may be little silly money about, but if collectors see something that is a true opportunity, they will pursue it and pursue it aggressively," said Tobias Meyer, director of Sotheby's contemporary art worldwide.
A rare portrait of Olga Koklova, the Russian-born ballet dancer who was Picasso's first wife, is also expected to generate excitement. Painted in 1923 during his classical period, it is one of his last great portraits of her. Olga is seated in a dignified pose taken from some of Ingres's early 19th-century portraits of society women. It is expected to sell for $30 million.
Picasso kept the portrait for himself. After his death in 1973 it went from his estate into the private collection of Daniel Wildenstein, the French dealer, who sold it a few years ago to an unidentified European collector who is selling it at Christie's on May 9. Franck Giraud, Christie's international director of 19th- and 20th-century art said, "Compared to all of the other women in Picasso's life, he painted very few portraits of Olga, all of which except this one are already in museums both here and abroad." 
Another rare portrait expected to bring a high price is Beckmann's haunting self-portrait painted in 1938 when he was in exile after the Nazis branded him a degenerate artist. The seller went straight to Sotheby's instead of playing the auction houses against one another. 
One of the last great German Expressionist paintings, it is being sold on May 10 at Sotheby's. It is estimated to sell for $7 million to $10 million. The painting is being sold by Dr. Stephan Lackner, Beckmann's lifelong patron who died last year.
A group of works by masters like Monet, Renoir, Cezanne and Picasso are being sold by Halit Cingillioglu, former chairman of Demirbank, which was seized by the Turkish government this year. It is unclear whether Mr. Cingillioglu used the bank's money or his own to buy the art. Tungay Ceylan, a spokesman for the Turkish bank regulators who seized Demirbank, said that because of the confidential nature of the interrogations of the people related to the bank by the inspectors he cannot provide any information about the paintings' ownership. Neither Sotheby's nor Christie's would say only that they do not comment on consignors. 
Sotheby's sale of Impressionist and modern art on May 10 includes nine paintings from this collection and Christie's sale on May 9 includes three. 
In the area of contemporary art both companies have several outstanding works that have received considerable publicity recently. The Spanish artist Maurizio Cattelan is to install a version of his "Ninth Hour," a room-size work consisting of a life-size wax figure of Pope John Paul II in white robes, clutching his processional cross and felled by a meteorite that has crashed through the skylight overhead. It first caused a stir when a version of the piece was on view at the Royal Academy of Arts in London as part of "Apocalypse: Beauty and Horror in Contemporary Art." 
In December, when it was shown at the Zacheta Gallery in Warsaw, two members of Poland's Parliament tried to vandalize it because they said it was disrespectful to their beliefs, but guards stopped them before any damage was done. The work will be shown in the United States for the first time at Christie's Rockefeller Center galleries and offered there on May 17; it is expected to sell for $400,000 to $600,000. 
More lighthearted is a porcelain sculpture by the 1980's art star Jeff Koons to be sold on May 15 at Sotheby's. "Michael Jackson and Bubbles," a 1988 sculpture of Mr. Jackson and his chimpanzee, is expected to bring $3 million to $4 million. The outrageously camp image has been used for Sotheby's new advertising campaign. It features a sleeker logo and a sliver of the company's newly completed York Avenue headquarters. James Allman, executive vice president for worldwide marketing said that in these competitive times it "is a way to differentiate us from the competition."

HEADLINE: With Merger Deal Gone Sour, EMI Must Counton Its Stars 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: LONDON, May 1 

 BODY:
When the EMI Group and BMG abandoned their talks to create a music industry giant today, Eric Nicoli, the EMI chairman, found himself once again having to talk up the company's prospects as a stand-alone entity.
 He pointed to EMI's preliminary results for the year ended March 31, also released today, showing a 6 percent rise in pretax profit, to $:260 million ($373 million), on a 12 percent jump in sales to $:2.7 billion ($3.9 billion), beating most forecasts. 
 "That is a better-than-respectable performance," Mr. Nicoli said in an interview. "EMI is doing fine. There have been inevitable distractions, but in spite of that, we've been able to maintain momentum." 
Putting an end to 15 months of uncertainty, first relating to merger talks with Warner Music, a unit of AOL Time Warner, and then to talks with BMG, a unit of Bertelsmann, briefly gave a lift to EMI's battered share price. But it closed up only slightly at 445 pence ($6.39) today. Since that is 44 percent below the peak of 799.5 pence ($11.47) in January 2000, EMI's shares might appear undervalued.
Not according to several analysts, though.
"A deal was imperative to their strategic future, and I don't see where they go from here," said Nicola Stewart, an analyst with Commerzbank Securities, who rates EMI shares a hold.
Economic sluggishness in Japan and the United States has hurt worldwide music sales, which declined 1.3 percent in 2000, according to Helen Snell, an analyst with ABN Amro. With American sales down a further 5.5 percent in the first three months of the year, Ms. Snell is not expecting business to pick up soon.
Meanwhile, with antitrust regulators steadfastly opposing mergers among any of the five major music companies, EMI can no longer look to cost savings from a merger to improve its margins.
Instead, it must compete by aggressively signing new artists, a risky and expensive business, analysts said.
That could leave EMI increasingly dependent on earnings from the recordings of a few big stars at a time when competitors are diversifying their entertainment portfolios.
Mr. Nicoli said EMI was no different from any other big music company in its efforts to sign star performers, an arena where it has competed aggressively. For example, EMI recently signed Mariah Carey in a $:17 million ($24 million) deal.
But artists are fickle -- EMI recently lost out the music publishing rights to a British pop star, Robbie Williams, to BMG -- and each lost star matters more to EMI than to its conglomerate-owned rivals.
Ms. Stewart estimated that a single best-selling act like the Spice Girls might account for as much as 15 percent of EMI's operating profit when its popularity is peaking. At Bertelsmann, which has major book publishing interests and recently bought RTL, a major European broadcaster, no one artist is likely to ever approach that figure; likewise at Warner Music, which is now a small piece of the sprawling AOL Time Warner cable-to-publishing-to-Internet empire.
In competing with such deep-pocketed giants, "EMI could be in a position where they pay too much to win big artists," Ms. Stewart said.
Another worry is that EMI has employed a me-too Internet strategy, trailing behind competitors like Vivendi Universal and Bertelsmann, which have actively explored ways to tap into online demand for downloadable digital music. (The other top recording company is Sony Music Entertainment.)
Mr. Nicoli said EMI had signed 40 new media deals since 1999 and recently joined AOL Time Warner, Bertelsmann and RealNetworks to distribute music online. "What we haven't done is throw cash at the opportunity," he said. "Most informed commentators would take the view that our strategy has been smart."
EMI is also reviving a plan first broached two years ago, but frozen by the merger talks, that calls for combining its music-publishing arm with a competitor's. But analysts do not expect a big payoff from the plan, perhaps less than $50 million all told, according to Ms. Snell.
EMI has held talks on and off with a variety of partners since it was spun off from Thorn, an appliance and electronics company, in 1996. Today, Mr. Nicoli ruled out any full-scale merger in the near future. But some analysts are not convinced that EMI will remain independent.
"One possibility that cannot be ruled out," Ms. Snell wrote in a research note to clients, "is a hostile bid from another major record company, which could then attempt to secure approval from the regulator by aggressively disposing of assets." She cited Bertelsmann as a probable bidder because as a private company it need not satisfy public shareholders by sticking to deals that create shareholder value right away. 
Susanne Erdl, a Bertelsmann spokeswoman, did not rule out the option of reopening talks with EMI. "The music market is fast changing," she said. "There will be lots of other possibilities later on.'

HEADLINE: In Twist, Rebels Help Drug Effort In Colombia 

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: GAITANIA, Colombia 

 BODY:
The warnings were dire as President Andres Pastrana's government, flush with American money, began an ambitious plan late last year that called on farmers to eradicate fields of coca and heroin poppies in exchange for economic aid.
 Many officials in Bogota and Washington said the rebels of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia might resort to threats and even violence to stop farmers from cooperating. Rebel taxes on illegal crops are a major revenue source that helps finance rebel operations. 
 But late in April, here in the cloud-shrouded mountains where the rebel force, known as FARC, was born in 1964, farmers agreed in principle to replace poppy fields with legal crops in exchange for subsidies and technical assistance. Rebel leaders from this region of southern Tolima Province watched closely as a letter of intent, the first step toward an agreement, was signed with officials. 
"They said we would not let the farmers cultivate their own crops," said a rebel leader who is in the political wing and was involved in discussions.
"But we don't reject help just because it is from the state," said the leader, whose nom de guerre is Marta. "We just want to be able to see the state support the farmers."
Although the revolutionary armed forces have not used violence to halt voluntary eradication, the rebels are apparently deeply involved in talks between the government and farmers, said local officials and farmers. 
"They seem to be getting more involved, to see if something works, if it does not," said Ruben Dario Gomez, who heads a farmers' cooperative. "They say that if something is happening in an area they control, they want to be involved. Everyone knows it."
Local officials said that in meetings rebels give opinions, offer suggestions and, in some cases, shape programs. Agreements, including the one here, are forwarded to top rebel commanders for approval.
"The FARC has its positions, its own criteria, in regard to discussions about these farmers' fields," said Gerardo Montoya, a provincial official involved in the negotiations. "In the points they made, they said that the people had been cheated before and that the state has never had a presence here."
Much of the rebels' concern, said those who attended meetings, was directed at Plante, the agency that uses money from a $42 million American grant for what are called alternative development programs. The programs are intended to give farmers a year to stop their illicit crops in exchange for $900 in seeds, pesticides and technical aid to help switch crops. The government has also promised to market products and build public works.
The rebels, however, see Plante as a tool of an American policy that counts on extensive fumigation to eradicate most of the illegal crops here. In interviews here and in the coca-growing heartland of Putumayo Province, farmers also said the agency had reneged on past agreements.
The quality control coordinator for Plante, Joaquin Gomez, disagreed, saying the agency had forged bonds with farmers. He also said the rebel force had not been an impediment. "We've been able to come in," said Mr. Gomez, who was at the meetings here. "We have had access to all the zones."
Still, among some negotiators here the sense remained that the rebels could have halted the letter of intent. That is worrisome to people like Hoover Mora, a town councilman who said the rebels' forceful comments left open the possibility that they would take punitive steps.
"They say they will not stop the program," Mr. Mora said. "But they are getting involved in the oversight, and I think that is a big contradiction."
Some experts on the rebels said they were in a difficult position because they had to choose between allowing eradication and losing financing or stopping eradication programs popular with farmers and risking alienating their base of support.

HEADLINE: St. John's Works to Shake Its Commuter School Image 

BYLINE:  By SAMUEL WEISS 

 BODY:
On any weekday night, the parking lots of St. John's University in Jamaica, Queens, start emptying as the commuter students -- the Long Islanders and the residents of Brooklyn and Queens who have historically defined St. John's -- begin their journeys home. 
 But at the south end of the 110-acre main campus, in a new $150 million residential village, the lights of five dormitories burn brightly as knots of students from all parts of the United States stand outside, talking and laughing as they await deliveries from pizzerias and Chinese restaurants. 
 "Things are markedly different," said the Rev. Donald J. Harrington, the university's president, reflecting on the changes at the 131-year-old institution since it opened its first dormitories in fall 1999. "You'd walk in here a couple of years ago and the campus would be very quiet at night and on weekends. Now it's just the opposite. The campus is alive all the time. We're now a 24-7 operation." 
If campus life has changed since St. John's became a residential institution, so have the university's aspirations.
"We see ourselves as being a national university," Father Harrington said. 
Whether or not the president's goal of national prominence is attainable, it is clear that St. John's has moved with speed and determination to make itself more visible and competitive. In less than a decade, the 18,500-student university has managed not only to build its first residence halls, but also to raise faculty salaries to levels competitive with that of the nation's leading research universities.
It has also spent $40 million to upgrade technology, developed a new core curriculum to go into effect next fall, and acquired two new campus sites in Manhattan and on eastern Long Island to complement the existing campuses in Jamaica and Staten Island. Fund-raising efforts have also stepped up, notably with two gifts of $10 million each in the last couple of years.
"It's an impressive series of steps," said Frederick S. Lane, a professor at Baruch College's School of Public Affairs who has been a planning consultant to many colleges and universities. "But building the reputation of a university is a long and difficult process, and it requires a sustained vision and strategy."
Reshaping the university is not without its risks. Since its founding, St. John's has been a gateway to the business world and the professions for thousands of working-class students for whom the university's low tuition made it possible to attend college. In the fall, tuition will rise to $16,900, more than two and a half times the $6,500 it was in 1989 when Father Harrington became president. He acknowledges unease among some trustees and faculty members who worry about a loss of the school's working-class identity and whether national recruitment will someday overshadow local admissions.
Established in 1870 by the Vincentian order to serve the city's poor and working class, St. John's has been a model of the urban commuter school, for immigrants striving to become the first in their families to earn college degrees and for working students attending law school classes at night. 
The main campus, an enclosed sprinkling of low-slung buildings set among lawns, athletic fields and parking lots, is in an area of well-tended private homes adjoining Jamaica Estates. The university was once largely for the children of Irish and Italian immigrants. Its student population today is about half non-Hispanic white, with the other half divided almost equally among blacks, Hispanics and Asians. Academically, the university is best known for its law school, whose graduates have included prominent litigators, judges and politicians, including three governors: Hugh L. Carey and Mario M. Cuomo of New York and George Deukmejian of California.
Now, seeking to expand the university's reach beyond the five boroughs and Nassau County, Father Harrington envisions the day when St. John's recruits students across the board, and not just athletes, for whom it competes with Big East Conference rivals like Villanova, Boston College, Syracuse and Georgetown.
Benefiting from its location in New York City, its identity as one of the nation's largest Roman Catholic universities and the longtime prominence of its men's basketball program (less mentioned are the national championships in soccer and fencing), national recruitment is off to a promising start. The 1,400 students living in the dormitories this spring come from more than 35 states, including Alaska and Hawaii.
The driving force behind the metamorphosis has clearly been Father Harrington, who is widely credited with reinvigorating a university that appeared adrift when he took over.
"The institution has just changed tremendously and improved significantly since he came," said Neil Jespersen, the chairman of the chemistry department, who has been at St. John's since 1977. "There's just a lot more grants, a lot more research activity, a lot more academic activity in general."
Father Harrington, 55, began his academic career as a theology instructor at Niagara University near Buffalo, where he ultimately became president before coming to St. John's. But he speaks comfortably these days in the vernacular of a corporate director, a position he currently holds with the Wall Street firm Bear Stearns.
He talks expansively about the need of colleges and universities to "meet the challenges of the new economy and globalization," but like a chief executive being coy about a new product line, he declines to discuss new programs in any detail, saying, "Higher education is still a business, and I'm not about to give away secrets to the competition."
There is one indicator that tells outside experts like Dr. Lane that St. John's is an institution worth watching.
"It's one thing for St. John's to decide to build a few residence halls," he said. "It's almost a no-brainer. But it is quite another for the university to also start paying top-tier salaries for full professors." 
That, he added, "signals a much more fundamental commitment to quality" by making it clear that St. John's is searching for the kind of faculty talent needed to build first-rate programs and promote research.
As recently as five years ago, salaries at St. John's were behind those of city and Long Island institutions like Queens College, Hofstra University, Fordham University and the State University at Stony Brook. But in raising faculty pay by as much as 6 percent a year, St. John's has outstripped its competition.
According to a recent survey in The Chronicle of Higher Education showing colleges where full professors earned the most for the 2000-01 year, St. John's ranked 41st, paying $101,100, slightly less than Dartmouth College but slightly more than the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.
Until recently, St. John's seemed unlikely to belong in such company. Dr. Jespersen recalled that when he joined the chemistry department 24 years ago, the level of research activity generated by the members of the department was practically nil. It remained so until about three years ago, when the administration offered a universitywide buyout that induced half the members of the department to retire.
Now able to recruit younger professors with doctorates from places like the University of Pennsylvania and the State University at Buffalo, the new members of the department have brought in almost $1 million in grant money, and the number of chemistry majors has grown from 3 to 10 students.
Responding to concerns that rising tuition will erode St. John's position as a working-class school, Father Harrington and other university officials note that financial aid has risen even faster than tuition. 
The university is providing $55 million this year in scholarship money, compared with $6 million a decade ago. Further, the university has adopted a policy of making 40 percent to 45 percent of its freshman admissions among those it classifies as economically disadvantaged.
"We are committed to our mission of serving the poor of the New York area," Father Harrington said.

HEADLINE: Toward a Global AIDS Fund 

 BODY:
The public attention given in recent months to Africa's AIDS crisis has not been matched with money. Last year the world spent about $1 billion on AIDS in developing countries -- a sum that will not even buy adequate prevention campaigns, much less health infrastructure, care for AIDS orphans and necessary medicines for the sick. But in a series of international meetings over the next few weeks, world leaders will be turning their attention to financing these urgent programs. The speech last week by Secretary General Kofi Annan of the United Nations at the African AIDS conference in Nigeria lays out a solid basis for a global attack on AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria. 
 Mr. Annan called for a global fund to fight these diseases -- with contributions from governments, foundations and wealthy individuals -- that would eventually add $7 billion to $10 billion a year to the current level of world spending. He recommended that the money go to preventing the spread of disease, cutting mother-to-child transmission of AIDS, caring for orphans, aiding scientific breakthroughs and buying medicine, including anti-retroviral drugs to treat AIDS. 
 The idea of a global fund has been endorsed by the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the group of the world's seven largest industrialized nations. On June 25 the U.N. General Assembly holds a special session on AIDS, and may formally establish the fund then. Actual pledges are expected in July, at a meeting of the world's wealthiest nations in Genoa, Italy. 
At least initially, a large part of the money will go toward building a health infrastructure in the African nations most ravaged by AIDS. African leaders from 43 nations have pledged to increase their spending on health, and especially on AIDS. The statement is a welcome sign that African leaders are taking AIDS and health issues more seriously. The few countries that have demonstrated a commitment to slowing the spread of AIDS have been able to do so. But many nations are still ignoring AIDS and spending less than $10 per capita on health each year. 
The global AIDS fund, which has gotten initial support from Italy, Britain, Canada and Sweden, is likely to be handicapped by a lack of leadership from the United States. While Bush administration officials speak about AIDS as a catastrophe, the president's 2002 budget adds less than 10 percent to this year's spending for AIDS overseas, raising it to $480 million. Former President Clinton suggested to the Nigeria AIDS conference that Washington should provide a quarter of the global AIDS fund. President Bush's budget falls more than $1 billion short of that.

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
Dodging the Bullet

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
Things are getting worse more slowly -- let's celebrate! That seemed to be the mood in the markets yesterday, after the National Association of Production Managers released its monthly survey for April. Any score less than 50 indicates that the managers surveyed see deteriorating conditions, and the index for April was only 43.2. But the index was up slightly from March -- as I said, things are getting worse more slowly -- and as the day went by investors seem to have concluded that this was good news.
 In fact, the N.A.P.M. index was only one of a number of straws in the wind that suggest that the economic situation might not be as bad as some -- myself included -- have feared. For all we know the good news is just a statistical blip, and we are still on track for a deep economic plunge. But we can now contemplate, at least for the sake of argument, the possibility that the United States will dodge the bullet -- that we will survive the bursting of the great technology bubble without going through an all-out recession. If so, we will have learned an important economic lesson. 
 Put it this way: Many economic commentators seem to subscribe to a sort of crime-and-punishment theory of recessions. They believe that after the economy goes through a period of speculative excess, it must then pay for that excess with a slump. 
But must irrational exuberance be followed by recession? The alternative to crime-and-punishment is let-bygones-be-bygones. Of course capital is wasted in a speculative boom, and much of that capital must be written off. Moreover, the sectors of the economy in which the speculative excess was greatest may not see much new investment for a while; it might be years before the demand for servers or business software resumes rapid growth. 
But why should this stop the economy in its tracks? There are always good investments to be made, if the price is right. Millions of Americans have decided that low interest rates offer a good opportunity to refinance their homes or buy new ones, even as the headlines warn of a slumping economy; and there are plenty of profitable opportunities in those old-economy sectors that got a bit neglected during the technology bubble. 
I've always favored the let-bygones-be-bygones view over the crime-and-punishment view. That is, I've always believed that a speculative bubble need not lead to a recession, as long as interest rates are cut quickly enough to stimulate alternative investments. But I had to face the fact that speculative bubbles usually are followed by recessions. My excuse has been that this was because the policy makers moved too slowly -- that central banks were typically too slow to cut interest rates in the face of a burst bubble, giving the downturn time to build up a lot of momentum. That was why I, like many others, was frustrated at the smallish cut at the last Federal Open Market Committee meeting: I was pretty sure that Alan Greenspan had the tools to prevent a disastrous recession, but worried that he might be getting behind the curve. 
However, let's give credit where credit is due: Mr. Greenspan has cut rates since then. And while some of us may have been urging him to move even faster, the Fed's four interest-rate cuts since the slowdown became apparent represent an unusually aggressive response by historical standards. It's still not clear that Mr. Greenspan has caught up with the curve -- let's have at least one more rate cut, please -- but the interest-rate cuts do, cross your fingers, seem to be having an effect. 
If we succeed in avoiding recession, this will mark a big win for let-bygones-be-bygones, and a big loss for crime-and-punishment. And that will be very good news not just for this business cycle, but for business cycles to come. 
For the big lesson of the late 1990's was that speculative bubbles spring eternal. The signs of irrational exuberance, not to mention sheer silliness, were there for all to see; yet the bubble expanded -- and then burst -- all the same. Surely there will be other bubbles, and other burstings, in the decades ahead. The best we can hope for is that when the bubbles burst the consequences can be limited. And the faint signs of good news in the U.S. economy are reason to hope that they can.
