HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT; 
Would-Be EntrepreneursShun Dot-Coms

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
Financial markets are fickle, and business school students are nothing if not attentive to markets. Last year, the students tried to persuade investors to buy into trendy, but ultimately doomed concepts like DesignAjewel.com. This year, they are pushing more mundane ideas like the Shrimp Factory.
 John Culley, a second-year M.B.A. student who entered a competition last month for best business plan at the Stern School of Business of New York University, came up with the idea for supplying fresh shrimp to high-end New York City restaurants by building shrimp-breeding vats in either northern New Jersey or the Bronx. 
 Mr. Culley plans to use high-technology filters to eliminate the waste produced by the shrimp. Otherwise, though, his venture has an old-economy feel. It is definitely not an Internet start-up, and he did not consider calling it shrimpfactory.com. 
"I think that most of the great ideas in that area have been mined," Mr. Culley said. "I have no aversion to a dot-com or any other technology company. I would do anything, if it's something I'm passionate about."
The latest evidence of a shift at business schools away from the dot-com mania of early 2000 and back to more traditional standbys may well be found in the ideas proposed by would-be entrepreneurs in business-plan competitions.
The message on campus after campus seems to be: say goodbye to DesignAjewel .com, an ill-fated idea pitched by N.Y.U. students last year, and get ready for locally grown fresh shrimp at Manhattan restaurants.
Or for an upscale handyman's service. In essence, that is what Ari R. Meisel, an undergraduate at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, decided to enter in the business-plan competition that ended Monday.
Mr. Meisel, who just turned 18, says harsh experience over the last year has taught him the wisdom of promoting a back-to-basics business. He has already founded three companies, he says, and the two that have done well -- Liontex, a Web site design firm, and Tek, an all-purpose technology consulting firm -- are both traditional enterprises. The one poor performer is Menus-To-Go.com, which offers the menus of New York City restaurants on the Internet.
"That never really went too far," he said. Mr. Meisel and his Wharton partners in the business-plan contest also toyed with the idea of a nationwide college student directory, but rejected the idea when they realized it would be hard to make money. Instead, they proposed a service company that would use independent contractors to install computers, stereo equipment or anything else in homes and businesses. "It's simpler and more fun when the ideas are not capital-intensive," Mr. Meisel said.
Other students have reached the same conclusion.
"We're steering clear of the dot-com bubble," said Jeff Freilich, a member of a team of students competing in a business-plan contest at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Their not-a-dot-com proposal involves testing drugs using computer software rather than real patients, saving time and money for pharmaceutical companies. "The pharmaceutical industry is one that's always admired," Mr. Freilich said. "It's very visible right now to the investment community, looking for what to do with their money."
Not everyone has abandoned cyberspace, of course, but even those who brave it are keeping their eyes wide open. Anthony M. Tarpey, a member of a team of M.B.A. students at Wharton, almost apologizes for the team's proposal for a system that allows marketers to send video clips as e-mail messages.
"I am aware that there was a bit of a backlash against Internet advertising, but we are really e-mail advertising," said Mr. Tarpey, whose company, OrangeMarketing, is already running and profitable. "We don't service dot-coms."
Business plans are the blueprints for start-up companies, outlining what entrepreneurs hope to do, how they plan to find customers and how soon they expect to be profitable. The plans should also explain how the fledgling business will cope with potential pitfalls.
Mr. Culley, for example, readily acknowledged during the question-and-answer portion of his presentation at N.Y.U. that contamination in the shrimp breeding vats could be a catastrophic event if it occurred too early in the life of the company. The only solution would be a new round of financing to keep Shrimp Factory operating while the tanks could be cleaned, he said.
In the last five years or so, plans entered in contests have become for M.B.A. students what screenplays and novels are for struggling writers: a shot at fame, prize money to finance the proposed business and in rare cases, unimagined riches. Timbre Technologies, which developed software that assists in the design of semiconductors, was started two years ago by the winners of a contest at the Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley, for example, and was sold in March for $138 million to a Japanese buyer.
Though enthusiasm for the contests has waned somewhat in the current economic slowdown -- the number of plans submitted slumped to 34 this year at N.Y.U. from 88 last year and to 135 from 206 at M.I.T. -- their popularity soared in the late 1990's. The N.Y.U. competition is in only its second year, while the business-plan contest at the Haas School is four years old, for example.
Jerome Engel, executive director of the Lester Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation at the Haas School, said he supported the idea of competitions at Haas only after M.B.A. students pointed out that they provided an opportunity to collaborate with students in other parts of the university. "That got me to agree that it was a fantastic idea," he said.
Sarah Kroon, an M.B.A. student at N.Y.U., said: "There is just a tremendous demand from students. Students really want some real-world experience in writing a business plan," as well as practice chatting with potential investors. 
The interest in the plans as a way to succeed quickly mirrors changes in how entrepreneurs are viewed in society, said Elad Gil, who is running the M.I.T. competition this year and who recently received his doctorate in biology from the school. It is possible for students to start their own companies today -- something not possible 15 or 20 years ago, he said.
"There's also the 'me-too' effect," Dr. Gil added. Current M.B.A. students see millionaire entrepreneurs who are also in their 20's, and the students decide that they, too, can get rich quickly, he said.
The competitions also teach students what investors really care about. Lesson No. 1 is that market appetite is more important than technology. Potential financial backers would much rather see hard evidence that people would actually buy a product, however simple or complicated it is, than look at a technological wonder that nobody really wants.
"You're obviously trying to get into the mind of the investor, especially given the dot-com craze and crash -- how are their expectations tempered, what are they looking for," said Christina Lawler, a first-year M.B.A. student at the Sloan School of Management at M.I.T. She is a member of Mr. Freilich's team in the school's $50,000 business-plan contest. "Whereas people might have been able to get away with bigger ideas that were not very well grounded" in previous years, Ms. Lawler said, "they're not going to be able to get away with that now."
DesignAjewel.com, for example, would have allowed customers to design their own jewelry online. 
In contrast, Mr. Culley's idea for the Shrimp Factory depends not on the Internet, but on something much more reliable: New Yorkers' appetites for seafood. "I read an article several years ago about the shrimp farming industry and its devastating effects," Mr. Culley said. Usually, such farms use ponds or vats to breed shrimp; the shrimp produce waste, which is flushed out into the environment, he said.
The Shrimp Factory, instead of flushing out waste-filled water, would run it through what is essentially a sewage treatment system, Mr. Culley said. Shrimp waste would be chemically converted into fertilizer for algae, which the shrimp would then eat. This means the whole process should not harm the surrounding environment, he said.
Mr. Culley said he had researched his idea for years, and this year he was apparently not alone in having done his homework. Over all, the ideas proposed now are better planned and the teams themselves more determined than last year, said Stephen Nordahl, managing director of T.S.X. Ventures, a venture capital firm based in New York, and a judge both this year and last year in the N.Y.U. competition.
"Last year there were a lot of these dot-com type companies that weren't necessarily fully thought-out business models," he said. This year, he added, "there are somewhat fewer participants, but they seem to be much more serious."

HEADLINE: Still Sluggish, Manufacturing Index EdgesUp 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1 

 BODY:
A manufacturing index edged higher in April, a report showed today, but the gain was less than expected and signaled that factories are having trouble pulling out of a slump.
 "Manufacturing is the economy's weakest spot and still is struggling significantly," said Mark M. Zandi, chief economist at the research firm Economy.com in West Chester, Pa. 
 The National Association of Purchasing Management's factory index was 43.2 last month, up from 43.1 in March. Analysts had expected the index to rise to 44 in April. 
A reading below 50 signals contraction of the manufacturing sector, and the index has been under that level since August. This year, companies have announced job cuts to pare costs as consumer spending flags. While the economy expanded 2 percent in the first quarter, that pace may have lost strength in the second, analysts say.
A separate survey by the organization found that more than a third of the purchasers for manufacturing companies -- 38 percent -- said they were "worried or pessimistic" about business over the next 12 months. That compares with 5 percent who were pessimistic in December.
"Two years ago, there was an insane euphoria that isn't going to occur for a while," Kenneth E. Guiles, purchasing director for the Eastman Chemical Company, said today at the association's semiannual outlook conference in Orlando, Fla. "But once people get back to business as usual in a modestly growing economy, then the demand will grow."
A majority of those responding to the group's survey said investment in new equipment would decline this year. Also, manufacturers are now operating at the lowest percentage of their capacity than at any time in the last decade, the survey showed.
Real estate and construction, meantime, kept buoying the economy, which is in its record 11th year of expansion. Work on office buildings, home improvements and public projects led a 1.3 percent increase in construction spending in March, the Commerce Department reported separately.
The monthly increase in spending, to a record $854.4 billion at an annual rate, was the fifth consecutive one.
The April factory survey gave some reasons for optimism. Manufacturers reduced inventories at the fastest pace since October 1996. At the same time, the indexes measuring production and new orders rose for the third consecutive month.
Inflation pressures stayed tame. An index of prices paid for raw materials fell in April, to the lowest level in two years. And purchasers said in the survey that they expected the cost of materials to stay unchanged and labor costs to decline.
The factory executives expect to hire 1.3 percent fewer workers this year, the survey showed. Purchasing managers at companies other than manufacturers said they expected to hire 0.5 percent fewer employees.

HEADLINE: Israel Arrests Ex-General as Spy for Spilling Old Secrets 

BYLINE:  By DEBORAH SONTAG 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, May 1 

 BODY:
Itzhak Yaakov, 75, a retired brigadier general who once oversaw weapons development for the Israeli military, is at the center of a supposed spy story that may turn out to be more Kafka than le Carre.
 For more than a month Mr. Yaakov, an Israeli-American with dual citizenship who has lived in Manhattan for the last two decades, has been in an Israeli prison on charges of "high espionage" that carry a maximum penalty of life behind bars. 
 Mr. Yaakov, known here as the father of the Israeli technology industry, was quietly taken into custody by a special security division of the Defense Ministry on March 28. That was four days after his 75th birthday was celebrated in the wealthy town of Savyon outside Tel Aviv by a who's who of Israeli political and economic leaders who regaled him as "Mr. Security." 
Mr. Yaakov was arrested at Ben-Gurion Airport after he finished checking in for a flight to Istanbul. 
His case was sealed and an order was issued barring the principals from speaking to the press, so his friends thought at first that he was simply away, enjoying himself as planned on vacation in Turkey.
Then on April 22, The Sunday Times of London reported Mr. Yaakov's detention and added that he was being questioned about his "relationship with a Russian woman who may have had access to his work" from the time when he is said to have played a role in the development of Israel's nuclear industry.
With the secrecy of his arrest broken, Israeli courts partly lifted the order withholding information from the press, and state attorneys made public some of the charges.
Mr. Yaakov is accused of passing confidential information to "unauthorized individuals" with the intention of "compromising the security of the state." The indictment says that despite warnings from security officials, he divulged classified information he had obtained during his service in the Israeli military, which ended 27 years ago.
His wife, Tatiana Mendoza, is a Russian-born American, but a "relationship with a Russian woman" does not appear to be a factor in the case, despite the initial report, which set the country buzzing about an aging Mata Hari.
Despite the accusations, Maj. Gen. Amos Yaron, director general of the Defense Ministry, said on Israel Radio on Monday, "We are not talking about a spy case." He called the incident "very unfortunate" and referred to Mr. Yaakov as a "man with a history of admirable deeds."
Nonetheless, General Yaron obliquely said that the authorities had had "no choice" but to arrest Mr. Yaakov for distributing sensitive information.
Friends, who call Mr. Yaakov by his nickname, Yatza, say they believe that his only offense was speaking to an Israeli reporter during a series of recent interviews in New York. They say that he felt compelled to tell his story, making a case for his own contributions to Israeli history, after an incident that hurt him: he was disqualified, or so he believed, as a potential nominee for the state's highest honor, the Israel Prize, because he was an expatriate.
Mr. Yaakov came from Israel's pioneer generation, and his personal history is interwoven with the state's. He was born in Tel Aviv in 1926 and attended the same elementary school as Yitzhak Rabin, several years behind the future prime minister. He served in the Palmach, a paramilitary branch of the Haganah, the Jewish underground self-defense force before independence, and commanded an important company during the 1947 war. 
He graduated as an engineer from Technion in Haifa. From 1955 to 1973 he served in the Israeli military, heading a weapons development unit for a decade. During that time he is believed to have played a role in the nuclear program.
It is unclear to what extent the charges against Mr. Yaakov concern Israel's nuclear weaponry. Israel is considered by experts to have the sixth-largest nuclear arsenal in the world, but it has maintained a policy of "deliberate ambiguity" about its nuclear program for decades. Israeli military censorship, which has loosened considerably in recent years, is still almost airtight on nuclear arms.
Mr. Yaakov's information would be very dated, older than the detailed revelations of Mordechai Vanunu, a nuclear technician who blew the whistle on Israel's nuclear arsenal in 1986 and was convicted of treason in 1988.
Much is now known about Israel's nuclear capacity, and Mr. Yaakov's friends said they doubted that he had fresh or detailed inside information.
After two decades as a businessman in the United States, where nuclear arms are discussed more freely, Mr. Yaakov may have lost the keen Israeli sense of the subject as taboo, his friends said. Still, he was not supposed to talk, regardless of his motives, which the authorities acknowledge publicly do not involve sharing secrets with an enemy of Israel.
An Israeli critic of the state's opacity on nuclear policy said, "There is a state within a state" on the nuclear issue.
"The myth that this issue stands apart allows them to justify all sorts of outrageous behavior," the critic said. "It appears they are using a 75-year-old man to send a message to a generation of people that they should die with their secrets, even if they are such old secrets that they're not of much value anymore in intelligence or military terms."
Mr. Yaakov left the military a week before the Arab-Israeli war of 1973. He went to work for Israel's Trade Ministry as chief scientist, nurturing the research and development companies that blossomed into Israel's lucrative technology industry. 
He emigrated to the United States in the late 1970's, largely for personal reasons. Last year he retired as chairman of Constellation 3D, a company that develops advanced data storage products, with offices in New York, Florida and California and laboratories in Israel and Russia.
The birthday extravaganza for Mr. Yaakov was given by two technology entrepreneurs. Before the party, Mr. Yaakov gave a series of interviews to Ronen Bergman of the daily Yediot Ahronot for an article that was supposed to be published in conjunction with the gala. 
He asked Mr. Bergman to sign a written contract pledging that he would submit the article to the military censor first. Friends of Mr. Yaakov say he would not have insisted on that condition if his intent had been to harm state security as the indictment alleges.
Mr. Bergman complied, the friends said, and the censor killed the entire article, a magazine-length piece of some 7,500 words. Not long afterward, the arrest warrant for Mr. Yaakov was issued.
General Yaron suggested that Mr. Yaakov had done more than talk to Mr. Bergman. He referred to a "manifesto," which some officials believe to be memoirs that Mr. Yaakov was preparing for publication. Mr. Yaakov's lawyers say there is no manifesto; friends say he was working on a novel that might have been partly autobiographical.
An American official said Mr. Yaakov had declined assistance from the American authorities. Friends say he is too proud and embarrassed to turn to his second country for help in dealing with the authorities in the homeland in which he used to be an authority. The United States offered help twice, but he declined.
Mr. Yaakov, who recently recovered from two heart operations, is confined in a prison hospital in Ramle. In a hearing on Wednesday, his lawyers plan to request that he be moved to house arrest, although he does not have a home in Israel. His wife, who is staying at a Tel Aviv hotel, cried when a reporter located her and asked her about her husband.
"It would be very unwise for me at this point to say anything," she said. "I can't afford to talk now. I would love to shout, but I cannot do this now. He is not well."
Mr. Yaakov's lawyers and several legal commentators here have asked aloud why Israeli officials chose to file charges of aggravated espionage against him when they are saying publicly that his alleged offenses cannot be considered spying in the classic sense. The legal experts said lesser charges exist relating to unauthorized dissemination of confidential information.
They have also criticized the director of the internal Defense Ministry security agency for what they see as overzealousness, and lamented the secrecy around the case. 
"This type of secret arrest has no place in a democracy," the newspaper Haaretz said. One columnist said, "The idea that Israel, in this day and age, can have such X-files is cause for concern."
State Attorney Edna Arbel protested the contention that Mr. Yaakov had "disappeared."
"People do not disappear in Israel," she said. "This is not Russia or Latin America. He was accompanied by four lawyers and his wife when he was arraigned."
Jack Chen, one of his lawyers, said: "We see this as a very sad story of a person who dedicates his life to the security of Israel and ends up caught in a huge story that gets blown out of proportion and jeopardizes his reputation, his career, his legacy, everything. It's a huge shock for him, but he's sure that eventually the truth will come out."

HEADLINE: Growing Signs of Progress In Writers' Negotiations 

BYLINE:  By RICK LYMAN 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 1 

 BODY:
Negotiations between Hollywood's writers and its leading movie studios and television networks stretched into this evening amid growing signs that progress was being made to avert a long-dreaded strike that would have the potential of crippling the nation's entertainment industry.
 Top negotiators from each side had met long into the evening on Monday, and were having significant success in chipping away at the list of issues separating the Writers Guild of America and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers, people on both sides of the talks said today. The main issues, though, including residuals and so-called creative rights, remained unresolved as the talks went into their final hours. 
 The contract deadline was 12:01 a.m. Pacific Daylight Time Wednesday, though officials from both sides said that talks could easily stretch beyond that if progress continued to be made. Indeed, some said, there was some optimism among negotiators today that an agreement might even be concluded before the midnight deadline, or very soon after.
"It's like a basketball game, where everything is decided in the last two minutes," said one studio executive who was close to the talks. "In other words, what's happened here is that the process has evolved into a fairly standard set of labor negotiations. And it looks like it's going to end up like most labor negotiations do, coming right down to the wire."
The prospect of a strike by the 11,000 members of the guild's West Coast and East Coast branches -- about a third of whom write for the movies and the rest for scripted television programs -- had been worrisome enough for Hollywood. But coming this year, before a June 30 contract deadline for the 135,000 actors represented by the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, it promised a double punch that would have effectively caused film and television production companies to shut down, lay off thousands and perhaps deal a devastating blow to Southern California's economy.
Last year, when the Writers Guild began to talk -- persuasively -- about taking a harder line in the current round of labor talks, the Hollywood studios responded by putting dozens of films into rushed production. Television networks were able to persuade some producers to stockpile episodes of programs for the coming fall season, and vowed to make up any gaps with increased reality and news programs.
The dominant issue in the talks was residuals, the amount of money paid to writers for the reuse of their work after its initial broadcast or theatrical run. But another flash point, at least for film writers, was a demand for greater respect and authority in the filmmaking process, including curbing the use of the "film by" credit for directors.
And in the final days of the talks, the issue of how writers would be compensated for use of their work on the Internet became a central issue. Although there have been only relatively small efforts to make money by putting films on the Internet, several major studios have said in recent months that they intend to mount fledgling film-on-demand efforts on the World Wide Web.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Priceline Shares Soar on Earnings

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Shares of Priceline.com, the name-your-own-price Internet commerce company, jumped 51 percent yesterday after an analyst raised his rating and the company reported better-than-expected earnings.
 Priceline said that its first-quarter loss was narrower than estimates had been and that it expected to turn a small profit in the current quarter, helped by steep cost reductions and a heightened focus on its core travel business. 
 Priceline shares rose 36 percent during regular trading on the strength of a ratings upgrade by a Goldman, Sachs analyst, and surged further after the company released its results at 4:30 yesterday. In after-hours trading, the stock reached $7.32. It closed the regular session at $6.59, up $1.74. Priceline shares traded as high as $162.38 two years ago and as low as $1.06 last December. 
Priceline, which drastically pared the scope of its business last November, reported revenue of $269.7 million for the quarter, down a shade over 14 percent from the period a year earlier. The company had a net loss of $13.8 million, or 7 cents a share, compared with a loss of $13.6 million, or 8 cents a share, in the first quarter of 2000. 
Excluding various charges, the picture looked brighter.
Priceline, which has dismissed about 35 percent of its staff since November, said its loss narrowed to $6.25 million on that basis, or 3 cents a share, compared with a loss of $7.28 million, or 4 cents a share, a year earlier. 
The consensus among Wall Street analysts was that excluding revamping and other charges, Priceline would post a loss of 5 cents a share. 
Based on current trends, the company said that excluding charges it expected to report a profit of 1 cent to 2 cents a share in the second quarter. 
In addition to a sharp reduction in employees, Priceline has reduced office space by almost two-thirds and postponed new business expansion indefinitely. Virtually all of its efforts are focused on its travel business. 
Last year the company, based in Norwalk, Conn., was plagued by customer complaints, criticism of its airline ticket process, the closing of affiliated grocery and gasoline-sales businesses and the departure of key executives, including Jay S. Walker, its founder.
During a conference call with analysts, Priceline executives said they expected to beat their target of cutting operating expenses by $35 million, and reaffirmed the company's expectations of 10 to 15 percent revenue growth in the second quarter from the first quarter.
Compared with the fourth quarter of 2000, first-quarter revenue was up 18 percent.
Priceline said it added more than 890,000 customers during the first quarter. The company, founded three years ago, has a customer base of nearly 10 million. Repeat and new-customer demand accelerated through the first quarter, Priceline said. 
"We are pleased with our momentum as we enter the second quarter," Daniel H. Schulman, the company's chief executive, said. 
But he added that "we are still very much in turnaround mode." 
Mr. Schulman said that while softer economic conditions presented challenges, the slowdown carried positives as well. 
"Our customers become much more cost-conscious in this sort of environment," he said. "This plays right into our brand strength." 
Before the market opened yesterday, Anthony Noto, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs, raised his rating and said the worst might be over for Priceline. 
In a telephone interview after the company conference call, Mr. Noto said "sequential results comparisons suggest things likely will get better from here."
"The more Internet companies can exceed their guidance on revenues and earnings the more they will improve their credibility. The stock market's reaction is telling you it thinks the chances of Priceline's becoming profitable in the second quarter are very good."

HEADLINE: Our Towns; 
Different Class Of Resumes In Jobless Line

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW PURDY 

DATELINE: ELIZABETH, N.J. 

 BODY:
JULIO SALINAS has worked in business most of his adult life, so it was hardly surprising that he showed up at the office yesterday morning wearing a summer-weight suit and patterned tie. What was surprising was that the office, in this case, was the unemployment office.
 Mr. Salinas, 59, a veteran beverage marketing employee, managed a money transfer company in Morristown, N.J., for the last three years. But at the end of March, he was laid off, along with 4 of the company's 13 other employees. He has left jobs in the past, he said, but "the other times I changed to increase my salary." 
 This time, after knocking on doors in vain for a month, he has even begun visiting factories. "I don't have to work in a jacket," he said.
The bottom is not falling out of the economy, but the line at the state unemployment benefits office on North Broad Street here illustrates how the slump has begun to sideline those used to going to work in jackets, pumps or any shoes without steel toes.
A visit to the same unemployment office a year ago found the line slightly shorter, but much less varied. Last spring, it was full of the hard-core unemployed and people who had left one job, confident that another would come along soon. One woman in line then had been temporarily laid off from that very unemployment office.
Yesterday, the line harbored refugees from a different economic stratum: administrative assistants, a buyer for a recently defunct chain of clothing stores, a recently laid-off manager for a sheet metal manufacturer, a banking services employee leveled by a huge layoff.
"A year ago, could I have imagined myself standing in an unemployment office?" asked Janet Brady, 42, who lost her job when the auto leasing company she worked for shut down. "Not really."
Optimism didn't evaporate with the good times, though, and seems to be keeping the recently unemployed here from despair. But suddenly, former office workers and former warehouse workers find themselves straddling the same fault line. "I feel like a rent-a-worker," said Ed Blasz czak, a lift truck operator who reeled off a resume impressive in its length.
A middle-aged woman, laid off from her job as an administrative assistant for a Fortune 500 company where she worked for 30 years, felt the same way. "It's quite a shock," she said, holding a publication called The Employment Guide. "I never had to look for a job. I never had to write a resume."
No massive layoff rocked Union County, which includes Wall Street-fed suburbs like Summit, the working-class city of Elizabeth and much in between. Its March unemployment rate of 4.1 percent is slightly above New Jersey's 3.8 percent and just below the 4.3 percent national rate. But the cumulative effect of downsizings and company failures is evident in the job-search applications of people recently laid off that cross the desk of Donna Westbrook, who oversees the state's unemployment operation here.
IT'S a varied crop," she said, reading through last week's applications. A stock transfer company employee who had been making $33,500. A $45,000-a-year human resources officer for a business systems company. A personal computer specialist who had made $54,000.
"I've got an 85K person in front of me," she said of a consumer services director laid off from a communications company. "We weren't getting PC specialists laid off last year." 
Ms. Westbrook saw the layoffs as only the beginning of a wave of new clients. But on the unemployment line it was anyone's guess how much the tremors would ultimately disrupt their lives.
Torie Murphy, 27, was laid off last Friday from her job as an administrator at a medical supply company. She went to work there after quitting college, abandoning her first loves -- the flute, the piccolo, the clarinet and the oboe -- because "you can't feed yourself in music." But the boom gave her a nice salary, which she is now afraid she will not be able to match. 
Living in the style to which everyone became accustomed in boom times may be an unrealistic expectation. Janet Brady, the laid-off auto leasing employee, was expressing concern about paying for family vacations and for college and private school tuition for her children.
She doesn't envision devastation, but she and her husband are uneasy. Her children -- bred in the boom -- are, in her word, oblivious. "They take a lot for granted," she said.
But after all, who didn't?

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate; 
New Economy Revives Printing House's Old Look

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
Sometimes, an office building tells its own story, if you know how to read it. Crowning the 11-story Romanesque structure at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and 20th Street, for example, are the letters "MBC."
 They speak of a time when 150 Fifth Avenue -- a stout, red-brick presence among limestone-white neighbors -- was the Methodist Book Concern, a vital hub of Methodism, whose press room, composing room and bindery turned out thousands of books, tracts and periodicals for nearly half a century. 
 It will become a hub again, in the vision of its new owners, who have signed up the building's first large tenant in decades: Digital Island, a computer network company based in San Francisco. It has taken two floors, roughly one-fifth of the building. 
For many years, 150 Fifth Avenue was a utilitarian property filled with small tenants paying relatively low rents. What renovation occurred was unsympathetic, like the addition of a flat marble entrance arch that obscured the ruggedly rusticated pink granite original.
That great granite arch has been revealed again by the new owners. Soon, layers of beige-gray paint will have been removed from the pink stone base. The lobby is to get a new silver-leaf, barrel-vaulted ceiling and glass walls with a textured surface meant to recall the stonework outside.
"The idea was somehow to find the balance between modern use and a 19th-century building," said David W. Levinson, the chairman of L & L Acquisitions (Robert Lapidus is the other L), which bought 150 Fifth Avenue last summer for $37.5 million in a joint venture with Carlyle Realty of Washington.
They have undertaken a $6 million renovation, designed by HLW International, and are asking rents around $55 a square foot annually. The building is being leased and managed by Insignia/ESG, of which Mr. Levinson is a vice chairman and Mr. Lapidus is a senior managing director.
Taking advantage of expiring leases, the new owners have reduced the number of tenants to 50 from about 125 and have moved other tenants around the building, opening up full 20,000-square-foot floors for the likes of Digital Island.
The building has changed hands several times. It was briefly owned by the developer Harry Macklowe. He sold it to Leon H. Charney, a lawyer and real estate investor who is best known as the host of "The Leon Charney Report," a current-affairs television program.
"I thought that area was really becoming Silicon Valley," Mr. Charney recalled. But when he started talking with e-commerce tenants two years ago, he detected that "something was waning." After holding on to 150 Fifth Avenue for about a year, he sold it to L & L and Carlyle.
Clearly pleased to bring a new media company into this old media landmark, but cautious about the long-term prospects of e-tenants, the owners required Digital Island to post a letter of credit equal to two years' rent.
As the renovation proceeds, long-obscured features emerge: Ionic column capitals at the 20th Street entrance and 11 skylights on the upper floors, perhaps installed to illuminate the printers' composing tables.
"It's been a treasure hunt," Mr. Levinson said, although workers have yet to uncover the lead time capsule placed under the cornerstone on May 23, 1888, containing copies of all the religious weeklies of the day.
The Methodist Book Concern furnished reading material to church members and helped support ministers, who received liberal commissions for selling the publications. "The preachers still feel the need of the press as their most potent ally in their work," said The Methodist Review in 1889.
The Fifth Avenue headquarters, designed by Edward Hale Kendall, was completed in 1890 and was expanded in 1900 and 1909, when a penthouse was added with decorative pilasters bearing the "MBC" initials amid religious icons.
After a 1939 merger that created the Methodist Church, the Book Concern moved to Nashville, where it still operates as the United Methodist Publishing House. It kept a bookstore and wholesale office at 150 Fifth Avenue until 1962.
Seven years ago, the building reclaimed a bit of its publishing heritage with the arrival of the Harvard University Press. In a 900-square-foot office, Joyce Seltzer, a senior executive editor, acquires and edits books and meets authors, agents and out-of-town visitors whose travel plans may not include Cambridge, Mass. She has one assistant.
"Not a lot of places have space for smaller tenants," Ms. Seltzer said. "This was one of the few buildings that did, so we were very lucky."
To permit renovation, the Harvard University Press office was moved within the building into a new space that the owners "put into terrific shape," Ms. Seltzer said. Its lease was extended to October 2002.
"Now, of course, I have to wait to see what happens," she said. "Everything will depend on the economy."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The office building at 150 Fifth Avenue at 20th Street, originally the home of the Methodist Book Concern, is having late architectural add-ons stripped away to restore its look in time for new e-commerce tenants. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Bargain Rent That May Prove Costly 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY and CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
When it comes to campaign headquarters, they don't come much better than the one Mark Green has found for his mayoral campaign. It is a rambling 4,000-square-feet warren on the third floor of the Graybar Building, a quick walk from Grand Central Terminal and smack in the middle of Midtown. He is renting it for a very attractive $32 a square foot, compared with the nearly $53 his landlord had sought for the same space just six months ago.
 And best of all, Mr. Green doesn't have to worry about any hassles from his landlord at 420 Lexington Avenue. The landlord, S. L. Green Realty, is controlled by his older brother, Stephen. 
 In a year in which all the mayoral candidates have been looking for ways to cut costs and avoid bumping against the stringent spending ceilings imposed by the city campaign finance law, economizing on campaign space is proving to be a particularly fruitful way to go. But it may well catch the attention of auditors from the city's Campaign Finance Board, who are monitoring compliance with campaign finance laws.
Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, is running his campaign out of a fifth-floor office on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx, in space that does not even have its own bathroom. Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller, has yet to rent a campaign office at all. He says he is happy working from a desk in his campaign consultant's office, spending money instead on television advertisements.
Mr. Green, who is the New York public advocate, finds himself in a particularly economical situation, in an ideally situated building that his 63-year-old brother, one of his more aggressive fund-raisers, purchased three years ago.
Mr. Green's aides and S. L. Green executives asserted that the $32-a-square-foot cost for Suite 335 was fair market value, since Mr. Green had agreed to move immediately into what otherwise would be vacant space, without demanding any improvements in the run-down offices and with the presumption that he would be out by the end of the year.
"We are paying nearly $14,000 a month in rent, well more than any other campaign," said Mr. Green's spokesman, Joe DePlasco. He noted that Mr. Hevesi was not paying a cent of rent, and added: "We pay fair-market range for the short-term use of unrenovated and otherwise vacant space. Especially since S. L. Green owns the building, we made every effort to make sure we are paying a more than adequate amount for this kind of space and that everything is fully disclosed."
But Pat Wrenn, a partner with Hinden, Sievers & Company, the accounting firm that vacated the space last September, said his firm moved to the Empire State Building after S. L. Green sought to raise his rent from about $28 to about $53 a square foot when the firm's five-year lease expired last year. Mr. Wrenn called the rent demand "exorbitant." Mr. Green's campaign moved in about three months after he left.
Other real estate agents said the asking rents for the Graybar Building ranged from $50 to $55 a square foot, even on low floors. According to CoStar Realty Information, a real estate database, there is vacant space in the building that is advertised for $51 to $55 per square foot, plus electricity. Gerry Nocera, the executive vice president at S. L. Green, said that the building was about 95 percent occupied, and that space had recently been renting for about $50 per square foot, though that figure did not reflect discounts given by the owners to tenants who were renovating their offices.
In addition to his main headquarters, Mr. Green has rented a separate fund-raising space -- 1,200 feet on the fifth floor -- in the same building since January 1999. He pays $21 a square foot for that space.
In the lease, Mr. Green agreed to a clause that allows the landlord, who is renovating the building, to make him move to another space with just 45 days' notice -- an upheaval that has happened three times, Mr. DePlasco said. By contrast, Mr. Green is assured his main campaign space on the third floor through this year, since renovation is not supposed to begin until 2002.
The question of fair rent has historically been a murky one when it comes to campaigns, and it raises a thicket of potential questions under the city's campaign finance law. If the board audits Mr. Green and concludes that he is paying below-market rent for his space, it could cause a number of complications.
For one thing, corporations are not allowed to make direct or in-kind contributions, like rent subsidies, to candidates. If the board concludes that Mr. Green is paying below the market rate, it can compute what it believes is a fair rent and apply that against Mr. Green's campaign spending limit, which is $5.23 million for the primary.
Nicole A. Gordon, the head of the New York City Campaign Finance Board, declined to comment on the specifics of Mr. Green's case, but said that auditors routinely examined campaign finances, sometimes randomly and sometimes based on complaints from newspaper articles or other candidates. In that case, she said, "you do have to evaluate what the market value is."
"There may be a lot of things that affect that," she said, "and I'm not in a position to judge that particular space. The general rule on getting space, or anything of value, is that you either have to pay the market value, or the difference between market value and what you're paying will be considered an in-kind campaign contribution."
An attorney for Mr. Green's campaign, John Siegal, said: "When the campaign was negotiating a lease, I reviewed it from the perspective as to how the campaign board would look at it. I was satisfied that it was in the fair-market range."
Mr. Hevesi pays his consultant, Hank Morris, $5,000 a month, a fee that includes the use of his office, Mr. Morris said. According to a Newsday report last month, Peter F. Vallone, the City Council speaker, pays about $1,100 a month to sublet offices on Park Avenue South from a company controlled by Dennis Mehiel, who is chairman of his campaign. Mr. Ferrer is paying $2,523 a month for his space in the Bronx.

HEADLINE: Power Concern Offers California a Secret Deal 

BYLINE:  By JEFF GERTH and LOWELL BERGMAN 

 BODY:
Duke Energy, a power-generating company accused of overcharging customers millions of dollars during California's year-old energy crisis, has secretly offered Gov. Gray Davis a deal that it hopes will solve its legal problems while helping to calm the state's chaotic electricity markets.
 The proposed settlement, outlined in documents prepared in March by Duke's lawyers, calls for an end to various state investigations, private lawsuits and state complaints to federal authorities accusing Duke of overcharging. 
 In return, Duke would make an unspecified "appropriate payment" but admit no wrongdoing.
"Duke is committed to sharing pain" and "expediting high-level confidential discussions that would embrace the governor's political and public relations needs," according to the documents, which were given to The New York Times by someone who wanted the issue aired publicly. 
Governor Davis acknowledged the secret discussions in an interview in San Francisco yesterday, and said he hoped to meet with more generators soon. But he insisted that none of the companies would escape a substantial payment because, he said, they have penalized the state with excessive prices.
"My general approach to the energy companies is that you have already charged the utilities a 50 percent credit penalty for the power they were buying from you," Mr. Davis said, so "you're going to have to have a very substantial reduction" in what the companies are owed.
Mr. Davis said Duke had walked in with "a number of demands," including an end to state inquiries but that that was not likely to happen.
"We're not about to call off the dogs," said the governor, a Democrat who will seek re-election next year.
Duke, based in Charlotte, N.C., is a major investor in California's wholesale electricity market, having spent more than $1 billion since the state opened its generating plants to outside operators in 1996.
It is also near the top of the list of companies accused of overcharging. Duke has been ordered by federal regulators to justify or refund $20 million in disputed charges this year, an amount that is third-highest among federally regulated companies in the California market.
By entering secret negotiations with Mr. Davis and being the first generator to settle, Duke could gain a public-relations advantage, in much the same way that the Liggett Group donned a white hat by being the first company to open talks with the state governments in the tobacco-litigation wars.
"We've just simply tried to be part of the solution," Richard B. Priory, Duke's chairman and chief executive, said in an interview, adding that the company was "offering ideas" and "throwing in suggestions."
Publicly, Mr. Davis has disparaged out-of-state electricity generators before and after he began talking with them privately. In an interview two weeks ago with The Los Angeles Times, he called the generators "the biggest snakes on the planet Earth" for their pricing practices.
California's electricity costs have risen to about $28 billion last year from $7 billion in 1999. By some estimates, they could approach $70 billion this year -- $2,000 for every resident. The state has stepped in to buy power for financially crippled utilities, including Pacific Gas and Electric, which is now in bankruptcy court. 
The Davis administration has struck power deals with companies like Duke in hopes of securing a stable and affordable source of power. To pay those bills, Mr. Davis is seeking the largest municipal bond issue in American history, $12 billion, although some state officials privately estimate that the final amount will be higher.
The governor hopes the bond issue will eventually take the state's taxpayers off the hook. But how those costs are allocated among ratepayers, utilities and generators, and whether the bond issue can even succeed, remain unanswered questions. A major impediment to resolving the electricity crisis, according to state officials, utility executives and economists, is the secrecy surrounding the administration's negotiations.
Several Republicans have sued the Davis administration to learn the terms of specific contracts entered into by the state. On Monday, the administration released a 67-page financial analysis, including its most detailed disclosure about the overall costs of state electricity contracts. Last week Republicans blocked legislation that Mr. Davis says he needs to pass the bond issue. The bill could come up for a vote later this week.
"The thing that has hindered Governor Davis the most among the legislative ranks is the demand for secrecy over the negotiations and the agreements that have been reached," said Senator Joseph L. Dunn, a Democrat from Santa Ana and the chairman of a select committee investigating the price spikes.
Mr. Davis, in the interview, said there were legitimate commercial reasons for keeping contract terms confidential.
The political uncertainty has spilled over into the markets, where the bonds would have to be sold. The state's credit rating, while still solid, is slipping.
Already companies that do business with California, like Duke, are citing the state's creditworthiness as a reason for charging higher prices in their dealing with the state, though the state has stepped in as buyer since February.
The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission recently ordered generators to justify high prices in California this year or pay $125 million in refunds. The companies -- including Duke, Reliant Energy, Dynegy Inc. and the Williams Company -- deny any wrongdoing and cite the state's credit situation as one reason for the high prices.
Mr. Priory, the Duke chairman, said that resolution of credit issues would lead his company to drop the so-called "credit premium" it now charges on power sales. As of March 7, Duke was owed more than $100 million by the state's power managers, documents show.
In its confidential submission to Mr. Davis and his aides, Duke said it would "forgive an appropriate amount of certain receivables, or make an appropriate payment based upon a methodology that fairly represents its share of alleged overcharges." 
The documents do not give an amount, but Duke's 2000 annual report shows that its wholesale energy division had written off $110 million for power sales to California that had not been collected. (Even with that write-off, the unit's profits before taxes doubled from 1999 to 2000, and quadrupled for the first quarter of this year.)
Duke's "preliminary global settlement template" of March 9 goes on: "Duke is committed to sharing pain with state and others on a fair and equitable basis, without admitting legal liability, because Duke has done nothing illegal."
Duke says that much of its California power was sold last year on the forward markets, not the more volatile and higher-priced spot markets. But Mr. Priory also noted in his interview that at least 10 percent was sold for "whatever the market price is."
On March 23, Duke's lawyer, at the request of Mr. Davis's legal affairs secretary, forwarded to the governor's office additional information about pending litigation involving Duke and its power sales in California. The documents show that a top Duke priority is the "prompt suspension of state investigations, lowering of rhetoric and stay of state litigation," as well as the withdrawal of state-related claims at the federal energy commission.
Also in March, the operators of the state's power grid told the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission that wholesale electricity prices in California were more than $6 billion above competitive prices over the previous 10 months. Duke has questioned the methodology of that submission and wants the claim withdrawn.
The inquiries of concern to Duke include those being conducted by the office of the attorney general, William Lockyer, and the California Public Utilities Commission. 
Barry P. Goode, the governor's legal affairs secretary, says he subsequently referred Duke's lawyer to the attorney general's office. The two state agencies say that their inquiries are continuing. Sandra Michioku, a spokeswoman for Mr. Lockyer, said, "Our investigation is ongoing."
Loretta Lynch, the president of the utility commission, said in a telephone interview yesterday, "The public utilities commission has not been involved in any settlement discussions with generators and our investigations into overcharges and withholding are ongoing and strong."
The Duke documents say the company should be given preferential treatment for its conciliatory stance.
Other generators said they were not involved in settlement discussions with Mr. Davis.

About This Report
This article is part of a joint reporting effort with the PBS series "Frontline," which will broadcast a documentary about California's energy crisis on June 5.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Gray Davis, whose administration has been marked by California's power crisis, acknowledged talks with Duke Energy, and said that companies would have to pay substantial amounts in any settlement. (Associated Press)(pg. A14)

HEADLINE: A Clinic Just as Busy As the Runways; 
40,000 J.F.K. Medical Visits a Year

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
It is remarkable, really, the number of bones, tendons and ligaments that endure a smashing each week at Kennedy International Airport.
 But there they are, in a pile of X-rays, the baggage handler whose left hand got caught in a conveyor belt, the passenger who did not believe a sign warning that rolling bags do not belong on escalators, the cabdriver whose rival for a fare thought the best method of negotiation involved an empty soda bottle and a closed fist. 
 Radiology plays a large role in the daily clinical life at the Kennedy Medical Office, just a few miles from the runways, but there is plenty else: diagnosing rare strains of H.I.V. and malaria and other diseases, treating an airplane full of flight attendants overcome by someone's awful perfume (yes, this happened), aiding family members suffering severe psychic trauma over the loss of a loved one in a plane crash. 
The Kennedy Medical Office is the largest and most complex airport health care system in the country, with a staff of 60 people -- many of them multilingual -- a 24-hour schedule and 40,000 visits a year, including physical examinations and drug testing for airline employees. 
The medical center, which is owned and operated by St. Vincent Catholic Medical Centers, in many ways reflects the shifting dynamics of air travel in recent years. A well-traveled public, crammed into economy class, is increasingly showing up with deep vein thrombosis, potentially life-threatening blood clots that can form in the legs from inactivity.
Fear and loathing among the traveling public over missed connections and lost baggage translates into increased head injuries from falling bags that should never have been shoved into the overhead. And manic expansion throughout the airport has taken a toll on construction workers, who now make up roughly 25 percent of the clinic's patients, up from almost none a few years ago.
Travelers often present the most complicated cases, from odd tropical diseases to a belly full of drugs that requires an X-ray, followed by an arrest. Sometimes patients cannot speak English. Often, their illnesses would befuddle even the most astute Manhattan hospital staff, which is not prepared to see what is possibly Ebola in its midst.
"Millions of people come in here who can't speak English and have very weird diseases," said Dr. Steven C. Garner, who, as St. Vincent's chief medical officer, oversees the clinic. "You need to have a high degree of suspicion. If someone from Florida comes in with gastrointestinal problems, you might think E. coli. But if they just came in from Nigeria, you need to think about what is endemic there." 
About 60 percent of the clinic's patients are people who work in and around the airport, many of them injured on the job. Roughly 20 percent are passengers. The rest are an assortment of people who live in nearby neighborhoods in Queens like Ozone Park and Howard Beach and whom the clinic has reached out to for its patient base.
It does offer a remarkably comprehensive selection of services, in a no-frills environment that finds aesthetic like-mindedness with the neighboring cargo loading area. There are doctors of primary care, ophthalmology, physical therapy and podiatry, a chiropractor and a program that provides vaccinations for people traveling overseas.
Joseph Vecchio, a former airport warehouse security guard, came in the other day to have his legs tested with a fairly unusual Doppler device that can detect clots. The clinic has been his primary care center since 1988. "I really wouldn't change doctors," he said. "I like it here."
Because the clinic has fewer Medicaid and uninsured patients than the hospital's other primary care sites, it is one of the few in the Catholic system that break even.
But Kennedy Medical Office's main business is generated by the sprawling community that makes up the airport. The center contracts with 400 airlines to give their employees physicals, random drug tests and eye exams. Many airport workers seek physical therapy or X-rays for on-the-job injuries, like those of Syed Haq, an airline agent who had a forklift land on his foot. (Bruise, pain, no break.) Ferreting out drug smugglers is a service to customs.
Pilots come to Dr. Jeffrey Hilowitz, an optometrist, who gives eye exams in a seat that simulates a cockpit and designs trifocals especially for them: the middle lens focuses on the instrument panel, the bottom is for the approach plates, those clipboards that pilots refer to on their approach, and the top lens corrects distance vision. 
Dr. Hilowitz is slightly frenetic and apparently optically obsessed, poring over his trifocals and eye charts with a passion that professional cooks reserve for rare shipments of fatty tuna.
"With pilots, you need to overcorrect nearsightedness because they look five miles out," he said. "LensCrafters? They don't know about these things. Trifocals? They never heard of them. I also do injuries, debris, that sort of thing." (Well, LensCrafters does know trifocals, but maybe not these trifocals.)
Odd airport health fact No. 1: Pilots should not fly for six hours after taking Viagra. The drug diminishes their ability to distinguish between blue and green, the main colors used in cockpits and airport lighting. 
Dr. Garner said that every day brings new cases from travelers, but by far the largest increase is in injuries that stem from too many passengers in too much of a hurry. Patients have often been conked in the head by luggage, are suffering a disease picked up abroad, or have gone into labor at customs. (Many of those are women who come to the United States to have their babies, who are automatically citizens.)
Erica Sellon, 21, was on a plane preparing to leave for London, where she is stationed in the Navy. She realized she had a urinary tract infection and was not going to make it. "I knew I would flip if I had to sit here for six hours like this," she said. 
Dr. Garner, who is trained in emergency medicine and radiology, sometimes reads X-rays in the middle of the night, between his duties at St. Vincent's 8 hospitals and 60 ambulatory sites. His interest in flight medicine has meant that the airport clinic is a pet project. "If someone comes in this place," he said, "they should get the same standard of care that they get at St. Vincent's or anywhere else."
The other day, he ripped through a dozen or so X-rays, dictating his diagnoses into a Dictaphone at an incomprehensible rate. A construction worker suffered a hand injury when a grinder fell on him. A twisted ankle. The conveyor belt incident.
"PatientNumber232nondisplacedfractureblahblahblah." A hand crushed between two packages, a sprained neck from lifting boxes. A young man who was fishing in Jamaica Bay in Queens and got a hook in his hand. A saleswoman who tried to prevent one customer from throwing a clothing rack at another and for her troubles got a broken hip. 
Odd airport health fact No. 2: A flight from New York to Los Angeles is the radiological equivalent to getting a chest X-ray. Should you care? Doubtful.
At the front desk of the medical center rests a red telephone. It rings each morning, as a test. Everyone expects that. No one wants to hear it ring later. But about three times a week a "33" comes through -- a call from the airport ordering all staff members to stand by because of the possibility of a crash. Of course, 99 percent of the time, nothing happens. Sometimes, when a plane has engine trouble or another problem that sets off the warning, a passenger who has a twisted ankle or is just panicky needs help.
In 10 years, there have been only three "34's," full plane crashes, at the airport, and no fatalities. (The clinic did provide assistance to grieving families from the Trans World Airlines Flight 800, Swissair and EgyptAir disasters.)
Each year, the clinic, with the Fire Department and other agencies, has a mock drill in preparation for a crash. A plane is set up far down the tarmac, and Boy and Girl Scouts who volunteer as passengers lie about the area "bleeding" and moaning. All are tagged to denote the severity of their injuries, and flares and smoke are provided for true effect. Clinic workers concede that this training exercise can be creepy, if effective.
Odd airport health fact No. 3: The clinic sees far more heart attack victims on Mondays than on any other day of the week. Something about people being stressed out about going back to work for the week, on a plane to boot.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Dr. Steven C. Garner, above, oversees the largest airport health care system in the country, at Kennedy. Left, Daniel Hendricks, a student pilot, took an eye exam. The clinic also gives physical exams and drug tests to airline employees. (Photographs by Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL; 
The Two Major League Teams in Florida Would Not Be Missed

BYLINE:  By Murray Chass 

 BODY:
Besides payroll disparity, the term heard most often in baseball these days is contraction. This has nothing to do with combining words with an apostrophe or women having babies. It has to do with jettisoning teams from the major leagues, reducing the number from 30 to whatever, in the owners' view, makes economic sense.
 Here is one view that says it will never happen. But if Commissioner Bud Selig is intent on trying to take that severe step, here is a modest proposal: lop Florida off the major league map and no one will miss it. 
 The Florida Marlins, the state's first team, had a chance to make it until their original owner, H. Wayne Huizenga, destroyed their future. The Tampa Bay Devil Rays, as they seem to be turning out, never really had a chance to make it. Vince Naimoli, the businessman who worked so hard to secure an expansion franchise on the state's west coast, is also guilty of undermining its growth. Maybe major league baseball was never meant for Florida, that is, major league baseball played from April through September. Major league baseball has always been popular in Florida in March, but that's spring training.
Both the Devil Rays and the Marlins have suffered steady attendance declines, the Devil Rays since their first season in 1998, the Marlins since 1997, their World Series championship season. Last season the Marlins drew about half the fans they attracted en route to their championship.
Three theories are often offered for the teams' problems: 1. Most baseball fans in Florida remain fans of the teams in the cities from which they migrated; 2. The state has too many elderly people whom they can't lure to games at night or in the summer heat; and 3. Fans are accustomed to paying far less for tickets to exhibition games and don't want to buy the more expensive tickets for regular-season games.
Whatever the reasons, though, Floridians just aren't interested enough to support the teams. Last season, the attendance for 14 teams, half of the other 28 teams, exceeded 2,767,378, the combined attendance of the Devil Rays in St. Petersburg and the Marlins in Miami.
Some people in baseball foresaw the disaster the Devil Rays have become. Between the time the franchise was awarded and the time the team began playing, some owners privately expressed concern that a mistake was being made. If a second team were going to play in Florida, they said, it should be in Orlando or halfway between Orlando and Tampa. They can't have a do-over, so Major League Baseball doesn't know if those owners were right, but they were right about St. Petersburg. Of course, no matter where the team had wound up, if it had been operated the same way, its troubles would very likely be no different.
It was Naimoli's way of running the team that roused the ire of his five partners and prompted them to act to remove him as managing partner. They succeeded in their effort last week after baseball officials finally understood the depth of their anger and their concerns for the franchise's future.
Naimoli is no longer in charge, although to hear him explain the development at his news conference last Friday, a listener would think the change was all his idea. "I've got to tell you," he said, "this is one of the happier days of my life."
The man was spinning so hard, he nearly spun himself into the ground. But he stopped whirling long enough to go to Detroit to join the Devil Rays for their weekend series against the Tigers. It just so happens that John McHale, whom the Devil Rays partners seek for the newly created position of chief operating officer, works for the Tigers.
Learning that Naimoli was in Detroit and talking to the news media about the search for an executive ("I'm looking for a C.O.O.," he was quoted as saying. "I'm getting a list of candidates together."), the partners, angry again, called Major League Baseball to ask to have Naimoli cease and desist.
"He's not allowed to do this on his own," said a person involved with the Devil Rays partnership.
McHale, a baseball official said yesterday, is scheduled to be in the Tampa Bay area tomorrow to talk to all of the partners and complete an agreement that will bring him there permanently. But the Devil Rays themselves might not be there permanently. Across the state, meanwhile, the Marlins are scrambling to get a new ballpark as the only way to salvage their franchise. They are not having a whole lot of success. 
The next three days are critical because the Marlins need the state Senate to approve a sales-tax rebate bill that would fund one-quarter to one-third of the estimated $385 million cost of the proposed 40,000-seat retractable-roof park. The appropriations committee has overwhelmingly approved the bill, but the senate president has refused to bring it to the floor because another committee has said the measure would have an impact on the state budget.
The time for the Marlins to win approval for funds for a new park was in the euphoric aftermath of the 1997 World Series, but Huizenga, a successful businessman but a failure at practical politics, shattered that chance by decimating the team. Selig, at the time, begged Huizenga not to do what he planned, but history shows the owner ignored the commissioner. The Marlins have paid for the decision ever since.
If the team fails to persuade the senate president to schedule a vote on the bill before midnight Friday, the chances for a new stadium will disappear.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
Myers Now Predicts Drop in Ad Spending

BYLINE:  By Bernard Stamler 

 BODY:
A leading media forecaster has reduced his estimate for American advertising spending in 2001, predicting for the first time a decline for this year from 2000.
 Jack Myers, chief economist at Myers Reports in New York, which publishes media and research newsletters and reports, estimated that ad spending would fall 1.5 percent this year from last year. 
In December, he predicted that ad spending in 2001 would increase 4.9 percent from 2000, when spending rose a robust 9 percent from 1999. In April, he trimmed his 2001 forecast by more than half, to an increase of 2.4 percent. 
 The most recent revision is being made because the decline in the national economy "is much deeper and of longer duration than we anticipated," Mr. Myers said, adding, "We are in a genuine advertising recession, and we can expect some radical belt-tightening and shifting of business plans and strategies."
For 2002, Mr. Myers reduced forecasts he made in December and April, when he predicted ad spending would grow 2.2 percent from 2001. Now, he forecasts an increase next year of a scant 0.2 percent from this year.

HEADLINE: TRENDS; 
More Women and Minorities Entering Ranks of Business Ownership

BYLINE:  By KATHLEEN O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
More women, blacks and Hispanics are choosing a workplace where they call the shots, according to results from a census of businesses. The number of businesses owned by women, blacks and Hispanics grew at a faster rate than that of all businesses in the mid-1990's, continuing a trend seen in previous years. 
 Despite the gains, the diversity of business ownership still does not reflect America's ethnic mix. Blacks, who accounted for 12 percent of the population in the 2000 census, owned just 4 percent of businesses in 1997, while Hispanics, who made up 13 percent of the population, owned just 6 percent. All three groups earned a much smaller share of total business revenue than their numbers suggest, in part because so many businesses had no paid employees aside from the owner. 
 The District of Columbia had the highest share of companies owned by women and blacks, and New Mexico had the highest share of businesses owned by Hispanics, a reflection of their population makeup, said Eddie Salyers, chief of the economic census branch of the Census Bureau.
 Past surveys have shown a high proportion of businesses owned by blacks have also been owned by women, said Mr. Salyers, explaining why Washington ranked high in the overall share of women-owned busi-nesses. In 1992, he noted, 45 percent of black-owned busi-nesses were owned by women. KATHLEEN O'BRIEN

HEADLINE: ON DISPLAY; 
Ups and Downs? A Place To Put It in Perspective

BYLINE:  By LYNNE ARANY 

 BODY:
WHILE the questions nowadays are usually more sophisticated than the old standby "How many people jumped to their deaths in the Great Crash of '29?," in these bearish times it is comforting to know that the Museum of American Financial History, just off Wall Street, has an answer: not many. (The economist John Kenneth Galbraith researched the matter and determined that there was no increase in the suicide rate that year.) 
 It was that quest for context -- and for "reassurance in times of market uncertainty," in the words of the museum's executive director, Brian Thompson -- that inspired its founding in 1988, the year after the stock market took a major tumble. 
 In a world where the ups and downs of the Dow are as inescapable as the weather, the museum, now a Smithsonian affiliate, seeks to help visitors understand the deeper economic forces that help shape their lives. 
Exhibitions like "Rockefeller Rediscovered" and "Morgan" (as in J. P.) allow visitors to trace a line from the robber barons of the industrial age to the day traders of today. The technology changes with the times, too, from interactive CNNfn consoles to an original 1867 Edison Universal Stock Ticker. And there are historic stocks and bonds, vintage photographs and personal ephemera. 
Appropriately enough, the museum is housed in the Rockefeller dynasty's old power base, the former Standard Oil Building, and is just a dime toss from the famous buttonwood tree under which the New York Stock Exchange was founded in 1792.
Museum of American Financial History, 28 Broadway, New York. (212) 908-4110 or (877) 983-4626; www.financialhistory.org.

GRAPHIC: Photo: BEFORE NASDAQ -- Edison's ticker, at the Museum of American Financial History. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)
