HEADLINE: TALES OF THE TAPE; 
Inflation Creates a New Breed of Movers and Shakers

BYLINE:  By MELISSA MILGROM 

 BODY:
WITH only days before the opening of a group show, P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center had a 12-ton problem. The 25-foot swimming pool from Tuscany had arrived on schedule, but the outhouse from Rotterdam and the life-size ceramic elephant from Rome were held up at Port Elizabeth, N.J., because of a snowstorm. 
 Finally, the delayed cargo arrived, and a team of art handlers, riggers, registrars and curators hurried to unpack the containers and install the show by March 11. 
 For four frantic days, the museum, in a converted school in Long Island City, Queens, resembled a construction site. Inside, cut-glass experts pieced together a hand-blown chandelier, while a ceramist diagrammed how to uncrate Luigi Ontani's elephant. 
Outside, two barefoot Italians dug a trench in half-frozen mud for Massimo Bartolini's swimming pool. Nearby, a crane hoisted Joep van Lieshout's outhouse onto its second-story platform as if it were a rooftop air-conditioner.
"This is the fourth outhouse I've moved," said Peter Lundberg, who was operating the crane. "But as art, it's the first one."
Art has always moved the masses, but it takes a cadre of specialists to move massive art. The process is both brutal and exacting, requiring riggers and art handlers to be part forklift operator, part mechanic, part engineer, part diplomat and part conservator. With all the variables, it is not surprising that museums rely on experts, usually outside contractors, to do the work. 
"We get paid to take risks and for some know-how," said Eddie MacAveney, an owner of More Transport, which specializes in moving art. 
No two pieces of oversize art are alike, and installers must be improvising and resourceful. Thomas Ritter's gargantuan Maximog, a futuristic all-terrain vehicle, can virtually traverse any place on earth. Except the Museum of Modern Art. Bringing it into the museum for a recent show required removing its wheels, bumper and gasoline (flammable liquids are not allowed in the museum). 
Riggers then maneuvered it sideways into the freight elevator and rolled the monster truck into position on dollies.
To minimize the challenges, art handlers research a piece's history before moving or installing the work. Still, certain artworks are astoundingly complex. 
"It takes a lot of effort to make something appear effortless," said Graham Stewart, who owns Art Crating, which specializes in moving oversize and complicated art.
Chris Burden's five-ton sculpture "Medusa's Head," which just came down at the Museum of Modern Art, is a gigantic orb whose fragile surface is crisscrossed with toy locomotive tracks that wind through intricate rock-encrusted tunnels. "It's an oversized Faberge egg," Mr. Burden said.
The sculpture travels with a 50-page instruction manual, a complement of tools and Mr. Burden's assistant, Spencer Stair, who has the piece memorized. 
"There are times when the work of contemporary artists tries the imagination of those of us who have to install it," said Jerome Neuner, director of exhibitions at the Museum of Modern Art. Before hanging it, technicians had to X-ray the reinforced concrete ceiling to see if it could hold the load.
The more outlandish the art, the more extraordinary the demands of installation. When installing Damien Hirst's dioramas-cum-aquariums filled with freshwater fish at the Gagosian Gallery in Chelsea last year, art handlers in scuba masks and snorkels had to dive into the tanks to arrange props the fish had knocked down.
Some works are so imposing the museum is altered to accommodate them. Facades are torn down, ceilings removed, garage doors concealed behind temporary walls. To install Rubens's 19-by-14-foot artwork "The Assumption of the Virgin" for a 1985 exhibition, the Metropolitan Museum of Art had to dismantle a steel door, frame and lintel and cut a 10-inch-deep, 50-foot-long groove across the ceilings of two galleries. Only then could 12 art handlers ease the canvas through the slot, up the Grand Stairway, into position. By the opening, the groove was gone -- only to reappear three months later, when the show came down and the process was reversed.
After a show, the exhibitions are prepared for transport. Climate-controlled crates are custom-built and expertly packed. The Met, for instance, has four employees who build crates and five workers who pack them. When lending a piece to another institution, museums color-code or brand the crates for easy tracking. Mr. van Lieshout's sculptures are actually made from shipping containers and can go directly onto a container ship or flatbed tractor-trailer without modification. Routinely, an installer, a courier or both will escort a piece. Despite the vigilance, accidents can happen. Friezes chip. Vases are knocked over. Paintings are vandalized. 
Occasionally the toll is human. In 1988, a rigger taking down a 16-ton sculpture by Richard Serra at the Castelli Gallery in SoHo lost his leg when it toppled onto him. In 1971 a worker installing a Serra at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis was killed when a two-ton steel plate fell on him. Mr. Serra was devastated by the fatality and could not work for a year. 
How a piece is moved is determined by its size, shape, materials, condition and value. The most difficult pieces to move are oddly shaped solid masses with fragile surfaces. For Mr. MacAveney of More Transport, a 400-pound plaster seashell coated in wax was far more difficult to move than the five huge Calder stabiles he transported at once. The Calders were disassembled and moved; the seashell was impossible to isolate in its crate without marring its surface.
When oversize art leaves a museum, it becomes heavy cargo. And that is how it is treated when it passes from cargo plane to boom crane to flatbed truck. A cargo ship is the least reliable method of transport because turbulent seas can slow travel and moisture can cause damage. The Met has not sent anything by ship since the late 1970's. Still, certain works are too huge for even the largest cargo plane, the Russian-made Antonov, which the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum occasionally uses to transport art to its museums in Venice, Berlin and Bilbao.
Each state has its own regulations regarding extra-wide loads, so hauling large sculptures across the country requires paperwork and planning. Last year, Mr. Hirst's supersize anatomical torso, "Hymn," arrived in New Jersey on a cargo ship the size of a small city. The seven-ton bronze was too wide to fit in the Lincoln Tunnel. Before it could be driven into Manhattan, transportation authorities flagged the load, provided escort cars, designated a route and reserved a time when it could cross the George Washington Bridge. "It's usually 4 a.m.," said Mr. Stewart, who handled the move.
SOME works are so valuable that moving them defies practicality. Expense means nothing when safeguarding, say, the 15 Vermeers that now hang at the Met. "You would never take the risk of putting the work of a single painter all on one plane," said the Metropolitan's chief registrar, Herb Moskowitz.
That museums are willing to undertake so much effort and expense for a temporary exhibition is remarkable. After all, as Franz Schmidt, the Met's manager for special projects, put it: "You're dealing with objects that cannot be replaced if they are damaged, broken or lost. You have insurance, but money cannot replace a chalice from the 10th century that was made for a czar or an emperor."
Through it all, the integrity of the artwork remains paramount. "The No. 1 rule is not to change the object," Mr. MacAveney said. "It's like that Hippocratic oath: 'Do no harm.' "

HEADLINE: The Good Times (Make That Not-So-Bad Times) Still Roll 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
IT remains to be seen how long the downturn in the economy will last, but museum directors seem to be prepared for the worst. Big donors have deep pockets, major art institutions say, and tend to keep giving regardless of swings in the market. Yet a recession mentality inevitably infects charitable giving. 
 "It's something we all give serious thought to," said Emily Rafferty, the senior vice president for external affairs at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York. "There's no question in a downturn you definitely will feel the hit. 
 "There isn't a fund-raiser around who wouldn't be concerned about it," she added. "We all hope that it's going to be short-lived." 
Indeed, the current cycle is a shock to the system after so many years of unprecedented prosperity. What happens to all the ambitious capital campaigns under way? The planned exhibitions? The expansions? Fortunately, museums say, they got while the getting was good, starting their major capital campaigns while plenty of money was floating around so that now they are nearing those goals rather than just beginning to set them.
The Montclair Art Museum in New Jersey, for example, is three-quarters of the way through its $18 million capital campaign, which will help the museum double in size and increase its endowment. "Basically, we have not seen any slack-off," said Bill Turner, a vice president who heads the museum's capital campaign. "I think if we lived on the West Coast in the dot-com world, maybe we would be more affected."
But even there, museums say their major donors include old money as well as new, and note that large technology companies now consider arts giving an integral part of their marketing strategies. "It's not just cosmetic," said David A. Ross, the director of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. "Museums are part of the marketing plan. We're perceived as a bargain."
On the whole, many museums are in a wait-and-see mode -- not canceling construction and programs that are in the works, but hesitating before taking on new costly projects.
At the Studio Museum of Harlem, the director, Lowery Stokes Sims, said the board had instituted a mandatory contribution from board members (she would not disclose the amount) and added that the museum was putting a display window in its store in hopes of attracting strollers from 125th Street.
But the museum is not panicking, she said, adding: "I have so many other things to worry about. We will prevail."
Arnold L. Lehman, director of the Brooklyn Museum of Art, sounded a similar note. "Optimism comes to me more naturally than pessimism," he said. "I don't believe in self-fulfilling prophecies, but if everyone has formulated their thinking toward a downturn -- toward recession -- by and large we'll get there." 
Mr. Lehman said the museum was proceeding with its major initiatives -- redoing the main entrance on Eastern Parkway and making major changes in its permanent collections. "I don't think we're simply going to look at the Dow every day and say, 'We're going to postpone all of this,' " he said.
The Met said that its $650 million capital campaign would continue, and there would still be a new Byzantine Gallery, new restaurants and a new Roman court. "Right now, we're not looking at compromising," Ms. Rafferty said. "It's a question of scale, rather than particulars." 
In San Francisco, Mr. Ross acknowledged that it was unseemly for companies to make large gifts to the arts when they were firing some of their employees. But he said conversations about prospective donations continued -- "discreetly."
Some museum executives say the news media runs the danger of fanning the downturn into a full-blown recession. "We've had so many years of such tremendous prosperity that the media sees six months of negative returns and says, 'Oh, my God, there must be a problem,' " said Glenn D. Lowry, the director of the Museum of Modern Art in Manhattan. "But I don't think that's how people see it. People have come to see cultural institutions as a centerpiece in their lives."
Museums have been through bad times before and worked hard to insulate themselves from heavy weather on Wall Street. The key seems to be building a loyal constituency. "Museums have had to be very, very adept in binding their communities in good times and in bad times to their programs," Mr. Lowry said. "That's because we live and die by our ability to relate to our public. By and large, despite economic swings, people will support institutions they believe in."
T HROUGH audience research, marketing surveys and trial and error, Mr. Lowry went on, museums like the Modern have learned how to make themselves seem essential, not a luxury. "Embedding ourselves in the fabric of life so we're not seen as a discretionary activity -- museums have gotten very good at doing that," he said. "At the end of the day, no one has to go to a museum, but millions decide they want to." 
Museums also have the advantage of being affordable, compared with other places to spend. 
The last few years of boom times have allowed museums to build a strong financial base, setting records in membership and fund-raising. "We're looking at a 10 to 12 percent increase in annual giving," Mr. Lowry said. He added that the museum's capital campaign was approaching $500 million, the endowment was up to more than $400 million and attendance was up more than 20 percent above projections for the first quarter of 2001. Six years ago, a big day for the Modern was 3,000 visitors; now the museum averages more than 5,000. At the Whitney Museum of American Art, annual attendance almost doubled in the last two and half years, to about 600,000. 
Still, museums acknowledge, it is harder to raise money for unsexy costs like infrastructure and operating expenses than for cultural programs. As a result, they are careful to diversify their income, so if one source dries up, others may continue to flow. "We have many different legs to stand on," Mr. Lowry said.
The Studio Museum in Harlem recently received a grant of $750,000 from the Ford Foundation that depends on matching funds from individuals. The Met has worked to raise money for specific endowment funds that can go to exhibitions and programs "with the goal that we would be less reliant on corporate funding, which is harder to get in a down economy," Ms. Rafferty said.
"You can't look at the institution in fund-raising only," she added. "It's thinking for the next five years." 
Museums say they are not considering raising their suggested admission prices ($10 for most), but may consider cutting back in some areas, even as they build up others. For example, because the young donors who belong to the Met's Apollo Circle have been enthusiastic about the museum's mini-courses, Ms. Rafferty said, "We might offer more of them and eliminate one large event."
Nevertheless, museums acknowledge that although prepared, they have to work doubly hard to remain secure. "One always has to be as prescient as possible about anticipating the market," Ms. Rafferty said. "There is no one who thinks there is always an up economy."

HEADLINE: Auto Sales Were Down Last Month 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 1 

 BODY:
Auto sales fell in April, providing the first important indicator of the economy's condition early in the second quarter and a sign that weakening consumer confidence is beginning to affect spending on high-price products.
 The auto industry sold cars, sport utility vehicles, minivans and pickup trucks at a seasonally adjusted annual pace of 16.6 million vehicles, down 10 percent from a year earlier. Sales in April were a little higher than what the auto industry considers to be the long-term demand for new automobiles but below the annual rate of 17.2 million cars and light trucks in the first quarter. 
 Sales did not drop quite as much as expected as a few foreign automakers did very well, gaining market share at the expense of their Detroit-based rivals. Some European and Japanese automakers have used the dollar's strength to export cars and car parts more cheaply to the United States and have passed on part of the savings to consumers through discounted loans and leases while booking fatter profits, too. 
General Motors, Ford Motor and the Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler all posted declines in sales of 15 percent to 18 percent, compared with sales in April 2000. But Toyota reported an increase of 6.7 percent, while BMW's sales soared 30.5 percent.
Auto executives emphasized that they had been expecting a slowdown in the industry because of surveys showing a decline in consumer confidence but were nonetheless disappointed.
"It's about where we had projected the industry to be, but I have to say we've undercalled the industry now for so long that calling it correctly, you kind of feel, 'Man, that was a weak month,' " Jacques Nasser, Ford's chief executive, said in a telephone interview today.
Auto sales have long been a favorite indicator of the economy's health for many economists, including Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve. They are often the first indicator to come out just after a month ends, and they cover a broad swath of the economy that is particularly sensitive to public confidence, something that is often difficult to measure.
Because auto sales slowed markedly late last year and then rebounded fairly strongly in the first quarter of this year, in line with gross domestic product figures that have since been reported, auto sales have become a favorite indicator of executives far from Detroit as well.
"We've paid more attention to it over the last six months, that's for sure," said Michael Capellas, the chairman and chief executive of Compaq Computer, which is based in Houston. "The auto industry has always been a pretty good indicator of consumer confidence and continues to be."
Auto manufacturing is a big part of the American economy, accounting for a quarter of the combined economic output of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana. 
Ford and G.M. made very different changes today in their production plans for the second quarter, presenting a blurry picture of the extent to which the auto industry can lead the economy out of a slowdown. Automakers need to rebuild dealership inventories, which were drawn down from January through March by strong sales and the idling of factories.
Ford, which announced an aggressive production schedule a month ago after idling many factories for a week or two at a time in the first quarter, said today that it would cut its planned production for the second quarter by 40,000 vehicles, to 1.19 million.
George Pipas, Ford's market analyst, said the automaker would eliminate costly overtime in June at two factories that make large pickup trucks and would extend to two weeks from one week a planned shutdown later this month at an Ohio factory that makes full-size vans.
But G.M., which had set a modest production schedule for the second quarter, said that it would add 36,000 cars to its plans while subtracting 4,000 vehicles from its planned output of light trucks, a category that encompasses sport utilities, minivans and pickup trucks.
Diane C. Swonk, the chief economist at the Bank One Corporation in Chicago, said that while auto output would be down from the second quarter of last year, the current quarter would still be the first three-month period since then with higher production than the preceding quarter. "The problems are bottoming out," she said, while adding that she was generally bullish about the economy right now.
Ford's sales dropped 15 percent in April from the level a year earlier, excluding its purchase of Land Rover last summer, while G.M.'s sales fell 15.7 percent. Chrysler suffered the biggest decline, with sales that were 18 percent off of last year's levels.
Dieter Zetsche, Chrysler's chief executive and president, said on Monday that shortcomings in a new compensation plan for dealers had made them reluctant to order more vehicles. The compensation plan has been redesigned, and Chrysler announced today a wide range of rebates and discounted auto loans on Chryslers, Jeeps, Dodges and Plymouths.
Nissan's sales dropped 16.3 percent and the Mercedes division of DaimlerChrysler suffered a decline in sales of 7.5 percent, while Honda's sales slipped 2.9 percent. But Mitsubishi's sales climbed 8.9 percent.
Today's somewhat slower sales figures helped to resolve a mystery that had been troubling many here: why auto sales in the first quarter did not reflect surveys that showed declining consumer confidence, even though sales and the surveys have been closely correlated since the 1960's.
In an interview three weeks ago at the beginning of the New York International Auto Show, Ronald Zarrella, G.M.'s president of North American operations, remarked: "You wonder what happened -- do you throw away 35 years of history here? We don't understand it."

HEADLINE: Former F.C.C. Chief Joins Investment Firm 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1 

 BODY:
William E. Kennard, the former chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, has decided to join the Carlyle Group, an investment company, as a managing director of its telecommunications and media practice.
 Earlier this week, Carlyle announced that Arthur Levitt, the former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, would join the firm as a senior adviser dealing with private equity investments. 
The company also said that Afsaneh Mashayekhi-Beschloss, the treasurer and chief investment officer of the World Bank, would join the firm as a managing director and partner. 
 Mr. Kennard, who recently announced his intention to join the board of Handspring, a maker of hand-held computers, said that he was excited about the opportunities presented by Carlyle.
"The firm has a strong commitment to invest in the telecommunications and media areas," he said. "They really want to increase their commitment to the sector. They didn't make a lot of investments in the area last year so their powder's dry."
Carlyle, which calls itself the world's largest private equity company, manages more than $12 billion through funds in the United States, Europe and Asia. Its employees and advisers include some who have held high government positions, many in Republican administrations. 
They include former President George Bush, former Defense Secretary Frank Carlucci, former Secretary of State James A. Baker III, and former White House budget director Richard G. Darman.

HEADLINE: Business Travel; 
The corporate jetbusiness is booming, even as the airlines complain about a softening economy.

BYLINE:  By Joe Sharkey; The Business Travel column appears each Wednesday. E-mail: jsharkey@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
THREE weeks ago, Warren Buffett, Richard Santulli and a bunch of our senior management people, we visited seven cities in Europe in three days," Kevin Russell said yesterday afternoon, describing what for most of us would have been the Business Trip From the Black Lagoon. 
 "Every day we had lunches and conferences in each city," he continued. "Day 1, we were in London and Paris. On Day 2, one group of us went to Cologne and a second group to Geneva. Then we all came back together in Frankfurt that night. Day 3, we all went to Geneva and Milan. That night, we got on a Boeing Business Jet in Milan at 1:45 in the morning and flew to New York, where Santulli went to an 11 o'clock meeting. Buffett flew on to Omaha for a business lunch the same day." 
 Mr. Russell's voice slid up a half-octave. "You think we could have done that flying commercial?" he asked. "Impossible!"
Mr. Russell is the senior vice president of Executive Jet Inc., the largest operator of private business jets and an innovator in the rapidly growing business of providing corporate jet service to companies that purchase fractional shares of an aircraft. In 1998, 11 years after the company was bought by Mr. Santulli, a former mathematics professor and Wall Street banker, Executive Jet was acquired by Berkshire Hathaway, the company controlled by Mr. Buffett. It now has a fleet of more than 900 business aircraft. 
For those fortunate enough to be able to fly that way, having a private jet available for business travel opens up possibilities and eliminates a lot of travail. In the last five years, as has been mentioned previously in this space, corporate jets -- once derided as symbols of decadence and wretched excess -- have become practical travel alternatives for a steadily growing number of companies. Among the reasons are ever-worsening commercial airline delays (450,000 last year, a record), rising business fares and airline scheduling that makes it difficult, as business interests expand geographically, to get from Point A to Points B and C -- especially if the destinations are not near major domestic and foreign cities with airline hubs.
Recently, of course, the airlines have been wailing about sagging profits as many companies have reacted to the softening economy by cutting back on business travel, the main source of revenue for the airline industry.
It would stand to reason that the cutbacks would affect the highest end of the business travel market, the corporate jet. But that doesn't seem to be happening.
During the first quarter of this year, as the airlines suffered, $2.1 billion in shipments of new business jets set a record, according to the General Aviation Manufacturers Association, a trade organization. 
Some of that revenue increase is attributable to shipments of top-of-the-line business aircraft like the new airliner-like Boeing Business Jet. Companies took possession of five of these during the quarter, at a cost of $40 million to $50 million apiece, not to mention 18 long-range luxury Gulfstream IV-SP's and Gulfstream V's. Gulfstream is owned by General Dynamics.
But sheer numbers of jet deliveries were up as well. During the first quarter, 146 business jets were shipped to corporate customers, up 7.4 percent from the corresponding period last year, when the economy was percolating along, according to the trade group.
That's partly because of the robust growth -- about 50 percent annually during the last three years -- in companies that sell charter flights and fractional business-aircraft shares, including Executive Jet and competitors like FlightTime.com, which was founded in 1985.
For example, Executive Jet, which says it will schedule more than 200,000 flights this year, announced yesterday that it had placed a $2 billion order for 50 luxury midsize Galaxy business jets from General Dynamics, with an option for an additional 50. In the last six weeks, Mr. Russell said, Executive Jet has committed to aircraft orders totaling about $3.5 billion. 
The boom in fractional ownership is, meanwhile, drawing attention from the commercial airlines. United Airlines said recently that it was considering starting a division that might provide corporate jet services like fractional ownership.
In recent years, the fractional ownership market remained buoyant in downturns. "When the Asian economy tanked, our business saw an uptick," Mr. Russell said. "Back in May of 1999, when the U.S. stock market had a downturn, we had an uptick. In the past six months, we've had an uptick as more companies realize that the cost of doing business is expensive, but they have to be more competitive."
Ed Bolen, president of the general aviation aircraft manufacturers' trade group, said that the overall industry was projecting steady growth for the next 10 years, though with "a few" manufacturers predicting "possibly a slight softening next year, but then a pickup," he said. So far this year, the only softening has been a 13 percent drop in sales for single-engine piston aircraft, the type usually purchased by private individual fliers, said Shelly Snyder Simi, a spokeswoman for the association. 
The European market, where national aviation authorities have long resisted business aviation, is now poised for strong growth, industry officials say. So is the Middle East.
Not to mention China, where businesses have been sending delegations to the United States to study the business aviation and general aviation market, Mr. Bolen said. Geography is a compelling factor there, he said. 
"China has figured out that they have to find a way to open the western part of the country to economic development" and link it to eastern China, he said.
"It would obviously be very expensive to connect western China to the east by building new railroads or highways. Whereas with a handful of airports, all you do is pour two miles of concrete in a few strategic locations and utilize general aviation."

HEADLINE: G.O.P. LAWMAKERS AND WHITE HOUSE AGREE ON TAX CUT 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM and RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1 

 BODY:
Republican negotiators from Congress and the White House agreed today to seek $1.35 trillion in tax cuts over the next 11 years as part of a compromise budget, less than what President Bush proposed but still by far the largest tax reduction in the last 20 years.
 The negotiators remained deadlocked today over spending, the other component of the budget plan. Senators want to permit much more to be spent on domestic programs next year than the president and leaders in the House are willing to accept. 
 Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, the leader of a group of 13 other Democrats and two Republicans that holds the balance of power on budget matters in the evenly divided Senate, said he would support the compromise if he was satisfied with the final spending figure. 
Mr. Bush, who made a large tax cut a central part of his election platform and the top item on his legislative agenda this year, appeared in the Rose Garden at the White House to proclaim victory, even though the figure agreed to today fell short of the $1.6 trillion that he had long demanded and that the House approved in March.
"We have more work to do to complete the full budget," Mr. Bush said, "but today we have accomplished significant tax relief and shown we can work together in a constructive way to get things done for the people of this country."
The compromise gave something both to the administration and to Mr. Breaux and his centrist allies. It also allowed the Democratic leadership in Congress -- which said even the $1.35 trillion figure was fiscally irresponsible -- to say it had at least forced Mr. Bush to scale back his original plan.
The plan would permit $1.25 trillion in tax reductions over the decade starting next year, just what Mr. Breaux had sought.
But the plan would permit an additional $100 billion in tax cuts this year to stimulate the economy. That brought the total to only $250 billion below the president's total of $1.6 trillion over 10 years. 
It is unclear what kind of tax cut Congress will enact to send the $100 billion back to taxpayers this year or how soon they might see any of it. If this amount is divided evenly among about 200 million taxpayers, it would mean an immediate tax cut of about $500 per person.
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican leader, said $1.35 trillion would not be enough to accommodate all the tax reductions the president asked for in his long-term package, but he would not speculate on what might be shelved. Mr. Bush's plan called for reducing all income tax rates, doubling the child credit, giving a break to two-income married couples and repealing the federal tax on large estates.
The measure the negotiators are working on is called a budget resolution. It is not legislation but rather a blueprint that sets the overall levels for tax and spending laws to be enacted later this year.
With the parameters of the tax cut apparently decided, negotiators from the White House, the Senate and the House began grappling in earnest with how to resolve their differences over spending. The budget plan adopted by the Senate called for an increase in spending of more than 8 percent next year; the House version stuck to Mr. Bush's request that the spending increase be held to 4 percent.
Before breaking off their talks this evening, the negotiators were discussing a compromise of about 5 percent.
But the nonbinding spending targets included in the budget resolution have been ignored by Congress in recent years, and all indications are that both the House and the Senate will have trouble living with a target in that range.
There is strong support in both parties for substantial increases in spending for the military, for education and for agriculture. Within the next three weeks, the Pentagon is expected to settle on a long-term budget request reflecting a series of comprehensive reviews of the nation's military strategy and needs. 
While those reviews are not yet complete -- and are offering conflicting advice on which weapons to keep -- officials said the Pentagon spending request for next year almost certainly would be higher than the $310.5 billion Mr. Bush proposed as a place-holder in his budget.
The panel overseeing one of the reviews, for example, has proposed increasing spending on more than 80 different weapons programs at a cost of $30 billion to $40 billion a year, according to two officials who were briefed on the recommendations.
A senior defense official, however, said today that Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld was more likely to seek a more modest increase of $10 billion to $12 billion in the overall budget for next year, slightly more than what the Senate passed but less than the House's open-ended version.
It is unclear how Congress will balance the pressures for additional spending with its commitment to avoiding a return to budget deficits and the stated desire of many Republicans to seek additional tax cuts this year beyond those called for in the budget.
Some Republicans are already considering pairing an increase in the minimum wage this year with a reduction in the capital gains tax. There is also considerable bipartisan support for a measure that the House plans to take up on Wednesday that would expand the popular 401(k) and individual retirement account programs.
The standoff on spending reflects the strains on the Republican leadership from the need to compromise to get anything through the evenly divided Senate while dealing with the demands of the conservatives who hold sway in the House.
If the spending increase on domestic programs for next year turns out to be much more than 4 percent, enough conservative Republicans in the House might bolt to cause the agreement to be defeated.
"As you move that number up, you see Republicans dropping off at a faster rate than you see Democrats coming on," said Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader.
But much of the additional spending allotted by the Senate measure would go for education. If the increase is much below 8 percent, a few Republicans and all the Democrats who voted for the plan last month can be expected to turn aainst the compromise.

HEADLINE: Mr. Bush's Nuclear Blueprint 

 BODY:
President Bush erased any lingering doubts yesterday about his determination to develop a missile defense system and to discard the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty. But in outlining his plans in a speech at the National Defense University, Mr. Bush signaled a willingness to approach these fateful steps with some caution and a recognition of the diplomatic and technological barriers that he faces in trying to overhaul longstanding principles about the management of nuclear weapons. Only by acting in that spirit can he possibly engineer the changes he favors. If his commitment to work with Washington's allies and with Russia proves evanescent, he could well start a dangerous and expensive new arms race. 
 The impulse behind Mr. Bush's plan is reasonable. In the wake of the cold war and the disintegration of the Soviet Union, there is no need for the United States and Russia to maintain thousands of nuclear weapons and to rely on the fear of mutual annihilation to keep the peace. Nor is it necessary for the two nations to negotiate new treaties to further reduce their arsenals, though accords already completed must be honored. Acting independently, Washington and Moscow can cut the number of strategic nuclear warheads that each possesses to 2,500 or even fewer from the present level of more than 6,000 apiece. We were pleased to hear Mr. Bush accept that principle yesterday in saying that he is "committed to achieving a credible deterrent with the lowest possible number of nuclear weapons consistent with our national security needs, including our obligations to our allies." 
 The potential obstacles to this enlightened approach are construction of a missile defense system and abrogation of the ABM treaty. The new strategic architecture that Mr. Bush has in mind, a world in which nations work together to reduce the threat of nuclear attack, cannot be realized if the United States rashly moves ahead on its own to build a missile shield and abrogates the ABM treaty. 
That would produce precisely the kind of destabilizing nuclear imbalance that Mr. Bush seeks to avoid. China would feel threatened because its limited nuclear forces could be thwarted by an American missile defense, and even Russia with its numerous warheads might believe its power had been blunted. Despite its economic tribulations, Moscow would have little choice but to invest in new weapons to offset the American advantage. 
Mr. Bush seems to appreciate these dangers, even as he talks about moving "beyond the constraints" of the ABM treaty. He spoke yesterday of working with the Russians, even someday developing a joint defense. The president's approach on the ABM treaty should be to negotiate revisions with Moscow, or to seek an agreement to set aside the treaty as outdated. With discussion rather than threats of unilateral cancellation of the treaty, he may find a willing partner in the Kremlin. But if Mr. Bush is merely offering diplomatic pleasantries to mask a decision to undercut the treaty, he will encounter fierce opposition in Moscow and considerable resentment among America's allies, many of which fear a renewed arms race.
After years of research and investment, the United States has yet to produce a defense that can shoot down a single warhead. The development effort should continue because nations like Iran, Iraq and North Korea are likely to perfect long-range missiles in the years ahead. But Mr. Bush must be realistic. The kind of space-based laser weapons that Ronald Reagan promoted as president remain improbable. It would be wiser, as Mr. Bush suggests, to work with more feasible technologies, including ground- or sea-based systems that can disable a missile during the initial phase of flight when it is far easier to target than a warhead streaking through space. It would be politically and financially reckless to start building an antimissile system before the technology is perfected. And the idea attributed to Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld of mounting an imperfect system to sow doubt among potential adversaries would actually inhibit the needed research.
Mr. Bush has now defined his goals. The world will get a better picture of his specific intentions later this year when he fills in the details. At that point, it will not be hard to tell whether he is following the patient and deliberate course he set yesterday or instead is embarked on an irresponsible effort to dismantle the ABM treaty and erect a missile defense system before he has made the necessary diplomatic and technical preparations.

HEADLINE: Worthy Or Wobbly?; 
Complaints Challenge Fairness Of Late 1990's Boom in I.P.O.'s

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

 BODY:
When Simon D. Roffe graduated from the Stern School of Business at New York University in 1998, he wanted to be a professional investor. He raised a few hundred thousand dollars from family and friends and nearly tripled his money the next year by buying many of the bull market's hot new technology stocks.
 Then those stocks came crashing back to earth. 
 "I learned from my mistakes," Mr. Roffe, 25, wrote in a recent e-mail message. "I expected to get rich quickly. I went from driving a Porsche Boxster to being unemployed virtually overnight." 
But Mr. Roffe, like dozens of other investors, now wonders if there was an artificial element to the investment mania and is fighting to retrieve some of his lost gains. He has joined one of dozens of lawsuits against an alphabet soup of companies that had hot initial public offerings -- from Ariba to PlanetRx.com -- and the blue-chip securities firms like Merrill Lynch, Credit Suisse First Boston and Morgan Stanley that brought them public.
The suits follow a broad investigation by securities regulators and prosecutors into the I.P.O. machine of the late 90's, which had the breathtaking power to turn a business idea that was little more than a few bullet points on a napkin into a publicly traded company with freshly minted millionaires at its helm.
A central accusation of the suits, and the subject of a new inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission, is that underwriters extracted promises from investment firms to buy shares of new stocks at higher prices than the offering in exchange for larger allocations of I.P.O.'s.
Everyone, it seemed, wanted to get shares at the initial offering price, but securities firms carefully doled them out to their very best clients, and perhaps friends and family of the company. Individual investors usually bought after trading began, what is known as the aftermarket.
The lawsuits raise fundamental questions about whether the market for new issues was manipulated at the expense of the little investor, who was shut out of the offerings and had no way of knowing whether some of the subsequent "buy" orders might have been prearranged at escalating prices, creating artificial demand for stocks that would later erode.
"At the time, I didn't know I was throwing loaded dice in a crooked craps game," wrote Mr. Roffe, who bought new stocks like PlanetRx and Marimba, but failed to receive shares of them at the offering price. "I was taught at N.Y.U. that market prices are reached in efficient markets, and they weren't polluted by market manipulation."
Last August, the S.E.C. issued a bulletin reminding Wall Street that promises solicited from clients to buy stock in the future, known as tie-in agreements, "undermine the integrity of the market as an independent pricing mechanism for the offered security" and are illegal, whether direct or indirect.
"I don't see that it caused a boom that didn't exist," said Barry Barbash, a partner at the law firm of Shearman & Sterling and a former director of the Division of Investment Management at the S.E.C. "But problems arise in the I.P.O. market in boom times, when there is a scarcity of hot allocations."
Several mutual fund and hedge fund managers agreed to discuss the trading of new stock issues and what types of commitments were made to buy additional stocks, though many did not want to be identified.
"It's like being a big tipper at a restaurant," said one hedge fund manager. "If you give $50 to the maitre d', you'll get a good seat.
So to line up shares at the attractive offering price, the fund manager had to promise to buy more. An investment banker made the consequences of not participating clear: no generous I.P.O. allocation on the next deal.
"I can remember one conversation I had," he said, "where someone said, 'Well, if you want bigger allocations, you need to buy more in the aftermarket.' "
But several fund managers suggested the practice was often less overt, with underwriters rarely strong-arming investment firms of any size.
"It's never that you have to," said Andrew J. Kessler, who runs Velocity Capital Management, a technology hedge fund. "It's the wink and the nudge." 
In all, about a dozen fund managers described a range of relationships with stock underwriters, and none of them felt they had done anything wrong. Some said they were asked what their interest was in buying more after trading began and placed buy orders ahead of time. Some said they volunteered that they were interested in buying shares and at what price. That price was always higher than the offering price.
While underwriters are permitted to try to prevent a new stock from sinking as soon as it starts trading, an accepted practice known as stabilization, they can do so only by buying shares at the offering price or lower. And they cannot pass this responsibility on to their clients without discussing it.
Generally, the fund managers said they made commitments to buy at least two to three times the number of shares that they were allocated at the offering.
For them, there was little downside. They generally placed limit orders, which are filled at or below a set price. So if the new stock zoomed, they did not have to buy at a superinflated price. If a new issue was offered at $18, they might put in a limit order at $23 or $24, Mr. Kessler said. If the stock began trading even higher, a number of things could have happened. A fund manager might have wanted more shares anyway and bought. The underwriter also might have applied pressure to buy at the higher price, one manager said. Or the order might simply have expired.
If a fund manager did not want to be a long-term investor, he would sell the stock after a few days, sometimes trading through a different firm. The practice, another money manager said, is referred to as puking a stock back to the market.
Robert E. Turner, chief investment officer of Turner Investment Partners, which has $12 billion in assets and manages mutual funds for the Vanguard Group and Merrill Lynch, said the underwriters would ask about a manager's appetite for more shares and at what level. The underwriters, he said, would expect you to buy at those levels, and they tried to keep track.
Mr. Turner's firm was a prolific investor in new issues like Ariba and E.piphany, two Internet software companies that had moonshot offerings. For a deal like E.piphany, Mr. Turner would tell the underwriter "if Siebel is trading at 10 times revenue, we would be willing to pay, say, seven times next year's revenues for E.piphany." He was referring to Siebel Systems, a competitor.
Underwriters have an obligation to spell out all agreements that might affect how a stock is priced and how it trades, as well as all the risks faced by buyers. The firms are strictly prohibited from taking orders for follow-up purchases of the stock before the initial pricing is completed because it could give investors a false impression of demand for a stock on the open market.
But a mutual fund manager's telling an underwriter he is interested in being a long-term investor makes for a gray legal area. Jay Ritter, a finance professor at the University of Florida, said he thought plaintiffs had a legitimate grievance that they were misled by aftermarket deal making, but that it might be challenging to prove.
"What's going to be tough is proving that the underwriter forced people" to place additional orders, Mr. Ritter said. "Without explicit testimony or e-mails, plaintiffs have to prove it was the underwriters' forcing the buyer to do that, rather than them voluntarily doing it."
If, as the suits argue, the underwriters lined up commitments from others at various price levels, creating a strata of price supports sometimes called a ladder, it raises questions of how much of the I.P.O. boom was driven by an undisclosed force.
At least a dozen law firms have filed complaints against stock issuers including Ariba, AutoWeb, Calico Commerce, Doubleclick, Marketwatch.com, Marimba, NetZero, PlanetRx.com, Priceline.com, Red Hat, VA Linux Systems and Ventro and their underwriters. Suits have also been filed against a Merrill Lynch fund that invested in Internet stocks.
"We believe the suits have no merit, and we will vigorously defend ourselves," said Victoria Harmon, a spokeswoman for Credit Suisse First Boston.
Joseph Cohen, a spokesman for Merrill Lynch, said, "We believe these are absolutely meritless claims, and we intend to vigorously defend against them."
Nearly every day a new claim is made against another one of the 90's stock rockets. Mr. Roffe's complaints are being handled by Howard Sirota, a lawyer with Sirota & Sirota, and Mr. Roffe's uncle.
"There were approximately 725 hot new issues since 1997, where the manager or co-manager was one of the major investment banks," Mr. Sirota said. "At least a couple hundred are going to prove to be manipulative."
For underwriters, the investor complaints are only part of their problems. Regulators and federal prosecutors are conducting a separate criminal investigation on whether some investment banks received kickbacks from customers in return for the profits they made on I.P.O. allocations.
Those kickbacks may have taken the form of additional or inflated commissions, usually in the trading of other stocks. None of the fund managers interviewed for this article said they funneled trading commissions to a firm, but one manager said it was common to direct more legitimate business through an underwriter after receiving a large allocation.
Some fund managers did not take part in any of this.
"We don't participate in these practices," Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest mutual fund manager, said in a statement. Indeed, a giant like Fidelity would not need to play the game, several smaller competitors said, because it generates so much business that underwriters would not want to cross its fund managers.
Philip Treick, who manages a hedge fund for Aesop Capital Partners, a small San Francisco investment firm, said he was unaware of such practices.
"I've never had a broker say to me that the size of your allocation will be tied to your market order," he said. "We've never played that game." 
He added, "When the I.P.O. window was open, we'd do I.P.O.'s. It was free money. But we never figured out how to get much."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-11

Bush to Skirt ABM Treaty In Quest for Missile Shield
President Bush called for sweeping changes in national security strategy, including a new relationship with Russia, that would include a defensive missile system and cut "to the lowest possible number" the nuclear arsenals both sides assembled during the cold war. In a speech at the National Defense University, Mr. Bush stopped short of saying the United States would withdraw from the Antiballistic Missile Treaty, though he made it clear that he intended to build an antimissile network that would violate it. A1

'State of Rebellion' in Manila
President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo declared a "state of rebellion" in the capital and ordered the arrests of opposition leaders, whom she accused of conspiring against her fledgling government. Three people were killed after protesters loyal to her jailed predecessor, Joseph Estrada, stormed the gates of the presidential palace. A11

Israel Jails 'Mr. Security'
Itzhak Yaakov, 75, a retired general who oversaw weapons development for the military, has been in an Israeli prison for five weeks on charges of espionage that carry a maximum penalty of life behind bars. He is accused of passing confidential information to "unauthorized individuals" with the intention of "compromising the security of the state." A3

Plane Experts Land in China
American technicians arrived on Hainan island to determine how to retrieve the Navy spy plane stranded there since its collision with a Chinese fighter on April 1. The technicians will inspect the plane today, a Pentagon spokesman said. A8

Castro Assails Trade Proposal
Fidel Castro denounced the proposed Free Trade Agreement of the Americas during a May Day speech to hundreds of thousands of flag-waving Cubans. He called the agreement a ploy by Washington to manipulate its allies politically and to dominate the hemisphere commercially. A4

World Briefing A8

NATIONAL A12-17

G.O.P. Negotiators Agree On $1.35 Trillion Tax Cut
Republican negotiators from Congress and the White House agreed to seek $1.35 trillion in tax cuts over 11 years as part of a compromise budget. That is less than what President Bush sought, but it would still be the largest tax reduction in 20 years. Talks on spending were stalled. A1

F.B.I. Director Decides to Go
Louis J. Freeh, 51, said he would resign in June, 8 years into the 10-year term he was appointed to by President Bill Clinton. President Bush said that Mr. Freeh's decision took him by surprise and that he wished Mr. Freeh would have stayed on. The administration is looking for a successor. A1

Bush Panel on Social Security
President Bush will name a commission on overhauling Social Security that will be heavily stocked with members of both parties who favor his proposal to create private investment accounts for all workers. A17

Ex-Klansman Guilty of Murder
A jury of eight whites and four blacks convicted Thomas E. Blanton Jr. of murdering four black girls in the bombing of a Baptist church in Birmingham, Ala., in 1963. Mr. Blanton, 62, was sentenced to life in prison. A1

Electric Utility Seeks a Deal
Duke Energy, which is accused of overcharging California customers millions, has offered Gov. Gray Davis a deal intended to solve its legal problems and calm chaotic electricity markets. Duke would make an unspecified "appropriate payment" but admit no wrongdoing. A1

SCIENCE/HEALTH

Genome Effort Feud
Rivalry between the teams that decoded the human genome has erupted again, with some academic biologists contending that Celera, their commercial rival, used a method that failed and relied on the academic consortium's to assemble its version. Celera officials denied that. A15

NEW YORK/REGION B1-8

State Letting Con Ed Fire Up Old Polluting Plant
Con Edison plans to restart the most-polluting power plant in the city, a small, dormant 50-year-old generator near the Brooklyn Navy Yard. State regulators, seeking to increase the city's power supply, tentatively agreed to the plan without an environmental review. Environmentalists and some legislators say that restarting the oil-fueled plant is illegal. A1

Inquiry Into Police Shooting
The authorities in Irvington, N.J., are investigating an officer's fatal shooting of an unarmed man who, officials say, tried to drive off as the officer approached him as the man was taking his girlfriend's two daughters to school on Monday. B1

The Price of Homelessness
It costs more than $40,000 in public money for a mentally ill person to be homeless for a year in New York City, nearly as much as it costs for the same person to live in supportive housing, according to a University of Pennsylvania study. B4

EDUCATION B8

Cardinal Closing 3 Schools
The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York said it would close three financially failing parish elementary schools, one in Manhattan and the others in Dutchess and Ulster Counties, as part of an effort by Cardinal Edward M. Egan to cut spending. B1

Senate Taking Up Schools Bill
The Senate voted to begin debate on the first major education bill in years, but a number of conservatives in Congress complained that President Bush's signature campaign issue was being seized by Democrats and stripped of Republican ideas. A17

Devils Lead Toronto, 2-1
The Devils beat the Maple Leafs, 3-2, in Game 3 of their playoff series. D1

A Sag in Auto Sales
April auto sales fell 10 percent from April 2000 levels, providing the first significant indicator of the economy's condition early in the second quarter and suggesting that weakening consumer confidence is starting to affect spending on high-price products. C1

Learning From 'The Sopranos'

HEADLINE: President to Name Panel On Social Security Plan 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1 

 BODY:
President Bush plans to set in motion his effort to overhaul Social Security on Wednesday by naming a commission heavily stocked with members of both parties who favor his proposal to create private investment accounts for all workers.
 Administration officials and Democrats in Congress said the co-chairmen of the commission would be Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the former senator from New York, who is a Democrat, and Richard Parsons, a Republican who is a chief operating officer of AOL Time Warner. 
 The other members of the 14-person commission include economists, business executives and former government officials, split evenly between the two parties. 
Without any changes, Social Security would run short of money to pay all promised benefits within the next four decades. 
Mr. Bush made creating individual investment accounts within the system one of the main planks in his campaign platform, and commission members said there was little doubt they would recommend such an approach.
But creating private accounts would not by itself solve Social Security's problems. In some ways, diverting money from the current system into personal accounts would deepen Social Security's financial hole, while also raising questions about whether retirement benefits should be subject to the inherent uncertainties of Wall Street -- especially after the stomach-churning gyrations of the last few months. 
Any comprehensive solution is almost certain to require additional steps that could set off a political firestorm, such as raising the retirement age and reducing cost of living adjustments.
As news of the panel's composition spread on Capitol Hill today, Democrats dismissed it as fixed from the start. "This is a stacked, completely orchestrated effort to come to a desired result, and I'm very disappointed that that is the decision they've made," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader in the Senate.
Mr. Bush, asked today about the makeup of the panel, would not address its leanings but said it was important to "make sure that there's an objective analysis of Social Security, how do we save it, what do we do to make sure it's viable in the future." 
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican leader, said it was possible that Congress could act on some of the commission's recommendations by the end of this year. But other members of both parties said it was far more likely that Congress would not take up the issue until next year, and that it would be difficult to pass a package that called for painful steps like benefit cuts, especially in an election year when control of the House and the Senate will be up for grabs.
Mr. Moynihan has long advocated the creation of personal investment accounts. Mr. Parsons does not have any extensive public record on the issue. Described by colleagues as a moderate Republican, he was considered by the administration for a number of top-level jobs.
Among the Democrats, Sam Beard, a former aide to Robert F. Kennedy, and Tim Penny, a former member of Congress from Minnesota, have been particularly active in promoting private accounts.
The other Democrats are Estelle James, an economist at the World Bank; Robert L. Johnson, the founder of BET, the entertainment and media company; Olivia Mitchell, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, and Fidel Vargas, who was a member of a Social Security advisory committee in the mid-1990's.
The other Republicans on the commission will be John F. Cogan, a Stanford economist who was an adviser to Mr. Bush's campaign; Gerald Parsky, a financier from California who was assistant Treasury secretary in the Ford administration; Carolyn L. Weaver, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute; Robert G. Deposada, the executive director of the Hispanic Business Roundtable; Gwendolyn S. King, who was Social Security commissioner under President Bush's father, and Thomas R. Saving, an economist from Texas A&M University.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Battered by the economy, Hook Media, an online agency, files for bankruptcy protection.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliot 

 BODY:
THE faltering advertising economy has claimed another victim. Hook Media Inc., a leading online agency, has filed for bankruptcy protection and is preparing to sell most of its assets to a division of Havas Advertising.
 Hook was founded in May 1998 in Boston and was one of the fastest-growing interactive shops in New England. At its peak, Hook employed more than 100 people in Boston and at offices in Atlanta, opened in August, and New York, opened in October. There were even plans as recently as December to expand in the first half of 2001 to Chicago and Los Angeles. 
 But the office in Atlanta was closed in February, putting 10 employees out of work, and layoffs were made in Boston and New York that reduced the staff to about 50.
The filing under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy law took place in Boston on April 23, said Don Epperson, president of Hook, who confirmed a report about the filing that appeared in the online edition of the trade publication Adweek. Mr. Epperson attributed the filing to "the market downturn and to one of our larger clients having financial difficulties." He declined to identify the client.
"That put us over the edge," Mr. Epperson said, "and we had to go over to 11."
Hook becomes the latest agency to fall prey to the effects of the sharp, sudden cutbacks in ad spending both online and offline by marketers. On Monday, the Worldwide Xceed Group, a Web designer in New York, filed for federal bankruptcy protection, which allows a company to pay its creditors while it reorganizes operations. Worldwide Xceed also sold the assets of two offices, in Chandler, Ariz., and Colorado Springs.
The recession that rocked Madison Avenue when it began a decade ago contributed to the closings of well-known agencies like Ally & Gargano; Geer, DuBois; and Smith/Greenland. While conditions this time are so far nowhere near as bleak, there has been a change in the agency landscape as a result of the increased competitive pressures caused by consolidation and globalization.
Years ago, agencies in trouble could retrench, regroup and recover. But that has grown difficult more recently, as shown by the swift closings of troubled shops like Lois/USA and Wells Rich Greene BDDP.
In another sign of just how anxious the climate has become, this columnist heard yesterday from several readers who could not get through on the telephone to an agency and said they thought the agency had gone out of business. The agency's executives said they were simply having telephone trouble and were startled to hear about the conclusion to which the readers had leapt.
Mr. Epperson said that negotiations were "pretty far along" for Havas to acquire the assets of Hook and hire most, if not all, the remaining employees, adding, "We hope to take all our clients with us." They include Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Massachusetts, the EMC Corporation and PricewaterhouseCoopers.
The plans call for Hook to be acquired by and become part of Media Contacts in New York, the interactive agency of Media Planning, part of the Media Planning Group unit of Havas.
Mr. Epperson referred questions to Maria Luisa Francoli, who heads the Media Planning Group at its headquarters in Madrid. That office was closed yesterday for a holiday. Steve Farella, chief executive at Media Planning, did not return a telephone call seeking comment.

HEADLINE: In America; 
Harvard's Heroes

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
You want heroes? Take a peek inside Massachusetts Hall.
 The temperature in Cambridge hovered around 90 yesterday as the "living-wage" sit-in at Harvard passed the two-week mark. The 30 or so students who continued to occupy Massachusetts Hall, and the dozens of students who have set up a tent city in Harvard Yard, outside the hall, were understandably weary. 
 But they remained upbeat, sustained by the intense belief that their school should not be contributing to the erosion of pay and benefits that has plagued low-wage workers in the U.S. for the past couple of decades. 
"It's a classic nonviolent protest," said Prof. Marshall Ganz of Harvard, who spent many years as an organizer for the civil rights movement and the farm workers' union. He praised the students for the tenacity and discipline they've shown in rallying support for their living-wage campaign. 
"Economic justice as a real core issue has been a long time coming," he said.
The bottom line for the students is that all workers should be paid a wage that covers the basic needs of food, shelter and clothing for themselves and their families. And they have vowed to continue protesting until Harvard meets that minimum threshold.
"I don't feel right going home at night knowing that the people cleaning up after us and preparing our food aren't getting paid enough to take care of their families," said Jenny Foster, a divinity student who is active in the living-wage campaign but is not one of those sitting in.
The students want Harvard to establish a living wage of $10.25 an hour as the minimum that could be paid to employees, whether they work directly for the university or for contractors hired by Harvard.
One of the many encouraging elements of the campaign is its cross-cultural aspect. The students, some from very privileged backgrounds, have gone to the mat on behalf of janitors, dining hall employees and others who grew up poor and are still struggling. Many of the workers are immigrants from the Caribbean and Latin America.
"I grew up in the coal fields of northern Appalachia," said Danny Meagher, a part-time campus museum guard who is 44 years old, married and has three children. Mr. Meagher's wife works, so his family is not poverty-stricken. But he makes only $9.48 an hour and some of his colleagues make less than that. He appreciates the sustained effort of the protesters.
"These students have chosen to stand up and take what I consider to be an incredible moral stand on behalf of people whose backgrounds are different from theirs," he said. "I think that's a fine thing. To me, they're a true reflection of what the university claims to be about. Harvard should be proud of them."
We have become accustomed in the era of globalization and the triumph of the markets to ignore such concepts as economic justice and fairness. Harvard officials do not argue that their lowest-paid workers are being paid what they're worth. They say they have an obligation, when considering the pay of these workers, to remain in step with the surrounding market. Why that should be so is not at all clear. If some company down the street pays its security guards less than a subsistence wage, why is Harvard, the wealthiest university in the nation, obligated to follow suit?
"They can use all kinds of market justifications, but that doesn't make it right," said Amy Offner, a member of the living-wage campaign. "The market doesn't have a lot to do with morality. It doesn't have a lot to do with justice. All it does is crank out numbers, and that doesn't tell us how we should treat each other, or how we ought to live."
However this plays out, the protesters have provided a great service by insisting that we no longer avert our eyes to the continuing assault on the living standards of working men and women, even at a great institution like Harvard.
John Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., was correct when he said yesterday that the issues of low-wage workers are "everybody's issues." The sit-in at Harvard, he said, highlights "the principle that workers who give their all every day should not be rewarded with poverty wages."

HEADLINE: Fed's Regional Survey Finds a Slowdown 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2 

 BODY:
The economy slowed in the last two months as retail sales were weak in March and manufacturers reported falling orders and production, the Federal Reserve said today in its latest regional economic report card.
 Rising energy costs have replaced wage pressures as a new inflation threat, the Fed said in the report, known as the beige book for the color of its cover. 
 Most of the 12 regional districts of the Fed report that labor market pressures have eased. 
"Almost all districts report a slow pace of economic activity," the Fed said in summarizing the overall performance of the economy in March and early April.
The beige book compiles anecdotal reports on economic developments in the regional Fed bank districts. It is used by members of the Fed's policy-setting Open Market Committee in its interest rate deliberations. The next meeting of the committee is on May 15.
The economy, now in its 11th year of expansion, grew at a 2 percent annual rate in the first quarter, after a 1 percent growth rate in the final three months last year. The report issued today suggested a more pessimistic view of the economy's prospects.
"Retail sales were weak in March but strengthened in April. Still, retailers in most districts are expecting only small gains, at best, in coming months," the beige book said.
Business travel is down, and manufacturing "continues to weaken across districts, with demand having fallen in most industries," the report said. "The high-tech and telecommunications industries are experiencing a pronounced slowdown."
More recent developments suggest the economy, while still not expanding rapidly, nevertheless may have bottomed out from its slowdown. Manufacturing, though still weak, is no longer worsening. The National Association of Purchasing Management's factory index rose in April for the third month in a row. New orders placed with factories for goods other than transportation equipment fell in March for a fourth consecutive month. Over all, they rose 1.8 percent.

Inflation was stable. Commercial real estate has cooled. Philadelphia -- Manufacturers reported shipments were steady although orders fell. Companies have cut spending on equipment. Kansas City, Mo. -- The energy sector was healthy while retailing and manufacturing were sluggish. Home building activity improved. Dallas -- Manufacturing declined, and the demand for business services was weak. The livestock industry remained "in good shape." San Francisco -- Businesses expressed concern over rising energy prices. Retailers reported weak-than-expected sales. (Source: Bloomberg News)

HEADLINE: Writers and Studios Take Negotiations to Next Level 

BYLINE:  By RICK LYMAN 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 2 

 BODY:
Talks between Hollywood writers and production executives quietly slipped past Tuesday's midnight deadline until, about 3 a.m. today, weary negotiators decided it was time to take a break, get some sleep, consider the offers that had just been placed on the table and then resume talks at noon, which they did.
 By late this afternoon, the talks appeared to be moving into what could be called their final phase. 
 For the first time since negotiations with the writers resumed two weeks ago, the chief executives of all of the major studios and networks involved in resolving the so-called creative rights issues with the writers -- issues of respect and status, including what writers believe is an overuse of the "film by" credit for directors -- came to the negotiations in an effort to resolve those issues.
If the creative rights issues could be resolved, the negotiators hoped that the remaining crucial issues involving payment of residuals could rapidly be addressed. 
"They spent a lot of time earlier today clearing brush, getting some of the other issues out of the way," said an executive involved in the talks. "What this says, all of the C.E.O.'s showing up, is that they are serious about making an agreement. It says: 'Ready, set, go. Let's wrap this up.' "
Among the executives who arrived for the creative rights meeting at 4 p.m. were Jeffrey Katzenberg of DreamWorks SKG, Alan Horn of Warner Brothers, Stacey Snider of Universal Pictures, Tom Rothman of Fox Filmed Entertainment, Leslie Moonves of CBS and Ken Lemberger of Sony Pictures.
"If we can resolve the creative rights, then it's a run for the roses," one executive said late this afternoon.
Negotiators for the Writers Guild of America, which represents 11,000 movie and television writers, have been seeking increases in several types of residuals, the fees paid for subsequent use of a writer's work after its initial broadcast or theatrical run, as well as concessions aimed at improving the status and power of film writers. Representatives for the major studios and television networks said that profit margins on movies and television programs were shrinking and too small to justify huge increases in residuals. 
The talks had begun their final day before the deadline on Tuesday with optimism running high. A late-night bargaining session on Monday had cleared away many issues, and there were growing hopes that a settlement might even be reached before the deadline. But as midnight approached, it became clear that there were too many issues unresolved, including many of the major ones involving residuals and creative rights.
Still, reluctant to let the momentum slip away, the negotiators kept talking past midnight. But before long, it became clear that there were too many outstanding issues for one night's work, and the positions of some in the negotiations seemed to be hardening rather than softening as the dawn approached.
So the talks resumed at noon today, with many still expressing hope that a settlement could be reached soon.
There was much speculation last week that the companies would place a final offer on the table in the closing hours of the talks. This was not done, largely because progress in the talks seemed to indicate that a settlement was possible without it. But if the talks continue to move slowly, or bog down, the companies might yet place a take-it-or-leave-it offer on the table, officials said.
Hollywood had been in a state of frazzled anticipation for six months as the contract deadline approached. Partly, this is because of the potential effect of a writers strike, which could have major repercussions on the coming fall TV season. But more than that, the contract covering the 135,000 actors represented by the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists expires on June 30, and those unions are also seeking increases in residuals and other concessions.
One concern that production executives have in the current talks with writers is that the guild will try to delay a resolution until closer to the actors' strike deadline, to give the two unions even bigger bargaining muscle. Guild officials deny this.
A dual strike by the actors and writers would effectively shut down film and television production in Southern California, perhaps dealing a devastating blow to the region's economy and causing studios and networks to lay off thousands.
"Every studio in town has a list," said one movie executive who is not directly involved in the negotiations. "The list says that, O.K., X number of days after a strike begins, this group of people are laid off, and X more days after that, this group, and so on. It would all start happening very quickly after a strike begins."
