HEADLINE: SPORTS BUSINESS; 
Playing the Arena Game in Newark Is Getting More Expensive

BYLINE:  By Richard Sandomir 

 BODY:
When he was discussing less-than-robust regular-season attendance at Devils home games recently, Lou Lamoriello, the team's president and general manager, said, "Things will be better in the new place."
 Newark is the promised land for the Devils and the Nets, a future urban refuge from shared tenancy in the Meadowlands. A deal to have a new arena by 2004 is idling, if not stalled. 
 The $215 million package of state and local subsidies approved by Gov. Christie Whitman evaporated when she left to work in the Bush administration, and it is anyone's guess whether her replacement, Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco, a lame duck, has the juice to equal or exceed his predecessor's generosity. 
With time ticking on the Newark plan and the patience of YankeeNets, which owns the Nets and a stake in the Devils, the proposed price tag of the arena is leaping past $300 million, toward $350 million and higher. And as the building cost rises, so will YankeeNets' belief that the subsidy should increase.
Figure, then, that to create this higher-priced arena-cum-urban renewal project, YankeeNets wants state, city and county aid worth 75 to 80 percent of the total cost. That's astonishing considering that two-team arenas stage enough basketball and hockey games and other events like wrestling shows, concerts and circuses to have traditionally made private financing relatively easy.
What YankeeNets wants "is definitely on the high end of the spectrum," said John Mansell, an analyst for Paul Kagan Associates, a media and sports analysis firm.
Chicago's United Center and Washington's MCI Center were built entirely with private funds, but they received city contributions for infrastructure improvements. For the newer MCI Center, Washington contributed $60 million, making the public cost 23 percent of the $260 million project. At the $400 million Staples Center, home to the Los Angeles Lakers, Clippers and Kings, a small amount of city money paid for land.
Every project is different, of course, and Newark is an interesting case. Saddled for decades with a reputation as declining and downtrodden, the city has had a gradual recovery symbolized in part by the success of the three-and-a-half-year-old New Jersey Performing Arts Center, which drew 560,854 people to its events last year. For Raymond Chambers and Lewis Katz, who bought the Nets in 1998 and merged with the Yankees a year later, the arena is a major element of their charitable endeavors.
"The real question is, do you allow cities to fail or give them a chance to win, whether it's Indianapolis or Newark?" said Harvey Schiller, the chairman of YankeeNets. He said that government help to build the Newark arena would relieve the state of some of its annual subsidies to the Meadowlands complex.
Mark Rosentraub, dean of the Maxine Goodman Levin College of Urban Affairs at Cleveland State University, said substantial public aid to a Newark arena could be rationalized if the negatives about the city were as considerable as they used to be. But the success of the Performing Arts Center suggests, to some extent, he said, the willingness of people to go to Newark for entertainment pursuits in numbers that did not exist in years past.
"There will be excess profits for the teams if you go to 80 percent public funding and the negatives aren't so great," Rosentraub said.
YankeeNets may look at sweetheart deals like one being offered by Memphis to lure the Vancouver Grizzlies as a model in its negotiations, but remember: cities luring teams from elsewhere tend to be financial toadies.
Whether seeking as much as 80 percent of the cost of the arena from the public is excessive depends upon whom you talk to."We're in a competitive situation," Schiller said. "We have rising costs of running the teams. This does not result in being greedy owners."
Last week, a settlement with the MSG Network opened the door for the Yankees to start a regional cable television network in 2002, which would eventually show Nets and Devils games. A network would have huge profit potential that could help pay more to build the arena.
Sam Katz, a sports finance expert who advised the Whitman administration, said that such a large public commitment to pay infrastructure costs, and use taxes to pay off bonds, "gets close to unconscionable."
"There's no doubt that the land and building will cost more as time goes by," he said, "but that doesn't mean governmental entities should bear that much of the cost."
In markets "inferior to northern New Jersey and New York," Sam Katz said, the public investment in two-team arenas has been in a range of 33 percent to 50 percent.
"This project has a particular problem in the prices paid for the Nets and Devils," he said, referring to the $150 million for the Nets and $176 million for the Devils. "They paid high levels for teams with significant operating losses."
It was easier for Abe Pollin to finance the MCI Center privately in part because he paid so little for the Washington Capitals ($6 million) and the Wizards ($1.1 million). Eighteen months after the arena opened in 1997, Pollin sold the Capitals and a stake in the Wizards for $200 million.
Sam Katz said the alternatives to Newark for the teams were limited. "I would take seriously the threat of putting the Nets in Madison Square Garden," he said. "But the Devils may just have to go, to Houston or maybe Orlando."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Ex-Heads at Auction Houses Indicted in Antitrust Case
A. Alfred Taubman, the powerful real estate developer and former chairman of Sotheby's, and Sir Anthony Tennant, his onetime counterpart at Christie's, were indicted on federal antitrust charges stemming from a conspiracy in which the two giant auction houses fixed commission fees charged to more than 130,000 customers over six years.
 The indictments contend that the two men masterminded a scheme that involved fixing fees to sellers of fine art, jewelry, and furniture and trading information that virtually nullified the bargaining power of customers in the $4 billion auction market. Page A1. 

Liberty to Sell Its Annuities Unit
Sun Life Financial Services of Canada has agreed to buy Liberty Financial's annuities business, Keyport Life Insurance, as well as the Independent Financial Marketing Group, Liberty's distribution arm, for about $1.7 billion, executives close to the deal said. C4.

Delta Pilots to Vote on Contract
The governing board of the union representing pilots at Delta Air Lines voted to approve a tentative contract and forwarded it to the union's nearly 10,000 members for a ratification vote. Meanwhile, Frederick W. Reid, 50, left, Delta's chief marketing officer, was promoted to president and chief operating officer. And at Continental Airlines, Greg Brenneman, its president, resigned. C5.

Tax Officials Raid California Office
The California tax authorities and local police raided the factory and home of a California businessman who does not withhold taxes from his workers' paychecks. C3.

Nasdaq Has Best Close in 2 Months
The Nasdaq composite index rose for a fourth day, reaching its highest close in almost two months, as investors snapped up technology shares. The Nasdaq rose 52.36 points, or 2.4 percent, to 2,220.60. But the Dow Jones industrial average fell 21.66 points, or 0.2 percent, to 10,876.68. The Standard & Poor's 500 index eked out a gain of 0.99 point, to 1,267.43. C7.

I.B.M. Advances Screen Technology
I.B.M. researchers have perfected a significant improvement in the process used to align liquid crystals that form displays in laptop computers and some desktop machines. C4.

Economy Claims Another Ad Agency
The faltering advertising economy has claimed another victim. Hook Media, a leading online agency, has filed for bankruptcy protection and is preparing to sell most of its assets to a division of Havas Advertising. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C6.

Fed Sees Weaker Manufacturing
The economy slowed in the last two months as retail sales were weak in March and manufacturers reported falling orders, the Federal Reserve said in its latest regional economic report card. Rising energy costs have replaced wage pressures as a new inflation threat, the Fed said. Most of the 12 regional Fed districts report that labor market pressures have eased. Separately, the Commerce Department said factory orders increased by 1.8 percent in March. Excluding transportation equipment, they fell 1.2 percent. C4.

Vodafone Pursues New Stakes
Vodafone plans to issue $4.3 billion in stock to help it buy stakes in phone companies in Japan and Spain that British Telecommunications must sell. World Business, Section W.

The New Yorker Dominates Awards
The New Yorker received several awards and some lesser-known magazines staged upsets at the National Magazine Awards. C6.

Taxation: Progressive or Regressive
President Bush's proposed tax cut has rekindled an age-old debate: how progressive or regressive should the income tax be? Hal R. Varian: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: In California, Solar's Time to Shine 

BYLINE:  By EVELYN NIEVES 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., May 2 

 BODY:
Strangers are flocking to Eric and Nicole Jorgensen's boxy 50-year-old tract house.
 At first, passersby noticed the two windmills on the roof. Now, with energy on nearly everyone's mind, the Jorgensens' place -- with solar panels on the back roof, a sun oven in the backyard and a meter that runs backward -- is a full-scale attraction. It draws fifth-grade classes, international news crews and fellow homeowners. 
 "California has so much sun that it's silly everyone isn't doing this," said Mr. Jorgensen, 34, a physicist at Stanford University. He hitched his house to the sun and wind last October, and it now produces more energy than it uses. 
While the Jorgensens may have been early converts to California's latest conservation movement, they are a lot less lonely than they were six months ago. Rolling blackouts, record-high utility bills, bankrupt and nearly bankrupt power companies -- as well as a state campaign that combines pleas with financial incentives to use less energy -- are all creating a populace focused on saving energy.
Not since the oil crisis of the 1970's have the words "solar power" been so popular. Not since the "small is beautiful" movement spawned the same decade has bragging about living simply been so in vogue.
Energy-saving fluorescent bulbs, once eschewed as too expensive and unattractive, are hard for stores to keep in stock. Businesses and government agencies are dimming lights and many consumers are buying energy-efficient appliances and adjusting thermostats.
Vice President Dick Cheney on Monday dismissed the notion that conservation alone would solve the nation's energy ills, but state officials here say it is having a decided impact. In February, for example, California businesses and consumers cut their energy use by 8 percent, with no financial incentives other than reducing their bills.
Last month, pleas for conservation from the state's power managers produced a 3 percent drop in use -- enough to end mandatory blackouts by 2 p.m., well before the 6 p.m. peak in the state's power demand. 
Last week, underscoring the conservation theme, Gov. Gray Davis said that state government offices had averaged consumption cuts of 20 percent in January and February.
Whether conservation will stick remains a big question. After consumers responded to the state's conservation alert during the blackouts last month, officials said, once the crisis passed, power users went back to their old plugged-in ways.
The state's Independent System Operator, which manages the power grid, warns that blackouts could be far more frequent and last longer if conservation does not become embedded in the public's behavior. "Conservation has to become a way of life," said Patrick Dorinson, a spokesman for the power agency.
Consumer and environmental groups had been critical of Governor Davis for not acting sooner to advocate conservation legislation, and concerned that he was relying too heavily on an $850 million conservation program for businesses and residents. But the groups now say they have been encouraged by the response to the call to conserve. 
Incentives including rebates and free energy-saving products are proving more popular than anticipated. San Diego Gas & Electric distributed what it thought was a three-month supply of energy-efficient light bulbs in just two months, and predicted it would soon exhaust nearly $20 million in residential conservation incentives -- rebates on energy-saving appliances, for example -- that were supposed to last all year.
Southern California Edison, like other California utilities, had been criticized for not promoting conservation efforts harder. It recently began publicizing its rebates with bill inserts and door hangers; in two weeks, it received more than 3,500 inquiries from customers.
Such signs buoy the governor's hopes of cutting energy use in California by 5,000 megawatts -- enough to power about five million homes -- by the summer, when energy use usually jumps by 50 percent.
Trend-watchers go further, saying that if California, the nation's most populous state, can demonstrate how simple conservation measures can save energy and money in uncertain economic times, the rest of the country will follow.
"It's not just an electricity crisis," said Gerald Celeste of the Trend Institute in Rhinebeck, N.Y. "It's also gas and jobs being lost and surely very few people believe that things are going to bounce back to pre-Internet-bubble-burst levels." Such a sobering economic downturn, "is what grows the consciousness," Mr. Celeste said. "And if you are lucky to learn from it, you change your way of thinking."
Anecdotal evidence that the collective mindset is changing in California abounds. In the last three months, sales have doubled at Real Goods, a company in the Northern California town of Hopland specializing in solar and energy-saving products, a spokeswoman, Rose Bell, said.
The company is selling out of fluorescent bulbs and radiant barriers, foil insulation that reduces the energy cost of air-conditioning, Ms. Bell said. 
It is also selling more of what are called utility intertie systems -- devices that use solar energy when the sun is shining, and use energy from the power grid at other times. And attendance at the company's workshops in solar power has tripled since the crisis began.
Cheryl Long, editor of the Mother Earth News, the journal based in Topeka, Kan., that is the bible for the alternative energy self-help set, sees a similar trend. She said that people have been seeking out the publication's Web site for information about "alternative energy, how to build a wind generator at home, how to get off the grid, et cetera."
Solar-energy system installers say the crisis has proven a big boon. Anoosh Mizany, who owns the Solar Depot in Marin City, just across the Golden Gate Bridge from San Francisco, said that his business was up 30 percent over last year.
"The more Stage 2 and Stage 3 alerts and so on, the more calls we got," Mr. Mizany said. 
Appliance retailers gush about how quickly their big-ticket items -- top-of-the-line refrigerators, dishwashers, washers and dryers -- are leaving their warehouses; new appliances are vastly more energy efficient than models of 10 years ago.
When Gus Martinez, an appliance salesman at a Sears, Roebuck store in San Bruno, approaches a customer, "the first thing that comes out of their mouth is 'energy efficient,' " he said. "Not even size, or what features they're looking for. They say, 'I've got to get my PG&E bill down.' "
Advertisements for solar-panel suppliers are plastered all over the state's Sunday newspapers. While far less complicated and expensive than they were 30 years ago, though, solar energy systems can be pricey.
The Jorgensens paid $13,000 for their solar intertie system, though with rebates, they said, the cost was less than $6,000. They said their system was more complicated and costly than many people would buy because they added a backup battery.
The Jorgensens also said that many systems would pay for themselves faster than they estimated theirs would because they had always been stingy about using energy. "The more power you've spent, the faster the systems pay for themselves," Mr. Jorgensen said.
Lance Drill, a freelance photographer who lives in a tiny studio apartment on the top floor of an aging five-story building in San Francisco, made his system simple. Mr. Drill bought a portable generator and a solar panel over the Internet for $400.
Showing off his system, Mr. Drill hooked the solar panel on the roof to the generator with a power cord that runs from the roof down the front of the building and through his window.
He said he expected to receive rebates on the generator and solar panel worth almost half his cost.
Mr. Drill said he expected his bills, about $80 a month, to drop considerably. A new state program is to reward customers who cut their summer energy use by 20 percent from the comparable period last year with a 20 percent rebate on their electric bills for the summer.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Eric Jorgensen converted his house in San Jose, Calif., to solar and wind power in October to conserve energy and reduce his electricity bills. "California has so much sun that it's silly everyone isn't doing this," he said. (Darcy Padilla for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
Some big decisions on the Treasury market are in the wings.

BYLINE:  By Jonathan Fuerbringer 

 BODY:
THOMAS JUTERBOCK, head of global government bond trading at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company, says there have been few disruptions in fixed-income markets as a result of the shrinking Treasury market and the decline in new issues of notes and bonds. 
 But, he said: "I don't think this is sustainable. Over time, we are going to get more distortions." 
 This is why the Treasury Department under the Bush administration will have to make some important decisions about the future of the Treasury market by November. In that period -- which includes the three quarterly Treasury auctions in May, August and November -- the Treasury is going to have to give a clear indication of what it wants to do with the government bond market. It can let this market fade away in the most organized and least disruptive way possible. Or it can do its best to keep the market alive. 
Because of large budget surpluses, the government is expected to have no real need to borrow in a few years. And if the government ceases to issue bonds and notes, the Treasury market would lose its role as a benchmark for interest rates, a haven for worried investors and a tool in many of Wall Street's regular financial transactions.
Until recently, the betting was that the Treasury market would fade away as long as surpluses remained robust and the economy did not fall into a steep decline. This view held sway because Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, has opposed any plan to keep the Treasury market alive by continuing to issue unneeded notes and bonds. This, Mr. Greenspan argued, would leave the government with surpluses that it could invest in stocks or bonds, and he is opposed to that because he says those decisions would be politicized.
Mr. Greenspan has also argued that allowing the Treasury market to die would present no problems because reviving it would be easy. Budget deficits are expected to return in the late 2020's, when the baby-boom retirees begin to strain the Social Security and Medicare systems. But the market could be at its crossroads in just a few years, and preparations for what happens then have to be made in advance.
The Treasury secretary, Paul O'Neill, changed the debate when he said the Treasury was actively considering keeping the Treasury market open. In a speech last month, he said the government could keep the Treasury market alive by issuing new debt even when it was no longer necessary and giving the proceeds back to the public as tax cuts.
"All things being equal, it is not a bad idea to try to figure out if there is a way to prolong the life of the Treasury bond market," said Lewis A. Sachs, an assistant treasury secretary in the Clinton administration responsible for debt management.
And many people on Wall Street agree. The Bond Market Association is pressing for the continued sales of the 30-year bond. As Mr. Greenspan noted in a speech to the association last Friday, "The Treasury market serves a number of useful purposes -- in addition to providing many of you with profitable employment."
Mr. Sachs said, however, that "it is not clear that the benefits of prolonging the life of the Treasury market would outweigh the substantial costs" -- namely, the interest that the government would have to pay on the notes and bonds it sells.
Mr. O'Neill has yet to give any details of such a proposal and said he had made no decision yet on the Treasury market's future.
The Treasury announced yesterday morning, when it released the details for this month's auction of 5- and 10-year Treasury notes, that it would introduce a four-week bill before the end of September. The new bill is part of an effort to better manage cash flow now that the Treasury has reduced the amount of debt it is issuing. The Treasury also said it expected to retire a total of $252 billion in debt during the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, up from $213 billion in the previous fiscal year and $100 billion in fiscal year 1999.
But the Treasury gave no indication of its thinking on the future of the Treasury market. Peter Fisher has been nominated as the new under secretary for domestic finance and will be the top adviser on whether to maintain the Treasury market. But he has not been confirmed.
So the first significant insight into what the new Treasury will do may not come until the announcement of its auctions for August. And what happens then to the 30-year bond, whose issuance has already been whittled down sharply, could confirm the Treasury's intentions.

HEADLINE: Cigna Warns on Profits, and H.M.O. Stocks Take a Tumble 

BYLINE:  By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
The Cigna Corporation, one of the strongest managed care companies, said yesterday that profits would be lower than expected this year, blaming weaker earnings from pension and retirement accounts that it manages for large employers. Analysts, however, were particularly concerned by an unexpected increase in Cigna's medical costs. 
 Cigna's announcement touched off a selling wave that drove down Cigna shares and other H.M.O. stocks. And it followed a warning three weeks ago by Aetna Inc., the largest health insurer, which said on April 10 that its first-quarter earnings would be lower than expected because of sharply rising medical costs. Analysts had discounted the Aetna warning somewhat, believing it was a special case tied to Aetna's problems with overly rapid expansion and friction with doctors. 
 "Almost every health care company expects cost increases of 10 to 13 percent," said Kenneth S. Abramowitz, managing director of the Carlyle Fund, an investor in privately held health care companies. "But when well-managed Cigna announces that they were behind the curve in setting prices to cover rising costs, that's a surprise."
Shares of Cigna, the nation's third-largest health insurer, fell $15.85, or almost 15 percent, to $92.85 yesterday. Wellpoint Health Networks, also a favorite with investors in managed care, lost $5.24, or 5 percent, to $94.55. The United Health Group was down $2.96, to $63.20, and Oxford Health Plans dropped $1.57, to $29.93.
Cigna, based in Philadelphia, said medical costs charged by hospitals and doctors rose 11 percent in the first quarter, topping the estimate it had made 90 days ago of an 8 percent to 9 percent increase. Cigna expects these costs to rise 10 percent to 11 percent over the entire year.
Some analysts were skeptical that insurance companies would be able to keep raising prices to cover growing medical costs if employers were cutting costs as the economy slows. "There is no way that corporate America is going to accept 12 percent health care increases," said Larry Feinberg, a managing partner of Oracle Partners, a health care hedge fund. 
But Lori M. Price, an analyst at J. P. Morgan, said insurers could trim premium increases by offering more restrictive benefits, for example cutting back on covering workers' families, and by increasing employees' out-of-pocket payments for drugs and doctor visits.
Edward Hanway, chief executive of Cigna, said health care membership growth this year was short of the company's expectations. Cigna covered 14.3 million people on March 31, up 1.9 percent from March 2000 but 11,000 fewer than on Dec. 31.
The company said in a conference call with investors that earnings for 2001 would be $7.25 to $7.45 a share, 10 cents below its earlier guidance. The average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/ First Call had been $7.56. Cigna earned $6.85 a share in 2000.
Roberta Goodman, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, said she had expected growth in health care income, which is about three-quarters of Cigna's operating income, to offset the drop from retirement. That did not happen.
Cigna did meet the expectations of analysts for first-quarter earnings. Operating income rose 3 percent, to $272 million, in the quarter, excluding a one-time gain on the sale of a Japanese life insurance unit. Operating income was $265 million in the 2000 first quarter, or $1.57 a share. Earnings per share increased 12 percent because the company repurchased 15.5 million shares over the last year. 
The company said lower stock market prices cut into its management fees as the value of retirement accounts last March 31 dropped $5.2 billion, or 9 percent, to $52.2 billion, compared with $57.4 billion on March 31, 2000. 
Cigna has a reputation for keeping investor expectations down by making conservative earnings estimates. Continuing that practice, the company assumed that the overall stock market would stay flat for the rest of the year, said James A. Lane, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney. 
The company's main customers are large employers with workers spread across the country. As a result, Mr. Lane said, Cigna has less ability than local insurers to keep costs down by leaning on hospitals and doctors for lower charges in some geographical areas.

HEADLINE: Ford's 70-Year Itch Could Be Relieved; 
As G.M. Stumbles, Its Perch at the Top Is Within Reach

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 2 

 BODY:
The last time Ford Motor was the world's biggest automaker was 1930, when Henry Ford, the founder, was still in charge, the Model A had finally replaced the Model T and Margaret Mitchell was still writing "Gone With the Wind."
 General Motors -- led by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., who organized a half-dozen separate car lines under one corporate umbrella and introduced the concept of the annual model change -- surpassed Ford the following year. It remained the nation's largest company, and at times, the world's largest, through most of the rest of the 20th century. 
 But now, to the amazement of many in Motor City, Ford seems increasingly likely to take from G.M. the top spot in the auto industry. Ford came within half a day's sales of passing G.M. in total revenue in the first quarter. And Ford actually surpassed G.M. in automotive revenue, although this was partly because G.M. cut production more deeply than Ford in response to the slowing economy. Many people in the industry expect Ford to edge ahead of G.M. in total revenue and automotive revenue within two or three years. 
The short-term reasons G.M.'s lead is likely to evaporate are simple. G.M. is phasing out its Oldsmobile division and is trying to sell its Hughes Electronics subsidiary or spin it off to shareholders as a separate company.And Ford will pick up additional sales from its acquisition of Land Rover.
But G.M.'s lost mastery has much deeper roots: an inability to respond to market trends quickly. G.M. missed the growth of the small-car market in the late 1970's and early 1980's, the move to more aerodynamic midsize cars in the late 1980's and the rise of sport utility vehicles based on pickup truck designs in the 1990's. And now it is stumbling in its response to the popularity of sport utilities based on car designs.
For most people in the auto industry, the question is no longer if Ford will overtake G.M., but when. "Their market share is going to continue to decline," said Chris Cedergren, the managing director of Nextrend Inc., an automotive consulting company. "The new generation can't relate to G.M. brands."
G.M. executives say that although their share of the United States market has been falling for 22 years, the trend is about to reverse itself. They are pinning their hopes on expanded production of full-size pickup trucks and sport utilities based on pickup designs, and on sport utilities based on car designs that Saturn, Buick and Pontiac will introduce this year and next.
The executives are nonetheless surprised to find Ford so close behind and gaining fast. "Most of us didn't anticipate we'd see this, but we have to be careful -- we don't expect these trends will continue," said Paul Ballew, G.M.'s executive director of market analysis, whose grandfather was making factory tools in a Chrysler plant here the last time Ford was ahead.
The most recent setback for G.M. has been in its initial effort to tap into the market for sport utilities based on car designs, like Honda Motor's Honda CR-V and Toyota Motor's Lexus RX 300 and Toyota Highlander. The car-based models offer a smoother ride and better fuel economy than traditional sport utilities. They are also less likely than pickup-based models to inflict major damage on cars during collisions, and they typically emit less of the gases linked to smog and global warming.
Sales of sport utilities based on car designs have tripled in the last year even as sales of sport utilities based on pickups have dropped 8.5 percent and the overall auto market has fallen 5.7 percent, according to Ward's Auto Info Bank, a market data service in Southfield, Mich.
G.M. and Ford jumped into the market for car-based sport utilities at almost the same time late last summer, with the Pontiac Aztek and the Ford Escape.
But the Aztek has been dubbed one of the ugliest automobiles in years by many auto reviewers, and has sold so poorly that G.M. has ordered hundreds of its engineers to start borrowing them from the company fleet so that at least some Aztek would be seen on Detroit roads.
The Escape is now the best-selling vehicle in the segment by a wide margin, and outsold the Aztek in April by 14,025 to 2,394. 
G.M. also missed the boom in pickup-based sport utilities in the 1990's, particularly full-size models, even though it had been making them longer than any other company, beginning in April 1935 with the Chevrolet Carryall Suburban. When Ford introduced the Expedition in 1996, it swiftly raised production to meet soaring demand. Its Expedition factory in Wayne, Mich., quickly generated more in overall profits than any factory in any industry, reaching an estimated $3.7 billion in pretax profits by 1998.
Only in the last year, as high gasoline prices, foreign competition and declining consumer interest have begun eroding the profitability of the market segment, has G.M. finally stepped up production significantly.
Ford led the move to aerodynamic styling in midsize cars in 1986 with the Taurus, which has been one of the nation's best-selling cars ever since. In the late 1970's and early 1980's, Ford paid more attention to attractive designs than G.M., which became so distracted with meeting new safety, emissions and fuel-economy regulations that it produced too many look-alike cars.
During the two recessions of the early 1980's, some questioned whether Ford could even survive. But because Ford came much closer to the brink of financial collapse then than G.M., the United Automobile Workers union let it lay off or push into retirement tens of thousands of workers, and allowed some restrictive work rules to be rewritten. G.M. was not as aggressive then in cutting its work force, and is only now coming close to matching Ford in factory productivity.
The decline of G.M. is the fading not just of an automotive giant but of a national institution that once wielded enormous influence. In 1928, when G.M.'s profits and market share were already soaring, there was a huge controversy when John Raskob, the chairman of the finance committee of G.M. board, was elected chairman of the National Democratic Committee and promptly moved its offices into the General Motors Building in New York. In the 1930's, G.M. bought up much of the nation's aircraft manufacturing and airline industries, as well as a big bank, although it has long since sold those investments.
G.M.'s vast corporate reach gave rise to the myth that one of its presidents, Charles E. Wilson, said in 1953 that "what's good for General Motors is good for the country." Mr. Wilson's actual words to a Senate committee, after he was nominated by President Dwight D. Eisenhower to become defense secretary, were somewhat different.
Asked by a senator if he could make a decision adverse to G.M.'s interests, Mr. Wilson replied, "I cannot conceive of one because for years I thought that what was good for our country was good for General Motors, and vice versa."
"Our company is too big, it goes with the welfare of the country," he added.
That dominance has gone the way of poodle skirts and outdoor waitresses on roller skates. Because of G.M.'s poor sense of the market, its share of auto sales in the United States has slumped to just 28 percent from 48 percent in 1978.
Ford has stayed remarkably steady at 23 percent, although partly by investing its profits over the last decade in the outright purchase of Jaguar, Aston Martin, Volvo and Land Rover. This has also raised the average price of Ford's vehicles, increasing total revenue. G.M. has instead purchased minority stakes in Fiat Auto and Fuji Heavy Industries, which makes Subarus, and has increased its minority stakes in Isuzu Motors and Suzuki Motor, but these companies remain independent and G.M. does not count them in its own sales.
Ford has surpassed G.M. on other criteria, like operating earnings and market capitalization. But in terms of revenue, Ford finished last year with $170.1 billion to G.M.'s $184.6 billion. That gap is closing and Ford will take the lead within the next several years unless G.M. makes a big acquisition or finally stabilizes its market share.
Last summer, Ford bought Land Rover, which has about $6 billion in annual sales, but only Land Rover's sales from July through December were included in last year's results. At the same time, G.M. plans to phase out its unprofitable Oldsmobile division, with $8 billion in sales, over the next several years. G.M. hopes to hold on to all of these revenues, said Darwin Clark, G.M.'s vice president for dealer relations.
But auto consultants say that G.M. will lose at least half of Oldsmobile's customers to rivals, so the loss of Oldsmobile could shave perhaps $4 billion from G.M.'s lead. Finally, G.M.'s board approved further talks with the News Corporation to dispose of Hughes Electronics, which had $8.7 billion in revenue last year. Add up these changes and it equals more than enough to wipe out the sales gap with Ford, even without further market-share deterioration by G.M.
Ford will not catch G.M. in overall sales this year, acknowledged Henry D. G. Wallace, Ford's chief financial officer. Like G.M. executives, Mr. Wallace contended that his priority was profits, not sales.
"With virtually the same revenues, our profitability was four times what theirs was," in the first quarter, Mr. Wallace said, keeping up the old Detroit tradition of chiding rival manufacturers.
Many in Detroit attribute G.M.'s persistent slowness in coming up with attractive car designs to a corporate culture in which executives are rotated from job to job without ever being punished for failure. By contrast, Ford has had a long history of pushing out unsuccessful managers as part of an often ruthless corporate culture.
G.M. executives acknowledge the criticism and say that changing the company's bureaucratic mind-set has been a top priority in recent years. "I don't think we can get done what we have to get done at this company without continued cultural change," said John Devine, G.M.'s vice chairman and chief financial officer and a former chief financial officer of Ford. 
But few doubt that G.M. has a long way to go. "I don't think the G.M. people consider themselves to be a business," said Gerald Meyers, a former chairman of American Motors who remains active in the auto industry as a consultant. "Every G.M. executive I've met has considered himself as part of an institution."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
CHEMICAL COMPANY TO LAY OFF UP TO 1,260 PEOPLE

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 The Rohm & Haas Company said yesterday that it would lay off as many as 1,260 employees to cut costs and make the company, which produces specialty chemicals, more competitive. 
Rohm & Haas, which makes additives for paints and owns Morton Salt, said the job cuts would save at least $200 million by the end of 2002. Some of the job reductions will be tied to plant closings in California and Mississippi, said a spokeswoman, Laura Hadden. The company, based in Philadelphia, which also makes chemicals used in electronics, has been hurt by declining sales as the economy has slowed.

HEADLINE: Poetry and Lyrics From One Deep Well; 
Paul McCartney Publishes His First Book of Verse

BYLINE:  By SARAH LYALL 

 BODY:
Some years ago, Paul McCartney, famous musician and fledgling poet, took a deep breath and showed a selection of his poetic works in progress to his old friend Allen Ginsberg.
 Ginsberg, who was visiting Mr. McCartney at his house in Sussex, England, had some thoughts. "He was all for economy," Sir Paul, as he has been known the last few years, said recently in his friendly Liverpudlian lilt, recalling his frisson of fear when Ginsberg took out his pencil and began cutting and tweaking. "He said to me: 'Never use the word "the." And also try to avoid "ing" -- don't use "singing," but use "sing" instead.' " 
 When Ginsberg suggested he change a poem beginning "Two doors open on the 18th of June" to "Two doors open. June 18," the lyricist put his foot down. "I said it's great, but you're making me into a New York Beat poet," said Sir Paul, who kept a copy of the scribbled-over "Ginsberg Variations," as he calls them, for posterity, though he took none of Ginsberg's suggestions. 
Sir Paul is so used to having critical control that he submits to editing only reluctantly. "Sometimes I've made small suggestions for cuts or changes, and sometimes Paul's accepted them," writes his editor in Britain, the poet Adrian Mitchell, in the preface to Sir Paul's first book of poetry, "Blackbird Singing," which has just been published in the United States by W. W. Norton. And so the poems in the book are very much his own, expressing his familiar obsessions with love and loss and life's vicissitudes in language that is generally simple and direct. 
In the flesh for an interview at his office in New York, he could not help appearing startlingly familiar, as if he were a cousin who just happened to be really famous. While the other surviving Beatles seem to have grown sharper and craggier, Sir Paul, 58, has softened. His face is still boyish and open, albeit creased with minor wrinkles. Discussing his poems while sitting on an immaculate black couch across from a de Kooning painting, he was dressed in a T-shirt, plaid pants and the sort of clogs that a hipster surgeon might wear on hospital rounds.
He is a canny manager of his empire and career, whose net worth, according to The Sunday Times of London, stands at more than $1 billion. In 1997 he was knighted by Queen Elizabeth, which made him officially Sir Paul. But it is as strange to think of him that way as it is to think of the rock star Bob Geldof -- a knight as well, and far scruffier than the always clean and shiny Paul McCartney -- as Sir Bob.
One of the striking things about "Blackbird Singing" is the bold inclusion of some 50 of the former Beatle's lyrics among more than 40 poems, a decision that cannot help but raise the old question about whether lyrics stand as poetry in their own right. Sir Paul is not so sure, though he was cheered when Ginsberg told him, long ago, that " 'Eleanor Rigby' is one hell of a poem." (Its lyrics appear in the book, along with those of "Hey Jude" and "Maxwell's Silver Hammer," among others.) 
Though they emanate from the same impulse, poems and songs come to him in very different ways, Sir Paul explained, mostly having to do with whether he has a musical instrument on hand. 
With songs he generally works through the lyrics and melody simultaneously, he said, illustrating his point by re-enacting on an imaginary piano how he hashed out the beginning of "Eleanor Rigby." 
"I was sitting at the piano vamping on the E minor chord," he said. He sang some of the notes, then began: "Da da da da da -- Eleanor Rigby picks up the rice . . . And in actual fact, it wasn't Eleanor Rigby, it was something else, because I got the name Eleanor Rigby later. Sometimes the real words arrive, and sometimes I have to kind of go back and fix it." 
"It's like 'Yesterday,' " he continued, starting to sing again. "At first it was 'Scrambled eggs/ Oh my baby how I love your legs,' which I thought, 'That's gotta be fixed. Can't go with that one.' " Similarly, he said, "Hey Jude," written for John Lennon's son Julian when his parents split up, was originally called "Hey Jules" until he decided that Jude was crisper. 
In poems, he said, the language tends to come and stay put. He wrote "Jerk of All Jerks," for instance, after being immersed, along with the rest of the world, in the news coverage of Lennon's murder in 1980. "The one phrase that came to my mind was that the guy who did it was the jerk of all jerks," Sir Paul said. 
The only other explicit reference to Lennon in the book comes in the lyrics to "Here Today," from 1982. It is an affectionate song, alluding to his and Lennon's mismatched temperaments and to Lennon's spikiness, but also to their underlying love. The two put aside their differences before Lennon died. "We had been arguing about stupid stuff -- money and things, things that weren't really important in our relationship but were the kind of things people argue about," Sir Paul said. But then they began to talk again. "We talked about him baking bread, him putting the cats out, him padding around the apartment in his robe and slippers, him bringing up his baby, Sean," he recalled. "It was really intimate and mature, good real talk between friends." 
In a way, Lennon's ghost -- the ghost of what might have been -- haunts the book, as does the spirit of Sir Paul's wife, Linda, who died of breast cancer in 1998 and who inspired some of his sweetest love poems and songs.
In 29 years of marriage, Mr. McCartney never spent a night apart from his wife except when he was in a Tokyo jail on drug charges in 1980, and he spent the year after her death in nearly constant grief, he said. He now has a girlfriend, Heather Mills, 33, a feisty former model whose leg was severed in an accident and who campaigns for land mine reform.
As he discussed his wife's death and his new life, his volubility fled for a moment, and he jumped up to adjust a chair on the other side of the room that was not sitting perfectly in line with the carpet. "It was perhaps unlikely in my life that I would have two strong women who I felt so strongly about," he said carefully. "Even though it's early days in my new relationship, I do feel lucky to have met someone strong and interesting and beautiful."
"Blackbird Singing" has been a best seller in Britain, but the critical reaction has been mixed, as always happens when Sir Paul embarks on a new venture. Some critics were delighted: "Unlike more rarefied poets, who communicate mostly with each other in obscure crannies of our culture, McCartney writes as freely (and often as beautifully) as a blackbird sings," Stephen Logan wrote in The Sunday Times of London.
But others have made it clear that they think his talents are strictly musical. "They're not bad so much as unfinished and inconsequential," Mark Hertsgaard wrote of the poems in The Los Angeles Times. 
The new poet tries not to care. "It's not as if I'm not used to it," he said. " 'She Loves You' was called banal when it came out -- it was the first time I had ever heard the word." And a review in The New York Times, he said, judged "Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band" "a very bad album," in Sir Paul's words. "But," he said, "I just get on with it." 
And, judging from Mr. McCartney's two poetry readings, one in Liverpool and the other at the 92nd Street Y in Manhattan, he is in no danger of losing his extraordinary appeal. Charming the onlookers out of their seats with engaging anecdotes, he ended both readings with rousing audience-participation recitations of "Why Don't We Do It in the Road?," included partly as a retort to critics who said some of his lyrics would not stand up to the rigors of being read aloud. 
In Liverpool he kept his cool even amid the most frenzied of fans. Swept up in a crowd of more than 1,000, he was greeted by a teenage girl who wore a vintage Beatlemania button that said "I slept with Paul McCartney."
"Oh, really," said Mr. McCartney, flashing a huge grin, "When was that?"

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
Next Mayor Will Inherit Hard Times

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
MYSTIFYING. A crowd of at least a half-dozen is fighting it out to be the next mayor of New York, a job that, objectively speaking, nobody should want. It's abundantly clear that Rudolph W. Giuliani's reputation as dragon-slayer will torment his successor. No way out of that one. But beyond that, the next few years are shaping up as dauntingly rocky for the city's 108th mayor.
 For one thing, Mr. Giuliani, indulging in a bit of apres moi-ism, is poised to leave the next guy with some heavy lifting. For another, there are growing indications of troubled times ahead because of factors no mayor can control. In fact, those factors control mayors, starting with the economy. 
 It is slowing. "The city's economy is going from being boomlike to moderately expanding to flat, all in the course of little more than a year," said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Economy.com, a consulting firm in West Chester, Pa. "I think we are going to see much more significant layoffs and lost incomes in coming months, and that's going to take down the city's economy another notch."
In the last year, revenue from real estate transaction taxes and from estimates on the personal income tax have slowed, data from the comptroller's office show. Businesses from advertising to tourism are cooling off, and investment banking and brokerage companies on Wall Street are expected to follow suit soon.
Mr. Giuliani's new budget plan projects a large budget gap, and fiscal experts expect that the budget surplus, which the city traditionally uses to help close the gap, will be smaller than in recent years.
So it seems more than likely that to pay the bills, the next mayor will have to make some unpopular decisions, especially since Mr. Giuliani wants over $500 million in tax cuts, which will probably win approval in some form from the City Council, since Speaker Peter F. Vallone is running for mayor.
The mayor contends that lower taxes have stimulated and will continue to stimulate the economy. "At the same time, he's making it harder for the next administration and the next Council to balance the budget if the economy doesn't strengthen soon," said Ronnie Lowenstein, director of the city's Independent Budget Office.
To complicate matters, a good hunk of next year's costs are unknown. Most municipal employees are working under expired contracts, and some, including the police and teachers' unions, may not settle until Mr. Giuliani leaves office. That means the next mayor gets the chore of handling negotiations, saddled with limited resources in this mayor's budget.
The same for two other big-ticket items: maintaining an expanded police force and dealing with impending changes in federal financing of welfare. Key to the crime reduction has been a very large police force, which has grown to 40,710 uniformed officers from 32,000 in 1989, before Mayor David N. Dinkins and the Council began an expansion that Mr. Giuliani continued.
When the economy was booming, the city could afford the large force, including the 4,000 police officers hired since 1996 under federal crime legislation and partly financed by Washington.
By next year all but 500 of those officers will have to be paid with city funds at a cost of $200 million, not counting wage increases. 
THE next mayor clearly cannot afford, politically, to shrink the force; he'll have to find a way to compensate for the missing federal money. The same could be true of federal welfare dollars.
The city and state stand to lose a bundle -- and not just for welfare -- unless Washington reauthorizes the welfare overhaul act of 1996 by September 2002. The state welfare population is about half what it was five years ago, but Washington sends the same amount of money to New York State now as it did then, which translates into a $1.7 billion annual surplus.
The city uses about $470 million of that money for child care, employment training and other services for welfare recipients. Albany spends its share of the surplus on costs both related to and unrelated to welfare, ranging from mass transit and education to covering the cost of tax cuts. If Congress reduces the welfare authorization, the city and state will be scrambling to pay for those programs.
These headaches and more will greet the next mayor. He will have a chance to preside over what could be the lean years after all those fat ones, and probably to dead-end his career, because we all know mayors of New York City never get anywhere beyond the five boroughs.
Now we really know why.

HEADLINE: DEAL IS REACHED ON U.S. SPENDING 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON and DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2 

 BODY:
A day after agreeing to cut taxes by $1.35 trillion over the next 11 years, the White House and Congressional negotiators settled today on a spending increase for next year greater than what President Bush had sought but less than what most Democrats said was needed to pay for domestic programs and the military.
 The deal was criticized by Democratic leaders on Capitol Hill but won the support of a handful of moderate Democrats whose votes the administration needs to get the measure through the evenly divided Senate. 
 The agreement, the final major piece of the first budget of Mr. Bush's presidency, called for an increase in spending of slightly less than 5 percent on programs whose budgets are set by Congress each year, including the Pentagon and most domestic initiatives outside of Social Security and Medicare. 
Mr. Bush had sought to limit the increase in these programs to 4 percent next year after an increase of 8.5 percent in the current fiscal year and amid a growing sense, especially among conservatives, that budget discipline was breaking down in an era of expanding budget surpluses. The initial plan passed by the Senate last month would have increased spending by more than 8 percent.
The increases would bring spending on the programs next year to $666.6 billion, up from $635.4 billion this year. Of that amount, $324.8 billion would go to the military and $341.8 billion to domestic programs. The total budget for the year, including Medicare, Social Security and interest payments on the national debt, would come to slightly less than $2 trillion.
Congressional aides were still working on the details late today as they rushed to have the measure ready for a vote in the House and probably the Senate on Thursday. But it appeared that the compromise stripped from the budget outline much of the increase in education spending that the Senate had originally supported. It retained plans for long-term increases in spending on agriculture, and provided up to $300 billion over the next decade for adding prescription drug coverage to Medicare.
"It's an agreement that makes a lot of sense," Mr. Bush said as he began a meeting at the White House with Republican leaders and several Democrats who supported the deal, including Senators John B. Breaux of Louisiana and Ben Nelson of Nebraska.
The deal on spending for next year came a day after negotiators had agreed that the budget plan would call for a tax cut of $1.25 trillion over the next decade, plus $100 billion in immediate tax cuts in this calendar year to give a boost to the flagging economy. Mr. Bush had sought a tax cut of $1.6 trillion.
In a sign that Republicans are likely to push for tax cuts beyond those included in the spending plan, the House today passed legislation that would expand the 401(k) and individual retirement account programs. By exempting higher levels of retirement savings from taxation, the bill would reduce federal revenues by $52 billion over the next 10 years.
The bill would gradually raise the maximum contribution by employees to 401(k) accounts to $15,000 in 2006, from the current level of $10,500. It would also gradually raise the maximum contribution to individual retirement accounts to $5,000 in 2004, from $2,000 currently. It would also make it easier for employees to keep their pensions when they change jobs.
The broad bipartisan support for the bill -- it passed 407 to 24 -- led some Republicans to predict that it could also pass the Senate even if it was not in the $1.25 trillion tax-cut package that the Senate Finance Committee plans to draw up next week.
The president held up the budget agreement today as evidence that he can build bipartisan coalitions to back his agenda, saying the deal was the result of hard work by members of Congress "who realized that what we're talking about is not partisan politics, but good budget politics, good budget policy."
But the deal had much to do with the complicated politics of Congress, especially the Senate, where Democrats and Republicans each hold 50 seats and shifting alliances are shaping legislation case by case. 
In this instance, the negotiators had to patch together an agreement that would keep at least a few moderate Democrats on board in the Senate without alienating conservative Republicans in the House.
In addition to Mr. Breaux and Mr. Nelson, two other Democratic senators, Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey and Zell Miller of Georgia, signaled their support for the compromise by attending today's meeting at the White House. Two Democrats from the House, Representatives Gary A. Condit of California and Ken Lucas of Kentucky, also attended, along with the Republican leaders of both chambers.
But Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader in the Senate, said that the spending level was unrealistic. 
Mr. Daschle said there would not be room for increases in spending that have bipartisan support, like for education, much less for expensive initiatives that are sure to be fought over in Congress, including Mr. Bush's call for a national missile defense, whose price tag remains unknown. The $300 billion budgeted for prescription drug coverage for retirees is widely considered to be less than what the program will ultimately cost.
After completing a review of the nation's military posture in the next few weeks, the Pentagon is expected to seek hundreds of billions of dollars over the next decade in spending beyond what the current budget contemplates. 
The dispute over spending is not entirely partisan. Republicans on the appropriations committees, which set the spending levels for each program, have already signaled that the overall increase of less than 5 percent is not enough to pass the spending bills this year.
In any case, the spending levels set in the budget plan that Congress is working on are nonbinding, and have been routinely breached in recent years by the time the appropriators have finished their work. Republicans said they would try to avoid doing so again this year, noting that Mr. Bush could veto appropriations bills that get too big, but even they did not sound totally convinced.
"There will be much more pressure this year to stay within the numbers, and there's a chance that will happen," said Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee.

HEADLINE: Top Democrats Warn of Battle On Missile Plan 

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2 

 BODY:
Senate Democrats put forward some of their most influential voices on national security policy today and made clear that President Bush's plans for an expansive missile defense system could well become a defining point of contention between the two parties.
 Just a day after Mr. Bush outlined a sweeping new security strategy, the Democrats raised sharp questions about his plan, bringing up issues of arms control, diplomacy, military strategy and the budgetary implications of an interwoven antimissile shield based on land, at sea, in the air and in space. 
 They said they would consider it a grave mistake for President Bush to abandon the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, which its defenders say has been the cornerstone of nuclear deterrence, and warned that unilateral deployment of a robust missile defense system could leave the nation less secure by sparking a new arms race. 
Standing alongside the ranking Democrats on the Armed Services and Foreign Relations Committees, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, said Mr. Bush had begun "one of the most important and consequential debates we will see in our lifetime."
Mr. Daschle questioned whether a missile defense was technologically feasible and said, "A missile defense system that undermines our nation politically, economically and strategically -- without providing any real security -- is no defense at all."
Senator Carl Levin of Michigan, the ranking Democrat on the Armed Services Committee, charged that the president's speech amounted to a unilateral decision "wrapped in conciliatory rhetoric." 
Raising the possibility that Russia might stop dismantling its nuclear arsenal, he said, "I have great concerns about a unilateral decision, because I believe that it could risk a second cold war -- Cold War II, I call it."
Mr. Bush has described only his vision for missile defense and has proposed no specific weapons systems or budget figure, and so "the devil is in the details," said Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, the ranking Democrat on the Foreign Relations Committee. 
If the United States deployed a system that could strike down most missiles from North Korea, but which caused Russia and China to start a new arms race, "would America be more protected or less protected?" he asked.
The Democrats conceded that while the Senate approves treaties, it does not have the power to stop the president from withdrawing the United States from the ABM treaty. But they could try to exert leverage through the annual bills providing money for Pentagon programs.
Mr. Levin said Democrats in the Senate would "try in some way to stop the expenditure of funds for a system that would abrogate the ABM treaty." But in a Senate split 50-50 with Vice President Dick Cheney holding the deciding vote, that could prove difficult.
The statements marked a new aggressiveness by Democrats on missile defense, a favorite issue of conservatives, and one that Democrats sought to blunt under the lead of President Bill Clinton.
One Democratic strategist on Capitol Hill said the party now felt freed from having to follow policies adopted under Mr. Clinton, and he called the brewing dispute over missile defense both a matter of policy and politics. 
He said that just as missile defense energized the Republicans' conservative base, Democratic loyalists and primary voters were strongly opposed to an expensive and unproven missile defense system. Several Senate Democrats are eyeing a presidential run in 2004.
Just two years ago, after Mr. Clinton dropped his longstanding veto threat, the Senate, by a vote of 97 to 3, overwhelmingly approved legislation to field a system to defend the country against limited attack from long-range missiles. 
All but three Democrats agreed to the measure after working out a compromise that they said ensured that any antimissile system would not interfere with arms control negotiations with Russia and that Congress would still have to authorize missile defense funds annually.
That turnaround was driven both new policy considerations in a post-cold-war world and by domestic politics. It came after a bipartisan commission headed by Donald H. Rumsfeld -- now Mr. Bush's defense secretary -- warned that within five years North Korea and Iran could have the potential to hit the United States with a ballistic missile. Democrats were also aware that going into the presidential election, Republicans were accusing them of a failed foreign policy and a weak military program.
Mr. Biden acknowledged that when he voted to make it United States policy to field a system against ballistic missile threats from so-called rogue nations in 1999, he did not think there was "any immediacy to it." 
Mr. Levin also said that in that vote, Democrats had agreed to field such a system only "when technically feasible" and only after reasserting their commitment to negotiate further arms reductions with Russia.
The Democrats conceded that they did not yet know many of the fundamentals of what Mr. Bush was proposing. In his speech on Tuesday he all but declared the ABM treaty dead and vowed to replace it with a new "framework." But he never said what that framework would be.
Some of the same themes were struck by other Democrats throughout the day. Senator Dick Durbin, an Illinois Democrat, said that "it would be folly to abandon the ABM treaty" before the Pentagon was close to developing a missile defense system that could work.
On the Senate floor, Senator John F. Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat, said that "missile defense is only a response of last resort, when diplomacy and deterrence have failed." He added, "And given that no missile defense system will be 100 percent effective, we must not set aside the logic of deterrence that has kept us safe for 40 years."
Mr. Kerry called Mr. Bush's proposal to reduce American nuclear stockpiles unilaterally "an important and overdue first step toward reducing the nuclear danger." But he said Mr. Bush would have to persuade his fellow Republicans to go ahead with the cuts.

HEADLINE: Where Roads Can Do Harm 

BYLINE:  By Jim Lyons; Jim Lyons, a professor at the Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies, was under secretary of agriculture for natural resources and environment under Bill Clinton.

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN 

 BODY:
Tomorrow the Bush administration is expected to announce its plans for the fate of President Clinton's initiative to keep nearly 60 million acres of our national forests free of new roads. This so-called roadless rule, issued Jan. 5, is one of the most important environmental efforts of the Clinton administration.
 While President Bush might argue the need for additional scientific review as a basis for some of his recent environmental decisions -- postponing stricter limits for arsenic in water, for example -- it is difficult to make a case for a further review or delay of the roadless rule. The facts, which were debated and reviewed over three years, are indisputable. 
 Roadless areas are important sources of clean water for many Western cities. As habitats for threatened and endangered species, they are vital to our efforts to preserve and restore biological diversity. Under the Clinton rule, more than half of the 192 million acres of national forest would remain available for logging, mining or other activity. The rule would have limited economic impact, since the roadless areas would have provided less than half of 1 percent of the nation's timber. Existing oil and gas leases (which provide less than 1 percent of domestic production) would stay in place.
Those who argue that access to our national forests will be limited without new roads ignore the 386,000 miles of roads that already exist, most in disrepair. If there is to be additional expenditure on forest roads, priority ought to be given to better maintaining existing roads and bridges.
Playing on public fears, opponents also argue that banning new roads will put communities at greater risk from wildfire. But the roadless rule permits road building when there is imminent threat of fire and allows the harvesting of small trees to reduce that risk.
Unfortunately, a federal judge in Boise, Idaho, ruled last month that the three-year process under which the roadless rule was developed was inadequate, even though it drew 1.6 million public comments and involved 600 public meetings. The public overwhelmingly supported the strongest possible protections for roadless lands. The judge stopped short of issuing a final order against implementation of the rule, saying he would wait for the Bush administration to report on its vision for roadless areas. To date, the administration has offered no defense of the roadless rule and every indication that it will seek significant change in the policy.
A move away from protecting roadless lands could imperil the Forest Service's entire road program. In 1997 Congress, concerned with both environmental damage and the cost of roads, came close to eliminating the entire forest road budget. Only the Clinton administration's commitment to consider protections for roadless areas saved the program. Should road building into protected areas begin again, money for maintaining and improving the existing roads would likely come under renewed attack.
Any attempt by President Bush to eliminate or modify roadless protections is almost certain to reignite the wars between timber interests and environmentalists in his father's administration. Those conflicts, sparked by court injunctions against national forest timber sales, eventually led to the creation of President Clinton's Northwest Forest Plan. Limited resources would be better spent managing forests than on more litigation.
Protecting the nation's remaining roadless lands is a scientifically sound, popular and politically pragmatic policy. It should not be sacrificed to ideology when the benefits are so clear.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (J. D. King)
