HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.
* denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "ABCD: A COLLECTION OF ART BRUT," Museum of American Folk Art, 2 Lincoln Square, Columbus Avenue at 66th Street, Manhattan, (212) 977-7170 (through July). Memorably vivid and widely abused, the phrase Art Brut (literally meaning raw or rough art) was coined in the 1940's by the French artist Jean Dubuffet. This exhibition, drawn from the holdings of a Paris-based foundation, tries to reinstate his original meaning, revisiting the amazing pantheon of artists who inspired it and proposing some additions. Its many highlights include works by acknowledged greats like Adolf Wolfli, Aloise Corbaz, Henry Darger and Augustin Lesage, but the show also introduces many equally riveting artists unfamiliar to American audiences. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Free (Roberta Smith).

* "AFRICAN FORMS," Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 966-1313 (through Aug. 8). This show forgoes the figurative sculptures and masks that made African art a foundation of Western modernism to concentrate on supposedly humbler stuff, objects of physical adornment and daily use. With some 400 objects created by 156 ethnic groups, it proceeds in clusters of related carved wood neck rests, stools and boxes; ivory hairpins and snuff bottles; all kinds of jewelry; baskets and ceramic vessels; and spoons, weapons and musical instruments. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50, students and 65+ (Smith).

* "BITSTREAMS" AND "DATA DYNAMICS," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through June 10). Companion digital shows with a well-mannered, slightly dull air of decorous efficiency and cheerful modernity that encapsulates what you may regard as an ethos at large. Both affairs survey the new technological age in art, and there is no denying the inevitability of the big message here, which we discount at the risk of sheer stupidity: technology is changing how artists, especially young ones, make all types of art and, in turn, how we experience it. Still, the work produced needs to answer the old question: Does it move us? And there's the rub. A few artists, like Paul Pfeiffer and Jeremy Blake, stand out in "BitStreams." In "Data Dynamics," works like "Apartment" and "Netomat," metaphors for the Web as global unconscious, suggest that Internet art is at least becoming more like traditional media, whereby most but no longer all of what you see is unremarkable. Don't skip the sound section in "BitStreams," 25 audio artists working squarely in the tradition of musique concrete, a half-century-old movement but with new digital means replacing tape recorders. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays; Saturdays, Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $8, students and 62+ (Michael Kimmelman).

* "WILLIAM BLAKE," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through June 24). A touching and beautiful show if you have a taste for Blake's art, which strives for ecstatic revelation on the level of his famous visions and rises to the heights of his verse, sometimes. From the Age of Aquarius to New Age, he has come to serve as the patron saint of flower children, Jungians, Freudians, occultists, spiritualists, nudists, unpublished authors, animal lovers, socialists and teenagers of the sort who read Hermann Hesse. By turning our attention to his laborious illustrations and watercolors, the exhibition compels us to think about him as a serious and original visual artist, which is to say as a more idiosyncratic and substantial figure than the cliches suggest. He truly believed that the world was ending and that he had been sent to set things right at the last minute. Whatever else he may or may not have been, Blake was the most genuine and uncompromising artist you can think of. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

* LEANDRO ERLICH, "Neighbors," El Museo del Barrio, Fifth Avenue at 104th Street, (212) 831-7272 (through May 20). The first solo museum show by this young artist is a single, stagelike self-enclosed environment. The scene is a drab apartment building hallway lined with closed doors fitted with peepholes. An elevator opens at the push of a button, but leaves you peering down into an empty shaft. The results feel like a blend of Magritte, Hopper and Hitchcock: reality turns surreal; the everyday world is a forlorn, walk-in still life charged with voyeuristic tension. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $4; $2, students and 65+ (Holland Cotter).

* "ANDREAS GURSKY," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9400 (through May 15). The giant pictures in this midcareer retrospective of Mr. Gursky, the 46-year-old German photographer, are so eye-poppingly, drop-dead gorgeous that in this world, where no good turn goes unpunished, you may feel compelled to react with suspicion and reserve. But knee-jerk resistance at the sight of the nondescript global emblems of new capitalist sprawl that he photographs is short-circuited by sheer awe at the incredible, sublimely weird, almost erotic glamour he imparts to them. The work is instantly attractive to the point of alarm, which is the feeling of falling in love. You might as well give yourself over to it and worry about the consequences later. Hours: Thursdays through Tuesdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; until 8:15 p.m. on Fridays. Admission: $10; $6.50, students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

"HEADING WEST: MAPPING THE TERRITORY" AND "TOURING WEST: 19TH-CENTURY PERFORMING ARTISTS ON THE OREGON TRAIL," New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue at 42nd Street, (212) 869-8089. These exceptional and deftly dovetailed shows provide sobering insights into our corporate-driven, celebrity-crazed, racially tense times by revisiting the relentless westward push that formed the United States. "Heading West" (through May 19) deploys a cache of often extraordinary maps to trace the progress of explorers, mapmakers, settlers, railroad builders, gold diggers and the repeatedly deceived and displaced American Indians. "Touring West" (through July 7) uses all manner of theatrical emphemera, among much else, to show that where the new Americans went, intrepid entertainers of every ilk and several nationalities were never far behind. Hours: Mondays, and Thursdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Tuesdays and Wednesdays, 11 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Free (Smith).

* PAUL McCARTHY, New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through May 13). From his far-out position where the psychic security of Hollywood's packaging of sex and violence doesn't exist, Mr. McCarthy taps veins deep in the collective subconscious, well beyond where most shock artists have the audacity or intelligence to operate. He has been a cultish presence in Los Angeles for years, and his moment has finally come in New York. We see an artist of wild highs and lows, of black comedy, cheap jokes, unspeakable actions, dry formalism and some real fiascoes -- the mark of an artist risking failure, a good sign. There is something beyond mere Pop parody or social provocation in the work, something to do with deep private needs and desires, which we perceive secondhand as comic pathos. It is art as tough therapy, disturbingly honest. Hours: Wednesdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays, noon to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, artists, students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

* BRIDGET RILEY, "Reconnaissance," Dia Center for the Arts, 548 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 989-5566 (through June 17). Once overly identified with Op Art, this British abstract painter never got her due in anti-Op New York, but a beautifully installed show of 40 paintings from 1961 to 1984 should change things. Concentrating on the early black-and-white paintings that made Ms. Riley famous, it presents stringently pure yet accessible works that have, at their best, extended the optical potential implicit in the work of Mondrian, Josef Albers and Ad Reinhardt. At their weakest, their meticulously calibrated patterns can be so aggressive that they virtually kidnap the eye, take it on a joy ride and leave it in a crumpled heap. Either way, the overall effect is of an artist of unusual dedication who has remained loyal to the original premises of her art and yet steadfastly refused to repeat herself. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students and 60+ (Smith).

* "SULTAN ALI OF MASHHAD, MASTER OF NASTALIQ," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through May 27). Sultan Ali (1442-1520), one of the titans of Islamic calligraphy, was born in the northeastern Iranian city of Mashhad and spent most of his long working life at the Timurid capital of Herat, where he perfected the elegant cursive style known as nastaliq and produced extravagant manuscripts for the court. Several examples of his work are included in this smoldering little show of books and album pages. And anyone wanting to get a sense of the exalted status that writing had in the Islamic world and of just how luminous illuminated manuscripts can be will be able to do so here. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

* "THE TREASURY OF BASEL CATHEDRAL," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through May 27). The jewel-embellished gold and silver liturgical objects and reliquaries in this show exist on some exotic outer fringe of beauty where the crass and the ineffable meet. Together they have a cliffhanger of a tale to tell, as frustrating as it is uplifting. (They were preserved as an ensemble until Basel city politics intervened in the 19th century.) There's the rarity factor: almost none of the 75 works have visited the United States before. And it's hard to remember the last time anything quite like their single-minded incandescence radiated from a local museum. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

* "VAN GOGH'S POSTMAN: THE PORTRAITS OF JOSEPH ROULIN," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9400 (through May 15). This revelatory micro-exhibition reunites five portraits of the postal worker Joseph Roulin, whom van Gogh met in Arles. The show affords an excellent opportunity to study the painter's craft as he processes a single motif through a series of approaches from painterly naturalism to richly patterned symbolism. It is fascinating as well to see the portraits in light of the biographical background. Roulin cared for van Gogh after the famous ear-cutting incident, and he grew in the artist's imagination from an amusing local character to a figure of Christ-like benevolence. Hours and admission: See above (Ken Johnson).

* "VERMEER AND THE DELFT SCHOOL," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879-5500 (through May 27). Genius does not flourish in a vacuum. That's the simple lesson vividly conveyed by this alternately tousled and crystalline exhibition. With 15 Vermeers -- nearly half his known paintings -- serving as ballast, this exhibition almost giddily spotlights a succession of artists, tracking the emergence of an increasingly effortless illusionism in Delft in the 1650's and 60's. Flower still lifes, whitewashed church interiors, townscapes and genre scenes by Pieter de Hooch, Carel Fabritius and Gerard Houckgeest are part of the mix, along with drawings and a breathtaking selection of small landscapes by artists you've never heard of. All this contextualizing sharpens one's sense of Vermeer's achievement, but it also spells out the milieu without which he would not have been Vermeer. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

"FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT AND THE ART OF JAPAN: THE ARCHITECT'S OTHER PASSION," Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street, (212) 832-1155 (through July 15). Some shows are like a vigorous read; you have to concentrate and try to follow the plot. Wright, an architectural colossus and a wily diva of a man, is the main character. The story of his infatuation with Japanese art, and of how he turned that love to lucrative ends by moonlighting as a top-dollar dealer in woodblock prints -- at least until disaster struck -- is a rich one. It's told through dozens of architectural drawings, documentary photographs, woodblock prints and a superb accompanying book by the curator, Julia Meech, which wraps wide-ranging art historical research in a nimble, personable style. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $3 students and 65+ (Cotter).

Galleries: Uptown

BERND AND HILLA BECHER, "Photographs From the 1960's and 70's," Zwirner & Wirth, 32 East 69th Street, (212) 517-8677. (through May 25). This exhibition samples the early efforts of the German team that helped establish the camera's art-world credentials with rigorous black-and-white photographs of lime kilns, blast furnaces and water towers that capture the body industrial (Smith).

* LOUISE BOURGEOIS, "The Personages," C & M Arts, 45 East 78th Street, (212) 861-0020 (through June 9). Bone-skinny, striking and each an individual, Ms. Bourgeois's 19 bronze "Personages" are enigmatic, people-size totems that stand in amiable camaraderie, like well-behaved guests at a cultural soiree. But their presence is insistent. Made from 1947 to 1953, and Surrealistic in origin, they greet the viewer at eye level, dispensing with the built-up bases that afflicted most earlier sculpture. Revisiting this powerful body of work strengthens awareness of the inspired personal vision with which Ms. Bourgeoise has enriched the universe of sculpture (Grace Glueck).

JIM PETERS, CDS, 76 East 79th Street, (212) 772-9555 (through May 19). Carnal desire animates deliberately grungy assemblages and collages, in a show by an artist with a master's degree in nuclear engineering. The contrast between roughly built, crustily painted structural elements and the photographs of attractive naked women that they frame suggests a tension between raw actuality and idealizing fantasy. One senses an underlying anxiety, which might be worth making more visible (Johnson).

HOUGHTON CRANFORD SMITH, "The Purist Landscapes," Richard York, 21 East 65th Street, (212) 772-9155 (through May 12). In Paris in the early 1930's this American painter learned Purism, a variation on Cubism, from Amedee Ozenfant. Returning to New York, Smith combined idealizing simplification and finely textured paint in pastoral landscapes, producing images of New England hills or harbors or South American mountains that call to mind Grant Wood, Rockwell Kent and Charles Sheeler. But they also have their own slightly comical, slightly melancholy serenity (Johnson).

Galleries: 57th Street

CHARLES HARBUTT, "Dreams and Memories . . . ," Laurence Miller, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 397-3930 (through May 19). This small retrospective looks back on an admirable 40-year career in photojournalism. With affectionate warmth and great framing instincts, Mr. Harbutt captures moments of riveting narrative pregnancy. In a shot in Milan in 1970, for example, five businessmen gather on an astonishingly long modern stairway against a high wall splashed by sunlight; you feel an almost divine immanence (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

ANTONIO FRASCONI, Sragow, 73 Spring Street, (212) 219-1793 (through May 19) and El Museo del Barrio, 1230 Fifth Avenue, at 104th Street, (212) 831-7272 (through May 20). This eminent, socially engaged printmaker is showing rough expressionistic, politically charged woodcuts from the 1940's at Sragow. At El Museo del Barrio is a recent series of richly colored, textured and abstracted prints that illustrate Langston Hughes's poem "Let America Be America Again" (Johnson).

ROBERT RYMAN AND IAN WILSON, Peter Blum Gallery, 99 Wooster Street, (212) 343-0441 (through June 2). Bringing together examples of Mr. Ryman's stripped-down paintings and evidence from Mr. Wilson's various Conceptual Art activities, this exhibition tellingly contrasts different kinds of aesthetic purism (Smith).

VALTON TYLER, Phyllis Kind, 136 Greene Street, (212) 925-1200 (through May 31). The paintings by this self-taught Texan verge on a kind of surrealistic kitsch, but they are persuasively strange. At his best, in large, weirdly stylized landscapes, Mr. Tyler accumulates simplified tubular and spiky forms into dense jungle scenes, which have the Cubist palpability and otherworldly dreaminess of Henri Rousseau (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

* "ANOTHER, ONCE AGAIN, MANY TIMES MORE," Feature, 530 West 25th Street, (212) 675-7772 (through May 12). This show of serial work has something for everybody, and possibly a little too much for some viewers. John Torreano covers the wall with bejewelled half-spheres, Lisa Beck with painted tondos, Nancy Shaver with stacked architectural outtakes and David Morreno with a suave pattern-painting titled "Door Knob Head: The Movie Sequence." Michael St. John edges into fraught terrain with a sculptural lineup of serial killers from horror films. Daniel Hesidence follows up with alarming paintings of bullet-strafed heads, all women. Howard Johnson is an island unto himself with thick collages made of ink drawings, reflective stickers, floor plans and G-strings, forming a grimy looking insider-Outsider Art melange with lots of promise (Cotter).

* ROBERT BARRY, "Early Works, 1966-73," Gasser & Grunert, 524 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 807-9494 (through May 19). This beautifully installed exhibition presents classic works by a pioneer of dematerialized art. Mr. Barry's visually minimal, verbally paradoxical works operate like Zen koans to heighten awareness of the mystery of consciousness. One, penciled in fine block letters on the wall, reads, "All the things I know but of which I am not at the moment thinking -- 1:36 PM; June 15, 1969" (Johnson).

FARIBA HAJAMADI, Christine Burgin, 243 West 18th Street, (212) 462-2668 (through May 12). This brainy, Iranian-born conceptualist uses photography to explore unspoken ideologies that drive Western museum practices. In six large, handsome, digitally manipulated views of museum exhibition spaces, Ms. Hajamadi gives her project an obliquely autobiographical spin by including obscure reflections of her own image and composing her own fictive installations of art and artifacts (Johnson).

"HOME AND THE WORLD: AN EXPLORATION OF IDENTITY AT CROSSROADS," India Center of Art and Culture, 530 West 25th Street, (212) 462-4221 (through May 31). The center is a recently opened nonprofit space devoted equally to art, literature, music and film, and most of those media play some role in this group exhibition of contemporary artists of Indian descent (Cotter).

MELISSA MEYER; ALEX STOLYAROV, Elizabeth Harris, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 463-9666 (through May 19). Ms. Meyer's loosely gridded, confidently improvised paintings exude a fine summery light. With wide brushes she layers loopy squiggles of color over radiant patchwork fields; the effect is rigorously economical yet hedonistically sumptuous. Mr. Stolyarov's compact, extremely thick, lusciously colored monochrome abstractions are like giant Chiclets (Johnson).

RUTH ROOT, Andrew Kreps, 516 West 20th Street, (212) 741-8849 (through May 12). A mischievous subversive, Ms. Root likes to paint little smoking cigarettes into the cracks between blocks of color in her grid-based abstractions. Now, for her second solo show, she adds instead a pair of little eyes to each picture, so that the paintings seem imbued with watchful consciousness. The artist also continues to create small, shaped and painted collages with no comic gimmicks, just a spirit of a lighthearted yet formally rigorous play (Johnson).

Other Galleries

* SIMON LEE AND CLAIRE LESTEVEN, Smack Mellon Studios, 56 Water Street, Brooklyn, (718) 834-8761 (through May 13). In Mr. Lee's cinematic installation, a screen stretching across the darkened gallery is filled with luminous drifting images of animals, trees, houses and figures, which appear to be under a microscope lens. They are all "live" projections of tiny plastic forms floating in a tank of eddying water. The results are a metaphor for the random flow of history, and a low-tech formal tour de force. In a separate solo show, Ms. Lesteven shows photographs and videos made with multi-aperture cyclindrical versions of a pinpoint camera, producing eerily distorted pictures of public spaces. Here, too, the means are straightforward, the ends evocative (Cotter).

QIU ZHIJIE, Ethan Cohen Fine Arts, 37 Walker Street, TriBeCa, (212) 625-1250 (through May 19). This young Beijing-based artist makes his New York debut with a show that plays with and extends classical forms. Calligraphic scrolls carry outtakes from the dictionary. On other scrolls, elements of ink-and-brush landscapes -- trees, figures, pavilions -- are cut loose from their original contexts. In a video the artist writes out Tang dynasty poems, but the tape is played backward so that he seems to be erasing them. He's moving in several directions at this point, but certain themes (cultural fragmentation, transience) and attitudes (brash Zen-style wit, nostalgia) are constants (Cotter).

Last Chance

GEORGES ADEAGBO, "Abraham: L'Ami de Dieu," P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Street, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084 (through Sunday). Mr. Adeagbo, born in Benin in 1942, is making his United States debut with a rich, deceptively low-key installation that resembles an African outdoor market, a New York City sidewalk sale and a personal archive in the process of being sorted. Hundreds of objects are neatly arranged on the floor and walls: paintings, secondhand books, record albums, African sculptures and magazines, many of which the artist gathered in New York, sent to Africa, then brought back for the show, reversing the global itinerary of African art centuries ago. It's a myth-laden history of the world, of art and of African and American culture circa 1960. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2, students and 60+ (Cotter).

DALE CHIHULY, Marlborough, 40 West 57th Street, (212) 541-4900 (through tomorrow). The master glass blower from Seattle is back, with spectacular chandeliers resembling tropical submarine flora and giant vases holding fantastic glass flowers. The material, color and luminosity of Mr. Chilhuly's work is undeniably seductive; the grandiose theatricality is a little annoying and the line between art and high-priced kitsch very fine (Johnson).

* "CORREGGIO AND PARMIGIANINO: MASTER DRAFTSMEN OF THE RENAISSANCE," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879-5500 (through Sunday). This copious and beautiful exhibition has nearly 130 drawings by two artists who were aligned in time, geography and, briefly, style in the third decade of the 16th century. Correggio, who blew the roof off Renaissance illusionism with the ecstatic ceiling paintings that he made in Parma in the 1520's, is represented by a room of exquisite mostly red-chalk studies that reflect a penchant for brazen foreshortening, glowing light and atmospheric sfumato. The two galleries of Parmigianino's drawings seem true to his Mannerist sensibility. A searching restlessness is evident in the constant shifts in medium, style and subject. So is a relatively new notion for his time: drawing for the sake of drawing. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

LISA CORINNE DAVIS, Lehman College Art Gallery, Bedford Park Boulevard West, the Bronx, (718) 960-8731 (through Tuesday). Lisa Davis's collage-style paintings are made up of hundreds of variable elements: fingerprints, headshots cut from magazines, pages torn from novels and history books in various languages, and a wide range of colors approximating skin tones. In the big, unframed quilt- or chart-like pieces that result, written narratives are hand altered, faces missing from history are inserted, and distinctions of race and ethnicity are subtly confused. Ms. Davis demonstrates how pointed information and good-looking painting can coexist (Cotter).

* "GEROME AND GOUPIL: ART AND ENTERPRISE," Dahesh Museum, 601 Fifth Avenue, at 48th Street, (212) 759-0606 (through tomorrow). This informative, well-produced exhibition studies the relationship between the 19th-century French academician Jean-Leon Gerome and his gallery, the House of Goupil, which by marketing reproductions of his works worldwide made him one of the most famous and successful artists of his day. Among about 20 paintings and 40 reproductions is the strikingly cinematic painting of a victorious Roman gladiator, the image that inspired Ridley Scott to make his Oscar-winning movie. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Free (Johnson).

CADENCE GIERSBACH, "Tropicalia," Roebling Hall, 390 Wythe Street, at South Fourth Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 599-5352 (through Monday). Imagine white vinyl cushions for lawn furniture, covered with faux-Impressionist landsape paintings, and you have a sense of Ms. Giersbach's new work. The scenes are taken from photographs of a Disneyesque theme park near Madras, India, though for many Westerners a visit to the city is a fantastic, head-spinning experience in itself. To complete this witty exercise in cross-cultural exoticisms, the gallery walls are painted with palm trees in feverish tropical green (Cotter).

SALLY GUTIERREZ, Parker's Box, 193 Grand Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 388-2882 (through Sunday). The work of this young conceptual artist from Spain gets at some of the distracted strangeness of urban life by combining art and documentary. In still-life photographs of city windows, objects are scratched out, leaving static-like shadows behind. In video interviews, two women -- one from Mexico, the other from South Asia -- talk with emotion about being immigrants in the United States, but only their hands, not their faces are visible (Cotter).

* DONALD JUDD, Paula Cooper Gallery, 534 West 21st Street, Chelsea, (212) 255-1105 (through tomorrow). The leading Minimalist sculptor's roots in painting, his penchant for visual drama and his reverence for the landscape are stunningly evoked in a plywood installation piece that hasn't been shown since 1976 and may look as good here as it ever will (Smith).

"JEAN POYET: ARTIST TO THE COURT OF RENAISSANCE FRANCE," Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, (212) 685-0610 (through Sunday). His reputation as one of the great manuscript illuminators of the Renaissance has declined over the centuries, with much of his work ascribed to others, but the French artist Jean Poyet (ca. 1445-1503) is re-established in this beautiful show as the true author of some well-known Books of Hours and other religious treasures. His use of perspective, color, light and shadow and his convincing representations of the human figure took his work well beyond the limitations of his Late Gothic predecessors, as seen in such powerful manuscripts as the "Missal of Guillaume Lallemant" and "The Hours of Henry VIII." The judicious use of lightbox transparencies, blown-up color photographs and a CD-ROM room where viewers can turn the pages of virtual manuscripts all add to the show's accessibility. It is one of the season's most impressive presentations. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays, 10:30 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6, students and 65+ (Glueck).

GRAPHIC: Photos: Dematerialized art: "Inert Gas Series: Xenon" (1969), by Robert Barry, from an exhibition of his early works at Gasser & Grunert in Chelsea. (Gasser & Grunert); A Gerome drawing in his show at the Dahesh, through tomorrow. (Musee Goupil, Boudeaux)

Museums and Sites

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. "Indigenous Peoples: Perspectives and Perceptions," weekend programs of events and performances. Tomorrow and Sunday at 1 p.m., a lecture on Hawaiian arts with a lei-maker, Kilohana, and Lehua Domingo; at 2:15, "Encircled With Love: The Musical Legacy of Her Majesty Queen Lili'uokalani," with Nalani Olds; at 3:30, a screening of "Black Indians: An American Story"; at 4:30, "The Cherokee Language and Cultural Circle," focusing on the Cherokee history and efforts to preserve Cherokee culture, featuring language demonstrations and dances. Admission (suggested donation): $10 for adults; $7.50 for students and 65+; $6 for children. Combination tickets are available. Information: (212) 769-5100; advance tickets: (212) 769-5200.

MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street. The museum collects, preserves and presents material related to the city's history. Tomorrow at 2:30 p.m., "The Monied Metropolis: New York City and the Consolidation of the American Bourgeoisie, 1850-96," with the author Sven Beckert, who will read from and discuss his book "The Monied Metropolis." Call extension 257 to register. "Gay Men's Health Crisis: 20 Years Fighting for People With H.I.V./AIDS," through Sept. 11; tomorrow at 2 p.m., a gallery talk presented by the curators of the exhibition. Sunday at 2 p.m., "New York Toy Stories," a permanent exhibition at the museum, will be the inspiration for a theater-musical performance by Theater in Motion. MUSEUM OF JEWISH HERITAGE: A LIVING MEMORIAL TO THE HOLOCAUST, 18 First Place, at West Street and Battery Place, Battery Park City, Lower Manhattan. Sunday from 1 to 2:30 p.m., "Lag Ba'omer Amulet Workshop," to make hamsa, hand-shaped amulets and blue bead bracelets intended to ward off the evil eye, with an art educator, Selina Alko; for children 7 and older. Monday night at 6:30, film and discussion series, featuring a screening of the comedy "Over the Ocean" (1991), in Hebrew, with English subtitles, with Eva Fogelman, psychologist and author. "Citizens Betrayed: The Hungarian Forced Labor Battalions, 1939-45"; through Sept. 3. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m.; Fridays and the eves of Jewish holidays, 9 a.m. to 3 p.m.; closed Saturdays. Admission: $7; students and 55+, $5; children 5 and under, free. Tickets can be bought by calling the museum, (212) 945-0039. Information: (212) 509-6130.

MUSEUM OF TELEVISION AND RADIO, 25 West 52nd Street, Manhattan. "Television Documentary Festival," devoted to the art and history of television documentary, featuring premieres and recently seen works, along with panel discussions, through May 20. Tonight at 6:30, "Broken Silence," a series of five documentaries, including testimonies, from Steven Spielberg's Shoah Visual History Foundation, along with original and archival footage, including Vojtech Jasny's "Hell on Earth" and Janos Szasz's "Eyes of the Holocaust." Tomorrow at 4 p.m., "A Tribute to Maysles Films," with screenings of retrospective works. Sunday at 2 p.m., "Retrospective: A Tribute to Maysles Films," with "What's Happening: The Beatles in the USA" and "Orson Welles: Spain," featuring Albert Maysles, who will introduce the screenings and participate in a discussion. Museum hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; open until 8 p.m. on Thursdays, and the theater is open until 9 p.m. on Fridays. Admission: $6; students and 62+, $4; ages 12 and under, $3. Information: (212) 621-6800.

NEW-YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY, 170 Central Park West, near 77th Street, Manhattan. Tonight and Monday night at 7:30; Sunday at 2 p.m., the Actors Company Theater production of "Separate Tables," by Terrence Rattigan. Tickets: $15. Reservations: (212) 645-8228. Tomorrow at 11 a.m., "Painting in the Park," a workshop for youngsters after they look at the society's painting collection. Free. Sunday at 2 p.m., a gallery walk with Norman Brosterman, curator, of "Out of Time: Designs for the 20th-Century," on view through June 10. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; students and 62+, $3; ages 12 and under, free. Information: (212) 873-3400.

STATEN ISLAND INSTITUTE OF ARTS AND SCIENCES, 75 Stuyvesant Place, St. George. Cultural museum and library with artistic, scientific and environmental collections. "From House Calls to Hospitals," through Sunday. "Objects of Beauty: Decorative Art From the Permanent Collection"; through Sunday. Museum hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Suggested admission: $2.50; students, children and 62+, $1.50; free for members. Information: (718) 727-1135.

Gardens

BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN, 1000 Washington Avenue, Crown Heights. "Exhibition of Oriental Brush Paintings," classic brush-and-ink works in traditional style, through June 10. Exhibition hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $3; $1.50 for students and 65+ (free for 65+ on Fridays); free for children 15 and under; free for all on Tuesdays, except holidays; free from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. The conservatory closes 30 minutes before the grounds. Information: (718) 623-7200. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 8 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.

NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN, Southern Boulevard and 200th Street, Bedford Park, the Bronx. "The New Renaissance Garden," through June 14, in the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory, evoking the gardens of the Renaissance, with related lectures, performances and walks. Parking: $5. EVENTS

"CARMINA BURANA," Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, Orange Street, between Hicks and Henry Streets, Brooklyn Heights. WALKING TOURS

"BUILT FOR DISPLAY: MOSTLY MUSEUMS," Upper East Side, discusses the growth of museums in the area, including the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Whitney Museum of Art, as well as the modern-style architecture of nearby residences and galleries. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. at Fifth Avenue and 86th Street. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. Fee, $15; $12 for Society members. Information: (212) 935-3960.

"FLATBUSH GINGERBREAD," Brooklyn. Visits examples of turn-of-the-century structures with stops at the homes of Nellie Bly and Charles Stillwell. HEADLINE: CAR-FREE; 
Mystic, Harpooned for Posterity

BYLINE:  By DIANE COLE; Diane Cole is the author of a memoir, "After Great Pain: A New Life Emerges."

 BODY:
Give me a watery place, where the horizon fills not just with present-day ships but with the ghosts of seafaring vessels from the past as well. 
 That place is Mystic, Conn. 
 Just gaze in any direction from the old-fashioned bascule drawbridge that overlooks the Mystic River in the center of town, and you'll see the lure -- and the lore -- of whaling and sailing all around you, perhaps most notably in the masts and sails of the historic ships preserved, and on display, at the Mystic Seaport museum, just walking distance away. 
Venture a bit farther north and you'll arrive at the newly expanded Mystic Aquarium and the Institute for Exploration. Or just return to where you started, pause a few moments more by the bridge, and imagine the long, lonely view commanded by the women the sailors left behind as they gazed from the trim white widow's walks perched atop the stately, columned captain's homes that line the streets along the river's banks. 
Alternately, in search of more recent history, stroll a few blocks west across the bridge on Main Street, and roam around the real-life location for the 1988 Julia Roberts movie, "Mystic Pizza." Don't be shy about trying the pizza, either; my son, Edward, and I both give it two thumbs up. 
Perhaps fittingly, for a town whose glory days date to the 19th century, we have relied on old-fashioned rail technology to transport us here. Amtrak drops us in downtown Mystic, where the small train depot is a brief walk (or, if you're laden with luggage, an inexpensive cab ride) to the Whaler's Inn, centrally located on Main Street. (Another picturesque downtown choice is the Steamboat Inn, a small bed and breakfast on the river wharf.) 
Staying in town, at the cozy white clapboard Whaler's Inn (whose main building was erected in 1865), rather than the larger, modern Mystic Hilton, near other attractions but farther removed from the downtown commercial hub and historic center, allows the pleasures of a weekend's worth of small-town living.
Since we're hoofing it, staying where the local action is (including several stellar ice cream parlors) also gives us more varied options for an evening. Best warm weather night-life bet: Take a twilight stroll by the water, and watch the Mystic River drawbridge open, once an hour, to let sailboats pass beneath. Or amble through the town, glimpsing the many surviving 19th-century white trim wooden Greek Revival cottages that whaleboat captains, ship's carpenters and shipyard owners once called home.
Guides are available, but you don't really need one; the closer you get to the river, the harder it is to find a block without at least several structures bearing proud placards announcing their original owners and dates of construction. Combine either ramble with dinner at any one of several reasonably priced local establishments, top it all off with a sundae, and you've got low-key living at its best.
During the day, a shuttle bus will run on Memorial Day weekend and then from July through Labor Day from one popular area attraction to another, including Mystic Seaport and the Mystic Aquarium. So you have the further option of resting your feet in preparation for another ramble later on.
Now comes the confession. Yes, we did spring for a taxi or two (or three). And in doing so on the way to the Nautilus and Submarine Force Museum in nearby Groton, we ended up befriending the driver, who turned out to be the deputy mayor of New London, just the other side of the Mystic River. ("This is how I meet the voters," she said.) 
But even with these motor-driven detours, we found that staying in town and using mostly shoe leather to get around helped dramatize the maritime panorama of this once-thriving seaport, which now chiefly prospers as a tourist town.

A Living From the Water
As early as the 17th century, Mystic's inland river shoreline began attracting boat-builders and fishermen. During the Revolution, the town's mariners fitted out as privateers to run the British Navy blockades, capturing and scavenging enemy cannon, munitions and supplies.
Certainly, for most of the 19th century, the seafaring savvy of Mystic's sailors helped account for their lively trade in fishing, whaling, sealing, shipbuilding, steam transport and shipping. In the years from the California Gold Rush to the outbreak of the Civil War, trim clipper ships built in the town's boat yards made speedy record runs around Cape Horn to San Francisco and back. And when steam power gained ascendancy over sail and wind, the town's boatyards adapted, turning to wooden steamships (and gunboats), 56 of which were built for the Union Navy. 
In the post-Civil War era, the local timber supply began running short. More changes spelled other economic troubles for the town. Steel-hulled vessels, too large and bulky for the relatively shallow Mystic River to accommodate, were replacing the wooden ships for which the town was known. Petroleum and plastics were proving to be more economical substitutes for whale oil and whalebone, forcing a complete shutdown of the whaling industry in the early 20th century. With business and trade declining rapidly, Mystic found itself harboring fewer seaworthy ships than ghosts of glories past. 
It's remarkable how vital those visions of the past remain at the living history museum at Mystic Seaport, which recreates -- in its architecture, exhibitions, original clipper ships and restored historic vessels -- the misty and mystical atmosphere of a 19th-century coastal New England village.
Throughout the outdoor museum's 17 acres, every building (and each is original, dating from the 17th to the late 19th century, many from Mystic but others transported from as far away as Maine) is linked to the necessities of lives bound up with the sea.

Inside and Outside
In our ramble by the houses ringing the village green, we stepped inside buildings fitted out, among other things, as a 19th-century cooperage (to build the barrels in which to store whale oil, along with other shipped goods), shipsmith (or blacksmith, at the ready to sharpen your harpoon), bank (with shipping office upstairs), general store (get that extra hardtack for the voyage), boat shop (for repairing old and building new vessels) and newspaper office (all the latest shipping news).
Depending on the day's schedule, you can catch would-be citizens in period costumes demonstrating how to carpenter a plank, repair a torn sail or cook the grub in a ship's galley.
As for a glimpse of how the town's upper crust lived, we dawdled before the handsome 1842 mansion, replete with gingerbread scrollwork, ornamental posts, tall bay windows and Bohemian etched glass, that belonged to Thomas Greenman, one of three brothers who owned the shipyard originally found on the seaport's grounds. 
Catering to our daydreams of life at sea was the elegant mahogany and red velvet captain's cabin rescued from the abandoned 1883 ship called the Benjamin F. Packard. It is now housed in a small brick building originally designed as the power plant for the Greenman family textile mill, which was also in Mystic. 
Exploring this replicated universe, we poked our heads inside a small planetarium that teaches would-be sailors how to navigate by the stars, then paused for a "mug up" at the Spouter Tavern, which offers coffee and snacks year-round and a warm fire and hot cider in the cold months. And we gained an even broader maritime perspective through a more traditional exhibition, "Voyages: Stories of America and the Sea," which chronicles every aspect of the country's history through the prism of its waterways. 
Engaging as all this is, the highlight is surely the vessels themselves. You can begin with the 1841 wooden square-rigged whaling bark, the Charles W. Morgan, the last surviving ship of its kind. As you walk along either side of the main deck, notice the six-man whaleboats that hang from davits, seemingly at the ready to be lowered and launched as a crew of harpooners eye the horizon in search of whales. Behold the heavy metal blubber hooks with which the dead whales were hoisted aboard.
On deck, too, is where sailors boiled down the whale blubber to extract its precious oil and, in assembly-line style, stored the oil in barrels below deck, precious cargo to be brought home and sold for profit. Just the way Melville described it in "Moby-Dick."

A Slave's Journey
Next, step aboard the newest, and in some ways most striking, addition to the Seaport's fleet, the recently reconstructed slave ship Amistad, which was built in the Seaport's shipyard and which took its maiden voyage as part of Operation Sail 2000. More precisely, I should say, step below deck, to the dark, dank quarters reserved for the "cargo" of kidnapped Africans to be sold as slaves upon their arrival in the New World. And this recreated Amistad, a guide told us, is somewhat larger than the original.
After coming up -- literally -- for air, we moved on to the full-rigged Danish 1882 merchant marine training ship renamed in 1934 for another literary seaman, Joseph Conrad. Don't miss the handsome figurehead of Conrad that decorates the front of this hybrid sailing and steamship.
Relatively young by comparison is a sleek-sailed 1921 fishing schooner, the L. A. Dunton, whose original home base was Boston and whose crew trawled the Grand and Georges Banks for haddock and cod. While all the boats are permanently docked, in warm weather you can take a brief cruise on the Mystic River aboard the Sabino, a coal-fired, wood-hulled passenger steamboat from 1908.
So much for man (and woman) and the sea. What about the creatures that lie beneath the deceptively calm currents of the Mystic River and beyond? That is the focus of the town's other well-known attraction, the newly renovated and expanded Mystic Aquarium and the Institute for Exploration.
Outdoors in huge underground pools set against a stunning landscape that mixes greenery with volcanic rock, beluga whales and harbor seals can be seen floating, frolicking and sometimes spitting huge bursts of water at visitors. A winding pathway leads to a more cavelike sea environment inhabited by sleek, white-whiskered Steller sea lions and then a rocky indoor-outdoor pool that is home to waddling black-footed penguins. In summer it makes an ideal spot to linger and await the cooling splash of an energetic flipper.
Indoors, among hundreds of other species, we found bony plated sea horses; leopard-spotted sharks; a grasping Giant Pacific octopus, whose reddish tentacles can span 12 feet; gorgeous technicolor coral reefs; a variety of neon purple fish that would look great in my living room; and, everyone's playful favorites, bottlenose dolphins. 
Finally we entered the newest addition to the aquarium: the atmospheric "Challenge of the Deep" put together by Dr. Robert D. Ballard, the oceanographer and underwater explorer best known for pinpointing the remains of the Titanic. Call me old-fashioned, but I wanted more narrative and fewer high-tech special effects.

Village Treats
From the aquarium it's a quick walk across the parking lot to the Colonial-style shopping mall next door, Olde Mistick Village. If you're hungry and still have an appetite for fish, try the stylish seafood restaurant Go Fish. (They have a nonfishy children's menu, too.) If you have time to shop, you might try our favorite among the 60-some stores, Scrimshanders, which specializes in scrimshaw: the ivory and whalebone carvings and engravings on which 18th- and 19th-century sailors whittled away the hours at sea. 
Still, for roaming and browsing, our favorite haunts were in town: before the weekend was over, the friendly waitresses at Mystic Pizza knew us as regulars. For a more formal dinner, try the Captain Daniel Packer Inne, in a restored 1756 building with original fireplaces and beams, which nonetheless retains a relaxed atmosphere, especially in its lively downstairs pub.
The shops on Main Street provide an eclectic mix. Among our top choices were Mystic Army and Navy (a very cool selection of contemporary camouflage, my son assured me); Radio Waves, a nostalgia store specializing in retro "I Love Lucy" souvenirs; the Company of Craftsmen, displaying ceramics and jewelry by local artists; and a funky stationery store, Everything but the Stamp.
On our last afternoon, having reached our shopping limit, we cabbed it to nearby Groton to tour the Submarine Force Library and Museum, site of the Nautilus. For submarine movie fans like us, this self-guided tour from fore to aft through the nation's first nuclear-powered submarine (launched in 1954) was a must. How advanced the now-obsolete torpedo, sonar and radio rooms seemed in comparison with the navigational equipment available to Mystic's 19th-century whalers! 
Well, there's nothing like a stroll through history to lend some perspective. Which is why we paused for one last view from the Mystic River Bridge before returning home to New York City on the Hudson River, where the bridges are definitely grander but none more scenic than the one from which we briefly glimpsed a slice of 19th-century small-town life.

From Tall Ship to Sub, With a Stop for Pizza

HEADLINE: Hyundai Attributes Income Rise To Demand for Its Big Vehicles 

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, May 3 

 BODY:
The Hyundai Motor Company said today that first-quarter income surged to $213 million, a 28 percent increase from the comparable quarter last year.
 The company attributed the rise to the weaker Korean won and to increased demand in the United States for its larger cars and its new sport-utility vehicle. 
The success of the large vehicles is a result of a reversal in strategy by Hyundai, which entered the American market in February 1986 with a small economy model called the Excel and the slogan "cars that make sense."
The falling won has enabled Hyundai to offer foreign customers large models with a significant price advantage over those of competitors. Since last year, Hyundai has been exporting its XG300 luxury sedan and Santa Fe sport utility vehicle to the United States along with the compact and midsize models that have been finding growing acceptance in America.
The company's exports to North America and Europe more than compensated for disappointing domestic sales, as South Korea experienced a resurgence of the kind of economic difficulties that precipitated the financial crisis of 1997 and 1998.
Hyundai said it sold 211,000 vehicles overseas in the first quarter, up 10.7 percent from the first quarter of 2000, while the number of vehicles sold in Korea declined 6.7 percent, to 162,000.
Over all, revenue at the company rose 18 percent.
Hyundai Motor also predicted a strong first-quarter report for Kia Motor, which it acquired at auction in late 1998. Kia, whose failure to pay its bills in mid-1997 was one of the first overt signs of the economic crisis that hit the entire country several months later, was expected to announce a first-quarter net profit of about $90 million.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs; 
Here Comes the Sun

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: ACCRA, Ghana 

 BODY:
The good news from Ghana, the West African state from which so many black Americans trace their roots, is that after decades of political mismanagement it is finally following the first rule of holes. The first rule of holes states: "When you're in a hole, stop digging."
 Having had its first-ever peaceful, democratic transition from one elected government to another last December, Ghana's new president, J. A. Kufuor, has a clear mandate to stop digging. Mr. Kufuor was elected by a solid majority by calling for improved governance, an end to official corruption and a renewed effort to expand trade and attract foreign investment. That's the good news. The bad news is: The hole Ghana has dug itself into is really, really deep. Half of Ghana's government budget goes to pay just the interest on its domestic and foreign debts, accumulated over years of idiotic African Socialism, plunder by leaders and weak governance, compounded by poor oversight by the I.M.F. and World Bank. 
 "The problem for us," President Kufuor said in an interview at his home, "is that you feel like you're in a hole, and you want to get out, and you hear all these noises and all this activity coming from the top of the hole. It leaves you feeling that everyone up there is busy and active and you feel very much alone. I want to feel that there is someone out there with some humanism to stretch back to me and help me out."
What is encouraging about Ghana is that the impulse for reform here was driven by the people below, not just the pols above. What worries Ghanaians, though, is that after so many years in the third world they may not be able to compete in the Fast World. 
I gave a talk at the University of Ghana, and afterward one student asked me: "Will the world have empathy for us?" -- as Ghana tries to go down this new path. "No," I said, "the world will have no empathy for you, but that's not what you want anyway! You want to appeal to greed. You want to create a sense of opportunity here that will attract wealthy Ghanaians to bring their money back home and create jobs. You want investment, not pity." The dependency culture here is so deep, though, this logic is very new.
Then another student asked: If it's true that in the age of globalization the big don't eat the small but the fast will eat the slow, what is Ghana to do? "We're naturally slow here," he said. "We eat slow. We talk slow. We sing slow. We like things slow. How will we compete in this world?" 
Direction is more important than speed, I argued. Ghana has been on the wrong road for so long its per-capita income is now $1 a day. It needs to get on the right road and go at any pace it can.
Ghana is rich in human and natural resources. What it has lacked are good fundamentals: institutions, decent schools and legal frameworks to get the most out of those resources. The secret for success in globalization is all about building good fundamentals -- not modems or bandwidth. "The lack of good governance is the bane of Africa," said Papa Owusu-Ankomah, deputy majority leader of the Ghanaian Parliament. "Without strong institutions we can't check abuses of power, and that has been the source of all our problems."
But generating institutions is not easy. Historically there are two ways: One is the way America got them -- through evolution: 200 years of slowly evolving the habits and laws to govern a modern society. The other way is how India or postwar Germany and Japan got them -- through imperialism: someone comes from abroad and imposes democratic structures until they take root. The problem for Ghana, and the rest of Africa, is that it is too early for evolution -- that takes decades -- and it is too late for imperialism. 
It will have to find the energy from within. Mr. Kufuor's election signals that Ghanaians want to try. Mr. Kufuor says he intends to try. The Bush team should go out of its way to help Ghana -- now -- with conditional aid. That is, aid, and debt relief, tied to the building of real institutions. 
The dawns are always spectacular on the vast African continent, but false dawns abound here as well. Just look at Nigeria and South Africa, whose democratically elected leaders are slowly sinking away. Ghana now offers the best chance to establish an African model for free-market democracy. Here comes the sun. Let's hope it's really rising, and if it is, let's do our part to keep it up there.

HEADLINE: Wages at Harvard 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 According to Bob Herbert (column, April 30), student protesters have the upper hand in the debate over the "living wage" for Harvard's lowest-paid workers. But a high minimum wage hurts some of those it is intended to help. 
If Harvard has to pay higher wages, it will hire fewer workers and seek those with more skills. 
 Harvard is a charitable institution, but its mission is education, not income redistribution. Protesters would divert benefactors' funds to serve their own social goals. Also, many people are far poorer than these workers. Programs for developing countries -- a longtime Harvard priority -- would be a better use of resources.
Moreover, the school should not condone the takeover of the provost's office. A community like Harvard can function only when each group respects the right of others to disagree.

N. GREGORY MANKIW
Cambridge, Mass., May 2, 2001

The writer is a professor of economics at Harvard University.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Letter 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

HEADLINE: Letting the River Run 

BYLINE:  By Christopher Hallowell; Christopher Hallowell is the author of the forthcoming "Holding Back the Sea: The Struggle for America's Natural Legacy on the Gulf Coast."

 BODY:
The Bush administration has scolded the city of Davenport, Iowa, for its failure to build a permanent flood wall to protect itself from the swollen Mississippi River. But as the administration, through the Federal Emergency Management Agency, appears to advocate lining the river with levees and flood walls, it should look downstream to Louisiana, which has come to its own solution, for better or worse, about how to handle its end of the Mississippi.
 After a disastrous flood in 1927 killed hundreds of people, most in New Orleans, Louisiana built several gated spillways north of the city that allow the river to overflow its banks and dissipate over natural flood plains or swamps. 
 These spillways require that large swaths of land remain open and undeveloped (all are popular fishing, hunting and recreational havens during low-water periods), but they have saved the city and the petrochemical complexes between New Orleans and Baton Rouge from severe flooding any number of times. And where there are no spillways, the river is lined with levees and flood walls that protect the sprawl of housing subdivisions, malls and industrial buildings that continue to accumulate in ever thicker density.
The combination of spillways, levees and flood walls has worked. But there is still a problem south of New Orleans, where there are no spillways. Here, the river is permanently enclosed behind levees or flood walls almost all the way to the Gulf of Mexico, a distance of some 80 miles. 
Before these levees were built, floods would send tons of sediment and nutrients over the wetlands year after year, building and supporting a bonanza of natural wealth. These three million acres -- a quarter of the country's coastal wetlands -- are a nursery for much of the marine life in the Gulf of Mexico. They also protect low-lying coastal communities -- and New Orleans, too -- from hurricanes by acting as buffers against storm surges and by absorbing high water.
The leveed river can no longer provide sediment and nutrients. As a result, the wetlands that spread from its banks are dying; some 16,000 acres a year vanish as the coast sinks and erosion chews away at the weakened roots of plants. Livelihoods are threatened because the wetlands no longer nurture fish, shrimp and oysters. As the fishing economy wobbles, a culture of bayou life, with large families living off the land, begins to die. 
Louisiana is trying to stop the land from disappearing, recognizing that the only way to save the coast is to allow the Mississippi River into the wetlands. It uses what the Army Corps of Engineers calls "freshwater diversions." Downstream from New Orleans, huge pipes arching over the levees pump water into the devastated marsh. In Caernarvon, 15 miles south of New Orleans, a levee has been cut to provide room for an elaborate gate that permits the Mississippi's water to pass in limited quantities into the dying marsh. Hundreds of acres of wetlands have been restored through these means -- which are really no more than meager imitations of nature's inclinations. These freshwater diversions are also expensive and controversial, because they destroy oyster beds, upsetting the powerful seafood industry.
Before it pushes for continuous levees along the Mississippi, the Bush administration should consider the lessons of Louisiana. Flood plains serve a crucial purpose, and when a river as prodigious as the Mississippi is denied a place to send its excesses, the land itself, and the people who depend on it, suffer in the long run.

HEADLINE: Internet Used-Car Seller Closes Down 

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
IMotors.com, the online seller of used cars that in January hired the former Maytag chief executive Lloyd D. Ward to head its operations, has gone out of business.
 The company, based in San Francisco, made the announcement last Wednesday on its Web site, saying it was closing because of "lack of sufficient capital." The company had raised about $137 million in financing over the last two years. It operated three reconditioning plants for used cars and had about 700 employees. 
 In an interview yesterday, Mr. Ward, the chief executive, said that iMotors had been making tremendous progress and that the company had been on track for revenue of about $100 million this year. But he said investors were looking for more immediate profits and that one major investor decided to pull out. The others followed, he said.
"It wasn't because of the business," he said of the investors' decisions to pull out. "We were driving business growth. We were getting a lot of traction. But we weren't yet profitable."
Among the major investors in the privately held company was Vulcan Ventures, the venture capital fund of Paul Allen, co-founder of Microsoft. A spokesman for Vulcan Ventures did not return telephone calls.
IMotors was supposed to succeed by buying used cars, refurbishing them and then reselling them online. The company wanted to create a nationwide system with a recognized brand name. To do that, it had also hired Kiran Patel, the former chief financial officer at Cummins Engine. 
Mr. Ward, who gained a reputation as a supermarketer at blue-chip companies and became only the second black to head a Fortune 500 company, resigned from Maytag last November after a stormy 15-month tenure. He then shunned opportunities at several big corporations to join iMotors and try to bridge the old- economy/new-economy gap, he said.
Shortly after he joined iMotors he hoped it might turn into a Fortune 500 company. Now, the climate was too hard, he said. "What is driving many investors right now is fear," he said. "There wasn't a lot of discipline when things were going up and there's not a lot of discipline now."
Asked about his own future, Mr. Ward, 52, said he might return to a major corporation. "I'm clearly an N.B.A. player and this was a pickup game," he said. "I'm going to look around, but I don't know what I'm going to do next."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lloyd D. Ward was chief executive of IMotors.com, the online used-car seller that recently shut down. Investors had been pulling out. (Sam Morris for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Weak Economic Data Take a Toll on Nasdaq and Dow

BYLINE:  By Jonathan Fuerbringer 

 BODY:
The question nagging at stock and bond investors recently has been whether the economic slowdown is continuing or whether the worst is over and a recession has been avoided.
 In April, investors answered positively, after a very negative March, and pushed stocks higher, with the Nasdaq composite index climbing 15 percent and the Dow Jones industrial average rising 8.7 percent. 
 Prices in the bond market slipped and yields moved higher as some investors concluded that the Federal Reserve might not cut short-term interest rates as much as expected. Then last week, the government said that the economy grew at a 2 percent annual rate in the first quarter, twice the pace expected by analysts and twice the rate in the fourth quarter of last year. 
But economic data released yesterday, combined with reports from earlier in the week, suggested that the slowdown might be continuing. And today, the government is set to release employment data for April, which many analysts think will show the unemployment rate rising to 4.4 percent from 4.3 percent in March, with few jobs created.
Yesterday's news -- and the expectations for today's jobs report -- was enough to push stocks lower while bond prices rose. But it is not clear whether sentiment has truly changed. Stocks may have fallen just because they had risen so sharply that any negative news could trip them up. Bonds, on the other hand, had been selling off for several weeks and were ready for a rally.
The Dow fell 80.03 points, or 0.7 percent, to 10,796.65. The Nasdaq, which is heavily weighted with technology stocks, dropped 74.4 points, or 3.4 percent, to 2,146.20. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 18.85 points, or 1.5 percent, to 1,248.58.
In the bond market, the yield on the 10-year Treasury note fell to 5.20 percent from 5.28 percent Wednesday while the price, which moves in the opposite direction, rose 20/32, to 98 16/32. The 30-year Treasury bond rose 30/32, to 96 9/32. Its yield fell to 5.63 percent from 5.70 percent on Wednesday.
Among the negative data released yesterday were weekly claims for unemployment benefits, which rose to 428,000 in the week ended April 28, their highest level since March 1996. The four-week moving average of claims is now at the highest level since the fall of 1992. 
William Dudley, chief United States economist at Goldman, Sachs, said the claims data "definitely shows you that the labor market is deteriorating, and that makes you more worried about consumer spending." He is predicting that the unemployment rate in April rose to 4.5 percent while there was a decline of 100,000 payroll jobs.
While Goldman is not predicting a recession, it is expecting the economy to be softer for longer than some other forecasters. And Mr. Dudley said it would not take much to change his forecast to a recession.
Although growth in the first part of the year has been stronger than analysts thought, some still think that a recession is possible because of the effect of layoffs. If they continue to increase, these analysts argue, consumer confidence will decline as more workers lose their jobs and other realize that they have a friend or a relative who has been laid off. That would lead to a reduction in consumer spending large enough to start a recession.
Fed policy makers made a surprise cut of half a percentage point in short-term interest rates on March 18 and are expected to cut again when they meet on May 15. Mr. Dudley said he thought that Fed policy makers were worried "that things could break," which means they might make another half-point cut, which would bring the short-term interest rate target to 4 percent. A weak jobs report today would improve odds for a half-point reduction. Until this week's new economic data, many investors had reduced their expectation for the Fed's next move to a quarter-point.
At the same time, Mr. Dudley said there were some positive signs, including how far along the adjustment of inventories has gone.
In another negative report yesterday, the National Association of Purchasing Management said its index for the nonmanufacturing part of the economy fell to 47.1 in April from 50.3 percent in March. This decline indicates that the slowdown that has already pushed the country's manufacturing sector into a recession is spreading.
On Tuesday, the association reported that its factory index rose to 43.2 in April from 43.1 in March, but that was less than analysts had expected.
Adding to the negative news in the economic data are the almost daily reports of layoffs. Yesterday, Newell Rubbermaid, the maker of Calphalon cookware and Levolor blinds, said it would cut 3,000 jobs, or about 6 percent of its work force, over the next three years. Vitesse Semiconductor said it would cut 12 percent of its work force and reduce executive salaries. Newell Rubbermaid fell $1.49, to $25.85, while Vitesse dropped $3.38, to $34.39. The Nasdaq was led down by Intel, which fell $1.52, to $30.40, and Cisco Systems, which dropped $1.33, to $18.66. The Dow was led lower by I.B.M., which declined $1.70, to $113.70, and Microsoft, which fell $1.23, to $68.53.

HEADLINE: Elite French College Tackles Affirmative Action 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: ST.-OUEN, France 

 BODY:
In this town, where blocks of public housing and laundry lines dominate the landscape, few high school students even dream of going to France's most prestigious colleges. In fact, no senior has ever passed the entrance exam for the Institut d'Etudes Politiques just a few miles away in the Seventh Arrondissement of Paris. 
 But all that may be changing. The institute, known as Sciences Po, has for decades shaped France's ruling elite, from President Jacques Chirac and Prime Minister Lionel Jospin to the heads of most major companies. Now Sciences Po has announced an affirmative action program, the first such effort in France. 
 "The most interesting thing is that it lifts the psychological barrier," said Gerard Stassinet, principal of the Lycee Auguste Blanqui, a high school in St.-Ouen, whose students stand to benefit. "Immediately after the program was announced there was a new feeling in this school. Already the younger ones were beginning to think about the future, which just wasn't happening before." 
While Mr. Stassinet is enthusiastic, not everyone is applauding Sciences Po's decision to forgo admission strictly by test results, a concept long embraced in France as the best way to level the playing field between rich and poor. 
The decision to create just 20 slots for students from disadvantaged areas -- where many of the residents are immigrants from North Africa -- has caused an uproar in newspapers across the country. 
Some have applauded the program as a small step toward addressing a growing disadvantaged population in France, and the often unspoken racial issue it entails. But others see it as an attack on a tradition that has produced scholars of high quality as well as a slide into an American-style system. In the daily newspaper Liberation, one former professor at Sciences Po contended that from now on when a nonwhite graduate presents a diploma, it will automatically be suspect. "What hypocrisy," wrote Zair Kedadouche, adding that the program was reminiscent of the colonial days in Algeria when most Muslims were kept in their place, but for a few "good ones" who were allowed to mingle with the French. 
Another commentator, in Le Figaro, called the program an act of "political correctness" that embraced the American approach just when the United States was coming to realize the "perverse effects" of such methods. On the bulletin boards at Sciences Po, hand-written posters are chronicling a fierce battle by a conservative student group that is challenging the new admissions policy in court.
"This is really a publicity stunt," said Arnaud Legros, one of the leaders of the group. "The director of the school is giving himself a little pleasure -- soothing his social conscience. He has never even been to these neighborhoods. A test is the best because everyone is equal before a test." 
Increasingly, however, the French are beginning to question that tenet. 
Mr. Stassinet, the principal in St.-Ouen, has no doubts that the tests are now a barrier for the poor. "You create an exam and right away the rich get whatever it takes to prepare for the exam," he said. "They get the best schools and they can afford special help or tutoring to get there. But there are intellectual abilities here and other ways of measuring them. These are not children who have had violin lessons from the age of 4, but there are good minds here." 
Like many others, he points to the statistics on the student body at Sciences Po. In 1987, 77 percent of the students came from more privileged groups, with parents who were teachers, professionals, managers or owners of their own companies. By 1997, the figure had increased to nearly 82 percent. Fewer than 2 percent of the students came from working-class backgrounds. 
The director of Sciences Po, Richard Descoings, said it was obvious to him that coming up with a way of diversifying the student body had to be a priority. "Here at Sciences Po is where we form our elite for both business and government," he said. "When you have that responsibility, it is impossible not to ask yourself who is coming here. We thought about our social responsibility and we decided we had to do something."
But even Mr. Descoings says he has been amazed at the anger over his small effort, announced two months ago, which is being criticized both in principle and in substance.
Under Mr. Descoings's plan, up to 20 students from just seven high schools from poor areas around Paris will be accepted for the next school year (the three-year school has 2,500 students). The admission process for these 20 students will resemble that of American universities, with consideration given to test results, high school references, grades and an interview. 
Some critics find the selection of the seven high schools arbitrary and unfair and the selection process open to all sorts of prejudices. Mr. Descoings shrugs off that criticism, saying that Sciences Po could not deal with all the country's problems and wanted to get a plan in place fast. "We needed to stop making speeches and get to the action so this is what we were able to do," he said.
So far, Mr. Descoings has had the support of the Socialist government's minister of education, Jack Lang (another of the school's graduates), who has applauded the program for focusing attention on "the recruitment by caste and class" and the "need for a democratic country to diversify the social origin of its elite." 
Whether the school's initiative will survive the court challenge remains a question. Mr. Descoings said he was encouraged when the court recently turned down a request by the conservative student group for an immediate hearing. "It is impossible to predict what will happen," he said, "since there really has never been any other program like this."
Much of the program has been put in place hastily with a sense of experimentation. Facing the prospect of choosing students to recommend to Sciences Po, the high school principals decided to ask students who were interested to prepare a special report. The students had to collect articles from the press on a subject that interested them and then write two papers, one a synthesis of the articles, the other an analysis.
Mr. Stassinet said he was completely surprised by what he was able to see from this exercise. Students at his school whom he would never have recommended emerged as the most interesting thinkers, he said. Those who have applied from St.-Ouen include the children of domestic workers, immigrants and the unemployed, and the applicants and their families have been interviewed by dozens of newspapers and television stations in the last few weeks. 
In March, some of them toured Sciences Po, where many of the students wear expensive leather jackets and the latest styles as they stroll from class to class through the halls of several 18th-century mansions cobbled together to make a campus. 
According to one newspaper account, there were some awkward moments. One professor told the applicants that he wanted to extend his welcome "even though he did not think they should be there." 
"A diploma," the professor reportedly said, "should be earned."
But few students from the disadvantaged schools seemed deterred. "The more they don't want us here, the more I want to come," said one young man from St.-Ouen who dreams of returning to Senegal to help his country. "They need to realize that we are not all idiots."

HEADLINE: Net Income Drops 12% at Adidas-Solomon 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: HERZOGENAURACH, Germany, May 3 

 BODY:
Adidas-Salomon A.G., a leading maker of sporting goods, said today that its first-quarter net income dropped 12 percent, hurt by declining demand for its shoes in the United States and by higher financial expenses. 
 The company said profit fell to 46 million euros ($41 million), or 1.02 euros a share, from 53 million euros, or 1.16 euros, a year earlier. 
Sales rose 2.7 percent, to 1.6 billion euros, held back by a 6 percent drop in North America, to 445 million euros. 
 Its chief executive, Herbert Hainer, has said that he aims to make the brand "cool" in the United States, where a fashion for urban streetwear has hurt Adidas. It also faces price-cutting by Nike Inc., which is clearing inventory after its third-quarter profit fell 33 percent. 
Shares in Adidas fell as much as 0.72 euro, or 1.1 percent, to 67.23 euros. They have gained 2.3 percent so far this year, compared with a 4.9 percent decline in the benchmark DAX index. 
Financial expenses rose to 33 million euros from 13 million euros in the quarter as net debt rose along with interest rates, while the dollar gained 7.5 percent against the euro. Much of Adidas's production is paid for in dollars in Asia, while the company's biggest sales market uses euros, analysts said. 
The company, whose products include Salomon skis and inline skates and TaylorMade golf equipment, said it would stick to its forecast of a 15 percent increase in full-year earnings. Sales are expected to rise 3 percent to 5 percent, with gains in all regions except North America.
