HEADLINE: Political Memo; 
Potent Tool To Tip Race For Mayor: New Budget

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Of the many ways that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani may choose to influence the race to succeed him at City Hall, there is one that already stands apart for its potential effectiveness -- and it comes in the form of a thick, two-volume document released by the outgoing mayor at City Hall last week.
 That document is the executive budget for 2002. And by design or not -- at least one of the candidates believes it is certainly by design -- Mr. Giuliani's $39.5 billion budget has been driving the conduct of the mayoral race to a measurable degree ever since. 
 It is influencing what the candidates are already talking about, and it is likely, in the months ahead, to curtail their ability to ladle out expensive campaign promises. It could even, if Mr. Giuliani's warnings about tough fiscal times ahead take hold, influence the way voters measure the qualifications of his successor, putting a premium on fiscal management and experience.
There has been much discussion in political circles about the obvious ways Mr. Giuliani has kept a hand in the contest to succeed him -- from hammering Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller, one day, to ostensibly promoting the candidacy of Peter F. Vallone, the City Council speaker, the next.
But it is at least as noteworthy that Democrats in the last few days have been talking about tax cuts -- Mr. Giuliani proposed a $525 million cut for next year -- and public subsidies to build new stadiums for the Yankees and the Mets, which Mr. Giuliani is advocating once again. In both instances, their responses to Mr. Giuliani's eighth budget suggest the extent to which fiscal life in New York might be different in a Democratic City Hall, where tax cuts and city-financed stadiums are unlikely to be high on anyone's priority list.
The mayor's spare budget proposal, filled with cuts, has helped to rob from these candidates the luxury of being able to make the kind of freewheeling campaign spending promises that were so routine in last year's political campaigns, which took place in flusher times. All four major candidates say they will not be able to propose new spending programs -- whether it is Mark Green's pledge to subsidize college tuition to police officers or Fernando Ferrer's call for a 30 percent raise for teachers -- without offering an account of how they pay for it.
"It should be a definite, definite consideration for anybody who is running for mayor whether they are promising more than they deliver -- and what it's going to cost," Mr. Vallone said yesterday.
In this context, it is hardly a surprise that some of the Democratic candidates seem a bit annoyed at what they see as an attempt by an outgoing mayor to set the table for their election contest. 
"It's clear to me that the mayor's budget is less economic-based than it is politically based -- with the obvious goal of trying to create mischief in the campaign and handcuff his successor," Mr. Green said in an interview. He said it would not work. "The prevailing view is that he is now the straw stirring the drink and that his comments play an important role in the mayor's race," Mr. Green said. "I don't buy that. People know he's history."
History or not, all four are trying to accommodate the situation that Mr. Giuliani's budget has helped to create, if in different ways.
Mr. Hevesi called a news conference on Monday to attack the budget as fiscally irresponsible, warning that it would leave the next mayor with larger deficits because of the proposed tax cut and underestimated costs. Mr. Hevesi said his remarks were motivated by a professional concern about the fiscal health of the city -- but they served, not incidentally, to reinforce his efforts to present himself as the fiscal conservative in the field.
"Maybe the way we respond to the budget could indicate a distinction between us," Mr. Hevesi said of he and his opponents. "But I have a charter mandate. Ultimately, I have to certify that the budget is balanced and that we are able to market our debt. My response is not going to be calculated to, will this win votes or will this not win me votes."
Mr. Ferrer has seized on Mr. Giuliani's budget as evidence for his central campaign theme, what he describes as the mayor's history of neglecting a large part of New York. The Bronx borough president has attacked the budget, noting its minimal increase in education financing and the tax cut.
"The tax cut is a symbolic tip of the hat to his legacy, and his real legacy will be wreaking havoc on public education," Mr. Ferrer said.
Mr. Vallone has taken an entirely different approach. He has, by virtue of directly negotiating with Mr. Giuliani over the shape of the final spending and tax plan, a direct political interest in its outcome and is moving to try to claim some credit for a budget that he said would be "the crowning achievement for the mayor and the City Council."
Finally, supporters of Michael R. Bloomberg, the Republican businessman who is considering a race for mayor, said that the perception that the city was moving into bad times -- which is implicit in Mr. Giuliani's budget -- would enhance his appeal, given his business credentials and Mr. Giuliani's attempt to argue that Democrats could bring the city back into profligate fiscal times.

HEADLINE: BUSH WILL MODIFY BAN ON NEW ROADS FOR U.S. FORESTS 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3 

 BODY:
The White House will put in place Clinton administration regulations intended to protect national forests from development but will allow those rules to be amended case by case, senior administration officials said today. 
 The rules were issued within the last 15 days of the Clinton administration and never went into effect. 
 The White House decision, which is to be announced on Friday, in effectgives local officials the power to modify a plan that would have banned new road building and most logging on some 60 million acres of federal land, or about one-third of the national forests. 
One Bush administration official who outlined the decision tonight said that while the administration supported the broad intentions of the Clinton policy, the planned changes would address preliminary concerns raised by a federal judge. 
"The goal of protecting millions of acres of land throughout our country is an important goal," the official said, outlining an argument that Secretary Ann M. Veneman of the Agriculture Department is to make publicly on Friday. "And through local forest-management procedures we can address the judge's concerns."
The timber industry and many Western states strongly opposed the Clinton plan, which had been developed over three years, and had challenged the plan in federal court as being unwarranted and misguided.
Supporters of the approach taken by former President Bill Clinton said tonight that the administration's decision was intended to undermine the plan while allowing the White House to claim that its hands had been tied by the courts.
"It's essentially a gutting of the rules with words and phrases saying that they're keeping it in place," said Doug Honnold, managing lawyer of the Earthjustice Legal Defense Fund's office in Bozeman, Mont.
In Idaho, a spokesman for Gov. Dirk Kempthorne, a Republican, said the exact details of the administration's decision would determine how and whether his state and others would go forward with their legal challenge. 
"There are a number of issues raised by Western governors that the Clinton administration ignored in promulgating this rule, and we are looking forward to seeing how they will be addressed by the new administration," said the spokesman, H. D. Palmer.
Michael Klein, a spokesman for the timber industry's American Forest and Paper Association, said tonight that the industry would not comment on the administration's decision until it had been made public on Friday. 
Conservation groups and Democrats have criticized the Bush administration for many of its early decisions on the environment. In recent weeks, administration officials said, top aides to Mr. Bush, led by John Bridgeland, a domestic policy adviser, have tried to come up with an approach to the forest plan that might prove politically and legally palatable.
Opponents of the Clinton plan called it a top-down federal initiative that ignored local concerns by putting vast areas of public land off limits to logging, energy development, off-road vehicle use and other activity. 
In a preliminary opinion last month, Judge Edward J. Lodge of Federal District Court in Boise, Idaho, seemed inclined to uphold those concerns, saying that the process used to develop the rules represented "an obvious violation" of the federal law that spells out requirements for public participation in federal rule making. Judge Lodge deferred until this month a decision on whether to block the Clinton plan, as requested by the State of Idaho and Boise Cascade, the giant timber company. 
For decades, decisions about how national forest land should be managed have been delegated in nearly all instances to local Forest Service planners, who have historically taken into account the priorities of state and local officials and regional industries. The Clinton rule was an effort to lay out broad rules for some forest lands that could not be changed at the local level.
As outlined by administration officials today, the Bush approach would return much of that power to local Forest Service planners. 
With the announcement, the administration will make good on a promise to Judge Lodge to inform him by May 4 of its decision on how to proceed with the rule. 
Environmentalists and other supporters of the Clinton rules have noted that they were not made final until the end of a process that included scores of public meetings and prompted comments from more than a million people. 
Niel Lawrence, a senior lawyer with the Natural Resources Defense Fund who is based in Olympia, Wash., said of the White House decision, "This is a stealthy way to undo the rules without really owning up to what they're doing, while spinning it as fundamentally pro-environmental." 
The Clinton rules, announced on Jan. 5, were initially to have taken effect on Feb. 12. Implementation was postponed twice by the Bush administration, most recently until May 12, as part of a comprehensive review in which the new administration had declined until now even to defend the broad outlines of the rule in response to the court challenge.
The officials who spoke on condition of anonymity said the crux of the decision was that the forest-protection rules would now take effect, as scheduled, on May 12, barring any ruling to the contrary by Judge Lodge. But as its guidelines are put in place, they said, broad discretion will be permitted for challenges by state and local authorities.
"We're going forward with the protections under the rule, but we're going to address the concerns," an administration official said.
Among the concerns he cited was the effective bypassing of state and local officials on decisions about road building, logging and other activities, which the officials have said undermined their economic interests. 
The plan would affect dozens of national forests in 39 states, including the Tongass forest in Alaska, the largest of the forests and the one where the most permits for logging are still under consideration.

HEADLINE: Florida Leaders Sign Agreement For Overhaul of Election System 

BYLINE:  By DANA CANEDY 

DATELINE: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 3 

 BODY:
Six months after a chaotic election in Florida decided the protracted presidential race, state lawmakers have reached agreement on a bill that would do away with hanging chads, butterfly ballots and questions about determining voter intent.
 It would also require that ballots in extremely close elections be recounted by hand -- the very practice that Florida election officials and the Bush campaign had opposed so fiercely last year in their battle with Democrats who were insisting that manual recounts would tip the election to Al Gore. 
 After weeks of partisan debate and negotiations, House and Senate leaders signed an agreement this evening to ban punch-card ballot machines, give counties money for equipment and set guidelines for recounts.
The Florida House and Senate, both controlled by Republicans, are expected to approve the bill in largely ceremonial votes before the legislative session adjourns on Friday.
The changes would be in place for the state's next general election, in 2002, and the National Association of Secretaries of State said they would move Florida ahead of many other states in overhauling voting systems. 
"This would be one of the most comprehensive election reform packages that have been passed," Kay Albowicz, communications director for the association, said. "Ironically, the state of Florida, where the bomb went off, is one of the first states to rebuild."
Gov. Jeb Bush, who created an elections task force to recommend improvements the day after his brother won Florida's 25 decisive electoral votes, and thus the presidency, said he was eager to sign the bill into law.
"Election reform has been a top priority of mine as well as the leadership in both chambers of the Legislature this session," Governor Bush said. "I look forward to signing this much-needed legislation that will ensure every Floridian's vote counts as well as serve as a model for the rest of the nation."
His language echoed the mantra of the Democrats last year, when Mr. Gore pleaded with state officials and the courts to "count every vote." 
Terry McAuliffe, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, praised the bill, saying: "I commend the Florida Legislature for taking the leadership on this. I wish Jeb Bush would call his brother George to get the same type of action up here in the Congress."
Commenting on Florida Republicans' accepting such changes now that the election was over, Mr. McAuliffe said: "All the things we were attacked on before, like manual recounts, all of a sudden they're the biggest supporters. If we had had manual recounts a year ago, Al Gore would be in the White House."
When the Bush team sued to block recounts last November, James A. Baker III, leading the charge for the Republican candidate, said that with hand counts, "there would be countless opportunities for the ballots to be subject to a whole host of risks."
"The potential for mischief would exist to a far greater degree than in the automated count," Mr. Baker said. He could not be reached for comment tonight.
Representative Johnnie B. Byrd Jr., the No. 2 Republican in the Florida House, said tonight that manual recounts were being retained because the law had been "clarified" to set standards and conditions for conducting them.
The measure has not been without controversy. A provision that would have been a step toward automatically restoring the voting rights of felons was dropped in negotiations between the Senate, which favored it, and the House, which opposed it. Another concession that would eliminate state matching funds for out-of-state campaign contributions was denounced by the Democrats, who are counting on the money in part to help wage a campaign to unseat Governor Bush next year.
Republicans and Democrats alike agreed that Florida residents had demanded a deal on election changes in the current legislative session to avoid ever again becoming a national embarrassment.
"I think we have done what the citizens of Florida wanted us to do,and that is avoid what happened during the election of 2000," said Senator Lisa Carlton, a Republican on the conference committee that hashed out the election bill.
The legislation provides counties with $24 million over the next two years to replace outdated equipment. Counties with 75,000 residents or fewer will get $7,500 per precinct to pay for optical scanners; more populous counties will get $3,500 per precinct for the equipment. Counties that can afford more expensive touch-screen technology can opt for that system.
Counties would divide $6 million for better education of voters and poll workers and $2 million to create a central voter database.
The new law would require a hand review of all ballots in which more than one choice was marked or in which no choice was marked in an election with a margin of victory of a quarter of 1 percent or less. The secretary of state's office would establish rules for the manual review, including how ambiguous ballots would be counted. 
"There are a lot of good things we can be proud of," said Representative Lois J. Frankel, the House Democratic leader If the changes been in place last November, Ms. Frankel said, "Al Gore would be president."
That, of course, is where Republicans and Democrats differ on the changes. Nonetheless, they agree that the overhaul will put Florida in the forefront of election reform.
"I think the best thing they've done is aggressively tackled the problem and taken pretty substantial action," said Tim Storey, an elections analyst for the National Conference of State Legislatures. "This will essentially guarantee that the scenario that played out last year will never happen again in Florida."
Many of the provisions address the most severe problems in the last election. For instance, the new law would create provisional ballots to prevent disenfranchising citizens who were wrongly eliminated from the voter rolls, as many in heavily black precincts were in November because they had been mistakenly purged along with ex-convicts. The provision would enable people whose registration was in question to vote and later have the issue resolved and the ballot certified.
In addition, the statewide standard for recounts would eliminate confusion over counting questionable ballots, which became a point of contention and prompted several lawsuits when canvassing boards like those in Dade, Broward and Palm Beach Counties used different criteria than when canvassers counted them by hand.
Since the November election, more than 1,500 bills related to election changes have been introduced in all 50 states combined, the National Conference of State Legislators said. More than 130 have been signed into law, and more than 1,000 are pending in 35 states.
In Georgia, Gov. Roy Barnes has signed legislation to place touch-screen voting systems in all precincts. In Maryland, the Legislature passed a bill requiring the state and counties to split the costs of a new system.
Still, elections officials at a hearing on Capitol Hill last week were not optimistic about achieving meaningful nationwide improvements by the midterm elections next year. The economic downturn will make paying for the changes on many states' wish lists difficult and some are moving slowly, the officials said.
"Florida has proven a state can put the money there even with a lean state budget," said Ms. Albowicz, of the secretaries of state association. "It should restore voter confidence. People will ask critical questions."
One reason, she said, is that "everybody got a huge civic lesson last November."

HEADLINE: Ford Tries to Burnish Image By Looking to Cut Emissions 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 3 

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company reaffirmed its concerns about global warming today, but said that it did not support stiffer federal fuel-economy standards or the international Kyoto Protocol on greenhouse gas emissions as ways to address the problem.
 In its second "corporate citizenship report," Ford said that it had formed a committee of executives to examine ways to reduce the company's contribution to global warming. 
 The report estimated that Ford factories and vehicles around the world emitted about 400 million metric tons of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases a year, or about 2 percent of all emissions caused by people. 
"On the issue of climate change, there's no doubt that sufficient evidence exists to move from argument to action," Jacques Nasser, Ford's chief executive, said in a preamble to the report.
Environmental advocates, with whom Ford's leaders have held extensive discussions, said today that they were willing to overlook the automaker's continued reservations about tougher fuel standards and the Kyoto agreement. 
Instead, they praised Ford for being willing to address the issue of global warming, particularly in light of President Bush's recent disavowal of the Kyoto agreement.
"Ford's efforts to be a responsible corporate citizen," the Sierra Club said in a statement, "are in stark contrast with the Bush administration's irresponsible remarks trivializing energy efficiency and President Bush's broken promise on curbing global warming."
The burning of gasoline by automobiles is the second-largest source of carbon dioxide emissions in the United States, after power plants. Many scientists say that the emissions may be causing the earth's atmosphere to become warmer.
For its part, Ford is trying to establish an environmentally friendly image in an effort to sell more cars. Today's report highlighted voluntary commitments that it made last summer. The company said that it would increase the average fuel economy of its sport utility vehicles by 25 percent by 2005. It also said that it would start selling a gasoline-electric hybrid version of the Ford Escape sport utility in 2003.
General Motors and DaimlerChrysler have since said that they would match Ford by improving the gas mileage of their light trucks, a category that includes pickups and minivans as well as sport utility vehicles.
Martin B. Zimmerman, Ford's vice president for governmental affairs, told reporters today that continued research into ways to improve fuel efficiency, like fuel cells, would be more valuable than new government mandates that automakers increase the fuel economy of light trucks.
"The way to solve this issue," Mr. Zimmerman said, "is not with small, incremental change." 
G.M. and DaimlerChrysler echoed Ford's comments. Dennis Minano, G.M.'s chief environmental officer, said that, in particular, the automaker opposed increases in the fuel-economy standards for light trucks, which are allowed to burn 33 percent more gasoline per mile than cars.
William Clay Ford Jr., the chairman of Ford, was among the first corporate executives to raise the global warming issue, mentioning it in speeches since 1996.
Mr. Ford and a few of his aides drafted last year's corporate citizenship report, which attracted national attention with its candid discussion of the safety and environmental drawbacks of sport utilities.

HEADLINE: Utility Plans To Put Limits On Its Plants 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
Citing a growing concern about global warming, the Entergy Corporation, one of the nation's largest electric power generators, announced yesterday that it planned to cap its emissions of carbon dioxide over the next five years. 
 Entergy's decision comes weeks after President Bush reversed a campaign pledge to regulate the carbon dioxide emissions of power plants -- a reaction, many analysts said, to pressure from the utility industry. 
 Opponents of emission controls argued that the cost would damage the industry and the economy. 
But industry experts and some environmental advocates said yesterday that Entergy's shift showed that the industry's views on climate change were not monolithic. 
"It is incumbent upon every individual and business to take voluntary initiatives to limit greenhouse gas emissions and reduce the risks we face today," said J. Wayne Leonard, the company's chief executive. "Entergy's program will demonstrate that companies can do the right thing while remaining competitive and profitable."
Entergy, which is based in New Orleans and operates plants in six states, took pains to note that its decision was not meant as a slap at the Bush administration. 
The company's plan would cap its carbon dioxide emissions at last year's levels over the next five years, despite plans to significantly increase its power generation. About 17,500 megawatts of the electricity that Entergy generates in the United States is from fossil fuels, and it expects to increase that capacity by 5,000 megawatts over the next five years, mainly by building natural- gas-fired plants. 
The company estimated that it released about 50 million tons of carbon dioxide last year. Without the cap, new plants would add 5.5 million tons to its emissions. The pledge does not affect Entergy's nuclear plants, including the Indian Point 3 plant in New York, or its foreign holdings.
Entergy shares rose 20 cents yesterday, to $40.45, on a day when power company stocks generally were lower.
The company plans to work with Environmental Defense, an advocacy group based in New York, to develop its emissions reduction program. It will also be the first American power company to join the Partnership for Climate Action, a group including DuPont, BP Amoco and Royal Dutch/Shell, that has pledged to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by at least 80 million metric tons annually by 2010. 
Entergy is still trying to figure out how it will cut emissions. The company said that 80 percent of the reductions would come from its operations and the remainder from trading emissions credits -- essentially paying others not to pollute. 
Utilities in the Energy Department's Climate Challenge program sought to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases by 47.6 million metric tons by last year. Industry experts say Entergy's plans up the ante and may prompt other power companies to take similar steps.
A spokesman for Entergy said Mr. Leonard had been studying arguments about climate change for some time but decided to cap the company's emissions after listening to scientists at a conference on global warming that Entergy sponsored in New Orleans last September.
Environmental advocates offered cautious praise for Entergy's decision, with one activist noting that global warming is a crucial issue in Louisiana. 
"We're so low in the water here in Louisiana that we will be among the first and worst affected as seas rise," said Gary Groesch, executive director of the Alliance for Affordable Energy in New Orleans.

HEADLINE: In Argentina, More Room To Breathe 

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, May 4 

 BODY:
At just about every public ceremony, the Argentine economy minister, Domingo F. Cavallo, reminds his audiences that his mother nicknamed him "Lightning" as a child.
 Since his appointment six weeks ago, Mr. Cavallo has kept up a prodigious pace, with new tax, tariff, currency and budget plans announced almost daily, and sleep reduced to catnaps on red-eye flights as he crisscrosses the globe shoring up confidence about his country among foreign investors and bankers. 
 There has hardly been a day when Mr. Cavallo has not chased down and denied another rumor that Argentina was about to default on its $150 billion in foreign debt, or devalue the peso, or both, moves that could bring emerging stock and bond markets from Brazil to Hong Kong crashing down along with Argentina's markets. 
This week, he staved off the wolf at the country's door by putting the final touches on a new loan agreement with the International Monetary Fund. The deal gives the country a bit of slack on budget deficit targets for the second and third quarters, and opens the way for him to reduce debt payments by arranging a swap of as much as $20 billion in bonds. 
And he successfully lobbied the lower house of Congress to pass a bill that would change the basis for the peso's value from a strict peg to the United States dollar to an equal mix of dollars and euros, should those two currencies ever reach parity.
In keeping with his heterodox approach, mixing supply-side economics with protectionism, Mr. Cavallo, a 54-year-old Harvard graduate, granted the slumping beef industry subsidized lines of credit and offered tax cuts to struggling manufacturers. And ever the cheerleader, Mr. Cavallo began predicting this week that the Argentine economy, the second largest in South America after Brazil, would achieve a 5 percent growth rate by the fourth quarter, while almost every other economist has been forecasting gloom and doom. 
"I'm forced to move on different fronts at the same time, because it's a serious situation," Mr. Cavallo told foreign correspondents at a breakfast this week. "But I'm very optimistic." 
Despite his stellar reputation as the man who, in an earlier stint in the job, defeated hyperinflation in the early 1990's by pegging the peso to the dollar, Mr. Cavallo has yet to persuade Wall Street that his plans this time around are anything more than smoke and mirrors. A recent Bear, Stearns report gave his program only a 25 percent chance of succeeding.
Many Wall Street economists have called Mr. Cavallo's proposed tinkering with the currency peg a distraction that might actually undermine the competitiveness of Argentine goods on world markets if the euro rises in value. And they say his loosening of bank reserve requirements risks destabilizing the banking system. 
"Domingo Cavallo is like a death-row inmate, desperately seeking a stay of execution to stay alive for one more day," Walter Molano, head of economic and financial research for BCP Securities, wrote to his clients this week. "The capital markets will remain closed until Argentina restructures its debt." 
Mr. Cavallo's go-go style and upbeat talk have clearly succeeded on one front: dispelling perceptions that the government of President Fernando de la Rua was paralyzed, uncreative and incapable of rousing the country out of a three-year recession. But even if Mr. Cavallo has halted the downward spiral of Argentine consumer confidence, there is little evidence yet that the economy is responding.
"There are no signs in sight of an improvement in consumption," Roberto Alemann, a former economy minister, said this week. 
The government reported this week that tax revenue fell more than 9 percent in April from April last year, suggesting that the economy was continuing its slide and that a growing number of companies were suspending tax payments rather than borrow more money from banks as interest rates rise. The decline in tax revenue came despite a new tax on financial transactions, intended by Mr. Cavallo to stem tax evasion and help push the budget deficit below $6.5 billion, as the I.M.F. requires.
Argentina had to postpone a $750 million bond sale last week because of soaring interest rates, raising doubts internationally about whether the country can make an estimated $23 billion in interest payments this year.
Bank deposits in April declined by $2 billion, after a $3 billion drop in March, suggesting that a growing number of Argentines are moving their savings abroad. 
Mr. Cavallo is basing his hopes for a recovery on making it cheaper for companies to step up production, employment and exports, while cutting government spending by $1 billion this year and addressing the debt-service problem by fighting tax evasion. He, meanwhile, hopes to use his considerable persuasive powers to keep raising consumer confidence.
After being granted many of the extraordinary powers he sought from Congress, he has raised tariffs on consumer goods and put a tax on check-writing to raise revenue quickly. But over the longer term, Mr. Cavallo still promises a more supply-side approach to invigorating the economy, with cuts in payroll taxes and business income taxes. Eventually, he promises a complete retooling of the tax system, moving to reliance on simple value-added and income taxes.
So far, though, no matter what he has tried, prices of Argentine bonds and stocks have kept tumbling, and interest rates have kept rising.
"You see lots of investor advice saying 'underweight Argentina,' " Mr. Cavallo said. "We're trying to convince investors, but obviously we haven't convinced them yet. But I am optimistic that as soon as consumer optimism recuperates, growth will revive and economic prospects will improve."
Mr. Cavallo's ratings in opinion polls remain high, far better than those of President De la Rua and other political leaders. But his image in the media is beginning to falter. And if the political cartoons on the covers of weekly magazines here are any guide, he may already be running out of time. In his opening weeks, he was portrayed as the puppeteer who held Mr. De la Rua by the strings on his lap. Lately, he has been depicted as the emperor with no clothes.

HEADLINE: What, Us Worry?; 
Layoff: A Spring Break For Some In the Dot-Com Generation

BYLINE:  By MATT RICHTEL 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, May 4 

 BODY:
Until he was laid off in February, Andrew H. Way oversaw customer service and some sales operations at an Internet company, an $85,000-a-year job that demanded 12-hour days. But lately, since moving to Seattle, he has centered his life around snowboarding in the nearby Cascade Mountains, where he plans to spend the summer hiking and fishing.
 Mr. Way is desperately trying to recapture his youth -- at 28. 
 He had intended to take it easy after college and work part time, he said, but was instead caught in an economic whirlwind. "I'd say, 'Whoa, what just happened?' " Mr. Way recalled of his corporate odyssey. "Two years of my life just went by, and I've got shirts with buttons and pants that are ironed and I'm working like an adult." He added, "I just sort of stepped away from myself for three and a half years." 
Mr. Way was part of the wave of young, educated immigrants to the Bay Area who were courted and loved, seemingly unconditionally, by employers during the dot-com boom. With that courtship now abruptly ended, workers who were laid off by the tens of thousands are dealing with being jilted in different ways -- some looking for work, others exploring how to pay debt they accrued.
But despite an economy that continues to deteriorate -- with layoffs and job losses spreading -- many here express little panic. Indeed, a number of them, like Mr. Way, are instead seeking to hit rewind, or at least pause, on their fast-forward careers. Living on savings they built up during the boom and still unburdened by mortgages or children, they are taking time off, planning extended summer travels and catching their breaths after a dot-com twister that picked them up after college and, just as suddenly, set them back down.
That attitude provokes concern from parents and even some experts who say some young people are being cavalier. Elders who sound the alarm assert that jobs may not be so plentiful or high paying -- or there might even be a full-fledged recession -- by the time those taking extended breaks decide to jump back in.
"They had this extraordinary opportunity to have their fantasy workplace in real life," said John A. Challenger, chief executive at Challenger Gray & Christmas, a Chicago job placement firm that tracks layoffs. Now, Mr. Challenger added, "it's like they're going to go back to the beginning of the tape and start the way most people start when they leave university."
Mr. Challenger's firm reports that dot-com companies announced in April that they would cut about 17,500 jobs, bringing the year's total to 51,500 and already eclipsing last year's total of more than 41,000. The ax will hit the San Francisco Bay Area the hardest. But Mr. Challenger said anecdotal evidence suggested that many younger people who had been laid off were approaching the news "very blithely," an attitude he attributed to the fact they have never experienced a downturn before.
Indeed, he and others who are more cautious are preaching to a generation whose opinions are informed by a life of tip-top economic times. For those in their 20's, their occupational lives have been characterized by uninterrupted demand. During the last downturn, in the late 1980's and early 1990's, their big worries involved acne and curfew, and many cannot fathom the thought of a prolonged economic slide.
"My dad's definitely got a different outlook," said Jeff S. Merrick, 25, who was laid off April 12 and recently left on a monthlong vacation to Costa Rica, stretching a 10-day trip he had planned. "When I said I was extending the trip, his first words were: 'A month? Don't you have to look for a job?' "
The younger Mr. Merrick, who was Mr. Way's roommate in San Francisco, might be forgiven for disagreeing with his father given his rapid career ascent. He graduated from the University of Montana in 1998 with a business degree, but got his first job offer six months before graduation; he was hired by Andersen Consulting to work in the Bay Area.
He spent 22 months at Andersen, now named Accenture, in a $35,000-a-year job, before he decided he wanted to expand his "roles and responsibilities." There was no dearth of places willing to let him do so. He said he could have his pick of "probably 10 different jobs." Ultimately, he took a position as a consultant at Electron Economy, a software consulting company in Cupertino that paid $65,000 a year. The job also required him to commute 40 minutes each way. 
He is now in Central America with his girlfriend, Kelly S. Lack, who was laid off on March 30 from a company called ZipReality.com, an online real estate broker where she earned around $65,000 as a marketing-communications manager. Ms. Lack, 25, said the timing of their respective layoffs "couldn't have been better."
Ms. Lack asserted that the layoffs were forcing her and her peers to relax. "My generation is so regimented -- we went through school, got jobs," said Ms. Lack, who had a job waiting upon graduation from the University of California at Berkeley in 1997. "These layoffs are good because they're teaching us to let go."
Echoing sentiments of others of her generation, Ms. Lack said her layoff was "kind of a relief." Indeed, some of those people laid off said they knew the hammer was coming down, leaving them with two overriding questions: exactly when would they be laid off, and how much severance would they get? Ms. Lack got two weeks of vacation, on the stingy side as dot-com severance goes, and is using some of the $5,000 to $10,000 of savings she set aside to carry her to a new job.
Mr. Merrick, who got 10 weeks of severance pay, said the time was ripe for a break. "At this stage in life, with a lack of responsibility, with no family or kids to worry about, if you're smart and saved up," he said, "you should definitely take advantage of this opportunity." Not that he was turning a blind eye to fun while he worked: last year, he managed to go on vacation in New Zealand and Australia, fish in Alaska and helicopter ski in Canada.
Mr. Merrick plans to take a bit more time off when he returns, then start looking for a new job. "I'm definitely not looking for a 30 percent increase -- I'm looking at realistically making $70,000 to $75,000," he said of his job requirements. "There are definitely jobs out there that offer that."
Mr. Challenger, the job placement executive, while saying such aspirations may be unrealistic, conceded that economic conditions could sparkle again. The Bay Area and California economies are still surprisingly strong. In March, the first month that the number of jobs fell nationwide, California added 57,000 jobs, 2,000 of them in Santa Clara County, the heart of Silicon Valley. Though the county's unemployment rate rose slightly, to 2.2 percent, it remains at nearly full employment.
"It looks more and more like it was a bubble, but we don't know that for sure," Mr. Challenger said, adding that a lot of people of the older generation are saying that younger people "are going to get their comeuppance, but who knows?"
Stephen Levy, director of the Center for Continuing Study of the California Economy, said evidence suggested that well-educated, skilled workers were still in demand. "There is not really a recession for highly skilled people," he said. "The market for college graduates, even with dot-com volatility, is enormously strong."
This is just as it was when Mr. Way graduated from the University of Montana in 1997 and dove into the job market, in spite of himself. After he graduated, he traveled around the country for a year, then returned home to the Seattle area, where he intended to fish, hike and water ski. To support his outdoor habits and free his afternoons for play, he took a $10-an-hour job at Amazon.com, working from 5 a.m. to 2 p.m. (He could leave at 1 p.m., he said, if he didn't take lunch).
But Amazon had other plans for him. Within 14 months, the company had given him four promotions, and he wound up in a $33,000-a-year position, working 12-hour days. Not only did his leisure time wane, he said he got caught up in the "addictive" pace of work, and eventually decided to leave Amazon because he did not feel there was sufficient room for advancement.
Mr. Way then moved to Missoula to take a position at a dot-com operated by friends, who soon relocated Mr. Way to San Francisco. In March of last year, living in San Francisco and frustrated in his work for the Montana-based company, which provided local entertainment information and news for Web sites, he again went job hunting and found opportunities bountiful.
"I was offered a job at 11 or 12 places," he said, noting that a standard part of the courtship ritual was for the companies to "push their A-list of V.C. firms" at him. He took a position at Buylink, an Internet company aimed at marrying makers of wholesale goods with retail stores, whose venture capitalist backers included the marquee firm Hummer Winblad.
Mr. Merrick, and a third roommate in their three-bedroom house five minutes' drive from the ocean, fared equally well. "You should have seen our house when we were living there during our prime," Mr. Way recalled. "The house was chock full of surfboards, five pairs of skis, snowboards, surfboards, windsurfing gear. We had three nice, nice cars parked outside."
But it came crashing down just as quickly. Mr. Way said Buylink was burning through its funds -- the company had acquired $5 million in venture-capital-backed financing in April last year. In February, Mr. Way became one of the company's layoff casualties.
"I definitely had some strong emotional ties there," he said, adding of the company: "It's devastating to think it's not going to work."
Mr. Way's misery had company, as the layoff bug hit the household hard. All three residents lost their jobs this year because of cost cuts. They jokingly refer to being laid off as getting a visit from "the can man."
These days, Mr. Way is working part time at a camping store, earning $7 an hour, so he can spend his free time playing in the mountains and reading. He said he was enjoying his downtime but he did have some trepidation about the future. He fears that when he and his peers decide to work again, the opportunities will be a lot less lucrative than they were during the boom.
"I was way ahead of myself in terms of actual salary," he said. "I realize I won't make that until I'm 40 or 45 -- you know what I mean? There aren't that many $75,000-a-year marketing manager jobs available."
It's amazing, he said, "what people in their mid- to late 20's expect now out of a job."
Mr. Way, despite his concerns that he may face a salary cut, is not willing to test the premise just yet. He plans to spend the summer fishing and hiking -- just as he had hoped to three years ago, before the boom came along. "I'm doing all the things," he said, "I was doing before."

Above, for-lease signs have become a common sight in the Bay Area as more and more dot-coms have announced layoffs. (Photographs by Peter DaSilva for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS AND BONDS; 
More Bad News, and the Stock Markets Are Happy to Hear It

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
As investors struggled to interpret a surprisingly negative report on unemployment, stocks dropped sharply early yesterday morning but quickly completed a somersault and posted fresh gains.
 Investors this week learned to love, or at least to live with, bad news, and the major gauges posted modest gains for the week as analysts began to anticipate somewhat more aggressive interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. 
 The reversal in the market, which was completed by 11 a.m., reflected deep divisions in perceptions of the economy's state and what, if anything, the Fed could do about it.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 154.59 points, or 1.4 percent, to 10,951.24, near its high for the year of 10,983.63, reached on Feb. 1. The Nasdaq composite index rose 45.33 points, or 2.1 percent, to 2,191.53, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 18.03 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,266.61. 
"We're at this seemingly anomalous situation where stocks rise on bad news," said David G. Dietze, president of Point View Financial Services, a money management firm in Summit, N.J.
The bad news came at 8:30 a.m., when the Labor Department reported that the unemployment rate climbed to 4.5 percent last month after the elimination of 223,000 more jobs from American business payrolls. The reported loss was the largest one-month decline since February 1991.
While regular trading had not yet begun, S.& P. 500 futures contracts, which are traded throughout the night, almost exclusively by professional money managers, fell 1.4 percent immediately, moving below 1,240 from 1,255. The contracts stayed below 1,240 until about 9:30 a.m.
Soon after, when the stock market opened, the S.& P. 500-stock index started just below 1,240 as well. But stock prices climbed quickly, and the prices of futures contracts followed.
Though analysts offered various explanations for the quick turnabout, perhaps none seemed as telling as a series of notes issued by Merrill Lynch, which did a quick turnaround of its own. In a note issued to clients just before 9:30 a.m., the firm's economists wrote that the economy was "beginning to look recessionary." 
Less than an hour later, the same firm wrote that "after further consideration, we are not, at this point, moving to a recession forecast."
Bruce Steinberg, Merrill's chief economist, said the apparent reversal was a result of an error by a person who tried to summarize his oral remarks, but that the whole incident "was a good reminder of what happened to the market this morning."
Treasury bond prices fell on the jobs data. The 10-year Treasury note fell 1/32, to 98 15/32. Its yield was unchanged at 5.20 percent. The 30-year bond fell 15/32, to 95 26/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.67 percent from 5.63 percent.
After viewing the jobs data, several analysts said they expected the Fed to lower interest rates by an additional half-point when it meets on May 15. They had previously expected a quarter-point cut.
If that perception drove stock prices higher, investors reacted oddly because a cut of a quarter-point more than previously expected "shouldn't have nearly as much of a difference on the economy as it made in one day," said Owen B. Fitzpatrick, who oversees $8 billion in stocks for the private banking group at Deutsche Bank's Bankers Trust unit.
Several analysts said the market's movement reflected a split between investors who thought interest rate cuts would soon revive corporate earnings and those who thought a recession in earnings would seep increasingly further into the economy's underpinnings.
Many money managers who have increased the cash levels of their portfolios now fear that the market has reached a bottom and that they will miss out on rising prices, some analysts said.
As optimism about the economy won the day, stocks that are sensitive to economic trends rose. Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing gained $2.24, or 1.9 percent, to $119.99. J. P. Morgan Chase gained $1.60, or 3.27 percent, to $50.60. 
Microsoft rose $2.22, or 3.24 percent, to $70.75, and I.B.M. rose $2.16, or 1.9 percent, to $115.86. 
While some investors may have panicked the moment the jobs report was issued, a different sort of panic set in as the day wore on, the kind that has become increasingly common as investors have begun flinching less at bad news.
David Henwood, chief investment officer for Raymond James & Associates, described that kind of panic: "I didn't buy tech when it was cheap. People are telling me the lows are in place, and you've got to use weakness to establish positions, and you can't sit on money when the market is moving."

HEADLINE: Pivotal Senators Find Flaws In Fine Print of Budget Plan 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4 

 BODY:
When Republican lawmakers return to the Capitol next week, they may find that the budget agreement they worked out with the White House this week is not the done deal they thought it was when they left for the weekend.
 Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, the leader of a group of 13 other Democrats and 2 Republicans who hold the balance of power on the budget in the Senate, told associates today that he had just read the fine print of the measure adopted by Senate and House conferees and that he was dissatisfied with the way one section on tax cuts was written. 
 "There is a great deal of concern that the conference report does not meet the terms and conditions he had agreed to," Mr. Breaux's spokeswoman, Bette Phelan, said. 
One of the Republicans in Mr. Breaux's group, Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont, was said to be unhappy that the negotiators had dropped from the final agreement $225 billion in additional allotments for education. "He has deep concerns," said Mr. Jeffords's spokesman, Erik Smulson. "Right now, you'd have to put him in the leaning-against category."
Without the support of Mr. Breaux and Mr. Jeffords, the agreement would probably be defeated in the evenly divided Senate.
The Senate and House had planned to vote on the agreement on Thursday. But the measure became snagged over technicalities before a final version could be printed. 
About 8 p.m. Thursday, the Senate decided to postpone its final vote until next week. And the House did likewise at about 1:30 this morning when two of the printed pages in the measure turned out to be missing because of a clerical error.
On Thursday evening, Mr. Breaux met with Republican leaders and was persuaded that the final version, still unprinted at this point, was precisely what he had agreed to -- $1.25 trillion in tax cuts in the 2002 fiscal year through the 2011 fiscal year, and an additional $100 billion in immediate tax reductions in the 2001 fiscal year (which ends Sept. 30) and in the 2002 fiscal year.
The understanding was that the $100 billion would be designed to stimulate the economy and that it would affect what taxpayers owed on the income they earned in this calendar year.
After the meeting, Mr. Breaux said he was "on board" with the Republican leaders.
But this morning, Mr. Breaux told associates, he read the printed version and learned that the $100 billion could be spread out over 11 years, although the measure stated that it was the sense of the Congress that it should be used in the 2001 and 2002 fiscal years. Mr. Breaux said he would insist on more precise language before votes were cast next week.
The section Mr. Breaux objects to was written by House negotiators, said Robert G. Stevenson, communications director for the Senate Budget Committee. "We have been talking with Mr. Breaux, and we'll continue to have conversations with him," Mr. Stevenson said.
Mr. Breaux's concern involved the tax aspects of the agreement, but other senators like Mr. Jeffords are concerned that the spending level for the next fiscal year is too low.
Initially, the House approved a 4 percent increase in spending -- what President Bush requested -- for the one-third of the budget outside interest on the debt and automatic benefit programs like Social Security and Medicare. This money would go for everything from schools to battleships. The Senate raised the figure to more than 8 percent, and the Republican negotiators compromised at 5 percent.
But on Thursday night, to resolve a jurisdictional dispute in the House, lawmakers decided to exclude nearly $6 billion allocated for emergencies like natural disasters.
There is little practical effect. Money for emergencies has never been part of the budget before and has always been spent as needed.
But the political effect was to bring the spending level down to a 4 percent increase over this year, making it appear that the president got exactly what he wanted.

HEADLINE: New Protests In Old Conflict With Vietnam; 
The Montagnards Bring Their Fight to New York

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
There was an anti-Vietnam protest in New York yesterday.
 Even before the conflict the Vietnamese call "the American War" sucked in a generation of young soldiers from the United States -- a war brought back to attention in recent days by Bob Kerrey and his memories of a 1969 raid on a village in the Mekong Delta -- a group of independent people in the Central Highlands of Vietnam made the fateful decision to side with the Americans against Hanoi and communism. 
 "It wasn't a mistake; it was the right thing to do," said Rong Nay, 55, who took part yesterday in a round of demonstrations against what he described as Hanoi's unending persecution and discrimination against the Montagnards -- a minority of 700,000 isolated people from at least five ethnic tribes in a country of more than 77 million, mostly ethnic Vietnamese. "During the war we fought alongside each other like brothers," he said of the American soldiers, who called their tribal buddies 'yards. 
The Montagnards (pronounced mohn-tahn-YARDS), or "mountain people" in the language of colonial France, were always scrappy. They didn't like the Americans' allies, the South Vietnamese, either, but that side seemed the lesser of two evils. All the Montagnards wanted was to be left alone in the chilly, dense green hills. When Hanoi's army took over the South in 1975, that hope disappeared. Mr. Nay went underground -- or, more accurately, into the forest -- and became deputy commander of a long, fruitless rebellion against Hanoi before fleeing Vietnam for the United States in the 1980's.
But why should the Montagnard rebellion resurface on the streets of New York this week?
Blame globalization.
Vietnam is a big coffee exporter and plantations are spreading into the highlands, flattening forests and taking over land that the Montagnards consider ancestral territory. In February, more than 20,000 people from tribal groups around Buon Ma Thuot staged the largest antigovernment demonstrations in Vietnam since the country's unification, prompting a military crackdown. More Montagnards fled Vietnam into neighboring Cambodia. Some of them arrived in this country only weeks ago after being hustled out of Cambodia by the United Nations high commissioner for refugees.
For the Montagnards who came to America, the adjustments have been difficult. But because they know that Hanoi is seeking American investment, about 300 Montagnard exiles boarded buses in North Carolina, where many of them live, and headed for the American Stock Exchange.
They want Americans to boycott the robusta coffee of Vietnam, which is generally known for its coarse flavor and often used for instant blends, and withhold investments that ultimately could endanger more minority livelihoods. They held up handmade signs in Chinese, Vietnamese, French and English -- a catalog of their past -- and played flutes and sang songs in their Rade language.
"I have nothing against coffee," said Y-Bin Enuol, 37. "I just want my land back so the plantations will belong to us."
H'Go Eban, 45, was marveling that in a few short weeks she had found her way to the heart of capitalism from the hills of Vietnam to keep the fight alive. "I am at peace here," she said, to the din of traffic on Trinity Place.
Next, on a day with weather a little like Saigon's in the summer, the Montagnards moved on to the United Nations to demand recognition as an endangered people -- they are thought to be the hill region's earliest settlers, of Mon-Khmer and Malay-Polynesian descent -- and finally to Vietnam's diplomatic mission to demonstrate for equal rights to land, education and, if necessary, emigration.
The Montagnards have other grievances that predate the encroachment of plantations, the demonstrators said. After the army of North Vietnam overran the South in 1975, Hanoi began to set up new economic zones to resettle people from overpopulated regions of a country with little land to spare. The Montagnards, who also call themselves the Dega people, began to be pushed higher into less hospitable land. Most of them were Christians: Roman Catholics converted by the French or Protestants won over by American missionaries, among them evangelicals who have been singled out by the government.
"After '75, we didn't have the right to live," said Nem, 42, who fled Vietnam last month and did not want to identify himself fully because some of his family members are also planning an escape.
"Our churches were closed and we had to worship at home," he said through a translator. "They brought in a million people to occupy our land. The security is very tight. The Vietnamese do not trust the Montagnards. But we do not plan to overthrow the government. We only want our rights."
Hanoi has its own set of problems with them. From the early 1960's, some of the Montagnards were being recruited and trained by the United States Central Intelligence Agency. Although the American government abandoned them to their fate after the fall of Saigon and began to admit them as refugees only after 1986, they are still supported by American veterans and civilian-aid officials who worked with them more than 25 years ago, making them suspect in Hanoi's eyes. In fact, veterans of the Special Forces have helped the Montagnards plan the New York demonstrations. There were some Green Berets on gray heads in the crowd yesterday.
After the protests around Buon Ma Thuot in February, Vietnam warned other organizations and pro-democracy dissidents, including intellectuals in the hill country city of Dalat, not to sympathize with the Montagnards. Protests stopped.
Kay Reibold, who runs the Vietnam Highlands Assistance Project at Lutheran Family Services in Raleigh, N.C. -- which has resettled hundreds of Montagnards in the United States -- said that the Vietnamese government has made it difficult to assist them in the highlands.
On Thursday, the Vietnamese government sharply criticized an American panel's recommendation that Congress not ratify a trade pact with Vietnam until the rights of all religious groups were recognized. The panel, the United States Commission on International Religious Freedom, said earlier this week that Hanoi should be asked to free dissidents and restore religious sites to the churches. 
Vietnam's Communist Party newspaper, Nan Dhan, countered by saying that it was the United States, not Vietnam, that was guilty of "mistakes and crimes," as proved by the case of Mr. Kerrey, the former United States Senator from Nebraska, now the president of New School University, who acknowledged recently that civilians were killed in a raid he led on the village of Thanh Phong in South Vietnam in 1969.
But Vietnam, trying to become part of the world economy, may no longer be able to escape the international human rights scrutiny that often accompanies globalization. 
The demonstrations yesterday came a week after another group of Vietnamese exiles living in several countries and young Vietnamese-Americans met with a United Nations human rights official, Goro Onogima, to talk about the plight of religious leaders and democracy advocates in Vietnam, and to ask for the appointment of a special envoy to monitor human rights there.
Vanessa Bui, of the Vietnamese Culture and Sciences Association, went to last week's meeting to plead for attention to the problems of intellectuals. She said that more than a quarter-century after the fall of Saigon, writers and thinkers were still "in and out of hard-labor camps."
The Rev. Le Huu Nguyen, a Roman Catholic priest who is executive director of the International Committee for Religious Freedom in Vietnam, said his goal was "to raise concern about the oppression and persecution of all religions in our country."
He was joined in the delegation last week by the Venerable Dr. Trich An Hue of the Vietnamese American Unified Buddhist Congress, Chau Nguyen of the Hoa Hao Buddhist sect and the Rev. Liem Thanh Nguyen of the Cao Dai movement.
And Pham Dinh De, president of the National Vietnamese-American Voters League, brought documentation on arbitrary arrest and detention from the State Department's annual human rights report to argue his case. "All the Vietnamese people need help," he said.
After their protest at the United Nations yesterday, some of the Montagnards, whose budget did not allow for a New York City hotel stay, bought hot dogs from a nearby street vendor. Others ate food that they had brought from North Carolina. Then they boarded the bus and settled in for the long ride home.

An article on Saturday about the Montagnards, a group of ethnic minorities formerly allied with the United States and now protesting their treatment by the Vietnamese government, misstated the name of a Buddhist leader who recently met with a United Nations official to discuss religious persecution in Vietnam. He was Dr. Thich An Hue of the Vietnamese American Unified Buddhist Congress, not Trich An Hue.
An article on Saturday about the Montagnards, former allies of the United States who are protesting their treatment by the Vietnamese government, misspelled the name of the Communist Party newspaper that responded to their charges. It is Nhan Dan, not Nan Dhan.

HEADLINE: In Racketeering Trial, Well-Dressed Strip Club Takes the Stage 

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, May 4 

 BODY:
For 14 years, the Gold Club has been the destination of choice for a restless segment of the city's huge convention business, clusters of boisterous men footloose in the city and eager to spend those precious evenings away from home in the company of nude dancers and expensive cigars. Shuttle buses to the club leave regularly from the city's best hotels.
 Starting next week, however, the city's more adventurous tourists may just as well ask their concierge to direct them to the federal courthouse downtown, where arguments in the Gold Club racketeering trial will begin after 18 months of legal preparation. 
 For pure salaciousness and dark intrigue, the trial is likely to rival anything that goes on in the private back rooms of the club itself. 
Over most of the summer, federal prosecutors will try to prove that the club was a cash conduit to the Gambino organized-crime family of New York, which they say provided protection in exchange. The club and its owner, Steven E. Kaplan, overcharged and double-billed the credit cards of unsuspecting customers, according to a federal grand-jury indictment issued in November 1999, adding to the unreported income of Mr. Kaplan and the Gambino family.
And most provocatively, the government charged that the club's dancers were ordered by their employers to provide sexual services to a long list of professional athletes and other celebrities whose presence at the club helped raise its profile. In one example of what the grand jury called organized prostitution, the indictment said the club flew several of its dancers to Charleston, S.C., in the spring of 1997 to perform a "lesbian sex show" and have sex with members of a professional basketball team. 
Lawyers involved in the case say the government's witness list is likely to include professional athletes like Patrick Ewing, Dennis Rodman, Terrell Davis and Jamal Anderson, among many others. None of the athletes are charged with a crime -- no money is alleged to have changed hands in the sexual transactions -- but last month Judge Willis E. Hunt Jr. of United States District Court ruled that testimony regarding sexual activity at the club was admissible whether or not it constituted prostitution. The ruling all but guaranteed that the witness list would resemble a box score or a gossip column, supplemented by dancers who may identify their private clientele.
Another possible witness is John A. Gotti, who federal investigators say was the acting head of the Gambino family after his father, John J. Gotti, was imprisoned for life, and before he himself was imprisoned in 1999 for racketeering and extortion. The younger Mr. Gotti, who prosecutors said was a friend of Mr. Kaplan's, was transferred from upstate New York to the federal penitentiary in Atlanta on April 25, but prosecutors will not confirm that they intend to call him as a witness.
The seven defendants in this initial trial from the indictment -- who include Mr. Kaplan, several colleagues and an Atlanta police officer -- have pleaded not guilty and hired some of the city's best-known and most ferocious defense lawyers. The defense team said the government had built its case on untrustworthy criminals and denied any ties to organized crime. On Monday, the lawyers began asking potential jurors their opinions about prostitution and the HBO show "The Sopranos," and Judge Hunt has already suggested that testimony could continue through Labor Day.
A Mafia-themed trial like this one, commonplace in the Northeast, is a novelty in Atlanta, never an underworld hotbed. It has generated enormous local interest, with newspaper and television accounts of every legal move. (The Atlanta Journal-Constitution's Web site offers to e-mail readers regular trial updates.) A doorman at the club said the publicity had significantly increased business, and the seven lawyers involved do not seem to mind the attention.
"In 20 years of practicing here, I can't think of any case in Atlanta that's ever involved New York Mafia allegations," said Donald F. Samuel, a prominent local defense lawyer who is representing Larry Gleit of Dix Hills, N.Y., the club's financial officer. "It's not a typical Georgia case. Of course, my client and Kaplan are just nice Jewish boys from Long Island."
The case has also shed light on Atlanta's growing distinction as a capital of the nude-dancing industry. The city's 22 "gentlemen's clubs" rival in number only those of Miami and Houston, thriving on Atlanta's convention business and its political tolerance. While Northeastern cities have struggled to restrict sex businesses, the industry has grown unfettered in many Bible Belt areas, and Atlanta is by far the largest city that allows alcohol to be served in bars where full nudity takes place.
"Yes, God bless them for that," said Don Waitt, publisher of Exotic Dancer magazine, an industry publication. "And it's got good weather. A lot of dancers don't want to live in places like Milwaukee."
With few other major attractions to entertain them, conventioneers in the city descend on the clubs each evening in taxicabs and shuttle vans, dropping tens of millions of dollars a year into the city's economy. At the Gold Club, a hulking black structure in Midtown with two gold lions by the door alongside a somewhat more menacing security staff, limousines and expensive cars pull up to the valet parking entrance in an unending stream. While other clubs have developed a more blue-collar clientele, the Gold Club has worked to attract celebrities from the worlds of sports and entertainment, hoping that lesser-known dance enthusiasts would follow. Much of the trial will be devoted to describing just how important such business was.
"It's sort of like the Studio 54 effect," a former employee of Mr. Kaplan's told the grand jury, according to a transcript obtained by The Journal-Constitution. "The more the word went out on the street, the more people wanted to come to your club."

HEADLINE: In Rockland Suburb, Deep Racial Change Melts Into the Everyday 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: HILLCREST, N.Y., May 4 

 BODY:
In the 1960s, this unassuming bedroom community in Rockland County attracted secular Jews from Brooklyn and the Bronx. They liked the affordable starter homes, the suburban hush and the bearable commute. In the 1990s, Hillcrest attracted immigrants from Asia and the Caribbean, often by way of Brooklyn or the Bronx. They liked the affordable starter homes, the suburban hush and the bearable commute.
 The changes in Hillcrest and in the composition of the Rockland County communities nearby reflect the increasing heterogeneity of suburban areas once assumed to be overwhelmingly white. But the shifts also show how racial change, particularly in sprawling suburbs, can occur not just relatively amicably but sometimes without attracting much notice. 
 Hillcrest lost a greater percentage of whites in the 1990s than any other place in New York, and since 1980 it has gone from almost all white to only one-fifth white. Hillcrest now has Rockland's highest percentage of African-Americans and Asians, plus a growing number of Hispanic residents, making it one of the state's most diverse communities. 
The change is news to many of the people living here, though.
"No -- no, the census is lying, the census is lying," insisted Winston Dyke, 68, a Jamaican immigrant and retired businessman who moved to the area 33 years ago. "I thought Hillcrest was predominantly white."
To be sure, some of the whites who left Hillcrest were fleeing nonwhites, some residents say. But other residents say those who left were a hard-working group of pioneers who either died, retired to Florida or sought roomier expanses. And residents credit local institutions with embracing, not resisting, diversity in a place that lost 52 percent of its white population in the 1990s.
"I think it happened nonchalantly," said Ryan S. Karben, the Democratic majority leader of the Rockland County Legislature who grew up in Hillcrest and now lives in nearby New Hempstead. "I don't know that there's a way to identify some specific explanation other than the people who were moving into the community shared the same fundamental values of the people already living there."
Perhaps one of the reasons Hillcrest has managed to evolve so significantly yet anonymously is that it is not a city, or a town, or even a village. Instead, it is an unincorporated hamlet of 1.3 square miles and 7,106 people in the Town of Ramapo, almost entirely lacking an institutional structure of its own.
Even within Ramapo, Hillcrest is often overlooked. To the south is Spring Valley, a diverse hub grappling with overcrowded housing, drugs and economic redevelopment, while to the southwest and northeast, respectively, are the Orthodox and Hasidic enclaves of Monsey and New Square.
The Hillcrest Fire Company on Route 45, the main drag here, is one of the area's most notable institutions. Across the highway, the businesses in the Hillcrest Plaza shopping center have labels instead of names, with signs like "Nail Salon" and "Bagels." Most of the mail bound for Hillcrest, N.Y., 10977, is addressed to Spring Valley, one of five places with the same zip code.
Hillcrest first attracted attention in the early 1900s as a summer retreat accessible by train for working-class families from New York City, about 30 miles away. The Tappan Zee Bridge was built in 1955, increasing traffic and easing access to New York City. Hillcrest added hundreds of single-family houses, mostly inexpensive Cape Cods or split-levels on small lots. Many secular Jews were among that wave of settlers, said Craig H. Long, Ramapo's official historian.
In 1980, 84 percent of Hillcrest's population was white, while blacks accounted for only 7 percent. Since then, the proportion of whites has dropped to 21 percent, while the number of black residents jumped ninefold, to 49 percent of the total. The number of Asians, meanwhile, has grown by more than 260 percent and Hispanics by 366 percent.
According to real estate agents and residents, no single factor or event contributed to this demographic change. Many people moved because their children grew up and left, or because they wanted to pay lower taxes for more land. But some also did not like the racial diversity, said Simone Desvarieux, a broker with All Century Realty.
"They didn't say it, but you could feel it," said Ms. Desvarieux, a Haitian immigrant.
Fifteen years ago, about 15 percent of Ms. Desvarieux's clients were immigrants; now, about 80 percent are immigrants, mostly from Haiti, Jamaica, India, the Philippines or Latin America.
Many newcomers have moved from New York City, lured by $225,000 houses that would probably sell for $300,000 elsewhere in the county. Many are first-time homeowners eager to keep their neighborhoods tidy and who hold jobs as teachers, taxi drivers, subway conductors and store managers in New York City, New Jersey, Westchester or Rockland.
Ramon Gonzalez, 48, is Puerto Rican, works as a mechanic and lives on a block of East Hickory Street that epitomizes Hillcrest's transformation. In 1990, he left the Bronx so that he could buy his first house. Back then, most of his neighbors were longtime homesteaders or Jews who had moved in after the 1960s; now, they are mostly Haitians, Filipinos and Indians.
"Everybody, we get along," Mr. Gonzalez said. "We all do our spring cleaning. It's like a chain reaction."
Thelma DeGuzman, 39, immigrated directly from the Philippines 10 years ago, joining relatives already in the area. She saw immediately that Hillcrest differed from her expectations of an American suburb.
"I thought there were only tall white people, because of what I see in the movies," said Ms. DeGuzman, a nursing aide. "But then I said, 'Oh, my God! This is like the Philippines! So many Filipinos!' " 
Some Roman Catholics, including Mr. Gonzalez and Ms. DeGuzman, belong to the ever-expanding St. Joseph's Church in Spring Valley, which now offers 13 masses in five languages, said the Rev. Rudolph Gonzalez, the church's pastor.
Local businesses sell Haitian, Chinese and Filipino newspapers. Two Indian-owned groceries on Eckerson Road rent out hundreds of videotapes from India. At Soun Sun Nhem's Asian Food Market, customers can buy phone cards for the Philippines, Thailand, Cambodia, Indonesia, Haiti, Mexico and Guatemala. The kosher deli is gone now, but Hillcrest still has more than the usual suburban fare of pizza and Chinese takeout -- residents can also eat at Vietnamese, Salvadoran or Colombian restaurants.
The town government has celebrated its diversity, which is something that cannot be said for many suburbs, said John Brunson, an African-American businessman who moved here from the Bronx in 1995 and is now president of the new Hillcrest Neighborhood Preservation Association.
Three years ago, Ramapo began organizing a series of celebrations, called Heritage Nights, to honor its residents' native cultures. For 10 years, the town has supported student exchange programs with towns in Ireland, Italy, Israel, the Philippines, India and Ghana and has printed brochures in different languages.
"If you put a mirror up in Town Hall, it'll reflect our community," said Christopher St. Lawrence, the Ramapo town supervisor.
Yet, the diversity has presented its share of challenges, too. In the East Ramapo Central School District, ethnic minorities make up 82 percent of the student body. More than 50 nationalities are represented in the schools. As a result, it is a constant challenge to educate new immigrants and minimize cultural clashes, said the superintendent, Jason P. Friedman.
At a youth counseling center here, most teenagers seeking help in the 1980s were white and battling drugs or alcohol problems. Now many are immigrants torn by cultural differences over issues such as parental supervision and corporal punishment, said the Rev. George R. Doering Jr., the center's director.
Still, most residents seem genuinely surprised and grateful that Hillcrest has changed so much with so little fuss -- so far.
"Isn't that something? I thought there were more whites," said Julius Graifman, 74, who is white and who moved to Hillcrest 38 years ago from the Bronx. "But that's O.K., we celebrate our diversity here. And besides, the people who moved in wound up being better neighbors than the ones who left."
