HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Jobless Rate Continued Its Ascent in April, to 4.5%
The unemployment rate, which has been inching up since a low of 3.9 percent in October, rose again in April to 4.5 percent from 4.3 percent in March.
 The work force fell last month by an estimated 223,000 jobs on top of a loss of 53,000 jobs the previous month, the Labor Department reported. The back-to-back job losses indicated to some analysts that the already sluggish economy has become even weaker and may be nearing, or even in, a recession. Page A1. 

Writers and Studios Reach a Pact
Negotiators for Hollywood's film and television writers reached a tentative agreement on a new three-year contract with the major studios and networks that will, if approved by the union's members, avert what was once thought to be an all-but-inevitable strike with the potential to cripple the nation's entertainment industry. A1.

Computer Associates Fixes Error
Computer Associates said a typographical error caused it to overstate its annual profit by more than $130 million last month. The company said that it earned 16 cents a share, or about $90 million, for the year ended March 31, excluding certain charges. On April 16, the company said it earned 40 cents a share, or about $230 million. C2.

A Not-Guilty Plea in Auction Case
A. Alfred Taubman, the former chairman of Sotheby's, pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court in Manhattan to charges that he and Sir Anthony Tennant, his onetime counterpart at Christie's, colluded to fix the commission fees charged to auction house customers over a six-year period in the 1990's. B12.

$2 Billion Real Estate Combination
Archstone Communities Trust agreed to buy another property manager, Charles E. Smith Residential Realty, for $2.2 billion in stock and $1.4 billion in assumed debt. C3.

'Survivor' Overwhelms Competitors
The finale of "Survivor: The Australian Outback," which revealed Tina Wesson of Tennessee as the winner, overwhelmed its competition Thursday night, averaging more than 36 million viewers. But it did not approach the huge number of viewers the original "Survivor" scored last summer when 51 million tuned in to its final episode. C15.

Malnutrition, second-degree burns, a slaughtered boar, hair falling out in clumps -- all that and still the thrill was gone from the second season of "Survivor." B9.

Brill's to Cut Publishing Schedule
Reversing plans announced a month ago, Brill's Content, the magazine about the media, will not change its name to Inside Content. It will keep its name, said Steven Brill, the magazine's founder. But the magazine, which has been published 10 times a year, will emerge in the fall, after a summer hiatus, as a quarterly magazine. C15.

Shareholders Take Smurfit to Task
At Jefferson Smurfit's annual meeting in Dublin, management came under heavy verbal assault from a new force on the Irish corporate scene: a crowd of shareholders impatient with the company's recent performance. C3.

San Miguel Chairman Avoids Ouster
Eduardo M. Cojuangco Jr., chairman of San Miguel, the largest brewer in the Philippines, held off a government bid to oust him at the company's annual shareholders meeting. Mr. Cojuangco, a close friend of both ousted presidents Joseph E. Estrada and Ferdinand E. Marcos, said he was eager to talk with the administration of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo about how to end a 15-year dispute over who controls 47 percent of San Miguel. C3.

PERSON: John Scanlon 

HEADLINE: John Scanlon, Tenacious Public Relations Consultant for High-Profile Clients, Dies at 66 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
John Scanlon, a public relations man who brought cunning, bare-knuckle tenacity and the nimbleness of a leprechaun to promoting the interests of high-profile clients, including Bob Kerrey in the current controversy over his actions in Vietnam, died yesterday at his Manhattan apartment. He was 66.
 Deborah Hayes, a spokeswoman for Mr. Scanlon's firm, Westhill Partners, said he had had heart attacks in the past and had most likely suffered another. 
 His battles, including defending the CBS program "60 minutes" against libel charges by Gen. William Westmoreland and casting what turned out to be seriously questionable aspersions on the character of a scientist for a tobacco company that he was representing, gave sharply personalized definition to a pervasive phrase: "spin doctor." 
Increasingly, Mr. Scanlon came to define a new, often harsher, certainly more immediate brand of public relations, often termed crisis management. His hardball tactics in trying to beat down a man who blew the whistle against a tobacco company led to an unsympathetic character based on him in the 1999 movie "The Insider." 
Mr. Scanlon kept turning up at the center of media storms. When news broke in February that Jesse Jackson had fathered a child by an unmarried associate and had secretly supported the child, there he was. This week, when not busy with Mr. Kerrey, he has been vigorously polishing the image of A. Alfred Taubman, the former chairman of Sotheby's auction house, who was indicted on Wednesday on federal price-fixing charges.
He represented Credit Suisse, a Swiss bank accused of keeping, after World War II, hundreds of millions of dollars deposited by Jews. 
"Sometimes you sup with long spoons," he said in an interview with New York magazine in 1997. "This was never an attempt to defend Swiss actions during the war, because they are, in fact, indefensible. But you can walk away from the issue and help nobody, or you can become part of the process of solving things."
He strongly denied that he was a paid liar. "That's not what we do," he told New York magazine. "I mean, we're strategic counselors."
Other public relations consultants, even some who opposed him, admired his skill. Howard J. Rubenstein, who represented Donald J. Trump in his divorce from Mr. Scanlon's client Ivana Trump, said he used his sense of humor to exceptional advantage.
"He once said I had more conflicts of interest than existed in Beirut," he said with a laugh. "But each time he would say something like that, he would say it with a twinkle."
Dan Klores, another public relations executive, said: "He didn't do dog-and-pony shows. He understood the news and how to embrace the media -- and also how to manage difficult clients."
He would often suggest ideas to journalists that were totally unrelated to any paying client, in the belief that the favor might be remembered. 
"He didn't just sell you stories," said John Leo, a columnist for U.S. News & World Report. "He paid attention to what you wrote and what you thought and what your interests were."
At a time when many, perhaps most, journalists are deeply skeptical of paid purveyors of story ideas, the big man with the Hemingway-style beard still managed to be friendly with many. Much of his success stemmed from his larger-than-life personality. He prodigiously entertained, drank, cooked and recited Irish poetry. His musical rendition of a Yeats poem, "The Golden Apples of the Sun," could moisten eyes.
"He consumed 16,000 calories of life a day," said Graydon Carter, editor of Vanity Fair.
One friend, Peter Jennings, the ABC anchor, said he and others learned to separate Mr. Scanlon's fine company from some of his harsher campaigns. "All of his close friends totally disapproved of his tactics," he said.
John Patrick Scanlon was born in Manhattan on Feb. 27, 1935. He grew up in the Bronx, just north of Yankee Stadium. His father worked for the Transit Authority, inspecting the electricity on the third rail. His mother cleaned houses.
He graduated from Catholic University in Washington and spent six years teaching in Roman Catholic schools. He thought about becoming a monk, but balked. "I couldn't take the chaste thing," he told New York.
He then taught at a public high school on Long Island. Wanting more income, he began selling textbooks. He hung out at the Lion's Head bar in Greenwich Village, where he fell in with writers from Commonweal magazine and other publications. He became a full-time activist against the Vietnam War and worked in Eugene McCarthy's presidential campaign in 1968.
He then worked as a press spokesman for the city's economic development arm in the Lindsay administration. Next, he worked for Phoenix House, a drug treatment program, as a spokesman. In 1973, he went to work at the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was wrestling with the city's deepening fiscal crisis.
He then began working as public relations consultant, gradually ranging beyond the clients chosen for purely idealistic reasons. When the Rev. Bruce Ritter at Covenant House became embroiled in a sex scandal, Mr. Scanlon was by his side. He fought heated battles against unions for Eastern Airlines and Tavern on the Green restaurant. He was on the side of the Tribune Company in its labor battle with employees of The New York Daily News.
"The thrill of handling the risky client seemed to overtake the thrill of handing the righteous client," the writer Alex Williams suggested in the New York magazine article.
Perhaps his most controversial client was Brown & Williamson, the maker of Kool and Viceroy cigarettes. At the time a grand jury was looking into allegations that the company had conspired to make cigarettes more addictive, Mr. Scanlon passed on to The Wall Street Journal a 500-page dossier on the employee who had blown the whistle, Jeffrey S. Wigand, a chemist.
It backfired. The Journal reported that many allegations were "backed by scanty or contradictory evidence," while others were "demonstrably untrue."
Mr. Scanlon's private life was pleasant. He had a Manhattan apartment; a house in Sag Harbor, N.Y.; and a house in County Westmeath, Ireland. Friends said he had been trying to arrange his life so that he could spend more time in Ireland. 
For years, he served as announcer and chief heckler at the Artists and Writers softball game in East Hampton.
His most treasured possession was a first-edition copy of James Joyce's "Ulysses," and he was a friend of the Irish poet Seamus Heaney. He was a patron of Concern Worldwide, an international relief organization with many Irish-American backers, and, at the time of his death, was writing a book on Ireland with Ed Tivnan.
He is survived by his wife, Julienne; his daughters, Caitlin Scanlon, of Los Angeles; Elizabeth Scanlon Hyman, of San Francisco; and Rebecca Scanlon of Manhattan; his brother, Michael, of Brooklyn; his sister, Mary Pat McDermott, of Manhattan, and one granddaughter.
Mr. Carter suggested Mr. Scanlon's greatest accomplishment was the ancient Irish art of making the language dance. "What he was brilliant at was rhetoric," he said. "He could take a white tennis ball, and, at the end of an hour, make you think it was black."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 7, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An obituary of the public relations consultant John Scanlon on Saturday misidentified the CBS News unit that he advised in the 1980's on its defense in a libel suit by Gen. William C. Westmoreland. It was "CBS Reports," which made the documentary "The Uncounted Enemy," not "60 Minutes."

HEADLINE: NEW YORK STATE IS SLOW TO SPEND WELFARE WINDFALL 

BYLINE:  By SOMINI SENGUPTA

 BODY:
Over the last four years, state lawmakers have set aside millions of dollars in unused federal welfare funds for a battery of programs intended to help poor New Yorkers leave the welfare rolls.
 The problem is, just months before Congress is set to debate the next round of state-by-state welfare allocations, more than half of the $1.19 billion that has been accumulating in Albany and was earmarked by the state for specific anti-poverty programs has not left the bank. 
 For example, of more than $53 million earmarked for transportation -- one of the most unyielding barriers to self-sufficiency -- roughly $2 million was spent as of last summer, state figures show. Of the $66 million set aside to provide drug screening and treatment for addicts, roughly $12.5 million was spent. And of the nearly $220 million offered to city and county governments to use for job training programs, just $837,000 was taken. 
State budget officials say the pace of spending has picked up since last summer, when they had used $258 million, or 22 percent, of the $1.19 billion that had piled up since the 1997-98 fiscal year began. A more recent breakdown is not available, but they say they have spent about $270 million more since last summer.
In total dollars, New York and California, with sizable populations of former welfare recipients and sizable leftover funds to draw from, rank highest among states having trouble spending their welfare windfalls. Smaller states, like Vermont, Rhode Island and Delaware, spend their allocations readily. 
But it is not entirely about size: Idaho, a state with a relatively small population, has a large sum of unspent welfare dollars, while Illinois, one of the nation's most populous states, has spent all its federal welfare surplus, the biggest chunk of it on child care.
As a share of its total federal welfare allocation, New York's unspent dollars rank roughly in the middle of all 50 states.
"It's a question of whether states have a strategy for how the money should be spent," said Rich Stolz of the Center for Community Change, a liberal Washington-based research group that published a study on the issue earlier this year.
In New York, state officials say the money has been slow going out the door because it takes time for private groups and government agencies -- at the state, county and local levels -- to create new programs to aid those trying to get off public assistance. Besides, they say, federal officials did not issue regulations spelling out how welfare dollars should be spent until two years ago.
Kevin Quinn, a spokesman for the Division of Budget, said getting the programs going, starting with selecting private agencies to provide the services, was very time-consuming. "Service providers needed time to start up their new programs -- programs that had never been undertaken on this magnitude," he said. "It was a total reform of a very complex system."
The radical overhaul of the nation's welfare policies in 1996 handed states lump-sum block grants. It gave them great flexibility on how to spend that money. Since then, New York has spent the bulk of its $9.3 billion grant -- more than $5.4 billion -- on direct cash assistance. But falling welfare rolls have yielded the state a bounty of federal welfare funds. The state turned over the largest chunk of that money -- nearly $1.5 billion -- to the child welfare agency. Millions more went for child care and the Earned Income Tax Credit, a tax break for the working poor. Another $662 million has been set aside as a rainy day reserve fund for anti-poverty programs. 
Pataki administration officials are eager to point out those expenditures, saying that the vast majority of federal welfare monies has been spent. "It's important to look at the whole picture," Mr. Quinn said. 
The money left unspent is earmarked for dozens of transitional programs, from English classes to wage subsidies for hiring welfare recipients to money for car loans, all intended to help New Yorkers get off and stay off welfare.
Critics, many of them Democrats in the State Legislature, argue that spending could be accelerated, if state and local agencies committed to doing that. "It seems to be a real reluctance to spend this money for transitional services for people leaving welfare," said Roger L. Green, a Democratic assemblyman from Brooklyn and the chairman of the Assembly committee on children and families. 
Mr. Green and other critics note that while welfare rolls have plummeted, poverty remains high. Statewide, 24 percent of all children lived below the poverty line in 1998, the most recent statistic available. And advocates for the poor contend that while many local welfare agencies have been eager to trim their rolls, sometimes removing people for failing to meet technicalities in program requirements, they have not been as eager to start programs to lift former welfare families out of poverty.
"There has to be a political will at the local level to spend the money," said Trudi Renwick, a senior economist with the Fiscal Policy Institute, an Albany-based research group that tracks state spending. "It's not an entitlement. There are no sanctions for local government."
Lawmakers and advocacy groups worry, too, about how Congress might view the unspent millions when it debates in a few months how much of the welfare block grant -- Temporary Assistance to Needy Families -- will go to New York. 
"If I'm seeing several states that have a lot of TANF money and are not spending that, I'm going to scrutinize that, particularly if other states are clamoring," said Russell Sykes, vice president of the Schuyler Center for Analysis and Advocacy, a private nonprofit group in Albany.
For its part, the Pataki administration points to the state's achievement in cutting the welfare rolls by nearly half in four years, and for devoting its share of federal welfare dollars to anti-poverty programs, like the Earned Income Tax Credit.
Gov. George E. Pataki has already called on Washington to maintain the same level of financing as in 1996 and to raise it slightly to account for inflation. The National Governors Association has also called on Congress not to slash the overall welfare funding levels. The current welfare law gives states great flexibility on what they can spend that money.
There is a dizzying array of programs -- some of them initiated by the Pataki administration, others by members of the Legislature -- on which the money would be spent. There are, for instance, four separate pots of money earmarked for transportation. 
A $57 million initiative called the Wage Subsidy Program was established to help nonprofit groups train welfare recipients and find them jobs. The first contracts for much of that money were awarded two months ago. 
Spending the money has been no easy feat, state officials say. For instance, a $220 million block grant that local municipalities can use for job training has remained practically untouched. The state set aside $70 million of that money for New York City last year. Several months later, the city applied for only about $61 million. It took another six months, state officials said, for the city to submit revisions that satisfied the state. City officials said this week they still have not received the funds. 
For some, the profusion of so many programs, large and small, is part of the problem. "TANF is funding such an array of programs and services," said Mr. Sykes of the Schuyler Center for Analysis and Advocacy. "That's a good thing. But perhaps it's time for a late course correction, particularly as reauthorization is coming up."

HEADLINE: WRITERS IN ACCORD WITH THE STUDIOS 

BYLINE:  By RICK LYMAN

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 4 

 BODY:
Negotiators for Hollywood's film and television writers reached a tentative agreement today on a three-year contract with the major studios and networks that will, if approved by the union's members, avert a strike. Only a few months ago, Hollywood thought that a strike was all but inevitable and that it would have the potential to cripple the entertainment industry.
 Top negotiators for the Writers Guild of America, representing 11,000 film and television writers, and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers, representing the studios and networks, stood side by side in the guild's offices just south of Hollywood at 3:50 p.m. today to announce the tentative pact -- three days after the previous contract had expired. 
 "This was one of the most difficult negotiations we've had in years because of the complexities facing this industry," said Nicholas Counter, chief negotiator for the alliance.
The Writers Guild had sought what it called groundbreaking changes in the way writers are treated in Hollywood and in the way they are paid, said Michael Mahern, secretary-treasurer of the guild's West Coast branch and co-chairman of the union negotiating team. 
Still, it was difficult to assess immediately how closely the writers came to reaching the goals they had set at the start of the talks, since the announcement of the tentative settlement today included details of only some areas of the proposed contract, those in which the union achieved what it considered important improvements for its members.
At the same time, the producers were reluctant to brag about their achievements in the talks, for fear of making it harder for the union to win an approval vote from its membership.
It was clear, however, even with the sketchy details released today, that the writers had won at least some improvements in most of the economic issues and had made measurable, if somewhat less-striking gains on issues relating to creative rights.
Whether these will be enough to satisfy union members who had been clamoring for even more aggressive gains remains to be seen in the voting.
Mr. Mahern said: "People told us it couldn't be done even if we went on strike for a year. Today we are announcing that we have done it, including groundbreaking improvements, and it was accomplished without a strike."
The economic improvements agreed to in the tentative pact would mean $41 million more to the union's writers over the three years of the deal, Mr. Mahern said, including improvements in residuals for foreign sales, basic cable, pay cable and videocassettes.
In addition, for the first time, provisions were reached to cover the use of films and television programs on the Internet, and the basic minimums for writers will rise 3.5 percent a year.
Mr. Counter and the studio chiefs arrayed around him said they would not describe any of the details of the tentative agreement, leaving it up to guild officials to do so. Mr. Counter said, however, that the pact had been approved by all of the alliance's members, so all that remained was for the union to get the approval of its members.
Guild negotiators will take the tentative agreement to the union's governing East Coast and West Coast councils in the next few days. Since those councils are made up of many of the same people who sat on the negotiating committee, which approved the tentative pact unanimously, acceptance is all but certain. After that, however, the agreement will still have to be submitted to a vote of the union's membership, and although approval is expected there, as well, it is not a sure thing.
Among the provisions of the tentative agreement was increasing the residuals paid by the Fox Television Network, which had a 50 percent discount on the residuals paid by major networks. Under this new pact, its residual payments would increase over the next two years until they are at the same level as those of the other networks. 
Another issue that drew much attention during the negotiations were so-called creative rights, concerning the way writers are treated and the amount of power and status they have concerning the feature films they write. For example, the writers sought guarantees that they be allowed to visit the sets of films based on their scripts and to be invited to premieres, press junkets and all cast and crew events for the film.
The tentative agreement, however, does not offer a guarantee regarding the set visits and some other issues, saying instead that they will become a nonbinding "preferred practice." Writers did receive guarantees to be invited to the premieres and other events. 
In addition, a joint committee of the Writers Guild and the Directors Guild of America will be formed to work on these and other creative rights issues. 
On the issue that drew the most attention -- the use of the "film by" credit for many directors -- the two sides said they could not come to an agreement. Instead, Mr. Mahern said, union negotiators decided to pull it off the table and continue discussions later.
"We sought to begin a process that will, with time, change the culture of this business," Mr. Mahern said.
Martha Coolidge, the film director who was part of her union's committee looking into the creative-rights issue, said the Directors Guild was generally pleased with today's tentative pact and felt it would, in the end, foster a better atmosphere between Hollywood's writers and directors. In particular, she said, directors were pleased that "preferred practices" would govern many creative-rights issues, rather than strict guarantees.
"These kind of relationships cannot be mandated," Ms. Coolidge said. "Our members have always felt that way."
Most immediately, today's settlement lifts the threat that Hollywood will be hit by two major strikes this summer and shifts attention toward coming negotiations for a new contract covering the 135,000 performers represented by the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists.
Hollywood has been nearly frantic for more than six months amid threats that the entertainment industry would be hobbled by the dual strikes. Movies were rushed into production so they would be finished in time to beat the strike deadlines.
Talent agencies and other companies instituted emergency plans, prepared layoff lists and warned employees and clients to save their money and not make expensive purchases. 
Much of the reason for this anxiety was the militant talk from union leaders, especially those in charge of the writers guild, who had vowed to take a hard line in this year's negotiations. The current union leadership, elected just over a year ago, came into office with a promise to be especially aggressive at the bargaining table, making up for what many union members felt were weak agreements in recent rounds of negotiations.
So it remained to be seen whether the agreement reached today -- which falls somewhat short of the goals that officials had set in the recent union elections and in public statements before the negotiations began -- will be acceptable to the union membership. 
Many say that the worsening economic climate will make even the most militant writers more reluctant to force a strike, and recent statements by many prominent screen and television writers have hinted at a greater willingness to take whatever concessions are offered and save the larger fight for next time.
The actors' contract expires on June 30 and those talks are set to begin next week.
While the actors unions have not made public their demands, they are expected to seek the same sorts of increases in residuals that the writers sought, as well as hefty increases in the basic minimums paid to actors, usually supporting actors, in films and television series. 
Officials of the Screen Actors Guild said in a statement that they would analyze the details of the writers pact "to see if it will be helpful in finding a way to address the specific needs of actors in our upcoming negotiations." But beyond that, they would not comment on today's agreement.
Mr. Mahern declined to say which of the issues had proved the thorniest during the talks. "I can tell you that they were all very difficult," he said. "There were no pins that fell on their own. We had to bowl them all over."
He offered only some highlights of the agreement, and said further specifics would be made public in coming days. 
The changes in the way residuals are computed for sales of films and programs to foreign markets will mean $1.3 million more for writers over the next three years, he said, largely by removing a cap on the maximum amount of residuals for a particular program.
Improvements in residual rates for pay cable programs, like "The Sopranos," will raise the amount writers receive to about $4 million under the new agreement from a total of $300,000 under the previous contract. Residuals for basic cable programs will increase by 20 percent, Mr. Mahern said.
And an agreement to pay writers a one-time $5,000 script fee for DVD and videocassette sales would raise those residuals by more than $1 million a year, he said.
Several people who had been involved in the proceedings, which were being held under a press blackout, said the talks had followed a frustrating pattern in recent days of rapid bursts of progress engendering periods of optimism that were then dashed when an unforeseen bump appeared to slow everything down and intensify emotions.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home; 
A Regime Of Thugs

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON 

 BODY:
The title of worst government on earth the most brutal, destructive, lawless -- can probably be claimed today by Robert Mugabe's regime in Zimbabwe. Mr. Mugabe has turned a prosperous country into a land of chaos and desperation.
 Example: Last week a gang of the thugs whom Mr. Mugabe calls "war veterans" invaded a grain storage depot holding grain donated by the European Union to the people of Zimbabwe. Over two days, with policemen watching, they stole 14 tons. 
 These so-called war veterans are Mr. Mugabe's instrument of terror. They began by invading white-owned farms, and they still remain on many -- camping on the land, obstructing farm operations, demanding food by threat. Now they have begun extorting money from businesses. In recent days they have invaded leading hotels, department stores and even a private hospital, demanding payments to leave.
Mr. Mugabe's purpose is to hold on to political power. He has ruled Zimbabwe since it became independent in 1980. There must be a presidential election by next March, and he is using violence to be sure he wins. Leaders of the opposition, the Movement for Democratic Change, have been kidnapped and killed.
Two of the opposition members of Parliament, Paul Nyathi and David Coltart, were in Washington this week, and I spoke to them by telephone. I asked Mr. Nyathi if he was afraid.
"No more than the average Zimbabwean," he said, "who faces beating on a daily basis. The whole of the country is under threat."
Before the parliamentary election last year, Mr. Coltart's polling agent was abducted; he has not been seen since. During the 1990 election there was an assassination attempt on an opposition leader. It failed, and the attackers were prosecuted and convicted. Mr. Mugabe pardoned them. 
What then, I asked, can the United States and the international community do? Mr. Coltart replied: "End the culture of impunity."
"Mugabe and his people have used violence for political objectives again and again in the last 20 years," Mr. Coltart continued. "The international community objected last year, but there were no sanctions. So they think that if they bludgeon their way to winning again now, the international community will forgive them and life will go on."
The two M.P.'s said they were not in favor of general trade sanctions, which would further hurt impoverished Zimbabweans. Instead they called for personal sanctions targeting Mr. Mugabe and his top aides: their travel banned, financial assets identified and so on.
"Robert Mugabe and his henchmen have not been personally affected by what they have done to the country," Mr. Coltart said. "Targeted personal sanctions would break their culture of impunity."
Why should U.S. policy makers care about Zimbabwe, a medium-sized country in the middle of south-central Africa? The answer, I believe, is that what happens in Zimbabwe is a key to stability in the whole region.
Zambia, next door, has been in turmoil over President Frederick Chiluba's attempt, just abandoned, to change the Constitution to stay in office. In Mozambique there are dangerous tensions. In Angola the civil war continues. And South Africa, the giant of the region, is in a time of political strain. By making clear that there can be no impunity for violence and a stolen election in Zimbabwe, the United States and others can raise hope of making it a model for southern Africa.
The role of South Africa in the Zimbabwe situation has been a puzzle. President Thabo Mbeki said nothing as Mr. Mugabe's depredations mounted. His justice minister, Penuell Maduna, went to Zimbabwe and announced that, despite physical threats to judges, talk of intimidation was "pure fabrication."
South Africa has a self-interested reason to worry about Mr. Mugabe's campaign of terror. To outsiders, investors and tourists, chaos in Zimbabwe is a reason to stay away from the whole area.
Last week the South African government did condemn violence by the "war veterans." Mr. Nyathi said South Africa had "taken rather long, but they are getting the message now. If they had taken a robust attitude from the beginning, it might have reduced the destruction. But better late than never."

HEADLINE: U.S. JOBLESS RATE HIT 4.5% IN APRIL; 223,000 JOBS LOST 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The American job creation machine went into reverse in April as companies shed employees across much of the weak economy.
 The work force fell last month by an estimated 223,000 jobs on top of a loss of 53,000 jobs the previous month, the Labor Department reported yesterday. The unemployment rate, which has been inching up from a low of 3.9 percent in October, rose again, to 4.5 percent from 4.3 percent in March. 
 After several years of expanding opportunity and rising income for millions of households, the back-to-back months of big job losses indicated to some analysts that the already sluggish economy had become even weaker lately and might be nearing, or even in, a recession. 
"These numbers mean that the economy is right now at about zero growth," said Peter Hooper, chief domestic economist for Deutsche Bank North America. "I don't see much of anything positive in this report."
The April job loss was the largest one-month decline since February 1991, when the nation was in the last recession. The once-robust labor market has been weakening since last spring, but most of the weakness had been focused on manufacturing employees and on temporary workers, many of them also employed in manufacturing. Now there is clear evidence that job-cutting has spread through the vast service sector as well.
"The weakness in the economy is no longer a manufacturing story or a high-tech story," said William Dudley, director of domestic economic research at Goldman, Sachs. "It is much more broadly based."
The stock market, however, treated the bad news as pointing to better times ahead. Prices rose on the major exchanges as investors seemed to conclude that corporate America, in cutting labor costs, was acting quickly to revive profits. Page C1. 
The employment report also seemed to practically guarantee another half-point cut in interest rates when the Federal Reserve's policy makers meet on May 15. Falling rates usually encourage people to invest in stocks by reducing the return on alternative investments.
"Business is biting the bullet, quickly cutting labor costs, and the markets see this as good news for stock prices," said James Glassman, a senior economist at J. P. Morgan.
Not everyone shares that optimism. Rising unemployment is particularly hard on consumer confidence, and the unemployment rate is now the highest since October 1998. The concern is that rising unemployment will make consumers pull back, weakening the economy even more and raising the unemployment rate yet another notch or two.
"The risk is that we are going to get caught in a vicious circle, with rising unemployment leading to cutbacks in spending which lead to further job losses," Mr. Dudley said. Most of the economic weakness so far has come from companies spending much less for machinery, computers and software.
Just a week ago, many experts believed the economy was beginning to recover. The Commerce Department reported that the gross domestic product had grown at an annual rate of 2 percent in the first quarter -- twice the rate in the fourth quarter. The Fed's aggressive rate cuts -- two percentage points since early January -- and still respectable consumer spending might be reviving the economy, some Wall Street economists said. The employment report threw cold water on that reasoning.
"The job numbers tell us that the second quarter is going to be weaker than the first quarter, although we might still be able to avoid a recession," said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at Wells Fargo Bank in Minneapolis.
Under pressure from shrinking profits, corporate America appears to be shifting its strategy for cutting labor costs. Until now, managers had preferred to eliminate overtime, cut back hours and use fewer temporary workers. The April report offered the first clear evidence that employers were resorting more frequently now to layoffs and hiring freezes. Hours worked last month fell sharply, but from the job losses rather than shorter workweeks, the Labor Department reported.
Conditioned by labor shortages in the late 1990's, "businesses had become reluctant to shed workers," Mr. Sohn said. "Now they are losing that reluctance and layoffs are becoming fashionable." 
The shift is reflected in the unemployment data. Nearly 3 million of the 6.4 million people who were unemployed in April had lost their jobs within the previous five weeks. That was 46 percent of all the unemployed, up from 43 percent in March.
"The flow of new people into unemployment is clearly rising," said Thomas Nardone, chief of the division that compiles the job figures at the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The Bush Administration viewed the latest jobs report as a justification for the $1.3 billion tax cut that Congress seems on the verge of adopting. "We need to give the economy room to breath and the first essential step is the president's tax cut," Labor Secretary Elaine L. Chao said.
The job cuts last month were widespread -- in transportation, hotels, recreation, general merchandise, apparel, wholesale trade, publishing, data processing. The handful of industries that gained ground included retailing, health services, child care and financial services, despite layoffs at some brokerage houses. Local governments also added jobs, especially public schools.
The biggest job losses came in manufacturing, which shed 104,000 jobs; the temporary-help industry, which eliminated 108,000 jobs; and construction, which shrank by 64,000 jobs.
All of the Labor Department's numbers are seasonally adjusted to offset employment trends that might otherwise distort the figures. That is, the Bureau of Labor Statistics estimates how many jobs should have been created in April in a normal year -- 895,000, in fact, and since only 672,000 showed up in the surveys of business payrolls, that counted as a job loss of 223,000.
What validates this process, Mr. Nardone says, are the trends, and the trend has been downward -- from an average of 256,000 new jobs created each month in the first four months of last year to a monthly decline, on average, of 14,000 in the same period this year.
As the labor market has weakened, wage pressures have subsided. Average hourly earnings for production and nonsupervisory workers, who held about 75 percent of the 132 million jobs in April, rose by a modest 5 cents, to $14.22.
The jump in unemployment last month came mostly at the expense of teenagers, whose unemployment rate rose to 14.2 percent from 13.8 percent in March, and whites, whose jobless rate increased to 4 percent from 3.7 percent in March. That is half the black rate of 8.2 percent, which fell slightly.
College graduates are also being hit, in part because of the devastation in the dot-com world. Their unemployment rate rose in March and April and, at 2.3 percent, is now six-tenths of a percentage point above its level a year ago.
"The slowdown," said Jared Bernstein, an economist at the Economic Policy Institute in Washington, "is bringing layoffs across the board."

HEADLINE: Richardson Pratt Jr., 78; Led Pratt Institute 

 BODY:
Richardson Pratt Jr., a former president of the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn and chairman of Charles Pratt & Company, which was established in 1891 to oversee the Pratt family interests, died Tuesday at his home in Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. He was 78.
 The cause was pancreatic cancer, said his wife, Mary. 
 Mr. Pratt, known as Jerry, was a great-grandson of the Pratt Institute's founder, Charles Pratt, who was a partner of John D. Rockefeller in the Standard Oil Company. Mr. Pratt was president of the institute from 1972 to 1990.
Born on March 25, 1923, Mr. Pratt grew up in Brooklyn and Glen Cove, N.Y. He graduated from the Choate School and received a bachelor's degree from Williams College in 1946 and a master's degree from the Harvard Business School in 1948.
During World War II, Mr. Pratt served on a Navy minesweeper. In 1948 he joined Standard Oil (now Exxon Mobil), where he held various positions in marketing, planning and economics until 1971, when he joined Charles Pratt & Company. He retired in 2000.
In addition to his wife, Mary Offutt Pratt, Mr. Pratt is survived by their three children, Laura P. Gregg of Bryn Mawr, Pa., Thomas R. Pratt of Coconut Grove, Fla., and David O. Pratt of Chestnut Hill, Pa.; eight grandchildren; and one great-grandson.

HEADLINE: Greenest Economies 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Newt Gingrich (Op-Ed, April 29) makes a good point about transformational politics and the environment. But environmental progress requires not only a transformation of political style. 
It will also require a transformation in economies here and elsewhere to structures that assure reductions in environmental impact per unit of economic growth. 
 Technologies that reduce environmental impact while increasing economic productivity exist. But to realize their full potential, public policy must shift from its overriding concern with regulating negative outputs to encouraging greater efficiency and productivity of energy and materials inputs.
Just look at the most advanced economies, and you'll find the greenest countries.

DON RITTER
Washington, May 1, 2001

The writer, a former congressman, is president of the National Environmental Policy Institute.

HEADLINE: For DiFrancesco, Fighting Words In Deodorant Ad 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 4 

 BODY:
It is not often that the chief executive of a big state demands an apology for a deodorant ad. But Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco appears to have caught Devils fever. 
 The Toronto Maple Leafs and the New Jersey Devils are tied, 2-2, in the National Hockey League playoffs, with Game 5 of their four-of-seven series set for Saturday night at Continental Arena in East Rutherford, N.J. 
 At least one corporate citizen of both Canada and New Jersey -- the Colgate-Palmolive Company -- appears to have taken sides in the series. On Thursday, an ad for the company's Mennen Speed Stick ran in both The Toronto Star and The Toronto Sun, showing a map of New Jersey and a picture of the deodorant. "Unfortunately, there are some smells even we can't do anything about," the ad reads. "Go Leafs Go."
The ad provoked Mr. DiFrancesco to make an outburst of indignation today, punctuated with clunky hockey references. "What stinks is a company trying to further their economic interests at the expense of New Jersey's reputation," he said. "I can understand trying to score with Maple Leafs fans who must be sweating right now, but this slap shot at the Garden State has put Colgate in the penalty box with me."
The, er, power play did not last long, however. Mr. DiFrancesco fired off a semi-serious letter of protest to Reuben Mark, the chief executive of Colgate-Palmolive, noting that it employs nearly 2,000 people in New Jersey and that the Mennen Company was a leading New Jersey manufacturer until Colgate bought it in 1992.
Mr. Mark put up no resistance, saying in a statement and in letters to a few dozen people who complained today, that Colgate was sorry "for the disrespectful and disparaging advertisement."
Asked if Mr. DiFrancesco would have dropped the gloves to battle Mr. Mark had he not apologized, the acting governor's spokeswoman, Rae Hutton, said Mr. DiFrancesco "believed that our hockey team would have taken care of things anyway."

HEADLINE: Old Fuels And Poor Policy 

BYLINE:  By Bill Richardson; Bill Richardson, a professor at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, was secretary of energy from 1998 to 2001.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
The Bush administration's energy policy, centered primarily on increasing the supply of oil, coal and nuclear power, is shortsighted and misaimed, focusing too much on the wrong fuels and too firmly on supply.
 There is no question that we need to reduce our dependency on foreign oil. Energy companies now enjoying record profits should use their newly minted resources to pursue additional exploration and to build desperately needed refining capacity. But drilling for oil need not be conducted in environmentally sensitive areas. And since oil is not a major fuel for power plants, finding more of it will do little to address an issue that demands immediate attention: providing for our growing needs for electricity. 
 Coal is an abundant energy source. But it should not be the fuel of choice for power plants, either, as President Bush signaled it would be when he rescinded a campaign pledge to regulate carbon dioxide emissions. Vice President Dick Cheney said last week that coal would be a primary source of power generation for years to come.
We are likely to need 1,000 new power plants by 2020. It is preferable that they be clean, efficient, gas-fired plants that emit few pollutants. Technological investment and changes in plants to increase energy efficiency will be curtailed if we continue on an exclusively pro-coal path.
Despite current capacity and price problems, clean-burning natural gas should be recognized as America's best source of energy for supplying electricity in the future. Meeting the nation's generation demands will require that we not only find and produce 60 percent more natural gas, but deliver it to markets. We need to be aggressive in the construction of 30,000 miles of new gas transmission lines and 275,000 miles of new distribution lines. All Americans should support construction of the proposed transcontinental natural gas pipeline, following the most economical route from Alaska's North Slope to the lower 48 states.
As for nuclear power, we have not yet resolved the intractable problem of where to store the thousands of metric tons of nuclear waste scattered across the country. False expectations should not be raised. We cannot build new power plants before we decide whether Yucca Mountain in Nevada is scientifically and environmentally suitable as a long-term depository. The contentious debate on its suitability should be made on the basis of science and not politics.
But no matter what the fuels, supply is only one element of energy policy. And because it takes a long time to develop new sources or build new infrastructure, the supply side is necessarily the longer-term part of our planning. Energy efficiency -- investments in developing and deploying technology to increase the efficient use of our scarce energy resources -- is our best bet for meeting the nation's shorter-term energy needs.
Last week's speech by Vice President Cheney cleverly showered energy efficiency and conservation solutions with faint praise. With the federal government the biggest energy consumer, the administration is right to cut its own energy consumption, if only by repeating the guidelines given last year. But much more can and must be done.
Increasing the efficiency of our vehicle fleet by just three miles a gallon would save us one million barrels of oil per day, out of the roughly 10 million barrels we import. Regrettably, Mr. Bush reduced the Energy Department's budget for energy efficiency and renewable energy programs by 30 percent. A partnership with automakers to increase mileage in vehicles to 80 miles a gallon was also significantly cut. The Bush Energy Department also caved in to the air conditioning industry to block a rule requiring residential central air conditioners to be more efficient.
It is important to the nation's future that we take a bipartisan and balanced approach to energy policy. Everyone needs to recognize that energy and environmental policy are two sides of the same coin. Perhaps most important, we need to emphasize supply and demand in equal measure. In the end, this balance will be the true recipe for success.

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Op-Ed 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

HEADLINE: Revolt at the U.N. 

 BODY:
Thanks in part to the inattention of the Bush administration, the United States lost its seat on the United Nations Human Rights Commission this week for the first time since the panel was established in 1947. But the administration's failure to detect and defeat the brewing rebellion among other nations was only one element of an embarrassing defeat. Even more important was the rising resentment abroad about America's often patronizing treatment of the U.N. and Washington's disdain for international compacts on issues ranging from the environment to the use of land mines.
 Critics of the U.N. in the administration and Congress will doubtless blame the world organization for the loss of the seat and cite it as another reason to withhold Washington's financial support and to take other punitive actions. Such a response would ignore the underlying issues that precipitated the revolt and only worsen American relations with the U.N., an institution with the potential to be a major asset to American diplomacy. 
 The Human Rights Commission itself is an example of the positive role the U.N. can play. The commission, which meets in Geneva, is often frustratingly bureaucratic, and counts among its members some of the world's most egregious violators of human rights, including Sudan, Pakistan and Togo. But this year the commission condemned human rights abuses in Cuba and Iran, and censured Russia for its actions in Chechnya. It sends special rapporteurs to investigate violations, a spotlight that is profoundly embarrassing to dictators. International human rights groups have correctly warned that the commission may be inactive without American leadership and that Washington's voice on human rights issues will be weakened. 
The United States was dropped from the commission when the three seats reserved for Western nations in this year's balloting went to France, Austria and Sweden in a vote of the 54 members of the Economic and Social Council, the U.N. body that oversees the commission. American diplomats apparently complacently assumed the American seat was safe after 43 nations assured Washington of their support and did not realize a revolt was developing, encouraged by human rights abusers, including Cuba and China. Washington also failed to persuade Austria or Sweden to pull out of the race. The breakdown may be partly due to the absence of a new American ambassador to the U.N. The White House has selected John Negroponte, an experienced diplomat, but has yet to submit his nomination to the Senate. 
President Bush and Secretary of State Colin Powell must be mindful of the erosion of international respect for the United States, even among some of its European allies. Not all the foreign complaints are justified. Washington has long been the commission's fiercest defender of Israel and the author of the most aggressive resolutions condemning nations such as China and Cuba. Those policies are entirely appropriate.
But other American behavior, including a tendency to treat the U.N. as a benighted and irritating stepchild, has needlessly provoked opposition. Washington's failure to pay U.N. dues is the most conspicuous example. But member states are also angry about the Pentagon's insistence that Americans not be covered by an international criminal court, the Bush administration's withdrawal from talks about global warning and even Washington's policies of pushing poor countries not to make copies of AIDS drugs. President Bush's open contempt for the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty has alarmed not only Russia, the other signatory to the accord, but NATO allies as well. 
Until a new election next year when Washington can try to reclaim membership on the Human Rights Commission, the organization is likely to take a softer line on most nations, and a more aggressive one toward Israel. But the more important fallout from this week's vote will probably come in Washington. The Bush administration and responsible members of Congress must move quickly to prevent a backlash against the U.N. 
Payment of Washington's back dues is vital to maintaining American influence at the U.N. The payment plan that was carefully negotiated by Richard Holbrooke in the last days of the Clinton administration remains a reasonable deal for the United States and should be approved by the House, where it has been stalled. The lesson of the commission vote is not that the U.N. is inherently inimical to American interests, but rather that Washington has to do a better job of working with other nations if it wants to retain its authority at the U.N.

HEADLINE: Cuomo and McCall Make Pitches to Party 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: COLONIE, N.Y., May 4 

 BODY:
A gathering of state Democrats here provided a preview of next year's gubernatorial campaign, as H. Carl McCall and Andrew M. Cuomo both dipped into national politics to make cases for themselves and against Gov. George E. Pataki.
 Mr. Cuomo, the former United States housing secretary who has worked in Washington for the last eight years, laid claim to Clinton-style centrism and economic growth. He also noted the governor's repeated appearances in state-financed advertising, calling on him to return at least $20 million spent on such ads to the state. 
 Mr. McCall, the state comptroller, likened Mr. Pataki to President Bush and attacked the governor's record on school financing, health care, energy and toxic waste cleanup. He also fired the only intra-party barb of the day, an indirect swipe at Mr. Cuomo's father, the former governor Mario M. Cuomo.
The meeting of the Democratic State Committee, at a hotel in this Albany suburb, was widely viewed as a showcase for the rivals, who have been jockeying for position for more than a year. While Mr. McCall remains the favorite of the party's leaders and elected officials, Mr. Cuomo -- who leads the comptroller in early primary polls -- got an enthusiastic reception.
Mr. Cuomo and his aides were determined to avoid a repeat of last year's state party convention, when a crowd that knew the comptroller better cheered him loudly but sat largely silent during Mr. Cuomo's speech. Today, Mr. Cuomo's camp made sure their allies, buttons and signs were out in force, slipped fliers under each state committee member's hotel door, and held a lunch for the committee before the meeting.
"I think the contrast was clear," Mr. Cuomo said after the event.
The gathering of more than 200 party officials demonstrated the early interest the race for governor is generating, even with the primary 16 months away. The two men sought to tap into New York's overwhelmingly Democratic leanings in national politics, and both roused the crowd with pointed attacks on the governor.
Mr. McCall linked Governor Pataki to "the am-Bush administration, turning the clock back" on issues like environmental protection. "It's hard now to be proud to be a United States citizen when you consider what they are trying to do," he said.
Governor Pataki, he said, is "trying to act like a Democrat and invade our Democratic base," by wooing Puerto Rican voters and women.
When his turn came, Mr. Cuomo referred several times to his association with President Clinton and the economic boom of the last decade. His remarks also were a subtle reminder of the generational gap between Mr. Cuomo, 43, and Mr. McCall, 65.
"There's a formula for the new Democratic Party," he said, one of promoting economic growth and smaller government. "I know it works; I was in the laboratory when they developed it."
He said that as housing secretary, he had focused on poor areas, like "Indian reservations in South Dakota, and upstate New York."
Governor Pataki's surrogates who attended painted both Democrats as holdovers from a worse time, when the elder Mr. Cuomo was governor.
"Andrew Cuomo and Carl McCall would like New Yorkers to forget what happened," said Patrick McCarthy, executive director of the state Republican Party. "Jobs were fleeing New York, taxes were at an all-time high, 1 in 11 New Yorkers was on welfare. And that all changed when George Pataki was elected governor."
At his lunch, Mr. Cuomo accused the governor of using public funds to promote himself by appearing in ads for state programs.
"You just have to turn on your TV set, you'll see George Pataki," he said. "Now, it may be the only place you'll see George Pataki is doing state advertisements. But you will see him there, and you pay to see him there. It's almost like pay-per-view. You pay your taxes and then you view Pataki on television."
Mr. McCarthy called the charge "the height of hypocrisy," saying that as cabinet secretary Mr. Cuomo had used public funds for self-promotion and politically motivated travel.
Mr. McCall dwelled on the particulars of Mr. Pataki's record more than Mr. Cuomo did, saying the governor had ignored a crisis in urban schools and a need to revamp the state's school aid formula, and had tried to weaken toxic cleanup standards. "If you've got no vision and you've got no commitment," he said, "you've got no business being the governor of the state of New York." 
The comptroller also indirectly disparaged Mario M. Cuomo, who, after 12 years as governor, lost to Governor Pataki in 1994. Looking back to that time, Mr. McCall said: "The party was in chaos, local organizations had been ignored. Leadership was distant and disconnected. We ended up demoralized, in debt, in disarray."
Andrew Cuomo would not respond directly to those comments, saying he preferred to remain positive.

HEADLINE: Exit Wounds 

BYLINE:  By Charles Taylor; Charles Taylor is a contributing writer for Salon.com.

 BODY:
 Outcast
By Jose Latour.
295 pp. New York:
William Morrow. $24.
 IT takes the Cuban writer Jose Latour only a few paragraphs to nail the milieu of 90's Havana in his new novel. Here his schoolteacher hero, Elliot Steil, recounts his day:
"Trying day, Steil reflected. His coffee and sugar reserves had simultaneously given out two days before, and breakfast had consisted of 40 grams of stale white bread washed down with a glass of cold water. A few minutes later he found his bike's rear tire punctured. He spent 75 minutes waiting for a bus, and at 10:02 a.m. punched his card at the Polytechnic Institute where he taught English, two hours and two minutes late.
"Lunch was a meager, poorly seasoned mixture of rice and insufficiently cooked red beans escorted by overripe tomatoes. The teacher had left the building at 5 p.m. pondering if he should walk home or waste some more of his free time on the almost nonexistent Havana public transportation system. The scheduled 8 to 11 p.m. blackout and pending household chores led him to cover the eight kilometers on foot."
That accumulation of annoyances is so vivid that by the time you reach the end you feel worn out and you still have hours to go until Steil's bedtime. Who wouldn't be ready to bolt for the United States? 
Steil gets his chance in the person of a man named Dan Gastler, who introduces himself as a friend of Steil's late father. Gastler explains that the dying, elder Steil has paid him to effect the younger Steil's escape from Cuba. Steil, fed up with the humiliations and intrusions that a Cuban not sufficiently enamored of Castro's revolution is prone to, agrees to Gastler's plan to swim to where his yacht will be anchored. 
All goes according to plan -- except the part where Gastler tries to kill Steil by pushing him overboard. Steil survives, encountering some other Cubans making their way to Miami on a homemade raft; once settled in the States, he sets about discovering why Gastler wanted him dead.
The hard-boiled sleuthing that follows is economical, smooth and entirely perfunctory. At its best, "Outcast" is too good a novel to fit into the narrow genre in which Latour wants to jam it. The increasingly hard-boiled attitude serves the novel in one way: it allows no room for a judgmental attitude toward the life of crime in which Steil casually indulges (stealing cars) to bring him closer to his dreams of revenge. 
The most interesting thing about "Outcast," after Latour's portrait of Cuba as a barely functioning dictatorship, is his take on the predicament of Cubans who come here. Steil's girlfriend, Fidelia (she was part of the rafting group that saved him), writes in her diary, "I walk into a drugstore and find a shelf stocked with 10 different brands of toothbrushes, each brand offering 10 different models; each model, 10 colors; each color, 10 toothbrushes dangling from a peg." It's mind-boggling to her. But for the refugees, it's a new kind of trap. Fidelia writes, "You recall the pitiful Cuban stores and feel, actually feel, the across-the-board failure of a materialism devoid of substance." 
THAT'S believable coming from someone unable to relate to a country where, for most, the affordability of something like a toothbrush is never in question. It's also a crock. I have a feeling that most Cuban refugees would tell you that when you don't have to worry about basic necessities, the soul takes care of itself. Fidelia's observation is that old canard about how suffering enriches the soul presented as a critique of materialism. 
Latour, who lives in Havana and who is the author of six previous novels ("Outcast" is his first book written in English), is on much stronger ground when Fidelia compares the safety of her son's school in Cuba with the dangers of American public schools. Here Latour implies the conclusion that his character can't bring herself to formulate: that perfect safety is achievable, but only in a dictatorship. It's in moments like this, and in the tenuous pleasures of Steil's new existence, that Latour suggests a potent and thorny theme: freedom as an anticlimax.

HEADLINE: Baseball Books in Brief 

BYLINE:  By Allen Barra 

 BODY:
 The Diamond In The Bronx
Yankee Stadium and the Politics
of New York.
By Neil J. Sullivan.
Oxford University, $30.
 Neil J. Sullivan uses the history of Yankee Stadium to reflect the currents of change that have swept through New York in the past century, particularly in the Bronx. He is very good on the social and political background that led to the baseball boom of the 1920's. Yankee Stadium was not simply the House That Ruth Built; it resulted from the increasing wealth of the rising multiethnic fan base that attached itself to Babe Ruth. Sullivan, who teaches public affairs at Baruch College, is also good on sizing up the new stadium game as it is currently played by baseball owners around the country. "The first point that can be held with near certainty," he writes, "is that an economic investment in a stadium will not be returned"; "wealth is not being created by the stadium so much as it is being diverted from one place to another." However, when it comes time to bring together the different strands of his ambitious book, Sullivan is tenuous and relies too much on secondhand material. And he repeats some of baseball's most cherished misinformation: Arnold Rothstein did not fix the 1919 World Series. "The Diamond in the Bronx" has many insights into the politics of the new stadium business and has some original observations about the rise of baseball in New York, but it reads like parts of two or even three books whose theses are not fully developed. Allen Barra
