HEADLINE: Q and A 

BYLINE:  By PAUL FREIREICH

 BODY:
The Jews of Manaus
Q. We are interested in learning about places of Jewish interest in Manaus, Brazil. -- Anita Lifson, Washington 
 A. About 900 miles inland from the Atlantic, Manaus is the capital of the state of Amazonas, in northwest Brazil. Of the city's 1.5 million people, about 800 are Jewish, according to Isaac Dahan, the local synagogue's cantor. 
 The Jewish community of Manaus dates from about 1890, when Jews were fleeing poverty and an uncertain life in Morocco and when Brazil was experiencing a rubber boom. The smuggling of seeds for rubber trees out of Brazil to England in 1876 and the successful planting of seedlings in Indonesia and Ceylon eventually helped cause the bubble to burst.
Early in the 20th century, there were 4,000 Jews in Manaus. Its first synagogue opened in 1920 and the second followed 17 years later. The two merged in 1960 when the Beth Yaacov-Rabi Meyr synagogue was built at 630, Rua Leonardo Malcher; telephone (55-92) 234-9558. Services are held on Saturday and on the major holidays. Only last month 200 people attended a seder on the second night of Passover at the community center, the Clube Hebraica Manaus, 1842, Avenida Joaquim Nabuco; (55-92) 233-0217.
There are no scheduled guided tours to Jewish sites, one of which is a cemetery. But Fontur Travel Agency, at (55-92) 658-3052, can arrange a three-hour tour by car with an English-speaking guide for $110 a couple. 
Among the attractions of Manaus, a major jumping-off spot for tours of the Amazon, is the grand 700-seat Teatro Amazonas that dates from 1896, the era of the rubber boom. For a glimpse, visit www.internext.com .br/demasi. An opera festival, already in progress at the theater, on the Rua Tapajos, runs until May 26. Telephone: (55-92) 622-1880.

Biking in Amsterdam
Q. My husband and I will be vacationing in Amsterdam in June with our children, aged 13 and 19. Ideally, we would like daylong bike trips from Amsterdam that might help them meet other students. -- S. C., Bethlehem, Pa.
A. There are at least a couple of companies in Amsterdam that run daily tours on rented bikes and there are some that do just rentals. 
Mike's Bike Tours, at Lijnbaans gracht 302A, telephone (31-20) 6227970, attracts students and backpackers, says its manager, Mike Luksetitch. On the Web, see www .mikesbiketours.com/amsterdam .html. Tours, which meet in front of the west entrance of the Rijks museum, run three to four hours. From May 1 to Aug. 31, they start at 11:30 and 4 p.m. The price, now $15.10, at 2.45 guilders to the dollar, rises to $17.15 on June 1. A rental without a tour is $10.20 a day. Credit cards not accepted. The bicycles used are Schwinns with six gears.
While there may be 15 to 20 cyclists on an average tour, there is no maximum. Bicyclists travel along the Amstel River, passing a windmill, farm and factory that makes both cheese and clogs. Then they pass the Vondel Park, break for a beer at the square known as the Leidseplein. (Your 13-year-old need not drink, of course, but you may or may not feel comfortable with a stop at a pub.) 
If time permits, the route may include the Jordaan district, sort of a miniature Greenwich Village; the Anne Frank House or the West Church (Westkerk). 
Yellow Bike Guided Tours, at Nieuwzijds Kolk 29 (near Centraal Station), (31-20) 6206940, fax (31-20) 6207 140, www.yellowbike.nl, runs tours of the city and the countryside daily from April 1 to Oct. 31. The three-hour city tours depart at 9:30 a.m. and 1 p.m., and cost $14.25; the six-hour countryside tours depart at 11 a.m., and cost $18.40. Credit cards are not accepted. 
Tour groups are limited in size to15 for the country and 12 for the city. The bikes are the company's own Yellow Bikes, which have no gears. 
Bicyclists on the city tour pass by or through the harbor, the Anne Frank House, the Jordaan district and the Vondel Park, the Van Gogh Museum, the Rembrandt House and the red light district. Along the way, there's a stop for a coffee break. The countryside tour heads north of Amsterdam, follows the dike and passes a windmill. It stops for lunch at a pancake house in Broek, which is not included in the charge. 
Visitors to Amsterdam who prefer to strike out on their own can rent from one of these companies, whose rates depend on the model: 
MacBike, Mr. Visserplein 2, (31-20) 6200985, fax (31-20) 4222579; www.macbike.nl. The daily rate is $5.10 to $7.65. The company plans to offer guided three-hour tours daily for $10.20 plus the bike rental fee. 
Bike City, 68-70 Bloemgracht, (31-20) 6263721, fax (31-20) 4223326; www.bikecity.nl. The rate is 12.50 to 23.50 guilders. If a credit card is used, a 5 percent charge is added.

Seattle to Vancouver
Q. My family of 10 adults is meeting in Seattle with plans to travel to Vancouver to start an Alaskan cruise. Rather than pay 10 separate fares of $45 to the cruise company, we thought it might be more fun to rent a van or a bus and driver if the cost were comparable to the $450 we would otherwise pay. Can you advise? -- Ernest Prupi, Seabrook Island, S.C.
A. It takes about three hours to cover the 140 miles between Seattle-Tacoma International Airport and Vancouver. For 10 people, a van or a minibus are the realistic options. A stretch limousine may sound like the stuff of fantasy, but it won't have room for all the luggage. 
Bayview Limousine Service, 22001 Pacific Highway South, Des Moines; (800) 606-7880 or (206) 824-6200, fax (206) 824-9884, www.bayviewlimo .com. It has Ford and Dodge vans in the 1998 to 2000 model years. Normally, they seat 14 passengers plus the driver. But to allow room for luggage, the rear seat is taken out, which still allows room for 10 passengers. The rate is $55 an hour, with a six-hour minimum. Added to that is a 20 percent tip plus a $4 airport parking charge and, for those who prefer to be met at the gate rather than the baggage claim area, another $10. Total: $410.
Beeline Tours, 1308 North 38th, Seattle; (800) 959-8387 or (206) 632-5162; cozybus@beelinetours.com. The rate is $550 for the trip on a 15-passenger minibus, which is basically a 1995 Ford Eldorado. Tips are not built into the fee structure. "They are accepted and earned, but not required," Michael Rogers, president of the company, said. Passengers are picked up at south end of the airport. HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT; 
Hawaii Still Resists Cruise Ship Gambling

BYLINE:  By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
HAWAII has consistently rejected legalized gambling, making it one of only three states, including Utah and Tennessee, opposed to casinos, horse racing, state lotteries and other forms of wagering. Last year a proposal to allow gambling on cruise ships in Hawaii waters, on condition that 96 percent of the state's share of the gambling revenues be allotted to public education, passed the House Tourism Committee but stalled in the legislature. 
 But even if sentiment turned in favor of cruise ship gambling, approval would likely be stymied by federal prohibitions. 
 The most recent such law, passed in December, prohibits cruise ships with casinos from starting and ending cruises in Hawaii. The only ship that met those criteria was Norwegian Cruise Line's SuperStar Leo, which was scheduled to move from Asia to Hawaii this December to begin year-round weekly cruises within the Hawaiian Islands, so there was little doubt what vessel Congress had in mind. 
Even before passage of the law, officials of N.C.L., as the Malaysian-owned cruise line is known, had agreed to shutter the SuperStar Leo's casino while in Hawaiian waters, the same policy followed by cruise ships that visit Hawaii on their way to or from foreign ports. Besides, each weekly SuperStar Leo cruise was to include a three-day excursion to Fanning Island in Kiribati, south of Hawaii, a round-trip journey of about 2,100 miles, during which the ship's casino would be open. Or so went the plan.
Once the prohibition was passed, the SuperStar Leo could still visit Kiribati, but it could neither leave from nor return to Hawaii unless it got rid of its casino. But to the surprise of industry officials, who thought N.C.L. would turn its back on Hawaii, the company stayed. In a phone interview, Colin Veitch, N.C.L.'s president, said the company believes that the underserved Hawaiian market held great promise with or without gambling revenues. "On-board gambling revenue amounts to between 5 to 7 percent of our total net revenue," he said, "about what we make from the bar, the on-board shops or from land packages." Most cruise line revenues, he added, come from passengers' fares. And even without a casino, he said, he expected the 1,960-passenger SuperStar Leo to be full year round.
But in March, N.C.L., owned by Star Cruises, said it would keep the SuperStar Leo in Asia and deploy to Hawaii the 2,200-passenger Norwegian Star, under construction in Germany. Mr. Veitch said that it made more economic sense to keep the Leo where it is, with its casino intact, and build the Star without a casino. So the Star is set to depart Honolulu on its initial Hawaiian itinerary on Dec. 16, the same day the SuperStar Leo had been scheduled to depart, and on the same itinerary. 
But why had the Leo been singled out by Congress in the first place? Piecing together that puzzle requires recalling the military appropriations bill passed by Congress in 1997 and signed by President Clinton. Its passage, vigorously supported by Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, and by the Defense Department, prompted Senator John McCain of Arizona to criticize it for awarding a monopoly to American Classic Voyages, which owns American Hawaii Cruises, a longtime fixture in the Islands. 
The provision decreed that no other company may operate any cruise ship accommodating at least 275 passengers among or between the Hawaiian Islands for at least 25 years. And it exempted American Classic Voyages from the law requiring that American ships be used to transport passengers between United States ports. As a result, American Classic bought Holland America's Nieuw Amsterdam, reflagged it as a United States vessel and renamed it the Patriot. In return for the money from Congress -- including a provision allocating $250,000 from a Defense Department maritime-technology program for initial design, which Senator McCain criticized as "an example of pork-barrel spending" -- American Classic agreed to build two cruise ships in the United States. But since the 1997 law did not prevent foreign-flag ships from carrying passengers between two or more American ports, as long as they also visited a foreign port during the cruise, N.C.L. did not anticipate any problems. While there are no foreign ports close to Hawaii suitable for cruise ship visits, Mr. Veitch said, the SuperStar Leo can reach 25 knots, about 5 knots faster than ships cruising the Caribbean, and therefore it could make the trip in each direction to Fanning Island and still have time to cruise the Hawaiian Islands. 
Until last fall no foreign ships were based in Hawaii and none were anticipated, whereupon N.C.L. announced SuperStar Leo's planned deployment to Honolulu with its weekly excursion to Fanning Island. In return, Senator Inouye added to the Labor Department appropriations bill a provision to ban casinos on cruise ships whose voyages start or end in Hawaii, even while those ships are in international waters. The bill passed handily, despite criticism from Gov. Benjamin J. Cayetano of Hawaii, who contended that cruise ship gambling was a state matter, not an issue for Washington.
Senator McCain also criticized the bill, contending that it would further insulate American Classic Voyages from competition -- which Senator Inouye and American Classic deny. Senator Inouye, a longtime opponent of gambling in Hawaii, said that his provision was intended to clarify any ambiguity in federal law "as to what types of gambling on board vessels are allowed and not allowed in Hawaii."
The various laws affecting cruise ship gambling could be repealed, and there may be increased sentiment to do so if Hawaii tourism is hurt by the nation's softening economy; the cost of energy in California, Hawaii's biggest domestic source of tourists; and by the continuing economic woes in Japan, Hawaii's second biggest tourist market. For now, though, those laws seem most likely to be around a long time.

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 5-6-01: On Language; 
Fulminations

BYLINE:  By William Safire 

 BODY:
The specialists are in open rebellion at the theft of their vocabularies. Egged on by sly agitation in this space to fulminate about raids by the general public on their fields' linguistic larders, the specialists have at last found an outlet for their ire at the twisting of their favorite terms.
 "I cannot resist the invitation to rail against the boneheaded misuse of organic," fulminates Stephen Slatin, at the department of physiology and biophysics of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx. "It does not, or certainly should not, mean 'vegetables grown without fertilizers' or 'fruit produced without pesticides.' " 
 Right on, says Richard Fireman of Chicago: "Organic used to mean 'carbon based.' An 'inorganic food' would be an oxymoron" -- prescriptive usagists would insist on the more specific "contradiction in terms" -- unless someone knows a way to get nourishment from stones."
Chemists think of an "organized body" as an animal or plant containing compounds derived from hydrocarbons; they call that kind of chemistry organic and bristle at the "unscientific" extension of meaning into food "grown without chemical additives or genetic manipulation." 
Geologists, too, excoriate lay writers with rocks in their heads. When I wrote that San Jose was the epicenter of the California computer industry's power consumption," Julian Stone of Rumson, N.J., noted: "Epicenter is a scientific term referring to the point on the surface of the earth above the underground focus of an earthquake. Do you mean that the center of power consumption in California is underground?" 
The geophysicist Joseph D. Sides adds, "Writers should be advised that epi- no more intensifies the meaning of center than does pen- intensify the meaning of ultimate." (The prefix epi- most often means "on" or "over"; pen, not a prefix, is from the Latin paene, "almost.") Sides defines epicenter as "the point on the surface of the earth vertically above the center of an earthquake, the quake's 'hypocenter.' " It is also, he says, "the point on the earth's surface vertically below the atmospheric detonation of a bomb, the 'hypercenter' of the explosion." He finds "misuse of the offending term attributable to spurious erudition on the part of the writers combined with scientific illiteracy on the part of copy editors."
Is your understanding of these terms growing exponentially? No! thunders a totality of mathematicians. "I'm vexed to hear some trend described as 'growing exponentially' when the writer means it is growing rapidly," writes Maurice Fox of Arlington, Va. "Exponential growth is not necessarily rapid. The mathematical term merely describes something whose rate of growth is proportional to its size. My savings account grows exponentially but not rapidly."
Geometric, or compound, growth can be fast or slow; if our economy grows by 0.1 percent a year, that's exponential, but the stock market tanks. A professor of physics at Tufts University, Roger Tobin, is equally annoyed at the lay misuse of exponential to mean "a whole lot," referring to quantity rather than rate of growth, "but to say my annoyance is exponentially greater today than yesterday is gibberish."
Tobin is not offended, however, by a general use of quantum to mean "sudden," provided we don't use it to mean "huge": "The crucial characteristic of a quantum jump isn't its size but its abruptness -- something goes from one state to another without passing through any intermediate states in between." That's one of the "stolen meanings" that started this specialist agitation, which is growing fast if not exponentially. 
Those intellectuals who name their companion animals Peeve (to be able to say "This is my pet, Peeve") have as their ally Jacques Barzun, America's only best-selling nonagenarian. "A couple of misplaced technicalities," he writes from San Antonio. "Synergy, which belongs to physiology and relates to the working together of muscles, etc. Applied to the merger of two clothing firms (actual), it is ridiculous, especially since technically the meaning is 'greater effect than the sum of the efforts.' " 
A semantic theft by educators is module, which Professor Barzun says "is used ambiguously to mean 'a class period' and 'a portion of program.' (Years ago, it was 'nucleus.') A module in architecture or building generally is a part that does not change size, character or function and thus serves as a measure of a larger whole. In a column, it is the measurement itself -- half the diameter of the base." 
Architects, too have their linguistic betes noires. ("Peeve, meet my bete, Noire.") "I am very annoyed at the current usage of the term architect," writes Fran Read, who is one. "Examples include 'architect of the peace plan,' 'software architect' and in the phrase spoken by several C.E.O.'s and commentators on CNBC, 'We rearchitected the software.' "
Read's pique is superstructured by Tim Groninger, a project engineer. "Word thievery in engineering has become especially acute," he seethes, "due to the ever-growing hunger for words in the world of computers. I can no longer use the word architecture in the traditional sense. The word now implies the design and construction of computer networks, not buildings."
The architect Edwin Elias-Narvaez piles on with "It is particularly galling to perform an Internet search for architect only to find thousands of references having nothing to do with the traditional meaning of the word." 
(The magazine Architectural Record recently interviewed Richard Saul Wurman, who said: "I invented the term information architect in 1975, when I was national chairman of the A.I.A. convention in Philadelphia. It was called 'The Architecture of Information.' Now I would say that somewhere between 20,000 and 100,000 people in the U.S. have information architect on their business cards.")
Fulminations from other fields are still coming in. Ophthalmologists narrow their eyes at the nearsighted semantic theft of their myopic. Yoga practitioners in rooster position cock-a-doodle mellowly but firmly about the extension of guru from "revered teacher and spiritual leader" to a sarcastic "self-appointed cult figure." And most of all, logicians everywhere pose the query, What are the philistines doing to our beg the question?
The specialists are not going to take it anymore. Semantic extensionists who want to beat them back should write to onlanguage@nytimes.com or On Language, The New York Times Washington Bureau, 1627 I Street NW, Washington, D.C. 20006. I'll be here at the epicenter.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

PERSON: SAFIRE, WILLIAM 

GEOGRAPHIC: SAN JOSE, CA, USA (74%) EARTH (93%); CALIFORNIA, USA (92%); VIRGINIA, USA (72%) UNITED STATES (92%)

TITLE: ON LANGUAGE (TIMES COLUMN)

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 5-6-01; 
Pox Populi

BYLINE:  By Verlyn Klinkenborg; Verlyn Klinkenborg is a member of the New York Times editorial board.

 BODY:
Since Feb. 19, Britain has been under the pall of foot-and-mouth disease, or aftosa fever, as it's called in other parts of the world. The clinical slides of afflicted animals are unpleasant enough. They show blistered tongues and gums, lesions on the coronary band, where hair meets hoof, a look of slackness and profuse salivation. But the news photographs are genuinely gruesome -- stiff, swollen cattle stacked on their backs in long rows for mass interment, sheep penned in great herds for killing, farmers looking away from the sight of it all in grief and disgust. If you believe Daniel Defoe, whose "A Journal of the Plague Year" is closely attested fiction, one of the worst horrors of the 1665 London plague was the shutting up of houses where infection was discovered. By official order, healthy occupants were imprisoned with the dying, a red cross marked on the door, a watchman posted outside. That's how the containment of foot-and-mouth disease works too. 
 Foot-and-mouth disease is a viral infection that causes fever, blisters and lesions, and results in weight loss and a reduction in milk production. It doesn't kill adult animals. It doesn't have to. The human fear of contagion kills them. Every disease is economic, to some extent, but foot-and-mouth is nearly a purely economic disease. Its worst effects are caused by fear of the economic consequences of its spread. Beasts that are healthy or would otherwise get well are destroyed not to save them from suffering but to keep them from endangering the market value of other, unaffected livestock. Above all, they're destroyed to protect international trade, since countries like the United States ban imports from countries where animals have been infected as well as those where they have been vaccinated (since it can be hard to tell vaccinated animals from infected ones). People who have no contact with agriculture -- most of us, in other words -- are sharply reminded from time to time that in the common agricultural view of things, cattle and sheep are primarily economic beings, their well-being, their care, their ultimate fate determined almost entirely by the investment they represent. This is one of those times. 
 It's not just images of mass killing, however, that make foot-and-mouth so disturbing. It's the fear of mass contagion, a fear that returns us, somehow, to a time of epidemics like smallpox or bubonic plague or Spanish influenza, a time when effective barriers against the spread of disease were almost nonexistent. Foot-and-mouth disease is an old-fashioned, pestilential scourge -- a word derived from the Latin excoriare, meaning, aptly, to strip off the hide. Foot-and-mouth moves swiftly, vehemently. It sifts across borders, carried on the wind, on the breath of animals, its symptoms condemning entire herds, whole regions. This is a mode of disease -- highly and pervasively contagious, like smallpox -- that's no longer familiar to most of us, not even in our nightmares.
The diseases we tend to dread these days are what might be called deep diseases: slow to catch, the catching and the ultimate causes often hidden as a result. Many cancers are deep diseases, and so is AIDS. Even when they are epidemic, we tend to think of these as inherently personal diseases. They don't rush through a whole society, sweeping away entire neighborhoods in a week or a month, driving the population into exile or seclusion. Deep diseases turn the body against itself, slowly twisting biological coherence into incoherence, inciting rebellion from within. 
Bovine spongiform encephalopathy, better known as B.S.E. or mad cow disease, is a deep disease, too, caused by prions, abnormally folded proteins that form clusters and slowly perforate the brain. Like AIDS, it's a relatively new deep disease. The European outbreak that was first recorded in 1986 was almost certainly caused when animal protein (some of it tainted with prions) was fed to cattle, part of the quest for a cheaper protein supplement and a greater profit margin in intensive agriculture. When humans eat meat containing prions, they don't contract B.S.E., but they can contract a related disease called new variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob, which results in dementia, abrupt muscular jerking, seizures and death. 
Terrible as foot-and-mouth disease is, its superficiality and epidemiological haste are almost merciful. More than 1,400 cases have been identified in Britain since Feb. 19, and 2,240,000 animals, most of them sheep, have been either slaughtered or marked for slaughter. It's a staggering rate of destruction, but when the destruction is done, there's an ascertainable chance that the disease will have been contained. B.S.E. is a different story. Britain has destroyed nearly five million ruminant farm animals, and the number of British B.S.E. cases has fallen from nearly 37,000 in 1992 to fewer than 1,500 last year. But because it can take years to show itself, and because the official response to it was so sullen and so politically corrupt at first, there's really no gauging its spread. In recent months, it has appeared in several European countries where it was unknown before. The question waiting to be answered is, Where is B.S.E. still lurking? A pungent question, since it may be lurking in some of us.
That deep fear is the lingering ghost behind the present foot-and-mouth outbreak. Though the two diseases are profoundly different, the imagery that surrounds them is so close -- the verdant countryside, the piles of dead animals, the grief-stricken farmers -- that it's impossible to consider one in the absence of the other. On a practical level, the decision to kill all the livestock even remotely at risk for foot-and-mouth conforms to the standard agricultural and mathematical models for how to handle this scourge when vaccination is not an option. But on another level it is a form of political self-preservation. When people see the news images of this slaughter and its consuming fires -- smoke billowing out of the green hollows of Cumbria and Devon, smoke tainted by the smell of burning flesh -- they don't think back to the foot-and-mouth outbreak that hit Britain in 1967. They think back only a few years to the discovery of B.S.E. They remember how vociferously John Major's government insisted that nothing was wrong, and how ready it was to put public relations before public safety. The present government remembers it, too, which is one reason that in March and early April parts of Britain looked like the landscape of forgotten contagion.
One disease is never a perfect metaphor for another. There are always fundamental differences, as there are between B.S.E. and foot-and-mouth disease. From a human perspective, these two epidemics are almost ideally distinct: the fatal disease is not contagious; the contagious disease does not affect humans. But it's the resemblance between them that haunts us, not the dissimilarity, a resemblance that evokes other epochs, other epidemics when humans, not animals, were the victims.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut; 
High-End Apartment Projects Planned for Stamford

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
OF nine projects containing nearly 4,000 rental apartments under construction in Stamford or elbowing one another through the city's regulatory pipeline, almost all are flush with amenities: swimming pools, clubhouses, fitness rooms, high-tech business centers, concierges and a smorgasbord of additional offerings.
 Of course, not all will be built at once, said Paxton Kinol, senior director of development for the Connecticut operations of AvalonBay Communities, a Virginia-based company that has been building in Stamford for a decade. "Over the next three years, 1,000 to 1,400 will break ground," he predicted, "and they will be spread so that one project will fill up before the next becomes available. The market can sustain that." 
 Irene Korin, senior executive at Stamford's Office of Economic Development, said, "There is a pent-up demand for 4,000 units" at market rates. In addition, a need exists for 2,800 units of low-cost housing for families earning under $50,000, according to a study last year by Abeles Phillips Preiss & Shapiro Inc. 
"The Stamford area is off the charts for high median income," said Allan Mallach, Abeles's consultant on affordable housing. Calculated by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, the median has jumped to $109,800 this year from $102,400 in 2000. The number of apartments to be offered at market rents of $1,200 for studios to $3,600 for three-bedrooms will probably fill the need in the city. The number of "affordables," estimated at around 260, will not. 
"Families earning $50,000 a year can afford 30 percent, or $1,250 a month, rent, including utilities," Mr. Mallach said, so in a city where the median income is high, it is particularly difficult to get new housing built that is affordable for those earning less than the median.
Rising office-vacancy rates -- now about 10 percent for downtown Stamford, an increase of 1 percentage point to 3 percentage points more than the rate a few months ago, according to various local commercial brokers -- could stall new office construction, already postponed for lack of tenants and financing. Robin Stein, Stamford's land use planner, notes that "the good thing about housing is if the market doesn't prosper, you just reduce the rent." But offices on long-term leases with employee and equipment commitments do not have that flexibility.
One solution is to convert a site slated for office construction to residential construction under existing commercial zoning that allows apartments. That is what is planned for Signature Place, a development by Roseland Property of Short Hills, N.J., which will file plans this month for a three-tower complex of 932 apartments. It will have the distinction of being the tallest building in town, with its largest tower zooming 37 stories, or 350 feet, over downtown Stamford. The project will replace the vacant, weed-infested wilderness behind the Town Center Mall, known for decades as "the hole in the ground."
Marshall Teicher, principal at Roseland, said the towers would be built in two or more phases, with 37,000 square feet of shops, restaurants, greengrocers, video stores, fitness and other service establishments at street level. He hopes to break ground in September and open the first phase 16 months later.
Because its project is within the Urban Redevelopment District, Roseland is eligible for a program in which developers can gain the right to build more units than regulations would normally allow by setting aside money for creating low-cost units on a different site. "You can't just write a check," said Mr. Teicher, who has committed some $2 million. "You have to find the site and get involved with a nonprofit or a builder who will do the construction."
Avalon, the leading apartment builder in town, at least in numbers, is involved in three projects: Avalon Harbor and Grey rock Tower, now under construction, and Hanover Hall, a redevelopment. When they are completed next year, they will bring the company's total to 1,464 apartments in six Stamford projects dating from 1991.
Often criticized for cookie-cutter design and opportunistic use of state statutes to force multifamily housing into some suburban towns by guaranteeing a percentage of low-cost units, Avalon is attempting to make changes. Avalon Harbor will be the company's first waterfront complex, situated on a former oil tank farm at 150 Southfield Avenue. Living rooms will be larger than at its existing projects, balconies will be a more important focus of the design, corner apartments can be custom built, and each tenant will have one free parking space in the 611-car underground garage.
Half of the 68 slips in the project's marina and 88 garage spaces will be reserved for the public, and there will be public access to a fishing pier, pedestrian path and boardwalk over a marsh that is home to a variety of shore birds. Tenants will have exclusive use of the pool, fitness and business centers, indoor basketball and racquetball courts, a billiard room and clubroom. Rents for the 323 units will range from $1,300 a month for a studio to around $2,700 for three bedrooms, and higher for customized units. There will be no below-market apartments. 
But Greyrock Tower, Avalon's 306-unit project at 50 Forest Street on the site of the former Burdick Elementary School, complies with the requirement by the city's Urban Redevelopment District for 34 low-priced apartments for renters earning at most 50 percent of the median. Typically, a two-bedroom apartment at the market rate of $2,300 a month would cost an eligible renter $1,165 at the reduced rate. 
Under construction by Cappelli Enterprises of White Plains, the finished building will be purchased and managed by Avalon. "It's a means of getting new apartments at a predetermined price with little risk," said Mr. Kinol of Avalon. The first four floors of the stepped-down building -- from 17 stories in front to 12 in back -- will contain the concierge's station, business center, leasing office, laundry drop-off and exercise room. A fifth floor clubroom will open onto the pool and the first group of apartments. A garage backs the first four stories. Except for the 34 units, rents for one- to three-bedrooms will be the same as Avalon Harbor's.
At Park Square West in the Urban Redevelopment District under construction by Corcoran-Jennison of Dorchester, Mass., a swimming pool, fitness and business centers, rooftop putting green, game room, juice bar and tea garden will eventually be available to tenants of 433 studios and one- to three-bedroom apartments. To be built in two phases, some units will be ready for occupancy late this month, including a portion of the 86 low-cost units to be rented to tenants whose income is no more than 50 percent of the median. Market rate rents range from $1,575 to $3,600.
ANOTHER project using the off-site provision for low-cost units is under development by Archstone Communities of Boston. Scott Shaul, a principal, said the company had promised $280,000 for that purpose with regard to its 244-unit project on Washington Boulevard overlooking the Mill River. Approved by the Stamford Boards of Finance, Representatives and Planning, it will be considered by the Zoning and Environmental Boards this month. At a site not yet determined, 10 apartments will go to tenants earning no more than 25 percent of the median income, seven to people at 50 percent, and five at 60 percent. 
A second Archstone venture of 160 apartments has broken ground at the corner of Bedford and North Streets. Both projects will contain fitness and business centers, pools and clubhouses. Ground-floor shops and riverside restaurants will be installed at the Washington Boulevard complex.
Another project going before the Zoning Board this month is Starwood Buckingham's 239 town house complex called Palmer Hill, at the Greenwich border on Havemeyer Lane and Palmer Hill Road. Robert Dale, managing partner of Buckingham Partners of Greenwich, said that two- and three-story colonial-style units of one- to three-bedrooms in groups of three to six per cluster will rent for $2,500 to $3,000. A residents' clubhouse, pool, meeting and fitness rooms are included. Occupancy is expected in late 2002, with 10 percent of the units to be rented below market. 
Collins Enterprises of Greenwich is preparing applications for Admirals Wharf at Stamford Harbor, a $200 million-plus mixed-use development. Fifty of its 500 apartments will be offered at reduced rates; amenities include a private yacht club.

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
Fitting Into History's True Fabric

BYLINE:  By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
THOUGH I'm not a big baseball fan, I'm a big fan of baseball fans. It's inspiring to watch them follow the game as if it were a matter of life and death. Many of us follow the cityscape with the same nutty devotion. New York won big a few weeks ago, when the Landmarks Preservation Commission voted unanimously to approve Jean Nouvel's design for a new hotel in SoHo. The decision's physical impact on the cityscape will be contained. But its effect on the city's mental landscape could be immense.
 The site for the 12-story, 180-room hotel is on the north side of Grand Street, between Broadway and Mercer, in the Cast Iron Historic District, one of the nation's first neighborhoods to be designated for protection by preservation laws. Nouvel's design, however, rises well above mere local interest. The designer of such acclaimed works as the Cartier Foundation in Paris and the Lyons Opera House, Nouvel has produced a plan that reflects SoHo's image as an international destination, a district of museums, galleries and fashionable shops and an incubator for design firms linked to the risky Internet economy. 
 Nouvel's design is also risky, at least for a neighborhood that in recent years has invested heavily in cobblestone paving, cast-iron lampposts and other dubious Ye Olde theme park "improvements." In scale, proportions and materials, Nouvel's metal and glass facades recognizably honor the district's cast-iron heritage. But the ratio of glass to metal and, particularly, the treatment of the glass mark this as a contemporary design. It is good, good, good and bad, bad, bad. Complex, just how we like 'em.
But not how the local Community Board likes them, evidently. In approving the design, the city's landmarks agency, led by Jennifer J. Raab, overturned a previous resolution to reject the design by the local community board's landmarks panel. Here is an excerpt from that resolution:
"Whereas the building appears to be a Retro revival of early- or mid-20th century structures; and Whereas, a modern building might be appropriate in the cast iron district, but this is not it; Therefore, be it resolved that Community Board 2 recommends denial of the application."
You must admit, there's a certain magnificence to this collision of legal form and nonsensical content. The resolution might have been even more magnificent if it had come right out and said, "Whereas, it stinks."
I am sympathetic to the framers of this resolution. In a city brutalized by development, the difference between architecture and real estate may be hard to discern. At least the theme-park motifs give the community a sense of control over its fate. More important, there is nothing ignoble about the idea that architecture, as a public art, should share elements of a common language. By the same token, the ideal of a common language depends on the willingness to learn one. The power of buildings to communicate is not entirely contingent on architects. It is a public responsibility to attend to what buildings have to say. That duty, or pleasure, lies substantially with members of the public who assert the authority to judge what architects do.
To be approved by the landmarks commission for building in a historic district, a new design must meet a standard of "appropriateness." This is a legal term. Nobody concerned with art values would ever use it, for a very precise reason: it is evasive. It abdicates responsibility for personal opinion without surrendering the right to exercise it. Like "decency" or "cruel and unusual," the term is unstintingly obedient to prejudice. "Context," another term that appears in the commission's charter, is another euphemism for the right to exclude the unfamiliar.
"Appropriateness" and "context," used as formal terms for architectural evaluation, are period pieces. Their usage reflects generational values, not timeless truths. Battery Park City, an experiment well worth undertaking in 1979, when its master plan and design guidelines were adopted, is perhaps the fullest expression of those values. Paradoxically, the project was built on 92 acres of virgin landfill, with virtually no context to speak of. The design guidelines were based on the facades of prewar housing on the Upper East and West Sides of Manhattan. Here, the decisive line was crossed from preservation to preservationism, the belief that the new buildings in the city should emulate the appearance of old ones.
That was then, this is now. It turns out that few things in New York are more deeply contextual than change. That is the city's great salvation from the uniformity of the grid. Manhattan is a sublime space-time configuration, with time providing the necessary open end. As an experiment in its own right, Battery Park City upheld this tradition. But if "appropriateness" and "context" are to have any constructive use, preservationism's limitations must be taken into account. Those limitations are now part of the history the city has carved into its skin.
Let's say that Nouvel wants to explore the themes of separateness and connectedness in the urban realm. He wants to reflect on the extent to which each of these concepts is actuality or illusion. Obviously, in dealing with these matters, Nouvel will want to take the context of a historical district into account. He will incorporate it into his own artistic framework, in fact. He may also want to explore the history of the site.
But his context will also extend well beyond these local considerations. It may also include the history of philosophy, science, perhaps even of religion. And he will probably seek a relationship to the overarching history of architecture, to the Casa del Fascio, the Schroeder House, the Seagram Building and other landmarks whose architects explored similar ideas in the past.
For the SoHo hotel, Nouvel has drawn on features from adjacent buildings: scale, materials, facade proportions, cornices and so on. But he has also inverted, reversed, abstracted, twisted and otherwise played with these features. He has exploited new technologies in glass, for example, to develop a vocabulary of exposure, veiling, reflection, dissolution, solid and void and gradations on the spectrum from the familiar to the unknown. He has tinted the glass in gray, blue and red, reinterpreting colors typically found in the neighborhood's painted masonry buildings. With perpendicular fins and abstract imagery screened onto the glass, he has given the building skin uncommon depth.
The design shimmers with emotional content: the reds of desire, anger or anxiety, the blues of passivity or urban disconsolation. Rectangular shapes, resembling sprocket holes, are screened onto one facade, inviting passersby to visualize the hotel as it actually is: a setting for dramas of anticipation or escape, for fantasies fulfilled or disappointed, appetites whetted beyond the possibility of satisfaction. This is how the outside world looks from the inside.
These ideas were not developed by those who designed the glass towers of mid-century Manhattan. Nouvel's building is metal and glass. Lever House is metal and glass. So what? Carnegie Hall is brick. The Dakota apartment house is brick. Seen one brick building, seen them all, huh? As a public art form, architecture is subject to any kind of public opinion. Openness is one of the glories of the medium. But you can't build moral authority on lack of curiosity about your subject matter, and architecture shouldn't always be judged by theme park values. Retro? Googie? Lava lamps, anyone? Recourse to such commercial terms only highlights the need for buildings that address the concepts Nouvel has taken on.
An essay on separateness and connectedness may sound like an abstract philosophical exercise. Actually, it is the central issue around which controversies stirred up by new buildings typically revolve. It is also a central question in the efforts of Elias Canetti, Norbert Elias, Hannah Arendt and other thinkers to understand group beliefs, including the appeal of fascism. Where does one person stop and another person start? What makes public opinion change, sometimes overnight? Who wants the Yankees to move from the Bronx? Show hands!
Where does a community start and stop? Clearly, in a city as culturally ambitious as New York, and in a neighborhood famed for incubating creative talent, the community cannot be bound by Houston and Canal Streets. The community is global and cosmopolitan. It includes many who know the difference between talent and schlock, who pride themselves on that ability, and who believe that New York's identity, and its future, are staked to the power of artistic discrimination. What future can there be for any city that says to the present: "Not in my back yard"?
Gio Ponti proposed that the architect's job is to "interpret the life of the inhabitants, transforming it into an expression of civilization and culture." But what if the inhabitants -- or the neighbors, the community -- don't like the interpretation? As a critic, I take it for granted that architects are going to see and feel things that I haven't yet analyzed. That's their job. They pick up vibrations and crystallize them into forms whose beauty may not be immediately apparent. This is how history feeds into the future. One yearns for the day when a design is found "inappropriate" because (Whereas) it too closely resembles the old piece of junk next door.
I look back at the last 40 years as a time when New York began a valuable self-education in its architectural heritage. Long may the lesson continue. But toward the end of the last century, the city lost sight of the difference between architecture and architectural history. Communities live in time as well as space. Context is a matter of time as well as space. And historical awareness, T. S. Eliot said, means acknowledging the pastness of the past as well as its presence. This acknowledgement shows greater respect for history than merely to crib from period styles. That's why it's "appropriate" that the Landmarks Commission gave substance to it. Time is its business.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A computer rendering of Jean Nouvel's design for a hotel on Grand Street in SoHo. The facade includes glass tinted gray, blue and red -- colors drawn from painted masonry buildings nearby. (Artefactory)

PERSON: MUSCHAMP, HERBERT; NOUVEL, JEAN 

GEOGRAPHIC: NEW YORK, NY, USA (79%) NEW YORK, USA (90%) UNITED STATES (90%); FRANCE (77%) NEW YORK CITY

HEADLINE: FILM; 
With His Feet in Many Chinas, So Hard to Pin Down

BYLINE:  By DAVE KEHR 

 BODY:
AS the cliche goes, there is not one China but many: the People's Republic, of course, but also the Special Administrative Region of Hong Kong, the oppositional island of Taiwan and the numerous ethnic Chinese enclaves studded throughout Asia, Europe and the Americas. 
 As a filmmaker, Tsui Hark has lived or worked in most of those places and, in his films, has imagined many others, including many Chinas of a mythical or historical past. 
 Currently based in Hong Kong, where he is one of the local industry's most prolific and influential filmmakers, Mr. Tsui (his name is pronounced Choy Huck, though friends and family call him Trey) will also be a conspicuous presence around New York for the next few weeks.
A new feature, "Time and Tide," will open on Friday. Two of Mr. Tsui's classics, parts one and two of his "Once Upon a Time in China" series, have been playing at the Film Forum in Lower Manhattan. And an eight-film series of Mr. Tsui's rarely seen works, including the 1980 political allegory "We're Going to Eat You" (a k a, "Kung Fu Cannibals") will be shown at both the Anthology Film Archives in the East Village (May 25-27) and Plaza Twin in Brooklyn (May 31-July 5). 
A figure roughly analogous to Roger Corman, America's "King of the B's," Mr. Tsui is a wildly proficient filmmaker, with his name on at least 60 films since 1979. As a director, writer, producer or actor, he has worked in almost every conceivable genre, dashing from broad slapstick comedy to tearful Cantonese melodrama, with stops for animated films and folk tales along the way.
The eclectic nature of Mr. Tsui's work finds its roots in his background. An ethnic Chinese, he was born in 1951 in what was then French Indochina and is now Vietnam. When he was 15, his parents immigrated to Hong Kong, and three years later Mr. Tsui departed for the United States, where he studied painting at Southern Methodist University in Dallas and shot a 45-minute documentary on Asian-American history called "From Spikes to Spindles." 
After graduation, he moved on to New York, where he worked as an editor of a Chinatown newspaper and contributed to community theater and cable television productions. That experience was enough to land him a job as a television producer when he returned to Hong Kong in 1977. 
At that time, the old commercial structures of the Cantonese cinema were giving way in the face of a Hong Kong New Wave, composed largely of socially oriented television directors like Ann Hui, Allen Fong and Mr. Tsui. Mr. Tsui's television series "The Gold Dagger Romance" was a critical and commercial success that led to his first feature, "The Butterfly Murders" (1979), a bizarre blend of martial arts, mysticism and invented mythology that thrilled local audiences and attracted the attention of Western film festival directors. 
With his wife, Nansun Shi, Mr. Tsui founded his own studio, Film Workshop, in 1984, and two years later produced "A Better Tomorrow," a watershed film that made international figures of the director John Woo and the star Chow Yun-Fat, both of whom now work in American movies (Mr. Woo in "Mission Impossible 2," Mr. Chow in "Anna and the King"). "A Better Tomorrow" forged a new genre out of elements of the traditional Cantonese kung fu film and the American gangster movie of the 1930's, setting domestic box office records and inspiring a legion of imitations (including two sequels, one directed by Mr. Tsui).
With his time, talents and interests spread over so many endeavors, Mr. Tsui is a difficult man to pin down, yet his style is immediately identifiable. As a director, he is the primary source of the unbelievable dynamism, the machine-gun editing, the extreme camera angles and the headlong rushing movement that gave a new breath of life to Hong Kong films.
From the beginning, Mr. Tsui was always willing to go a little bit further than his colleagues. Where Asian action filmmakers like King Hu (whose graceful, lyrical style in films like "Raining in the Mountains" is the major influence on Ang Lee's "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon") were classicists who respected the integrity of their plots and characters, Mr. Tsui was an instinctive postmodernist for whom style was its own justification. 
Where King Hu told stories, Mr. Tsui assembled images, built rhythms, raided widely different cultural traditions and in general created a cinema meant to appeal to the eye, ear and skin far more than to the brain. Where the traditional Chinese martial arts films, the swordfighting films favored by Mandarin audiences or the barehanded kung fu films preferred by the Cantonese were grounded in the music, acrobatics and choreographed violence of Chinese opera, Mr. Tsui's films owed their allegiance equally to Western movies, television and pop music. Mr. Tsui perfectly summarized this blend with the English title he gave to one of his earliest successes, "Peking Opera Blues."
Shown at the 1983 Cannes Film Festival, Mr. Tsui's ineffably weird "Zu: Warriors of the Magic Mountain" (which features the kung fu star Sammo Hung as a monk whose magically extensible eyebrows entangle and hold off a ball of cosmic evil) baffled and intrigued Western viewers with its unbridled imagination and incomprehensible plotting, pitting warlords against democratic activists in the chaotic years after the 1911 revolution. 
Somewhere between the poles of pure fantasy and sharp political engagement lies the essence of Mr. Tsui's work. For the critic Stephen Teo, whose book "Hong Kong Cinema: The Extra Dimensions" remains the definitive study of the region's filmmaking, Mr. Tsui's work represents a sort of "nationalism on speed." Here, "the mythic world of martial arts represents the peak of China's science and culture," Mr. Teo writes, and the dense, convoluted plots of his films portray a "China that has failed to realize its potential due to the failure of talented people to unite, engaging instead in internecine struggles to the detriment of all."
Perhaps it is Mr. Tsui's personal experience of the Chinese diaspora that has forged his vision of a hazy, hallucinated nation with no definite boundaries, an ambiguous history and traditions that can be instantly invented and instantly abandoned. The "Once Upon a Time in China" series, which began in 1991 and recently reached its sixth installment, is Mr. Tsui's most explicit attempt to create a country of the mind, a China that the Chinese can take with them, in the form of films, tapes and Asia's ubiquitous video compact disks, in their worldwide migrations.
The central character of the series, played in the first three episodes by Jet Li (a gifted martial artist who has now begun his own American career, as in "Romeo Must Die"), is a historical figure, Wong Fei-Hung, a freedom fighter from Guangdong Province. But for Chinese audiences, the historical reality of the character has long been absorbed by his incarnation in a series of martial arts adventures, produced through the 50's and 60's, starring Kwan Tak-Hing -- just as Wyatt Earp, Wild Bill Hickock and many other Western heroes have been assimilated by Hollywood. 
Jet Li's interpretation of the character is far more boyish and open than Kwan Tak-Hing's (at least in the few scraps of footage this writer has been able to see). Here, Wong Fei-Hung represents a younger, more flexible China, still committed to traditional values (he is a doctor of herbal medicine) but open to the use of Western technology (guns and movie cameras) when it suits his purposes.
Mr. Tsui has developed his notions of China through other historical series, including the "Swordsman" films (set in a more distant, magical past), the "Chinese Ghost Story" series (in which heroic monks confront demons with distinctly imperialist agendas) and many one-shots, including the shrewd, sober, meticulously crafted period adventure that might be his finest film, "The Blade" (1995). 
But increasingly Mr. Tsui has been leaving that theme behind. Like John Woo, he has followed the siren call of American studio filmmaking, directing the Belgian action star Jean-Claude Van Damme in two features, "Double Team" (1997) and "Knock Off" (1998). For all of his evident adaptability, Mr. Tsui has not been able to complete the Hollywood transition, perhaps because he is too accustomed to being his own boss to accept the dictates of studio marketing advisers. 
Still, Mr. Tsui is discovering that you can't go home again, particularly when that home, Hong Kong, has been transformed by major political and economic upheavals. Investors have abandoned the Hong Kong cinema in recent years, frightened off by the Asian economic crisis and by the inroads that the Motion Picture Producers Association of America -- the international lobby of the Hollywood studios -- has been able to make into markets that once resisted imported product. Hollywood now seems poised to take over the Asian market just as it has conquered Europe, leaving little for indigenous filmmakers except low-budget genre films starring local pop stars and comics.
"Time and Tide" is the first film that Mr. Tsui has made in Hong Kong in five years, and it feels strikingly different from the work he did in the past. No longer does the notion of China, as a place real or imagined, figure in the fiction; the action could be taking place in any major city, and there is even a more or less gratuitous action sequence set in South America, a market where martial arts movies are very popular. Surviving from Mr. Tsui's established style is the film's incomprehensible plot, something to do with an improvised alliance between an apprentice bodyguard (the Cantonese pop star Nicholas Tse) and a minor gangster (the Taiwanese rocker Wu Bai) and a general sense of headlong energy.
The early sequences, in which Mr. Tse discovers he has accidentally impregnated a lesbian police officer, are a sly parody of Wong Kar-Wai's hyper-stylish Hong Kong melodramas ("In the Mood for Love"), but the film eventually turns into a nonstop shoot'em-out, with a wild finale that finds the female lead (Cathy Tsui) giving birth while simultaneously fending off an army of attackers with an automatic pistol. The target of the parody has shifted from Wong Kar-Wai to John Woo, who featured an unforgettable maternity ward shootout in his 1992 movie "Hard Boiled."
"Time and Tide" suggests that Mr. Tsui now sees his challenge as separating himself from the moribund Hong Kong film industry, which he helped to create and was largely created by. Like Mr. Wong and Mr. Woo, he must find a way to recreate himself as a global filmmaker, with no particular loyalty to any production system, national character or sense of cultural history. There may still be many Chinas, but the movies are fast becoming their own sovereign domain, a vast, featureless country in which local distinctions are lost.

HEADLINE: Nassau Government Buildings Going to Seed 

BYLINE:  By STEWART AIN 

 BODY:
NASSAU COUNTY is falling down. Oh, the county government's most glaring budget gaps are being patched up, the tax rolls are being updated and the arm wrestling with union leaders over contract concessions has begun. But the millions of dollars' worth of buildings it owns -- literally the facades it presents to the public -- have fallen into such disrepair that the county complex in Garden City is beginning to look like a third-world capital.
 County officials say there's enough money to pay janitors, painters, plumbers, carpenters and electricians and buy them the materials they need. Even so, the job isn't getting done. New York State reimburses counties for the upkeep of state court buildings, but over the last two years it has withheld $2 million from Nassau because of what David Bookstaver, a spokesman for the state Office of Court Administration, described as "the county's failure to meet the standards in the contract." Now, the state is moving to assume direct responsibility for maintenance of its court buildings in Nassau. 
 Maintenance at all county-owned buildings is coming under renewed scrutiny. In the last two weeks, Judith A. Jacobs, the majority leader of the Nassau County Legislature, has asked the county attorney for a list of all property it owns or uses, requested that the county Health Department conduct periodic safety inspections of all county-owned buildings and asked for a full accounting of a county-owned warehouse at 404 Peninsula Boulevard in Hempstead.
Those requests were prompted by Ms. Jacobs' April 19 visit to the Hempstead building, which stores paper the county uses for copying and printing.
"That was the worst thing I've ever seen," she said. "A garage door had been eaten by rats and termites. Rolls of paper and boxes had been eaten by rats. There was a horrible odor that we kept thinking was from a dead animal. And there were stains on the rolls of paper that we thought were water stains from the roof that had caved in. I was nauseated by what was there; we all felt sick. We were later told it was rat urine we had seen and smelled."
"What happened with the oversight by general services to allow this building to deteriorate to this level?" she asked in a memo to William Tripp, who as deputy commissioner of Recreation, Parks and Support Services is the official responsible for building maintenance.
Asked what she believed was the cause of the maintenance problem, Ms. Jacobs replied: "There's a lack of oversight and not enough employees. And those who are there can do only what is humanly possible."
Mr. Tripp said that although his department is budgeted for 306 full-time employees, it has only 267. "The economy has been very good and it was difficult to fill lower-paying custodial jobs," he explained. "People could get higher-paying jobs in private industry."
But John Zaher, a spokesman for the county executive's office, said the county managed to spend $472,000 in 2000 for temporary custodial help.
Mr. Zaher said the Nassau Council of Black Clergy had been illegally operating a food pantry in space loaned by the county at one end of the Hempstead building and that its food had caused the rodent problem. He said all food in that section of the building was discarded and the area cleaned and fumigated. He said the county-owned space at other end of the building, where the Long Island Council of Churches stores food for its food pantry, was not affected.
Mr. Zaher said the cleanup crew discarded about $2,000 worth of ruined county material, but that the bulk of the supplies were salvageable and would continue to be stored there. He also said the county was studying whether to repair or replace the leaky roof.
Ms. Jacobs said her office has received complaints about the maintenance of other county buildings. In the County Executive Building at 1 West Street in Garden City, Ms. Jacobs pointed out rooms where paint and plasterboard are coming off the walls. Around the corner, beneath the weather-beaten dome of the Old Courthouse, wires could be seen hanging down through the ceiling where tiles used to be.
Anthony P. Giustino, the president of C.S.E.A. Local 830, which represents 11,000 county workers, said the Department of Social Services building on 11th Street has a history of fires and fire code violations.
His assistant, Timothy J. Corr, said the air conditioning in the building housing the county clerk's office "is broken four out of five days" and that this condition has existed for the last three years.
Another union official, Stanley Bergman, said that basic cleaning was not being done. "The carpets are rarely vacuumed, the bathrooms are filthy, the floors are not swept and employees are bringing in their own mops and toilet paper," he said.
Mr. Tripp said electrical problems at the Department of Social Services building are being corrected. Regarding conditions in the Old Courthouse, Mr. Tripp said the county Legislature would be asked in the next two or three months to approve the hiring of a consultant to determine the scope of the work that needs to be done there.
He also said the county Legislature rejected a proposed $8 million capital improvement bond issue for the county clerk's building five years ago and that it has tabled a request for a smaller appropriation.
"The cleanliness in the building has been improved in the last year and a half," Mr. Tripp insisted. "I have heard nothing about employees bringing in their own toilet paper. If someone did that, I'm sure I would have gotten a bill."
Mr. Tripp said Deputy County Executive Curtis Fisher had been appointed by the county executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, to lead a committee to survey all county buildings and to deal immediately with all acute needs.
"We'll prioritize those projects, taking into consideration those buildings to which the public has access and those with the greatest number of county employees," said Mr. Tripp, who will sit on the committee. "I assess the county buildings to be in fair condition. Some buildings are a 10 -- 10 is the best -- and some are a 1, like the Hempstead building."
Ms. Jacobs said she would rate the county's buildings as "fair to horrible. Fair is the highest I would ever give one," she said, "and it goes downhill from there pretty rapidly."
Michael G. Zapson, a Democratic member of the county Legislature, said the court buildings are at the lower end of the scale. "I think the courts are poorly maintained and I'm not surprised the state is tossing us off the job," he said.
The state's takeover of court building maintenance, now scheduled for June, comes none too soon for court officials, who say repeated complaints about conditions in their buildings have fallen on deaf ears.
Justice Edward G. McCabe, the county's administrative judge, sent a letter March 7 to Ms. Jacobs. 
"All water fountains have been closed due to lead in the containers," he wrote. "Leaks are not repaired, carpeting is in shreds and mended with electrical tape, ceilings in various offices are falling in pieces and left unrepaired, juror seating -- particularly in the County Court -- is in deplorable condition, handicapped ramp railings have been removed and not replaced, and cleanliness in each building is almost non-existent."
Until 1998, the state reimbursed the counties 25 percent of their maintenance costs. That was increased to 50 percent in 1999 and to 75 percent last year. Two months ago, it was increased to 100 percent. 
About four years ago, Mr. Zapson said, the state began complaining about conditions in the state court buildings in Nassau. Two years ago, it balked at reimbursing the county.
Mr. Tripp said the county was not told until about a year ago that the state was refusing to pay the cleaning bill. He said the county did not notice because there is such a lag in state reimbursement payments that the last check from the state arrived on March 24, 2001, even though reimbursement payments were ended Jan. 1, 1999.
He said that one of the first things the county did was to change the company the county had hired to clean the buildings. And he pointed out that the county Legislature will be asked on Monday to approve a $12 million bond issue to repair leaks in the roofs and windows of the court buildings.
Mr. Zapson said he believes a big part of the problem was the amount the county paid the cleaning service. 
"We paid 29 cents per square foot for cleaning," Mr. Zapson said, noting that the state believes it should cost 70 cents per square foot to get the job done right.
He also attributed the poor cleaning job to "poor administration by the county." 
Ms. Jacobs said all of the building problems point to an "infrastructure breakdown."
"The county's budget collapse is only an indicator of a collapse throughout the county," she said. "How do you explain this to taxpayers who are living in the richest county in the state?"
Asked where the county would get the money to make the necessary repairs because of the county's money crunch, Ms. Jacobs replied: "When the health, safety and welfare of individuals are at stake, it is the responsibility of the county to provide livable and habitable conditions. I'm not talking about turning this into the Taj Mahal, but I can find the money to sweep the floor, paint the walls and have an exterminator come in once a month."

HEADLINE: Habitats/West Orange, N.J.; 
A Garden Designer Finds The Grass Is Greener

BYLINE:  By TRISH HALL 

 BODY:
ARE there any great places to live that are still undiscovered, where regular people can buy houses for the price of a tiny one-bedroom apartment in Manhattan? 
 Bill Mitchell thinks there is at least one, and he talks about his new town with the passion characteristic of recent converts. It is charming, he says, and all the shopping he needs is nearby. It's diverse, with a variety of ethnic and economic groups. It has the architecture and terrain of Westchester County without the high prices. And, he says, as a gay man, he feels perfectly comfortable. 
 The town is West Orange, N.J., where Mr. Mitchell spent $270,000 last July for a three-bedroom house with a porch that in the winter looks out on the Manhattan skyline and in the summer on leafy trees. 
The town was developed in the 1920's and 30's as a suburb of Newark. But a few years ago, it became a more appealing option for New Yorkers when direct train service was started to Penn Station. It takes just 30 minutes.
Mr. Mitchell, however, doesn't spend a lot of time on trains. Most days he drives, loading equipment and plants into his van for the trip to Manhattan, where he designs and installs rooftop and terrace gardens. Mr. Mitchell became passionate about gardening when he was working as a computer systems designer and living in an apartment at Castle Village near West 181st Street in Manhattan. The complex has acres of gardens, and Mr. Mitchell volunteered to work in them.
"I would come home in my suit and go right down and start weeding," he said. When his company decided to have an outside firm do its computer work, Mr. Mitchell decided to change careers. He got his certificate in landscape design and horticulture from the New York Botanical Garden.
The apartment in Washington Heights was spectacular, a large one-bedroom penthouse with view of the Hudson River and the Palisades. Mr. Mitchell might still be there were it not for the death of Gary Parks, with whom he lived for for 15 years. When Mr. Parks, a dance critic and editor, died about a year and a half ago from a brain tumor, the apartment no longer seemed right.
Mr. Mitchell wanted an easy place to keep a car, and he wanted a house that could accommodate two dogs, so that his yellow Labrador, Bella, would have company. 
And so, thinking about moving, he went to New Jersey one day to visit Marcia and Chris Pelletiere, friends in South Orange. He and Mrs. Pelletiere sing in an eight-person a cappella group called the Accidentals.
Caught up in their enthusiasm for the area, he spent part of the day driving around with Dennis Cahill of ReMax Village Square in South Orange. A month or so later, Mr. Cahill called and told him that one of the Tudor-style houses he liked was for sale; it had been on the market for 12 hours and already had four offers.
Mr. Mitchell immediately offered a bit more than the asking price, figuring he could sell his penthouse in a minute, and got the house. "My sainted father gave me a bridge loan," he said -- a short-term loan intended to bridge the time span between buying one house and selling another. He closed on the house in July and moved in in October, after painting, buying new appliances and replacing some floors.
ON the first story, his house has a small foyer leading to, on the left, the living room, with a beamed, vaulted ceiling and stone fireplace, and on the right, a dining room. Over the fireplace in the living room is a portrait done by his great-great uncle, Maurice Siegler, who lived in South Orange. Although Mr. Mitchell discovered the town through his friends, he actually spent the first few years of his life in the area, where the Russian Jews on his mother's side and the Greeks on his father's side had settled. Most of his childhood, though, was spent in Willingboro, a suburb farther south in New Jersey.
Beyond the dining room is a large eat-in kitchen with a sitting area. Upstairs is a bedroom, Bella's room and a television/guest room.
On a warm spring day, Mr. Mitchell sat on the porch he had painted a French blue-green and talked about the garden he plans to create when he is not so busy with clients. "This is one of my dreams," he said, "to design a debris garden." 
He plans to use old castoff items, maybe turning a celadon green toilet tank into a bird bath, and the bowl into a water lily pool. A radiator he found in the house might make a good table base. "Most people in New York don't want that kind of garden," he said. "I'm going to provide an example."
He will also put up fences to protect Bella and his new dog, a golden-retriever-Rottweiler mix named Sam. When he decided to move to New Jersey and get another dog, he thought he would get a small, cute, cuddly one. Instead he ended up with a big ferocious one that showed up in a neighbor's yard, abandoned.
The house was easy to furnish, because he had quite a bit in his apartment in the city. Surprisingly in a strong market, the apartment hasn't yet sold. The first potential buyer backed out at the last minute, and the second was rejected by the co-op board. Because the price is in line with others in the building, Mr. Mitchell was mystified by the lack of bids.
Then, when he noticed that deals kept falling through on important personal dates, like his anniversary with Mr. Parks, he wondered if maybe he was being sent a message from another world.
He called an exorcist in Ohio who had been recommended by friends, an exorcist who, as Mr. Mitchell put it, works remote. "He took a look, figuratively speaking," Mr. Mitchell said. The exorcist told him that Mr. Parks's spirit was in fact in the house in New Jersey and wasn't blocking the sale.
Many agents are showing the apartment, and Mr. Mitchell is hopeful. Meanwhile, he's happy in his new place, a place that instantly felt like home.
"I don't know anything about feng shui," he said, "but it's just comfortable. I think I'm very lucky."

HEADLINE: DOWN THE SHORE; 
Staying Power

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS 

DATELINE: OCEAN CITY 

 BODY:
David Pitfield is trying to sell his four-bedroom duplex near 45th Street and Asbury Avenue a couple of blocks from the beach in the quiet south end of the island. Recently, Mr. Pitfield decided to move up to a new, bigger house a few blocks away, but he isn't particularly worried if he doesn't unload the old one quickly.
 "I can tell you that he can easily get $3,000 a week for the place in rent," said Mark Grimes, Mr. Pitfield's agent at Ocean City Realty. "I'd estimate that rents here for good properties have doubled in the last four or five years. It may soon flatten, but that hasn't happened yet." 
 Times are flush at the Shore. For the last few years, the boom in rentals was attributed to the good economy and the raging bull stock market. This year, the economy has slowed significantly and the bull market has had its horns shaved. Still, no one is anticipating a bad summer.
"Now I guess we say that gas prices are keeping people closer to home and that people know they have a good time when they come," said Candace Forbes, owner of Ralph Hayes Realty Inc. in Point Pleasant Beach. "As long as the people here aren't too greedy with prices, we can attract the same clientele year after year."
Ms. Forbes said that the towns farther north -- from the less expensive ones like Lavellette to the upscale ones like Mantaloking -- were doing quite well. The well-to-do are apparently unworried about prices, she said, and the budget-minded have a little extra cash to spend at the beach.
"Here in Point Pleasant Beach, our rentals are going fairly well, but we still have openings," she said. "Things are going for approximately what they rented for last year. Most of the openings we have left are for early July and late August, but there are spots elsewhere as well."
She said weekly rents for three-bedroom units ranged from $2,500 to $2,800 for a beachfront condominium to $1,500 for a unit with one bathroom a block from the beach to $1,000 for a smaller place with no air conditioning about two blocks away.
In Wildwood, farther south along the 126-mile Jersey coast, the rental market is booming. "Rents have gone way up here, especially in quieter Wildwood Crest and North Wildwood," said Jessica Lees, at Lees Real Estate Agency. "People are excited about a Wildwood revival, with all the Doo-Wop architecture and new restaurants."
"I know a man who raised his rent $700 a week this year, which is unheard of here," Ms. Lees added. "It's a four-bedroom, three-bath beachfront in North Wildwood that went from $2,300 to $3,000 a week in one year, and he booked it up." 
Still, she said that most rentals in Wildwood went for far less. "Even one block off the beach, you can find a two-bedroom apartment for as little as $600 in Wildwood Crest," she said. "I still think we have something for anyone, but it looks good for both higher rents and more people renting."
Not that there aren't some clouds. Some real estate agents, like Mike Powers at Tim Kerr Power Play Realty in Avalon, are a bit wary. For instance, Mr. Kerr said that in Avalon -- an upscale resort situated with Stone Harbor on what is known as Seven-Mile Island between Wildwood and Atlantic City -- some owners might have jacked up prices a bit too much.
"Some people bought for high prices and think they have to justify it with exorbitant rents," said Mr. Powers, who noted that there are actually fewer rental properties in town this year because of duplexes made into single-family homes and owners who have decided they no longer need to rent to make the mortgage.
"At some point you have to say that renting for $5,000 a week at the shore isn't what you want to do," he said. "If it isn't a really great house, maybe you either decide to buy something yourself, go to something more reasonable or vacation in Europe for that kind of money."
But for bed-and-breakfasts in places like Bay Head farther north and Cape May to the South, life is good. Many places in Cape May now require a four-night minimum for small, if charming, rooms that cost $150 a night or more.
"It's really getting almost year-round here," said Patricia Joyce, who owns the Duke of Windsor bed-and-breakfast on Washington Street in Cape May. "People come from late February to New Year's. But the summers have been really good of late. There are more than 50 places here in town, and everyone seems to be doing well."
Things seem to be changing a bit in the towns of Margate, Ventnor and Longport, which share Absecon Island with the larger and tawdrier Atlantic City. Historically, people have rented homes in those towns for the season -- with few vacationers, if any, staying for only a week.
"But now I see a lot of people who want to come for one month instead of the whole summer," said Ronnie Alper, a real estate agent in Margate. "The summer rental market is a little slower here because people just aren't doing the whole summer as much or those who do have finally bought their own houses."
On the other hand, prices haven't really gone down, Ms. Alper said, noting that one five-bedroom house in Margate one up from the beach was rented for $58,000 for the summer, up from $44,000 last year.
"I would have thought people would have been more affected by the stock market," she said. "But if you love the ocean, you just want to be here whatever it costs."
