HEADLINE: Why Mortgage Rates Aren't Even Better 

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
DELIGHTED though they may be at the potential business, mortgage brokers are grinding their teeth, frustrated by a bulging loan-application pipeline that was jammed, at first, by refinance fence-sitters waiting for that optimal interest rate, followed around April 15 by tax write-off seekers urged on by their accountants, and in recent weeks by Fed rate-cut dreamers.
 At the same time, would-be borrowers are confused and even angry that, in fact, the recent short-term interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve has had little or no effect on reducing long-term mortgage rates. For what most borrowers don't understand, say mortgage-industry analysts, is that immediate moves by the Fed are far removed from mortgage rates -- which already were, and still are, near historic lows. 
 "The phones have been ringing off the hook," said James Fresella, president of Apollo Financial Services, a small, three-agent mortgage lender in Riverdale, N.J. "When the Fed cuts rates, we're inundated with anywhere from 30 to 40 calls a day; and normally it would be two to three a day."
Then come the strained conversations. 
"They're yelling, 'What do you mean? Are you crazy? Why aren't mortgage rates coming down?' " Mr. Fresella said. "It's very frustrating. And you have to be courteous enough to explain to them that even though the Fed cuts rates, it doesn't affect mortgages directly." 
The picture is little different, just enlarged, at the 60-agent New York Mortgage Company in Manhattan. "Everybody's loan-processing pipelines are bursting," said Steven Schnall, the company president. "It's been happening all year."
"The problem for lenders is that, unlike in a purchase transaction where the borrower must immediately go to closing," Mr. Schnall said, "a lot of refinancers have been sitting on the fence, waiting to lock in, because of rumors that the Fed was going to cut rates."
"There were certain people who were very happy with a 6.875 percent rate a few weeks ago," he continued, "and those were the people who heard the talk that the Fed was going to cut rates. So they said, 'I'll wait.' And they were surprised that the Fed cut had almost no effect."
On April 17, the day before the Fed announced its latest half-point rate cut, interest on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.36 percent. At the start of business last Thursday, the average was 7.32 percent.
Since the beginning of the year, said Douglas Duncan, the senior economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, "more than 50 percent of all mortgage applications in the nation have been for the purpose of refinancing."
"People are converting adjustable-rate mortgages to fixed-rate mortgages," Mr. Duncan said, as they try to lock in to current favorable rates. "People are shortening their terms; going to a 15- or 20-year mortgage, rather than refinancing a 30-year. They are taking cash out of the equity they've built up in their homes to pay off personal debt. Or they are just looking to lower their monthly payments."
For several months, Francisco Cedeno has been weighing whether to refinance the 30-year fixed-rate mortgage on the home he bought in Union, N.J., a year ago. He has been discussing it, increasingly frequently, with Mr. Fresella at the Apollo mortgage firm.
"I've been calling Jim for the last two months," Mr. Cedeno said. "The last month it was kind of weekly, and now it's come to every two, three days, right after the last Fed cut."
Mr. Cedeno, a hedge fund analyst, and his wife, Maritza, have two children, Angelica, 4, and Steven, 1. "We bought about a year ago, when interest rates were peaking," Mr. Cedeno said. The price for the four-bedroom, extended Cape was $175,000, of which $160,000 was financed at 8.25 percent. 
"I see the Fed dropping rates, the economy slowing down, and I'm thinking that's a good thing for refinancing," Mr. Cedeno said. "Then I found out that that only affects short-term rates, and mortgage rates are still going up."
The Cedenos hope to lower their monthly payments so they can renovate the driveway, the front steps, the kitchen. "Some of the work I'm doing myself, with some relatives," Mr. Cedeno said. "I can't really make a long commitment with a contractor."
"When you try to make a move, it's like the rates know you're coming, and they go up," he said. "I'm frustrated because, well, I don't know, some days they're down, some days up -- nothing concrete."
Besides the average of 7.36 percent for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages on April 17 -- the day before the Fed's last rate cut -- the average for 15-year fixed-rate mortgages that day was 6.92 percent, and for one-year adjustable-rate mortgages it was 6.43 percent for the first year of the mortgage. (Adjustable-rate mortgages, or ARM's, initially offer low rates for a set number of years -- as a sort of enticement -- after which the rates may rise steeply.)
By Thursday morning, the average for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages stood at 7.32 percent, four basis points below the rate on April 17 (each percentage point equals 100 basis points); the 15-year fixed rate was 6.82, down 10 basis points, and one-year adjustable rates averaged 6.21 percent, 22 basis points below the rate on the day before the Fed cut. 
"There is a great expectation that mortgage rates will immediately move in the same direction and by the same magnitude as changes in Fed monetary policy," said David W. Berson, the chief economist for Fannie Mae, the federally chartered home financing agency. "As a result, when the Fed cut the federal funds rate by 50 basis points on April 18, the popular expectation was that long-term mortgage rates would immediately decline by the same amount."
"In fact," Dr. Berson said, "mortgage rates had already incorporated the expectation of this Fed easing of the federal funds rate into the level of long-term mortgage rates."
ONE analyst, Keith Gumbinger of HSH Associates, a mortgage research company in Butler, N.J., tweaked the media for its coverage of the Fed and mortgage rates. "The airwaves and news pages were full of discussion of how the Fed move will bring lower borrowing costs to home buyers, refinancers, consumer borrowers," Mr. Gumbinger said. "But painting the Fed move as an across-the-board rate cut for everybody left many potential borrowers with a bad taste in their mouths when their brokers told them, 'Rates aren't going down; they're actually rising right now.' " Long-term mortgage rates had actually spiked up a bit in the days after the Fed cut.
"Follow-up pieces may more completely evaluate what happens, what it means," Mr. Gumbinger said, "but nothing grabs a consumer like a 40-point headline."
What most borrowers are unaware of is that mortgage rates are not set by the Fed; they are, instead, closely tied to long-term bond yields. A significant portion of the bond market consists of bundles of mortgage-backed securities, whose yields tend to rise and fall along with long-term Treasury bonds -- not with the short-term rates that the Fed directly influences. And this year long-term rates have not fallen very much, a fact that has surprised some bond market analysts.
Sometimes, when the Fed raises short-term interest rates because it wants to pre-empt an increase in inflation, long-term mortgage rates may rise in order to make the bundles of mortgages sold to investors attractive to buyers fearful of future inflation. At other times, when the Fed lowers short-term interest rates in order to stimulate the economy, mortgage rates may not drop as steeply as the cut made by the Fed, and may even rise because they have already declined in anticipation that the Fed would be easing rates. 
The latter scenario is precisely what has happened in recent months, said Mr. Gumbinger, the analyst at HSH Associates.
On April 18, the Federal Reserve cut short-term interest rates -- specifically the federal funds rate, which is the overnight lending rate between banks, and the discount rate, which is the interest rate the Fed charges banks to borrow from it -- by 0.5 percent, or 50 basis points. "The Fed stated that it believed the economy is soft and that the softness will continue," Mr. Gumbinger said. 
"What does it mean to Mr. and Mrs. Mortgage Borrower? Unfortunately, very little," Mr. Gumbinger continued, "because mortgage interest rates did most of their declining last year, long before the Fed got involved, and remain near historic lows." The low for the last 10 years -- in fact, the last 33 years -- was 6.68 percent in October 1998.
From mid-May of 2000 until early January of this year, the average interest on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages declined from 8.82 percent to 7.34 percent. Surprisingly, the long decline was sparked by a half-point increase in the federal funds rate to 6.5 percent on May 16, 2000, which, coupled with sharply rising energy prices, caused a marked slowdown in economic growth.
"The high cost of short-term borrowing helped slow the economy appreciably, which was the Fed's intent because growth had been running so strong that the Fed was afraid inflation might gain a toehold," Mr. Gumbinger said. "However, as those higher short-term interest rates began to do their work, the higher energy prices kicked in, causing a more pronounced slowing in the economy than the Fed anticipated."
"Yet, even as the economy slowed, the Fed held those short-term rates at a very high level," Mr. Gumbinger continued. "And long-term mortgage rates declined along with the diminishing growth in the economy." Because demand for credit is very low during a slowdown and inflation pressures are usually near their low point, lenders lower rates to attract borrowers.
"That brought us up to January of this year." Mr. Gumbinger said. "The Fed responded to -- what's a nice word for it? -- the unexpected slowdown by trimming rates one half of a percentage point on Jan. 3. And because the Federal Reserve has shown its willingness to address the economic slowdown, thereby increasing the possibility of renewed growth just down the road, mortgage interest rates stopped declining, and have since been bouncing in a narrow range."
SINCE the Fed's first interest rate cut on Jan. 3, 30-year fixed mortgage interest rates have fluctuated between a high of 7.34 percent during the week ended Jan. 26 and a low of 7.07 percent the week of March 23. "So on Jan. 3," Mr. Gumbinger said, "there was that half-point cut by the Fed; then, on Jan. 31, there was another; on March 20, another, and on April 18, the most recent one. But despite those cuts totaling 200 basis points, mortgage rates have moved in a range of only 27 basis points."
Dr. Berson at Fannie Mae concurs with that scenario, adding that even another Fed cut is unlikely to further reduce mortgage rates. "It's likely that another 50 basis points of Fed easing is already incorporated into the current level of mortgage rates," he said. "The economy would have to weaken so much more than currently anticipated that the Fed would have to go beyond the 50 basis points already anticipated for the next several months in order for long-term mortgage rates to decline further."
Mr. Duncan at the Mortgage Bankers Association said, however, that he "would disagree slightly that a full 50 basis points are already incorporated into interest rates in mortgage markets."
"Certainly 25 basis points are already in the market," he said, "but there is some potential for lowering mortgage interest rates if the Fed goes another 50 basis points."
"Still," he added, "the bottom line for mortgage consumers is that there is not much room for a decline in rates."
One year after buying his two-bedroom duplex town house condominium on West 89th Street, complete with a fireplace and a garden in the back -- "not many New Yorkers can say they have their own tree" -- Steven Savad is sitting on the mortgage refinance fence.
Mr. Savad, chief financial officer of Restaurant.com, an Internet company that creates Web sites for restaurants, and his wife, Sherri, an advertising planner, paid just under $1 million for their home. "You're sort of a victim of whatever the rates are at the time you buy," he said. 
The Savads financed about half the purchase price with an adjustable-rate mortgage in which the rate is fixed for the first five years, then becomes an adjustable in which rates can change annually for the remainder of the 30-year term. The rate for the loan, called a 5-1 ARM, was 8.125 percent, carrying a monthly payment of about $4,000.
While he has "no regrets about the mortgage," Mr. Savad is taking a hard look at the new realities.
"If I simply wanted to refinance with the same vehicle that I have -- a new 5-1 ARM -- I could do it and reduce my monthly payment by roughly 15 percent," Mr. Savad said. "But the rate wouldn't be much different on a 10-year fixed because I've also seen them at around 7 percent."
The Savads, their interest piqued by news coverage of the Fed rate cuts, are thick into the process. "In this day and age, with the way news is broadcast, you almost can't help but breathe it," Mr. Savad said.
"I'm going to lock in, that's for sure," he said. "The question is when, exactly -- likely very soon."

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX; 
State of the Reunion

BYLINE:  By MARCY WEBSTER; Marcy Webster is a writer who lives in Moorestown.

 BODY:
WE'RE in our celebration years. We attend significant anniversaries and birthdays so often that I recently bought an economy-size roll of gold-foil gift wrap. Our own household is temporarily between milestones, but we're beginning to gear up for something major: our 50th anniversary will fall in the middle of this year.
 Probably both of us would prefer to have a low-key party at the house in South Jersey where we've lived for more than 30 years. Our nearby children have overflow room for the two others who live far away, so we can send the North Carolina family to our son's house in Riverside and the Vermonters can sleep six miles south in Haddonfield. Our old house with its well-worn rooms and big, shady yard is a perfect place to convene. We've fixed our grandchildren an attic playroom and a gated secret garden beneath the wisteria. 
 It would be work. There are 16 of us now. The children help in substantial ways, but conservatively, that's 24 sheets, 640 dirty dishes, 200 bottles for recycling, 50 discussions about plans, 10 losses of the remote control and 20 arguments about the rules of games. And when we are at home, we tend to slide into our original roles. I feel responsible for everything. Still the guardian mother, I worry about designated drivers and dangerous escapades. I'm always trying to fix things. Fussing to keep mayonnaise off William's sandwiches and poultices on Rowan's poison ivy. Fretting until I force a smile out of anyone who's sulking. My husband, a most peaceful and patient man, overreacts to the pressure and gets cranky if everybody doesn't eat together. He stands at the stove broiling fish to order while the potatoes are still like stones. Sometimes our children fall back into the sibling roles that they've really outgrown, and once in a while an unresolved issue simmers along with the soup.
It would be more expensive but more relaxing to do what we did for our 40th anniversary. In each quarter of that year, we left New Jersey to take one of our second-generation families on a short trip. That's demanding in its own way, but we had fun planning an appropriate place for each group so that the golfers didn't have to go to museums and the childless couples didn't have to wait for a sitter to show up.
We took the turnpike south to the kind of relaxed venues where it's acceptable to sit around in stocking feet, sipping beer and reliving sandies and miracle putts. The couples with toddlers met us at a safe place on a New England lake where we spent long days in steady rowboats and early nights in rooms that smelled of cedar logs. We saw our children, and their children, in settings that brought out their best. We learned once more how much talent and energy and affection they have. That kind of trip allows us to focus all our loving attention on one set of people without the inevitable competition for favor that surfaces now and then in even the most selflessly mature people. And to tell the truth, we like their undivided interest in us.
Last spring we were missing our Charlotte-based son and his family. So we met them in Virginia for a weekend, and on Saturday night we found ourselves in the formal dining room of an elegant hotel. There was spectacular food and service but, most rewarding of all, there was an orchestra playing romantic music by Rodgers and Hart. I danced with my 10-year-old grandson, his parents danced together, but the evening's most tenacious dancer was Hannah, who led her grandfather onto the floor time after time while their entrees got cold and the other diners applauded their twirls. I hope we can keep those tender moments coming, celebration or not. It's the kind of interlude that gets muffled in the confusion of a larger cast.
Traveling that way, in intimate groups, eliminates the intensity that we'd have in a full family reunion. But then, aren't we losing the point? If 50 years of marriage is about anything, it's about that. It's about common memory and shared feelings, no matter if the memories still burn and the feelings still hurt. What are we celebrating if not the struggle and the triumph of raising four people who love one another and us, most of the time?
I cherish the meals when our children sit around the table and reminisce about the epic failures of our house cuisine. They don't remember them right, but that's O.K. The lime peas story is true, and the birthday cake that no one could cut or chew; those disasters were mine. I get anxious when they move from food to "What was the worst thing you ever did?" to "What was your closest call?" But from the distance of 48 years of motherhood, I ought to be able to make myself relax and listen.
If we celebrate at home, I will have to relinquish my podium behind the sink and find a helper to deal with the dishes and a caterer to provide the food. If we're lucky, we can coordinate the fruit, corn and tomatoes that the out-of-staters crave with a break in the summer humidity that they can no longer endure.
And I'll hide the balding teddy bear that both sons claim, or Solomon-like, slice it down the middle and sew up a half of each. There will be an alcove set aside where the little girls can dance, and we'll spin 50 years of music, our picks. If we have to, we can hire a referee for the soccer games, and another one for the Scrabble. 
But if I should win the lottery before then, I'm cancelling that plan and taking everybody to a luxury resort in Hawaii.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Discounts That Come to Travelers Who Wait

BYLINE:  By JANE L. LEVERE 

 BODY:
MICHAEL DWECK, an advertising executive from New York, was eager to attend a dinner his brother was giving in San Francisco last winter. Although the party had been planned for a while, his brother forgot to invite him until the day before.
 For many people, talk of making such a trip would have ended right there. After all, who wants to pay the premium prices that airlines and hotels typically charge for last-minute bookings? 
 As it turned out, Mr. Dweck, who is 42, did not have to. He found a great deal on one of a growing number of Web sites that specialize in such travel. He said he paid $408 for a package including a round-trip ticket from Kennedy International Airport to San Francisco, on nonstop flights, and a two-night hotel stay at the Sofitel in nearby Redwood City, with a waterfront view. He figures that he saved about $2,000 on the trip: the cheapest fare he could find elsewhere for a transcontinental flight was $1,680, he said, while Sofitel's rack room rate that weekend was $360 a night. 
His experience is not unusual. More travelers are finding 11th-hour bargains, whether on specialized sites like site59.com, which Mr. Dweck used for his California trip, or on general travel sites like those operated by Priceline, American Express and Expedia, which is controlled by Microsoft.
Many of these sites are now receiving huge numbers of tour packages, cruises, hotel rooms and airline tickets to sell, and at unusually low prices, because of continuing soft conditions in the travel industry.
The speed of the Internet has made it easier to book at the last minute. In a report issued last July, PhoCusWright, a Sherman, Conn., company that researches online travel, found that one-quarter of all Internet users, or about 25 million people, took an "unplanned, last-minute or spur-of-the-moment" trip recently. The Travel Industry Association of America, a trade group, noted a similar trend in survey results released in February. It found that one-third of all nonbusiness travelers who planned and booked trips online did so within two weeks of their departures.
Of course, not everyone may be comfortable booking a holiday at the last minute. Such travel often means a lack of choice, whether among airlines, cruise lines, hotel chains or even destinations. But people whose plans are flexible -- or who just have a sense of adventure -- can save from 10 to 70 percent off published travel prices. That certainly appeals to Cheryl Tormey, 43, a bill collector from Monroe, Conn. She says she has bought cruise vacations for herself and her husband, Raymond, 45, a computer technician, from moments-notice.com for the last three summers and plans to buy another this year, probably in late June. "I've got to wait to see what's available," she said. "Although it could get nerve-racking, I've gotten used to doing this. I've saved a tremendous amount of money on the cruises, probably a couple of hundred to five hundred dollars," on each cruise.
As travelers' acceptance has grown, so has the supply of offerings. David S. Miranda, chairman of LastMinuteTravel.com, which started in February 2000, says his company is receiving 30 to 40 percent more discount offers today than it did a year ago, at prices 10 percent lower. And Mike Putman, president of 11thHourVacations.com, established in 1996, says he has received more new inventory in the last six weeks than in the previous nine months. Both sites are also reporting significant sales increases. Mr. Putman says his sales have quintupled since the start of the year, while Mr. Miranda expects second-quarter sales to climb 50 percent over the first quarter.
Pauline Frommer, editor of the Web site Frommers.com, which tracks travel bargains, said the deals were numerous. "We're seeing tremendously low rates -- like a $655, six-night, air-and-hotel package in Paris in June -- in part because of the recession, and in part because of fears about foot-and-mouth and mad cow diseases in Europe," she said. "There's also an incredible surge in Alaska cruise deals, because of overbuilding by the cruise lines and people being nervous about spending money."
FOR the longer term, Kate Rice, an analyst at PhoCusWright, predicted that the spur-of-the-moment travel sector could surpass other online travel categories because the last-minute sites "do such a great job putting together distressed inventory that suppliers can sell cheaply, without undermining their published prices."
Web sites sell last-minute travel in a variety of ways. Most of the sites are privately owned, although some are public or backed by larger travel companies. 
Some sites specialize in creating and selling their own offers. Those sites include site59.com, which started a year ago and is backed by the Boston Consulting Group, Goldman Sachs, Starwood Hotels and Resorts, Bass and others. Another is a publicly traded company, lastminute.com, which began in Britain in 1998 and is backed by Bass, Starwood and the British Airports Authority, among others; it also has sites for several other countries, including France, Germany, Italy, Australia and South Africa. (When Americans buy travel from these sites, they must make their own arrangements to reach an overseas destination where their trip would begin. Also, all airline tickets must be picked up abroad.)
Some sites, like LastMinuteTravel.com and Travelzoo.com, essentially act as billboards for other travel companies. They post discounts the companies choose to offer and link buyers directly to sites where they can make purchases. Go-today.com offers vacation packages created by its parent company, Europe Express, a wholesaler that sells tours to travel agents, while moments-notice.com, which has a $25 annual membership fee, offers tour packages and cruises that travel companies are unable to sell. 
Then there are the Web sites that sell all types of travel, including the last-minute variety. Those sites include Expedia.com, AmericanExpress.com, Travelocity.com, Hotwire.com and Priceline.com. And most major United States airlines have offered deeply discounted tickets online for last-minute travel for the last several years, while TravelWeb.com has offered deeply discounted hotel rooms for stays the next weekend.
Not surprisingly, major restrictions are often imposed on last-minute bookings. Site59.com, for example, usually does not permit changes or refunds, while most others charge a fee for cancellations or changes. Some sites, like Priceline and Hotwire, do not reveal the name of the travel company whose services they sell until the purchase is made, while others, like site59.com, show that information up front.
Travelers can also sign up for sites' electronic mailing lists. Many sites send out regular e-mail alerts, some tailored to their customers' individual interests. 
Todd Leasure, 32, a mortgage broker from Marietta, Ga., whose family also owns a condominium in Longboat Key, Fla., has arranged for LastMinuteTravel.com to notify him whenever there is an air-fare sale on flights between Atlanta and Tampa. He says he has bought discounted tickets four times through the site, most recently in March, when he found a $135 round trip on Delta. "I usually don't know when I can go to Florida until the day I travel or the day before because I'm a salesman," he said. "I have to take care of my clients, because if I don't, they'll get upset with me."
JOB responsibilities also keep Tara Kennelly, 32, an executive assistant at AOL Time Warner who lives in Hazlet, N.J., from planning too far in advance. In February, she bought a weeklong vacation with her fiance, Kennneth Lagana, an executive at cbssportsline.com, to Playa del Carmen, Mexico, through LastMinuteTravel.com. They paid a total of $1,278 for the trip, which included two round-trip tickets on American Trans Air and upgraded hotel accommodations at the Allegro Royal Hideaway. 
Ms. Kennelly said they "were just looking to get away, but we couldn't plan that far in advance."
"We looked online and it came out perfectly," she added. "I always wanted to go to Mexico, and the price was incredible."
She was so pleased with the arrangements, she said, that she expects to use the service again, when she goes on her honeymoon next spring.
Mr. Dweck, meanwhile, says he expects to take more impromptu trips over the next few months, rather than spending all his vacation time on Long Island beaches.
"Instead of renting a house in Montauk, as I have for the past four years, this summer I'll probably take four or five little trips with site59 and go to Montauk for a couple of weeks," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 13, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on the Personal Business page last Sunday discussed last-minute travel bargains available over the Web. The article cited the positive experience of Michael Dweck, an advertising executive from Manhattan, who had used a travel site, site59.com, for an impromptu trip to San Francisco. Mr. Dweck was quoted as saying he would probably use the site again.
A reader has pointed out that Mr. Dweck's company, Dweck! Inc., has a relationship with site59.com; he is listed as a creative partner. Mr. Dweck, telephoned last week, said that he saw no conflict because he took the impromptu trip in February 2000, before he signed on with the company, and that the article erred in saying the trip was this past winter. The article's author, a freelancer, said she had been unaware of Mr. Dweck's dealings with site59.com and had been directed to him by its public relations firm when she asked for names of recent customers.

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK 

BYLINE:  Compiled by Warren Strugatch; E-mail: libiz@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Arrow Electronics Reports A Rise in Quarterly Income
Arrow Electronics Inc. (NYSE: ARW) of Melville has reported that its net income for the first quarter was $77.4 million on sales of $3.3 billion, or 74 cents a share. In the first quarter last year, Arrow reported income of $63.1 million on sales of $2.8 billion, or 65 cents a share. 
 Francis M. Scricco, Arrow's president and chief executive, said that there might be some softening of results in the months ahead. Weakening economic conditions in North America resulted in a sales slowdown late in the first quarter. 
 "Our operations in the Asia/Pacific region experienced a similar weakening during the quarter," he said. "In Europe, however, our businesses continued to perform well. Second-quarter unit volumes will be below first-quarter levels. Given our industry's well-documented supply imbalances, gross margin erosion can be expected."
Arrow, a distributor of electronic components and computer products, is Long Island's largest company, with sales revenues of $13 billion last year.

Around the Island
Del Laboratories (Amex: DLI) of Uniondale announced Monday that net sales for the first quarter were $72.7 million, up from $67.5 million in last year's first quarter. Net earnings were $1.3 million, or 16 cents a share, up from $501,000, or 6 cents a share last year. The results "reflect the continued strength of our brands," said Dan K. Wassong, the chairman and president. . . . Curative Health Services (Nasdaq: CURE) of Hauppauge has reported that first-quarter revenues were down compared with last year. Total revenues for the quarter were $13.5 million, compared with $22.2 million in 2000. "Considering the weakness in the hospital industry, we're pleased with the performance," said John Prior, the company's president. . . . Vicon Industries Inc. (Amex: VII) of Hauppauge said that sales for the second quarter of its fiscal year slipped to $17.2 million, from $17.4 million in the same period a year ago. Net income totaled $418,000, or 9 cents a share, up from $186,000, or 4 cents a share. Ken Darby, the chief executive, said the results reflected a slowing economy. . . . Morton's Restaurant Group (NYSE: MRG) of New Hyde Park has urged shareholders to reject what it called a hostile takeover bid from the BFMA Holding Corporation of Pompano Beach, Fla. Carl C. Icahn is backing the Florida group.

SECTION: Section 3; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 2824 words

HEADLINE: ...And to Penny-Pinching Wizardry 

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
BY now, it is the stuff of legend: in the 1980's, Robert L. Crandall, then the head of American Airlines, came up with the idea of removing just one olive from every dinner salad served to passengers. They would never notice, let alone squawk, he figured, and the airline could save some money. He was right, to the tune of $40,000 a year.
 For much of the 1990's, while the bull ran free on Wall Street and corporate tills brimmed with cash, those kinds of small-but-they-add-up cost considerations were few and far between in corporate America. Then the dot-coms began imploding, many of them disappearing and many others metamorphosing from perk-filled playgrounds to bare-bones bastions. And now, as the larger economy has turned from boom to blah, the spirit of Crandall's Olive is stalking most corporate and Wall Street halls. 
 Sure, the companies are going after the multimillion-dollar cuts -- the asset sales, the downsizing, the buying of goods and services on the Internet, the farming-out of manufacturing and assembly operations to low-cost parts of the world. But all kinds of companies, from Wall Street firms like Credit Suisse First Boston to manufacturers like Xerox to media concerns like AOL Time Warner, are also chopping away at work amenities. Gone are the lobster-and-Champagne celebrations, the daily fresh flowers and free sodas, the first-class (or even business-class) air travel, the limousines, the meetings in exotic climes -- much of the same fat, in fact, that many companies eliminated after the market crash of 1987 but that had crept back on.
"We're not saying, 'Stay at Motel 6 and eat at McDonald's,' and we're not attacking compensation, benefits or any of the things that make for real quality of life," said Kenneth S. Goldman, chief financial officer of Student Advantage, a direct marketing company in Boston. "But you can drink filtered water instead of bottled, and you can be happy at a Holiday Inn instead of a Marriott. And not everyone needs a cell phone, and no one needs a limo."
While the companies are direct about asking their employees to tighten their belts, they are making their customers sacrifice, too. More olives, as well as many other things big and small, are disappearing from the flight plan. Airlines are cutting back on staff, flights and paper tickets, as well as on breakfasts, juice and wine selections and even the table linens in first class. United Airlines alone is saving about $50,000 a year by removing olives, lemon peels and grapefruit juice from its list of bar condiments.
IN the true spirit of Crandall's Olive, some companies are introducing cost-saving measures in ways that they hope their customers will never notice. There are fewer diapers in many packages of Procter & Gamble's Luvs and Pampers, and Kimberly-Clark's Huggies. The prices for the smaller packages are lower, but the per-diaper charge is higher. And customers who buy Fritos and Cheetos, made by the Frito-Lay division of PepsiCo, are getting smaller packages with fewer treats for the same money.
The lighter packages have bulked up corporate coffers: for the first quarter of the year, operating earnings at Frito-Lay North America were up 10 percent from the comparable period last year, in large part, said Andrew Conway, an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, because of that so-called weight-out program.
Product variety is on the downswing, too. Online shoppers, for example, can no longer buy an $8 rake from Amazon.com. The company recognized that shipping it -- or a host of other low-ticket products -- cost enough to eat up any profit margin on them.
Employees, however, are so far bearing the brunt of many of the corporate cuts. In some cases, companies are simply enforcing rules that no one much followed in the boom days. In others, they are imposing -- or strongly suggesting -- new fiscal restraints. But the fact is, company after company is clamping down.
Here are some of the areas under the cost cutters' microscopes:

HOUSEKEEPING -- American Standard, the maker of plumbing fixtures and air conditioners, is saving $70,000 a year at a plant in Tyler, Tex., by having its crew vacuum the entryway floor mats instead of sending out the mats for cleaning. The same factory was paying to have used wooden pallets carted away; now it is selling them. The net gain is $38,000 a year.

GREENERY -- Xerox is saving $200,000 a year by cutting out a plant-watering service; employees have installed an "adopt a plant" program to keep the foliage hydrated. Art Institutes International at San Francisco, a commercial art school, went one better. It had been paying a local company about $700 a month to provide and maintain plants and cut flowers throughout its seven-story building; it has reduced the cost to $450 by forgoing foliage in hallways, offices and other areas that only the staff frequents. "We want to be smart with how we spend our resources, without looking like we're cutting costs," said Barbara L. Roberts, the school's president.

RIDES HOME -- The Goldman Sachs Group used to pay for car services to drive analysts home after 8 p.m., even if they lived in suburbs that were a triple-digit fare away. "Now, unless we're really working well past 9 p.m., we settle for a taxi to the train station," a Goldman analyst said.

FREE FOOD -- Goldman has also eliminated the boxes of apples, grapes and oranges that used to be available all day. And editors and writers at Time Inc., part of AOL Time Warner, have been weaned from the free fruit, sodas and lavish closing-night dinners to which they had become accustomed. At Xerox, catered meetings are out. Instead, "people order in subs that they pay for out of their own pockets, or take a break and have lunch in a local cafeteria," said Kathleen A. Hargather, vice president for nonproduction purchasing.

OFFICE SUPPLIES -- Student Advantage insists that all employees use the pens and papers that the company stocks in bulk -- "if you want neon-colored Post-it notes or gel pens, it's on your nickel," Mr. Goldman said. And Canon U.S.A. is recycling furniture. For example, during an expansion, its Hawaii office asked for about $70,000 for new chairs, desks and such. Instead, Canon shipped excess furniture from its Jamesburg, N.J., office. The shipping and reassembling cost was $17,000.

TRINKETS AND TROPHIES -- Investment bankers at Credit Suisse First Boston have been told to keep the cost of Lucite mementos -- the fancy clear tokens that are usually distributed to clients and bankers after a deal and that can cost $75 to $250 each -- to below $2,500 a deal. The firm used to give out 20 to 50 a deal, including some to members of the Credit Suisse team; now the bankers are to give most of the trophies to clients. (At The New York Times Company, even little keepsakes are going by the boards. At the annual Take Our Daughters to Work Day last month, some girls complained that for the first time they did not get goody bags and had to bring their own pencils and paper.)

CELEBRATIONS -- It used to be that when a big merger deal went down, the investment bankers and their clients -- and their spouses or significant others -- would have lavish weekend celebrations at hotels or convention centers. And those were in addition to the closing dinners, with lobster and free-flowing Champagne. Several big investment banks, including Credit Suisse, Goldman and the Salomon Smith Barney unit of Citigroup, are eliminating such weekends and asking their staffs to keep down the dinner guest lists.
"It's not as onerous as you might expect," one investment banker said. "After all, there just aren't that many deals to celebrate these days."
Nor do the Wall Street firms expect any big resurgence soon. Instead of flying its managing directors somewhere for its usual summer meeting, Goldman Sachs will hold a teleconference. The firm has already canceled its annual winter dinner, a year-end celebration at which hundreds of partners from around the world convened to make merry in merrier times.
Many less frivolous expenses are being cut, too.
Some companies, like Electronic Data Systems and Xerox, report that they are curtailing off-site training sessions and are instead encouraging employees to use online tutorials or are asking some of their own employees to teach classes.
Merrill Lynch used to provide high-producing brokers with access to expensive computer-linked trading networks like Level II, which provides real-time information on Nasdaq trades. Now, if they want it, brokers must pay for the service themselves -- as well as for any assistants deemed superfluous.
"Level II was a nice but not necessary tool to have, but I really need two assistants," said one broker, who has dropped the data service but is paying his second aide's $4,000-a-month salary himself.
Time Inc. is getting rid of one of its most coveted jobs, that of editor at large. Editors who held that title made as much as $300,000 a year consulting to the company's various publications, yet produced little actual text themselves. Now some have been asked to join the staffs of its magazines, while others are renegotiating their salaries. Of about a dozen such editors, at least four have left the full-time staff; those who remained have joined specific magazines.
A growing number of companies are encouraging or even mandating paid or unpaid vacations, sometimes to allow for a temporary plant closing, sometimes to get accrued vacation time off the books, sometimes just to cut overall payroll costs.
And some, like Credit Suisse First Boston and Intel, are trying to keep the payroll from swelling by asking the graduating students to whom they had made job offers to delay their starting dates -- or not to come at all.
THE reasons for the penny-pinching vary widely. At companies that have cut whole swaths of employees, it appears unseemly not to spread the pain among those who remain. And now that the dot-com universe has lost much of its allure, few companies feel that they need special perquisites to recruit or retain most employees.
Companies also want to show customers and shareholders that they are holding the line on costs. "Due to current market conditions, firms want to display an 'all business, less pleasure' attitude," said Eliezer M. Fich, a visiting assistant professor of finance at the Kenan-Flagler Business School at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.
But big cost cuts have big costs of their own. Laying off employees requires huge reserves for severance. Installing supply-chain management programs or setting up Internet buying and selling services can also be expensive and disruptive. For instance, Nova Chemicals, based in Calgary, Alberta, is spending $3 million to install a system that will let it buy many of its supplies online.
But there is no financial cost in cutting back on fruit and parties. Nor is the psychic cost very high these days. Employees -- many of whom have seen colleagues and neighbors laid off -- are for the most part accepting the cutbacks without much squawking. "You can't blame the company for trying to save a buck by getting rid of the unnecessary," another Goldman analyst said.
In fact, employees at some companies are pitching their own ideas for cuts. Soon after Richard H. Brown became the chairman of Electronic Data Systems in January 1999, he sent an e-mail message to the company's 140,000 employees, asking each to come up with an idea for saving $1,000 at E.D.S.
"Employees in Michigan got rid of extra phone lines, a team in California got rid of modems, three people in Toronto began booking air travel seven days in advance," Mr. Brown recalled. "People voluntarily booked cheaper hotels and canceled expensive training sessions in favor of Internet courses."
Such savings gave a big boost to the bottom line -- as did the layoffs of more than 13,000 employees. E.D.S. ended last year with operating margins of 9.5 percent, compared with 7.5 percent in 1998.
A MANAGER at one Xerox division made something of a game out of a company-imposed cutback. In the first quarter last year, Xerox held 114 lavish kickoff meetings at which sales representatives enjoyed themselves as their bosses pepped them up to sell the latest products. This year the company, which has lost money for several quarters, saved $19 million by holding just 15 "live" meetings and holding the others with a combination of conference calls and intranet slides.
To forestall the inevitable grumbling, Michael Long, the manager in charge of the sales meeting at Xerox Business Service Systems, sent care packages to the sales staff. The packages, costing $11.81 each, included microwave popcorn, crayons, balloons, chocolate coins and a happy-sad picture of the field vice president that could be reversed by the participants during the meeting to help them visualize their leader's reactions.
"We inserted music and trivia quizzes and sound effects, we kept the meeting light, and we embraced the idea of 'fun without funds,' " Mr. Long said.
Companies that are not under such financial pressure are more likely to try the carrot than the stick. Canon U.S.A., a main Xerox competitor, never used to pick up extra hotel costs for employees who wanted to extend business trips over a weekend. Now, it will do so to take advantage of the cheaper air fares available for trips that include Saturday-night stays. "I don't want anyone to feel they have to stay over the weekend, but if they want to, and it saves us money, we'll encourage it," said Seymour Liebman, a Canon executive vice president.
Similarly, Barry W. Perry, chief executive of Engelhard, a specialty chemical company, recently installed a video conference setup on the executive floor of its headquarters in Iselin, N.J..
"Historically, when our executives needed to talk to people elsewhere, they flew," Mr. Perry said. "I didn't want to put in an edict about cutting out executive travel, but I think they'll soon realize this is faster as well as cheaper."
E.D.S. did not want to carry the cost of the employee health club at its Plano, Tex., headquarters, but it also did not want to take away the perk. So it recently donated the gym to the local Y.M.C.A. -- and arranged for employees and their families to receive discounts. "Families weren't allowed to use it when we owned it, so they saw it as a plus," Mr. Brown said.
Many companies, while not asking employees to give up anything, are nonetheless forcing them to conserve on supplies; others are asking that they procure things more cheaply.
Ames Department Stores, a discount chain, just installed lights that are set off by motion at its headquarters in Rocky Hill, Conn., "and our people are getting used to flinging their hands up every now and so often to keep the office lights on," said Rolando de Aguiar, Ames's chief financial and chief administrative officer.
Xerox, whose employees now must rent compact cars when they travel, is refusing to pay the high gasoline prices that rental companies charge when an employee forgets to fill the tank before returning the car. "We're looking for savings associated with usage as well as with eliminating costs," Ms. Hargather said.
Companies that have held the line on costs for some time are having to dig deep to find more fat. Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher, & Flom, the big New York law firm, clamped down on meal allowances, car services and catering costs during the recession of the early 1990's, "so we don't have a lot of easy pickings laying around now," said Earle Yaffa, the firm's managing director.
Skadden did find some new savings: it now uses lower-quality copy paper and has cut out administrative clerks -- the college students it used to hire during the summer to fill in for vacationers. "Actually, we had to work hard to keep these people busy, and we realized we don't really need them," Mr. Yaffa said.
Similarly, Lehman Brothers Holdings went through "a pretty extensive program to whack costs" in the mid-90's, according to William J. Ahearn, a Lehman spokesman. Though Mr. Ahearn said Lehman "never offered the free shoeshines and massages that people thought we did," the firm nonetheless saved $300 million by cutting back on "chairs, computers, lights, air travel, everything except salary or bonus or incentives."
This time around, Lehman has gone well beyond such incidentals. For example, it used to pay Bear Stearns to handle the transaction-clearing activities for its stock trades; recently, it started handling the process on its own, at an estimated savings of $35 million a year.
The key for all these companies, of course, is to make sure that the excesses do not creep back in when the bull returns to Wall Street and health is restored to balance sheets.
"I still worry a little about how to make people recognize that all this cost-cutting isn't a short-term thing," Ms. Hargather of Xerox said. "Our goal has got to be to keep costs down, not just get them down."

HEADLINE: LOVE & MONEY; 
You're in a Jam? Here I Am

BYLINE:  By ELLYN SPRAGINS; Ellyn Spragins is a freelance writer in Maplewood, N.J. Her column about money's influence on relationships appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: loveandmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
I THOUGHT that there would be a lot of pain and angst from the current wave of corporate layoffs that is roiling people's lives. Silly me. Pain and angst are so last century. The new economy, tattered though it may be, now has a companion -- the new, happy-go-lucky layoff. 
 It works like this: You are handed a pink slip from your employer, but it's no big deal because layoffs are a part of life these days. You'll write a novel or start your own business. Maybe you'll just charge right back into the same industry. Drake Beam Morin, a firm in Stamford, Conn., that helps with career transitions, has even documented how easily these layoffs go down the hatch. It found that more than two-thirds of the 3,000 laid-off executives it surveyed from January 1999 to April 2000 were not very concerned about finances and said their job searches had improved family relationships or had no effect on them. 
 Funny, that is not how I remember it. When my husband was laid off during Wall Street's turbulent 1980's, our relationship was stretched painfully. Losing a salary wasn't as bad as losing the balance in our partnership. John sometimes trudged off to a phone booth in Grand Central Terminal rather than stay at home and listen to me angrily and obsessively itemize his job-hunting tasks.
It was a strain to act normally around friends. I remember wishing I didn't have to explain why someone had spotted my husband, unshaven and unshowered, picking up a dozen bagels downtown long after other husbands had boarded the 6:45. Both John and I can still recall the mixture of gratitude and resentment we felt toward supportive former colleagues who were still collecting year-end bonuses and Hermes ties.
Has all of that really disappeared? Well, there are plenty of happy layoff stories around. But why did an old friend refuse to discuss her husband's layoff from a year ago -- on or off the record? What made another close colleague clam up about her own recent job loss? Then there was the executive who has been laid off four times in 10 years. He didn't want his name used.
The stigma may be gone for some. But losing a job is still a profound assault on your identity -- the face you present to yourself and to the world -- not to mention your bank account.
Friends and family usually pass the early stages of unemployment with flying colors. Supportive, loving -- you name the heart-warming behavior -- they enact it. It is the third, fifth, or seventh month of unemployment that turns spouses into part-time enemies and friends into indifferent slugs. 
Patrick Hansard, 47, of Princeton, N.J., was laid off in January from Grolier Inc., the book publisher, after it was acquired by Scholastic; he had run Grolier's international marketing and sales division. The job loss was his second in four years. Remembering the first, yearlong job search, he said, "At first, I didn't want to contact colleagues too often, because I felt like a burden." Pushing himself into networking, he was upset by how unhelpful some of his closest co-workers were. "It puts your relationship in a different light," he said. "The memory of their behavior will remain."
I learned the first rule of living with a laid-off spouse: Listen and care. But don't let his identity crisis cause you to doubt him. Jill Andresky Fraser, who interviewed dozens of laid-off workers for her book, "White Collar Sweatshop" (W. W. Norton), says most people who receive pink slips blame themselves. "They feel like a failure, and that feeling plays itself out with other people," she said. "They are unable or unwilling to socialize. No matter how supportive their spouse is, they feel guilty and jealous."
The rule for friends of laid-off workers is equally simple: Act normally and be persistent. That may be difficult if a friendship revolved around the friend's job, its perks or its salary. Should you continue to include your laid-off friend in after-work drinks with colleagues? Should you include him when buying tickets to an expensive new show? The more that those activities mattered to you, the more distant you'll feel, said Joan Indursky DiFuria, co-founder of the Money Meaning & Choices Institute, a counseling service in San Francisco that helps people deal with the emotional issues surrounding money.
On the other hand, she added, if your friendship is built upon "a person's kindness, spirituality, athleticism or other qualities, the more there is to hold the relationship together."
ACTING "normally" doesn't mean avoiding sensitive topics and expensive restaurants. The trick is to continue enjoying all the things you liked about your laid-off friend. Don't stop the invitations now, even if you think he can't afford to go along. 
Recognize that you won't get it right all the time. Some days, out-of-work friends will want to talk endlessly about their job searches. Other days, they will slam down the phone when asked if they have landed anything. 
But getting it right is not as important as it seems. Staying the course is what matters. You won't save them from pain and angst. But you will let them know that the job wasn't everything.

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Ford Super Duty F-250 and Chevrolet Silverado 3500HD; 
Reaching Critical Mass in the Civilian Arms Race

BYLINE:  By DAN NEIL 

 BODY:
AMERICA is the land of the very, very big. Big hair, big malls, big cities, big Las Vegas hotels that look like big cities, big movies starring big ships that sink in a big way. Big is practically a good unto itself, not to be confused with the relativistic notion of "scale," to which some old-fashioned professors of design still cling.
 If the roads seem smaller, it is only because you are sharing them with a new breed of giants. Heavy-duty pickups -- loosely defined as trucks with gross vehicle weight, or G.V.W., of more than 8,500 pounds, including the vehicle and the maximum cargo load -- account for about a third of the two million full-size pickups bought annually in the United States. 
 Once these trucks were merely girded versions of full-size, light-duty trucks. Then, for 1999, Ford brought out its Super Duty series, a group of Sumo-sized pickups several inches larger in every dimension than comparable F-150 series trucks. 
General Motors' answer is the Chevy Silverado HD and GMC Sierra HD, both new for 2001. Though not quite as large as the Super Dutys -- the G.M. 4x4's are about 77 inches high, compared with Ford's N.B.A.-caliber 80 inches -- they are sufficiently enormous to cause one's mental pinball game to tilt. My test truck, a Silverado 3500 4x4 Extended Cab LS (the model designations are enormous, too), loomed over traffic like a lifeguard crossing the kiddie pool.
Trucks in this class are a peculiar breed of rolling trompe l'oeil; they have the visual cues and proportions of regular pickups, only supersized. It is as if Roger Corman, the B-movie master, had applied the same forced perspective he previously used on spiders, rabbits and overradiated women.
The needs of consumers notwithstanding, an arms-race mentality seems to have taken hold in the heavy-duty pickup market. Last year, Ford made hay with the Super Duty's superlatives -- it had the most towing and cargo capacity in its class. This year, it is G.M.'s turn to crow, since the Silverado and Sierra HD's have the beefiest engines, the most towing capacity, the highest cargo limits. In a segment closely tied to the American work ethic, there is equity in being the biggest, strongest and toughest.
The dog yet to bark is Dodge, which is considering building its own uber-truck. Currently, the biggest Dodge Ram, the 3500 4x4, based on a light-duty chassis, loses the cargo-carrying comparison by more than a half-ton to the Silverado HD.

Chevy: An Easy-Listening Diesel
The biggest motor in G.M.'s fleet is the new Duramax 6600 turbo-diesel V-8, which produces 300 horsepower and a seismic 520 foot-pounds of torque. Developed jointly with Isuzu, the Duramax does for big diesel engines what Volkswagen's 1.8-liter did for small ones -- that is, make them behave so much like gas engines that you notice the difference mainly at the pump. The Duramax banishes the noisy clatter of big diesels; at idle, it sounds as if someone is softly playing maracas in the glovebox.
But the Duramax is hardly delicate. The engine carries a 200,000-mile warranty and G.M. practically dares buyers to break it. With it, the Silverado 3500 4x4 has a gross combined vehicle weight rating (the maximum combined weight of truck, trailer and cargo) of 24,000 pounds. The HD series is also available with less potent engines, including a 6-liter gasoline V-8 (300 horsepower, 360 foot-pounds of torque) and an 8.1-liter big-block V-8 (340 horses, 455 foot-pounds). The gasoline engines are available with a new six-speed manual transmission and a more familiar four-speed automatic.
Channeling the diesel's muscle to the ground is a six-speed manual transmission or a new five-speed automatic from Allison, the largest supplier of automatic transmissions to the commercial truck market. The Silverado's height makes room for its tractorlike underpinnings, huge axles, differentials and frame rails. Four-wheel antilock disc brakes with dynamic rear proportioning, which adjusts the braking power for the cargo load, are standard.
For all its heavy-duty hardware, the Silverado HD is remarkably civilized. G.M. employs two sets of leaf springs in the rear. For a comfortable ride, the supple upper leaves support the vehicle when unloaded -- think of Big Daddy Contractor driving to the job site. Loaded, the truck settles onto the thicker leaf springs underneath. The tested Silverado, at $41,206, was loaded with leather, polished alloy wheels, OnStar electronics and an optional electronic shift transfer case, with push-button activation of four-wheel drive. The exterior styling was similarly executive, with a smoothly integrated front grille bisected by a thick chrome bar wearing Chevy's gold bow tie. Much of the rear of the truck is clad in body panels of composite resin -- plastic, if you like -- which give the truck a futuristic sheen. 

INSIDE TRACK: An 800-pound gorilla in a Hugo Boss suit.

Ford: Supersized Inside and Out
With more than 44 vehicle configurations -- including two- and four-wheel-drive, single or dual rear wheels, an assortment of cabs, bed sizes, trim levels and engines -- the Super Duty chassis can be many things to a great many entrepreneurs. In the two and a half years since the series was introduced, more than 1.1 million have been sold. And that's not counting the jumbo Excursion S.U.V. built from many of the same parts.
The Super Duty's styling is wonderfully over-the-top, with what looks like chrome barbells for grille accents and a huge all-steel bumper for a its jaw. Hiding under the bumper is a structure to help prevent drive-over damage in the event that this gladiator should collide with a smaller vehicle.
The exterior is finished with cues from long-haul trucks: cut-down window sills and extended rocker-panel steps to aid those trying to vault into the knee-high cabin.
You can get a Super Crew with four big doors, but I drove a SuperCab with smaller, front-opening rear doors. (Ford prefers not to call them "suicide doors.") The interior felt like a six-passenger handball court, with 67 inches between doors -- so much room that you cannot lean on the center armrest and prop your other elbow on the door, unless you are, you know, circus folk.
Various amenities are similarly elephantine: a huge cup holder tray on which you could serve high tea; a center armrest "mobile office center" the size of a laundry hamper. Otherwise, the switches, dials and gauges are Dearborn orthodox.
Ford offers three engines in the Super Duty line: a 5.4-liter V-8 rated at 235 horsepower and 335 foot-pounds of torque; a 6.8-liter V-10 (275/410); and a 7.3-liter diesel V-8 (235 horses and a whopping 500 foot-pounds of torque at a low 1,600 r.p.m). The test truck -- an F-250 Super Duty 4WD XLT -- came with the single-overhead-cam V-10, which provides almost all its torque at a mere 2,000 r.p.m. It ran quietly and smoothly and was enough to put the 5,642-pound vehicle afoul of the highway patrol within 9 seconds from being at a standstill.
My F-250 had the beefy 4R100 four-speed automatic transmission and shift-on-the-fly four-wheel drive. In a brief off-road venture in the four-wheel low range, the Ford had a distinctly agricultural feel. The high cost of renting a crane discouraged me from trying to get the truck stuck in the mud.
The Super Duty is many things, but nimble is not one of them. A turning radius of 48 feet makes you feel, when parking, as though you are arriving by air in Lakehurst, N.J., with the newsreel cameras rolling. Given its nose-heavy balance and its solid-beam, leaf-spring suspension front and rear, the Super Duty 4x4 is, as might be expected, not particularly limber around corners. It spins its tires vigorously at the least excuse, and when unloaded, the ride is somewhat jouncy and bouncy. It would behave better with the proverbial ton of bricks in the back.
However, like the Silverado HD, the Super Duty is surprisingly genteel inside. The cabin is quiet and vibration-free. The steering is light and responsive. Thanks to its prodigious wheelbase (up to 172.4 inches with the Crew Cab), it provides limo-like smoothness on the highway -- great, if you have seven tons of prom dates to chauffeur.
All Super Dutys have four-wheel disc brakes, and antilock brakes are standard on the larger versions. The test vehicle checked in at a reasonable $31,195.
What is not to like? Well, someone may have to answer to a higher power for the fuel economy, or lack thereof. My test model got about 10 miles to the gallon in mixed driving, but I feel sure I could have coaxed it down to single digits. Visibility through the side windows is fairly limited; regular-sized vehicles -- like Cadillacs -- can ride along unseen below the sills. Use those mirrors!
But, over all, I could not help but be seduced by the Super Duty's charms, the first of which is the sheer, moronic fun of driving a wicked monster truck. Besides, I liked the opportunity to pose as a burly blue-collar guy. Here I come, Big Daddy Contractor. Look at the hourly workers run.

INSIDE TRACK: The colossus of roads.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
Stock Investors Manage to Ignore 223,000 Lost Jobs

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
A GIANT tree fell in the forest on Friday, but to stock market investors, it didn't make a sound.
 The crash that only the bond market appeared to hear was the news that the United States economy lost more jobs in April than it had at any time during the last 10 years. According to the Labor Department, payrolls plummeted by 223,000 in the month, and the unemployment rate rose to 4.5 percent, its highest in two and a half years. Equally ominous was the rate of employment growth as measured by a survey of households; for the first time in a decade, it fell into negative territory. That rate typically goes negative only in a recession. 
 What the jobs report signified to some economists was an imminent weakening in consumer spending. So far, that spending has held up remarkably well, giving the only bounce to an otherwise drooping economy.
But to stock investors, the jobs report was a nonevent. They remain convinced that the economy will recover in the second half, in large part because Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, is slashing interest rates. The bulls argue that stocks are the place to be, because the market sees past the current slowdown and has a quick recovery in its sights.
Rising unemployment, however, changes the quick-recovery script substantially. As long as they have jobs, consumers are willing to keep up profligate spending habits even if they have to borrow money to do so. Once they lose their jobs, however, consumers may well snap their wallets shut.
"In the face of rising joblessness, consumer confidence gets hit," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "That will take personal consumption growth well below the 3 percent pace we've been cruising at during the last couple of quarters."
Add this to the already weak spending by corporations and the negative impact that a strong dollar will have on exports, and Mr. Roach concludes that the relatively narrow economic downturn is about to become much broader.
James W. Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management in Minneapolis, has a similar worry. He says that within three to four months, the nation's unemployment rate may be as high as 5.4 percent. "We're going into this slowdown with the highest fixed-cost structure ever at companies, because of the technology boom," he said. Those costs are the interest expenses and depreciation costs that followed corporations' big investments in technology. "If you can't cut your fixed-cost structure, you've got to cut your variable," he said. "That's why we've seen such alarming layoff announcements."
Mr. Paulsen reckons that with such high fixed costs, corporations may continue to pare jobs even when the economy is growing slowly. "Because interest rates have been coming down, consumers have been able to pile on more debt," he said. "But if you start destroying jobs, we're going to find out there is a consumer debt problem. And that's one of the reasons we are going to have a hard time restarting the economy."
Which brings us to Mr. Greenspan. While stock market investors revere him, others think his rate cuts may have a muted impact this time around.
"We'll probably have a nice fiscal stimulus," Mr. Roach said. "But the Fed will not be able to get the classic traction with this policy easing. The real problem here is that America is working through the aftershocks of an equity bubble. And balance-sheet adjustments, both on the part of companies and consumers, must be made before the economy can respond as it classically does to a monetary ease."
