HEADLINE: U.S. SCIENTISTS SEE BIG POWER SAVINGS FROM CONSERVATION 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5 

 BODY:
Scientists at the country's national laboratories have projected enormous energy savings if the government takes aggressive steps to encourage energy conservation in homes, factories, offices, appliances, cars and power plants.
 Their studies, completed just before the Bush administration took office, are at odds with the administration's repeated assertions in recent weeks that the nation needs to build a big new power plant every week for the next 20 years to keep up with the demand for electricity, and that big increases in production of coal and natural gas are needed to fuel those plants. 
 A lengthy and detailed report based on three years of work by five national laboratories said that a government-led efficiency program emphasizing research and incentives to adopt new technologies could reduce the growth in electricity demand by 20 percent to 47 percent.
That would be the equivalent of between 265 and 610 big 300-megawatt power plants, a steep reduction from the 1,300 new plants that the administration predicts will be needed. The range depends on how aggressively the government encourages efficiency in buildings, factories and appliances, as well as on the price of energy, which affects whether new technologies are economically attractive. 
Another laboratory study found that government office buildings could cut their own use of power by one-fifth at no net cost to the taxpayers by adopting widespread energy conservation measures, paying for the estimated $5 billion investment with the energy savings.
But the Bush administration, which is in the final stages of preparing a strategy to deal with what it calls an energy crisis, has not publicized these findings, relying instead primarily on advice from economists at the Energy Department's Energy Information Agency, who often take a skeptical view of projected efficiency gains and predict a much greater need for fossil fuel supplies.
Administration officials said that some of the national laboratories' studies were based on theoretical assumptions that do not translate well into policy.
"We are looking for practical solutions here," said Jeanne Lopatto, a spokeswoman for the Energy Department. "Whatever works, we're interested in. But some of these ideas have been funded over many years and they have a very small impact on energy needs."
The once obscure debate between scientists at the national laboratories and economists at the information agency, both sides working for the Department of Energy, reflects a raging dispute between President Bush and many Democrats and environmentalists. While both sides agree that the United States faces energy problems, Mr. Bush's team has emphasized the quest for new supplies, while his critics emphasize untapped potential to reduce demand.
Vice President Dick Cheney, speaking publicly last week on the energy plan he is in charge of drafting, used the information agency's projections when he said that the nation would need at least 1,300 new power plants by 2020. Mr. Cheney used the figure to dramatize the need to mobilize public and private resources to close a supply gap.
Mr. Cheney has not publicly noted that other Energy Department studies show ways to trim that number. The conservation measures that the scientists consider feasible would save future energy costs and prevent air pollution from hundreds of power plants.
The laboratories' estimates assume widespread application of some time-tested efficiency standards and the success of some newer inventions that scientists love but many bottom-line economists tend to distrust as expensive or unrealistic.
Their work was reviewed by outside experts from industry, government and universities.
Some of the proposed conservation steps are neither costly nor complex. Just this week, researchers at the Energy Department's Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory announced that they had developed a fluorescent table lamp that reduces the need for overhead lighting. The laboratory says the lamp matches the combined output of a 300-watt halogen lamp and a 150-watt bulb, but uses a quarter of the energy.
"Widespread use of this lighting system in offices and homes could greatly reduce the current power problems we have in California," said Michael Siminovitch, a scientist at the laboratory.
Other technologies have been proved in field tests. At Fort Polk, an Army base in Louisiana, electricity use during peak hours fell by 43 percent after base managers installed fluorescent lights, low-flow shower heads, new attic insulation and new home heating and cooling systems.
Most of the savings came from installing geothermal heat pumps, an efficient home heating and cooling system that circulates fluids through underground coils but otherwise uses conventional technologies. Hundreds of homes on the base were equipped with the systems, generating immediate cost savings for electricity and totally eliminating the homes' use of natural gas for water heating. The entire installation cost was covered by a private contractor that makes a profit by sharing in the government's cost savings for the first 20 years.
The heat pumps, though still something of a novelty, are completely proven and save so much money that President Bush installed a system at his new ranch home in Crawford, Tex., Mr. Cheney's official home, the Naval Observatory in Washington, also uses geothermal heat pumps to cut down on its energy bill.
A study prepared by the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory last year contended that striving to make such savings often made sound economic sense.
The study found that the federal government, the largest energy user in the United States with some 500,000 buildings, could reduce its own energy consumption by one-fifth. The investment necessary to realize those gains would be $5.2 billion, the study said, but the energy savings would knock nearly $1 billion annually off the government's energy bill, an attractive rate of return.
Some private companies have already made significant advances in what are known as combined heat and generation plants, which could become industry standards, energy department experts say. Chevron has estimated that it saved $100 million a year after it withdrew a refinery from the Texas electricity grid and relied on an on-site generator, which allowed it to recycle waste heat from the generation process for refining.
New efficiency standards for clothes washers, water heaters and air-conditioners adopted by the Clinton administration were projected by the Clinton Energy Department to reduce electricity demand by the equivalent of 170 300-megawatt power plants over 20 years if fully enforced.
President Bush's fiscal 2002 budget slashed the department's spending on researching and developing energy-efficient buildings and factories, more fuel-efficient automobiles, new appliance standards and more efficient lighting. Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham said some of that work was better left to the private sector.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Cheney, both former oil industry executives, seem to have assigned a tertiary role to efficiency improvements, behind new drilling for oil and gas and new construction of energy infrastructure, like pipelines and power plants. Neither the president nor the vice president has promoted his own energy-saving home as a model.
In fact, Mr. Cheney said last week, "Conservation may be a sign of personal virtue, but it is not a sufficient basis for a sound, comprehensive energy policy."

HEADLINE: Questions of Style In Warnaco's Fall 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
EVEN in 1992, after Linda Wachner had engineered the leveraged buyout of Warnaco Inc., a sedate maker of intimate apparel, and turned it into a cash machine, taken it public and become a darling of investors, stock analysts and financial writers, few mistook her for the model executive of management textbooks.
 That year, Fortune magazine named her America's "most successful businesswoman" and other publications grouped her with movers and shakers like Henry Kravis and Ronald Perelman. But even in the most generous tributes, there were always mentions or hints of Mrs. Wachner's unusual excesses in her use of her position. 
 She became known for an outsized compensation package -- in 1999, for example, her base salaries, totaling $3.785 million, from Warnaco and Authentic Fitness (which Warnaco has since bought), exceeded the base salary for John F. Welch Jr. at General Electric, which has roughly 50 times the revenue and 100 times the net income. (Mr. Welch, however, received about $10 million in bonuses that year, while Mrs. Wachner got none, and Warnaco said the boards of both companies had approved her compensation.) 
Mrs. Wachner also developed a reputation for demoralizing employees by publicly dressing them down for missing sales and profit goals or for simply displeasing her. Often, many former employees said, the attacks were personal rather than professional, and not infrequently laced with crude references to sex, race or ethnicity -- an accusation that Mrs. Wachner flatly denies.
As one of the few high-profile women running a big company in the early 1990's, however, Mrs. Wachner was a Teflon chief executive. She was, after all, still building Warnaco from a sleepy bra company with $590 million in sales into a $2.25 billion-a-year powerhouse with a dream team of retail brands like Calvin Klein jeans and underwear, Chaps by Ralph Lauren sportswear and Speedo swimsuits. She delivered financial results that made her widely discussed indulgences, financial and managerial, appear to be a means to an end -- or at least a forgivable sideshow.
No longer. The Warnaco Group, as the company is now known, has almost completely collapsed. The company announced last month that it lost $338 million last year, or $6.41 a share, and had little more than $11 million in cash on hand. The stock has crashed from $44.375 a share in July 1998 to 75 cents on Friday. At the beginning of April, the company, laden with almost $1.84 billion in debt, acknowledged that it was in violation of the terms of its bank loans. A few days later, Warnaco's auditors, Deloitte & Touche, said that unless Warnaco could renegotiate the terms of those loans, they had "substantial doubt" that the company could continue its operations.
If that were not enough, in the last nine months, two groups of shareholders have filed class-action lawsuits contending that Warnaco and its executives artificially inflated the price of the company's stock by issuing false and misleading statements about its financial performance. And last month, the Securities and Exchange Commission notified the Warnaco Group that it was investigating possible violations of securities laws in connection with previously filed financial statements and reports.
Emboldened by these events, many investors, former employees and retail partners are now willing to assert what was only whispered all along: that Mrs. Wachner's management style has hurt and perhaps even killed the company. These intimates of the company argue that her personal criticism of employees, among other things, has led to excessive staff turnover and robbed the company of talent it needed to maintain quality operations. Warnaco has, for example, employed three chief financial officers at the Authentic Fitness division in five years, five presidents of Calvin Klein Kids in three years and three heads of Warnaco Intimate Apparel in four years. 
These critics also say that Mrs. Wachner's lust for Midas-size pay packages has caused the company to make poor short-term decisions that buoyed the top line and plumped earnings. They want her out.
"We have lost confidence in her," said Ted White, director for corporate governance at the California Public Employees' Retirement System, the giant pension fund known as Calpers, which owned 260,856, or 0.5 percent, of the company's shares as of its latest filing and is agitating for her ouster. "We are distressed with the performance and we question whether she has the ability to turn the company around."
Warnaco has an answer to Mrs. Wachner's critics. It amounts to this: a lot of bad luck, not Mrs. Wachner, has hurt the company.
The confluence of closings, bankruptcies and consolidations among retailers, as well as the weak economy and the adverse impact of a well-publicized lawsuit by Calvin Klein, all contributed to Warnaco's current position, said Howard Rubenstein, whose public relations firm was hired to represent the company in recent weeks. High interest rates in the last part of 2000 compounded the problem, Mr. Rubenstein added.
Mrs. Wachner declined to be interviewed, but in a written statement denied that she was unprofessional to employees. "My management style is tough but fair," she said. "I would certainly never knowingly do anything to humiliate or embarrass anyone."

Conquered and Divided
In May 2000, when Calvin Klein sued Warnaco and Mrs. Wachner to try to terminate her license to make his jeans, the personal nature of his attack was conspicuous. The complaint, in United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, called Mrs. Wachner abusive and unprofessional.
In an interview at the time, Mr. Klein angrily expanded on the topic. "She runs it like a monarchy," he fumed, describing Mrs. Wachner's performance at Warnaco. "She is abusive to our people. Verbally, the language is disgusting."
The visceral nature of Mr. Klein's comments stunned outsiders, but former employees say it came as no surprise to them. In interviews, more than a dozen former employees consistently painted Mrs. Wachner as an executive with a brilliant financial mind, but also as a manager with an autocratic style that often became abusive. For example, employees say she routinely used racial or ethnic slurs when chastising employees.
In her written response, Mrs. Wachner categorically denied making such remarks.
To counter criticism from former employees, Warnaco provided several current executives who, in phone interviews that were monitored by a company lawyer, described Mrs. Wachner as an exemplary employer. For example, Suzanne Karkus, president of the Calvin Klein Jeans women's division, said that in her 20 years in the business, she had never had a boss who was more honest or supportive. "If she gives her word, she comes through 100 percent," Ms. Karkus said. 
Christopher G. Staff, president and chief operating officer of the Authentic Fitness unit, said Mrs. Wachner's compassion for employees was evident when a manager collapsed in the office several years ago. "Linda not only got down on the floor with him and called 911, she went with the litter to the hospital," Mr. Staff recalled.
In other interviews, though, some former employees who consider themselves among Mrs. Wachner's most ardent admirers did not say she was easy to work for. But they said she upbraided employees only for good reason. "If you expect everyone to be extremely nice and polite -- it is unrealistic for apparel," said Martin J. Rose, who ran Warnaco's worldwide advertising and marketing from February 1997 to February 1999. "I don't think she ever lost her temper in a way that was unjustifiable."
Chris Heyn, who was president of Warnaco's Hathaway shirt division from 1991 until 1992, said Mrs. Wachner could be intimidating, but only when people failed to do their jobs. "When you did not make numbers, she would dress you down and make you feel knee-high and it was terrifying," he said. "But she only lost it over business stuff. Only when we missed numbers."
Many other former employees, however, said Mrs. Wachner's wrath was kindled easily, was often irrational and often crossed the line between business and personal. Most former employees, even those who left on good terms, refused to speak for attribution because they still feared Mrs. Wachner. One former executive, raising a common theme, said, "The only people who survive at Warnaco were people who were abused children."
Another added: "She is the main reason why Warnaco has grown and the main reason it has fallen apart. There is some genius there, but she cannot run a $2 billion corporation by herself."
Several employees described a common practice designed, they felt, to make them feel small: Late in the evening, Mrs. Wachner would telephone an employee who had fallen out of favor and demand that he or she meet her at the offices of Warnaco, at 90 Park Avenue in Manhattan, at 39th Street, the next morning. Then she would leave them sitting in a room for hours, sometimes the entire day, waiting for her.
Another specific incident, recalled by several employees, involved Alexander Cannon, who was president of the men's sportswear division at Warnaco until 1998. They said that at a meeting of executives, Mrs. Wachner turned to Mr. Cannon and belittled him with a crude comment about the behavior of his wife, from whom he had just separated. Mr. Cannon declined to comment. Mrs. Wachner declined to discuss the specific allegation. A Warnaco spokesman noted that Mr. Cannon had worked at the company for 11 years.
Another employee remembered being castigated by Mrs. Wachner at a meeting of division presidents after a batch of shirts had arrived from a factory at an unacceptably low quality level; he later learned that Mrs. Wachner had changed his order from including an enzyme wash to a less expensive garment wash, altering the quality, without informing him.
Mrs. Wachner and her senior advisers do not recall any such incident, said Stanley Silverstein, general counsel for Warnaco. He said Mrs. Wachner always insisted on the highest quality.
The widespread impression that Mrs. Wachner treats employees roughly has left Warnaco with one of the highest executive turnover rates in the industry, several retail talent-recruiting agents said.
Former employees said this made it harder for the company to cope with the economic slowdown that began last year. The firings, or "public hangings," as one former employee characterized them, made executives reluctant to warn of slowing sales or defecting customers. "People were overwhelmingly afraid to do anything that might be construed as not toeing the company line, as it was perceived as traitorous," he said.
Mr. Silverstein discounted the effect of employee turnover. "There is high turnover in the apparel industry generally," he said. "Warnaco's experience tracks this industry pattern." He added that all current division presidents had been with the company for years. For example, David Clark, president of the intimate apparel division, has been with the company for 22 years, and Susan Guensch, president of the Speedo unit, has worked for that business for 16 years.
Without the company's cooperation, it is impossible to say exactly what the turnover rate is at Warnaco. But in addition to those already cited, executives who have departed include Mr. Cannon, who left less than a month after Mrs. Wachner was said to have commented on his wife; he is now president for merchandising at Nautica Sportswear. The former head of the Calvin Klein underwear division, John Kourakos, left in 1996 and is now president for menswear at Tommy Hilfiger. And the president in charge of Chaps by Ralph Lauren, Mindy Grossman, left in 1994 and is now global vice president for apparel at Nike. James R. Mogan, who was recruited from Maidenform in 1997 to be president of intimate apparel at Warnaco, left last month.
"Linda is her own worst enemy," said another former employee, who said she has repeatedly been asked to return to the company. "No one who can get work elsewhere wants to put up with her."

In Pursuit of Sales Targets
Mrs. Wachner's legend in the rag trade has grown so large that it is sometimes hard to separate fact from fiction. One story that some employees swear by, but that Mrs. Wachner adamantly denies, is that she had a flashing light for her gold BMW and would use it to move quickly through congested Manhattan traffic. The story may well be apocryphal -- Warnaco said its drivers do not recall using flashing lights -- but like any good legend, it suggests a kernel of truth. It portrays a Linda Joy Wachner determined to get ahead at any cost.
Former employees, investors and clients for Warnaco goods concur in describing Mrs. Wachner as someone determined to make goals, no matter how she got there. Former employees describe a women obsessed with hitting financial targets like sales and earnings -- especially earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization costs are deducted. This rough measure of a company's operational earning power, known as Ebitda, is an important gauge of whether a company with big debts can repay loans. It also figured in calculations for Mrs. Wachner's bonus.
Of course, many modern chief executives have used tricks to keep revenue numbers up and to appease Wall Street. But Mrs. Wachner's critics say the short-term methods she used to meet analysts' forecasts -- like selling excess inventory at cut-rate prices -- now haunt her.
The main issue behind Calvin Klein's lawsuit, for example, was whether Warnaco had cheapened his brand by selling an unauthorized number of jeans to discount outlets like BJ's Wholesale Club and Sam's Club, a unit of Wal-Mart Stores. The suit was settled before the court could decide if Mrs. Wachner had exceeded her authority, but pretrial discovery left little doubt that Warnaco was selling huge quantities of Klein jeans to such outlets.
Former employees recall that in the last week of each quarter, Mrs. Wachner would round up her senior executives on the company plane and visit the headquarters of Costco, Sam's Club and BJ's consecutively until enough merchandise was sold to meet the revenue numbers the company had promised to Wall Street. "If we were not making the numbers, we were on the plane trying to dump merchandise," said one former employee from Warnaco's Klein division.
These employees said that in addition to eroding the brand integrity of her most important licensee, such discount sales were corroding the company's relationship with department stores, Warnaco's most important clients. "In order to make our numbers one quarter, she sold over one million units to Sam's Club," recalled another former employee, referring to pairs of jeans. "These were first-quality goods that were scheduled to go department stores.
"It left all the people who we had orders with, like Federated and May, high and dry and very angry," said the former employee, referring to the two big department store companies.
Warnaco also showed its insensitivity to exclusivity concerns from department stores in January 2000, when Mrs. Wachner decided to sell Calvin Klein underwear in J. C. Penney stores. That helped to bolster Warnaco's sales, but it infuriated upscale department stores that did not like being grouped with Penney.
At the time, Michael Gould, chief executive of Bloomingdale's, one of Federated Department Stores' chains, complained to Women's Wear Daily, the retail industry trade newspaper, that selling to Penney "dulls the luster of the brand."
Other Calvin Klein licensees affirmed that view in depositions taken for the Calvin Klein lawsuit against Warnaco. "We are not in as many doors, and our profit margins are now a lot weaker," testified Jordan Lipson, chief executive of American Essentials, which makes Calvin Klein brand socks. He said Neiman Marcus and Nordstrom had called him to express their displeasure.
Warnaco denied that its sales to the discount warehouse stores interfered with its commitments to department stores, and said that in the changing retail market, the company had to reach out to the new outlets. "These extremely successful retailers have changed the tapestry of retailing in the U.S.," Mr. Rubenstein, the spokesman, said. "And Warnaco would be remiss not to participate in this phenomenon."
Because most chains do not break down their sales by brand, it is impossible to say with certainty that Mrs. Wachner's actions cost Warnaco any department-store business. But financial results show that while she added sales from J. C. Penney and continued to feed the discount warehouses, Warnaco's revenue took a steep dive last year.
Excluding revenue from companies that it acquired in 1999, most significantly Authentic Fitness, Warnaco said its net revenue declined by $271.4 million, or 13.2 percent, from a year earlier. Sales of Calvin Klein goods shrank by $134.8 million.
In a conference call with stock analysts after filing the company's annual report, Mrs. Wachner blamed a soft retail environment and the loss of major retail customers like Uptons, a unit of the privately owned American Retail Group of Norcross, Ga.; Eatons, a Canadian chain acquired by Sears Canada Inc., a unit of Sears, Roebuck; and Mercantile, which was bought by Dillard's Inc. (Warnaco also blamed bankruptcies or consolidations at Uptons, Eatons and Mercantile for disappointing sales in 1999 in an amended annual report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.)
While the general retail environment did slow last year, comparative data indicates that Warnaco's troubles ran much deeper than the industry as a whole. Annual sales for intimate apparel in the United States were down in 2000, but only by 0.2 percent across the industry, according to NPD, a market research firm in Port Washington, N.Y.
At one Warnaco competitor, the Sara Lee Corporation, which makes the Wonderbra, sales for intimates and underwear rose 6.2 percent in the nine months ended March 31, 2001. Similarly, the VF Corporation reported that sales of its two main department-store lingerie brands, Vanity Fair and Lily of France, had grown by more than 10 percent each last year. "We think we are taking market share," Cindy Knoebel, a spokeswoman for VF, said.
In its annual report, Warnaco noted that its market share for bras at department and specialty stores, as measured by NPD, had slipped to 35.7 percent in 2000 from 39 percent in 1999. "Our consistent record of share growth dominance is not diminished by a modest decline in year-over-year share," Mr. Silverstein, the general counsel, said.
But if Mrs. Wachner's effort to make sales and earnings numbers meet ever-greater goals hurt the company, they had the opposite effect on her own bottom line.
In 1996, 1997 and 1998, for example, Warnaco's Ebitda fell short of the amount Mrs. Wachner needed to earn a $1.3 million bonus for meeting Ebitda targets. But in each of those years, Warnaco, like many other companies, recorded certain expenses as very large nonrecurring charges. Under the terms of Mrs. Wachner's compensation contract, in the calculation of her bonus, "extraordinary charges" may be excluded from earnings with the approval of the board's compensation committee, Warnaco says. That allowed Mrs. Wachner to take her full bonus in those years.
In 1998, for example, Warnaco's annual report to the S.E.C. said its "adjusted" Ebitda was $384 million, beating its $297.6 million target and earning Mrs. Wachner a $1.3 million bonus. If $197 million in special charges and $55 million in "general corporate expenses" had been stripped out, however, Ebitda would have missed the goal and Mrs. Wachner would not have received her bonus. (Earnings have been so poor since then that she did not get a bonus in 1999 or 2000.)
Investors and securities analysts who have criticized Mrs. Wachner's pay package are suspicious, because nonrecurring and extraordinary charges occurred in 8 of the last 10 years. They also pointed out that these nonrecurring charges included routine apparel-industry business costs like write-downs for excess inventory and costs associated with introducing a new brand or sprucing up an old one.
Warnaco said the charges were all made in accordance with accounting standards and were accepted by its auditors, then PriceWaterhouseCoopers. (In 1999, Warnaco changed auditors to Deloitte & Touche.)
"The actions were taken by the company to rationalize 14 acquisitions and 7 divestitures over the last six years without regard to bonus considerations," Mr. Silverstein said.
Outsiders remained critical of the sum Mrs. Wachner received. "How can anyone justify that pay?" asked Graef Crystal, a well-known executive-compensation expert who is critical of excess pay. Mr. Crystal estimated that since 1993, Mrs. Wachner took home at least $158.5 million in salary, bonus and stock gains from Warnaco and Authentic Fitness. "She treats that company like her personal wallet," he said.
The company said that more than half of that figure, about $87 million, came from stock options, and that the money was reinvested in Warnaco stock.

Friends in High Places
With Warnaco struggling for its life, large investors like Calpers are putting pressure on Warnaco's board to make Mrs. Wachner more accountable or to fire her.
The board includes outsiders like Walter F. Loeb, publisher of a retail industry newsletter bearing his name, and Donald G. Drapkin, a vice chairman of MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings, Ronald Perelman's investment company, as well as insiders like William S. Finkelstein, senior vice president and chief financial officer of Warnaco. But much attention is being directed at two newly appointed directors, Harvey Golub, former chairman of American Express, and Frank A. Olson, chairman of the Hertz Corporation, to see how they might shake up the company.
Joseph A. Califano Jr., a secretary of health, education and welfare under President Jimmy Carter and a Warnaco director since 1993, said in a statement supplied by Mr. Rubenstein that Mrs. Wachner had the "full support of the board of directors and will continue to commit her energy and her talents to leading the company through these challenging times."
Certainly, Mrs. Wachner is not to be counted out easily. In the past, she has used luxurious homes on the Upper East Side and in Southampton to woo powerful friends, like the billionaire Sid R. Bass, who have come to her defense. Over the last year or so, Mr. Bass's Prime 66 Partners bought large volumes of Warnaco stock on the open market, and owns almost 10 percent of the company.
Perhaps more important to Mrs. Wachner's future is her contract, which contains a very golden parachute. If the company fires her, it is obliged by the contract to pay her five times the highest annual salary and bonus that she has ever received; that would mean a parachute of about $44 million. That is more cash than the company has in its accounts, Mr. Crystal said.
In a newspaper interview last year, faced with the perennial question of why turnover was so high at her company, Ms. Wachner said Warnaco had "no room for nonperformance."
This week, through a spokesman, she dismissed the idea that the company's current problems might cause her to resign for nonperformance. "Absolutely not," the spokesman quoted her as saying.

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Civil War: All for One and None for You

BYLINE:  By NEAL GABLER; Neal Gabler is the author of "Life the Movie: How Entertainment Conquered Reality."

 BODY:
THROUGHOUT last year's presidential campaign, George W. Bush's recurring mantra was bipartisanship. Everywhere the Republican nominee went, he reminded voters of the cooperation he had forged between his Republican gubernatorial administration in Texas and the state's Democrats; and he promised it would be the same in a Bush White House. President Bush picked up the theme again for the flood of coverage marking his 100th day in office, telling one interviewer that he had already effected a "change in attitude" in Washington where, he said, it was no longer a zero-sum game between the parties.
 To his credit, Mr. Bush sensed that the American people were tired of all the political rancor. For more than 30 years, the country had been divided -- first between hawks and doves on Vietnam; then between President Richard M. Nixon's supporters and detractors on Watergate; then between Reaganites and unreconstructed liberals; and for the last eight years between the right wing that had overtaken the Republican Party and Bill Clinton, who said that his biggest puzzlement was the hatred the opposition directed toward him. 
 In the past, Americans had learned to live with political jousting and even appreciate it. After all, politicians always disagree; that is the essence of politics. What made the fractiousness of the last 30 years so disturbing was the depth and venomousness of the disagreement -- though it was part of an increased fractiousness throughout the culture, in everything from intensifying divisions among racial and ethnic groups to television programs like "Crossfire." Everywhere, Americans were yelling at one another. 
Hostility is still a growth industry, but Americans seem less tolerant of incivility after the Clinton impeachment raised it to new levels. Indeed, when he began his appeal to bipartisanship, Mr. Bush may have tapped into a "niceness" offensive that had gradually been creeping across the nation.
You can see it in the way the Motion Picture Academy has its Oscar presenters announce, "And the Oscar goes to . . . " rather than "And the winner is . . . " You can see it in the increasing emphasis in education on the theory of multiple intelligences, which rewards students who might not otherwise be rewarded by the traditional intellectual yardsticks. You can see it in youth sports leagues that regularly give every participant a trophy rather than celebrate winners. You even see it in the exaggerated cruelty of Anne Robinson, the hostess on "The Weakest Link," who serves to ridicule hostility while she exercises it. All these subtly testify to a reduction in the meanness that had been overtaking the country -- a desire to get along again.
In this kinder, gentler nation, Mr. Bush seemed ideally cast as Mr. Congeniality. Part of his appeal is that he, like his father, is a moderator if not exactly a moderate, someone who views politics as a kind of fraternity party where people are expected to get along. He not only campaigned on the notion that the American people want their representatives to put the public weal above petty partisan concerns, he displayed a personal manner, self-effacing and glad-handing, that seemed to prove the importance of personality over politics, of cooperation over strident ideology.
So how does this square with the marked partisanship of his first 100 days, where he left most Democrats out of the budget process, rebuked American allies on the Kyoto treaty and sought to undo many of President Clinton's environmental initiatives? It squares because President Bush's idea of bipartisanship is something far different from, say, the Republican Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg's support of Harry S. Truman's policy of communist containment or the Republican Senate Minority Leader Everett Dirkson's support of Lyndon B. Johnson's Medicare bill. 
This isn't proposed as a means to an end -- say, creating a consensus on policy -- as bipartisanship historically has been. For President Bush, presiding over an America that seems to just want nice, bipartisanship is posited as an end in itself. In effect, this new bipartisanship purports to create a consensus on the importance of creating a consensus, and it is predicated on the notion that the American people are so desirous of a less toxic political tone that they really don't care what the consensus is about.
Seen this way, bipartisanship is less a policy than an aesthetic -- a glow of good cheer to satisfy the desire for comity. But because it is an aesthetic, it doesn't require reconciliation. In its name you can just as easily use the opposition's refusal to surrender to your program as evidence of their refusal to engage in bipartisanship -- the charge Senator William R. Bennett, Republican of Utah, leveled at Democrats in the budget debate. They opposed Mr. Bush's full $1.6 trillion tax cut, he said, only because they wanted to embarrass him. As Mr. Bush's supporters seemed to see it, the Democrats who opposed him should be voted out at the next tribal council for not sacrificing themselves to the common good.
IF this sounds familiar, it should. This sort of bipartisan aesthetic draped over blatant partisanship is the basis of the highly rated television programs "Survivor" and "The Weakest Link." Key to their popularity is that they satisfy both the new niceness and the old competitiveness -- providing the vicarious warmth of community and the vicarious charge of aggression. The subtext of both shows is that while one must ostensibly work for the common good, one does so only to the point where the common good serves one's needs. After that, it is every man for himself.
In a way, President Bush, by managing to be both genial and single-minded, is the first "Survivor" president. He has adapted the "Survivor" techniques to the political arena, talking endlessly about the "new tone" in Washington while advancing his own interests, and he has received generally high marks for doing so. But there is a contradiction here -- as on "Survivor" itself. A unilateral bipartisanship of capitulation is like President Bush's compassionate conservatism or his economic environmentalism. It doesn't gibe. Mr. Bush may not be the "moronic president" that his critics assert, but he is the "oxymoronic president" -- whose partisan actions seem often to belie his benign bipartisan words. 
Even so, the president may have read the public mood correctly in knowing that a smile and handshake are far more important to the American people than political infighting at a time when the entire culture has been riven with conflict. If so, he may be painting the Democrats into the same corner the Republicans painted themselves into when they shut down the government rather than bargain with President Clinton. He can always blame them for not getting along. 
On the other hand, there is the chance people may see through the bipartisan aesthetic no matter how enticing the image of political brotherhood; what works on "Survivor" may be unstable in the political arena. Indeed, the one desire of the public powerful enough to trump the aesthetics of comity may be the desire for something genuine within the never-ending spin. Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, has built a bipartisan following not just by talking about bipartisanship but by crossing political divides and defying ideological boilerplate. Without that, a bipartisan aesthetic is just politics as usual with a happy face.
Everyone says they want niceness now, but during these first hundred days, the public is still the Kucha and Ogakor tribes on Survivor, and the president is still angling for the prize, flashing a smile while waiting to bare his teeth.

HEADLINE: Tony Blair's Big Idea 

BYLINE:  By Bruce Ackerman and Anne Alstott; Bruce Ackerman and Anne Alstott, law professors at Yale, are authors of "The Stakeholder Society."

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN 

 BODY:
Tony Blair's re-election campaign opens a trans-Atlantic dialogue on the future of equal opportunity. While President Bush pushes for an enormous tax cut, Mr. Blair, the British prime minister, proposes giving the next generation a start toward economic security and independence. 
 Mr. Blair's big idea is to guarantee each child a financial stake. Every infant born in Britain would receive a baby bond worth between $450 and $750, which would mature when he or she reached 18. The Treasury would make additional deposits of $75 to $150 when the child was 5, 11 and 16. Thanks to compound interest, young adults would start life with as much as $7,500, which could be used for a variety of purposes -- from college tuition to buying a home, from starting a business to a rainy-day fund. 
 Mr. Blair's proposal puts real substance into idle talk about a third way between socialism and capitalism, and stands in sharp contrast to President Bush's plan for a large tax cut. Mr. Blair's proposal affirms the values of private property, personal responsibility and economic freedom while also giving all young adults, not just the lucky few with rich parents, a chance to take charge of their lives.
President Bush's commitment to leave no child behind is fine, but not enough to equip adults for freedom -- especially those Americans who don't go to college. University students get enormous subsidies, but they are not in the majority. The rest of America needs cash in the bank to withstand economic shocks and gain economic self-confidence.
The stakeholding idea has a rich history. In 1797, Tom Paine argued that all new democratic republics should guarantee each 21-year-old citizen a grant equivalent to 15 pounds. Over the last decade, academics and politicians have looked again at stakeholding. Moderate Democrats have proposed government-funded children's savings accounts. And this year, the Bush administration even included a small amount in its budget for individual development accounts, which help the poor build assets. But Tony Blair is the first major world leader to put stakeholding where it belongs -- at the top of the list of political priorities.
What if Mr. Bush had approached his budget in the same spirit as Mr. Blair? Suppose the president had dedicated $1.35 trillion over 10 years, not to a tax cut, but to a baby-bond plan. That sum would finance an annual bond program of $135 billion, giving each of the four million babies born in America each year a bond of almost $34,000. With interest, these bonds would (conservatively) yield $50,000 when they matured.
The Blair government is considering whether to restrict the money's use to ensure responsible spending. We suggest that an American program should instead give full control only to high-school graduates.
We believe that a nation committed to equal opportunity can make a sizeable commitment to its young citizens. But if these numbers seem outsize, consider what even a portion of the tax-cut dollars could mean for an American-style baby bond. With these bonds, the adults of the next generation would start off with a stake in America and take their rightful place as members of a property-holding democracy.

 INTERNATIONAL 3-24

Continuing His Pilgrimage, Pope Arrives in Syria
Pope John Paul II became the first pope to visit Syria, where he sought to improve relations between religious faiths. He was greeted by President Bashar al-Assad, who then gave a speech accusing Israelis of torturing and murdering Palestinians and suggested that Christians and Muslims make common cause against those "who try to kill the principles of all religions with the same mentality with which they betrayed Jesus Christ." 4

Strict Call for Mideast Peace
An international committee investigating the continuing violence in the Middle East has issued an unexpectedly strong call for an Israeli freeze on settlements and a Palestinian crackdown on terrorism as a prelude to the resumption of peace talks. 4

Russia Debates World Bank Aid
The Russian government is debating whether to turn down a $150 million loan from the World Bank to contain a serious tuberculosis epidemic. Opponents charge that the loan is part of a ploy by Western drug companies to seize the Russian market from home-based drug companies. 18

U.S. Faulted in Tobacco Talks
Negotiations in Geneva for a global pact to curb tobacco use stumbled, with major countries backing away from tougher provisions and health campaigners charging that the Bush administration was trying to water down the treaty. 17

Praise for Missile Defense Plan
India effusively praised elements of President Bush's missile defense plan and said nary a critical word, bringing howls of protest from the opposition party. 24

Scientists See Big Savings From Energy Conservation
Scientists at national laboratories have projected enormous energy savings if the government takes aggressive steps to encourage conservation in homes, factories, offices, appliances, cars and power plants. Their studies, completed just before President Bush took office, are at odds with the administration's assertions that the nation needs to build a new power plant every week for the next 20 years to keep up with the demand for electricity. 1

The C.I.A. is now working with film makers, television producers and writers, in an effort to get out what it calls the truth about the agency. 1

Sugar Program Faulted
Both refiners and consumer groups are criticizing the government's sugar program, which has led to high prices and overproduction. 1

Executions Expected to Rise
Federal executions, while infrequent, are expected to increase because the law has been broadened in recent years to include more crimes. 26

New President for Princeton

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Texan Finds That Pay Phones Can Pay Off

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
Wireless phones do not frighten Charlie Sullivan. He has one himself and talks on it all day long while he drives around Texas seeking new places to put pay phones. He has 1,375 of those.
 Lots of people say wireless phones ought to scare Mr. Sullivan, president of ComChoice, a privately owned pay phone company based in Canyon Lake, in central Texas, about midway between San Antonio and Austin. But Mr. Sullivan intends to belie the widespread notion that cell phones are pushing pay phones off the American landscape. 
 The common wisdom has been spread by some of the largest pay phone companies, including Verizon, which tell their shareholders that wireless growth has undercut their pay phone operations. Wall Street analysts use the same reasoning to underscore the inexorable strength of wireless stocks. Even a trade group representing 1,450 independent pay phone companies like ComChoice perpetuates the idea, in pleading for government regulations more favorable to its members. Charitable organizations also raise the alarm, warning that homeless people will soon have no place to make phone calls. 
In defiance of the myth of the vanishing pay phone, Mr. Sullivan is competing with the large phone companies by putting his telephones in places where other telephones, including wireless ones, are scarce and where people tend to make calls using coins instead of credit cards -- something that lets his company collect more of the money directly. 
His favorite locations include low-income neighborhoods like the south side of San Antonio near South New Braunfels Avenue, and buildings maintained by the Del Rio public housing authority. He has secured various spots throughout the border city of Laredo. He also likes highway convenience stores and truck stops, where he can snag the mobile who may have no mobile phones. 
Operating 900 to 1,000 pay phones last year, ComChoice had revenue of just over $1.2 million, with an operating profit of $139,000, according to Mr. Sullivan.
"This whole idea that cell phone technology has killed the pay phone business is really not the case," Mr. Sullivan said. 
Industry data would seem to support his point. Since passage of the Telecommunications Act of 1996, which ordered the Federal Communications Commission to encourage competition in the pay phone industry and ensure that phones are available in low-income areas, the number of wireless subscribers has grown by 189 percent, to more than 110 million, according to the Cellular Telecommunications and Internet Association, a trade group. And yet, since 1997, the total number of pay phones has held steady around 2.1 million, according to the National Payphone Clearinghouse, which coordinates payments from long-distance companies. 
BellSouth cited wireless phones as a factor when it said in February that it would abandon the pay phone business whether or not the company could find a buyer for the 143,000 phones it owns in nine Southeastern states. Indicating that use of pay phones had fallen sharply, BellSouth said it would leave the pay phone business by the end of 2002 and focus on broadband communications, wireless telephones and interactive pagers. BellSouth has recently combined its wireless business with that of another regional Bell, SBC Communications, to create a new wireless company, Cingular. 
SBC, which has a 60 percent stake in Cingular, is also the owner of Southwestern Bell, the local telephone monopoly in Texas, Oklahoma and three other contiguous states. And even if BellSouth is no longer interested in the pay phone business, Southwestern Bell has shown every sign of staying in the game. In fact, gas station by gas station, street corner by street corner, Southwestern Bell is competing with Charlie Sullivan.
"Southwestern Bell considers the pay phone business to be very competitive," said Joe Izbrand, a spokesman for SBC. "We continue to view it as a viable part of our business."
Mr. Sullivan's competition with Southwestern Bell has been fierce, not only in the market but in court. Twice he has been party to class-action lawsuits against Southwestern Bell, accusing it of using predatory practices and subterfuge to maintain its hold on the pay phone business in Oklahoma and Texas.
Mr. Sullivan's involvement in the business began in 1991, when he founded Payphone Providers Inc. in Texas, seven years after many state public utility commissions took part in the breakup of the Bell system by allowing private ownership of pay phones. 
From a mere four phones initially, his business gradually grew. And for years the main antagonists of him and other pay phone operators were the long-distance companies, whose 1-800 and calling-card calls the pay phone providers are required by law to carry -- even though payment typically awaited an often complicated and protracted process with the various carriers that might be involved in any one call. In the third quarter of last year, Mr. Sullivan said, he received $78,000 in compensation for such calls but was unable to collect an additional $117,000 he said he was owed.
Pay phone owners won a significant victory earlier this year, however, when the F.C.C. ruled that the first long-distance carrier that picks up any call not involving coins -- usually a well-known outfit like Qwest or AT&T -- is the company automatically responsible for compensating the pay phone operator. 
"Now that we can track it back to one carrier, that's going to change the economics of this business big time," Mr. Sullivan said.
By 1995, Mr. Sullivan's business owned 350 phones. From each, he grossed an average of $120 a month from coin calls and $75 from operator-assisted calls. But his partners were squabbling, so Payphone Providers sold out to another independent pay phone company in Texas.
The next year, the Telecommunications Act elicited a frenzy of activity from pay phone operators. The law barred the Bell companies from discriminating in favor of their own pay phone services and from subsidizing their pay phone operations through revenue from local telephone customers. 
With 10 partners, Mr. Sullivan formed Coin Link L.L.C. and joined a land rush to the north, where the Oklahoma Corporation Commission had become one of the last state utility commissions to allow pay phone competition. Coin Link set up some 700 phones at a cost of about $1,500 apiece. But Southwestern Bell's longstanding monopoly was a force to reckon with. 
"They literally had a pay phone everywhere a pay phone could possibly be needed, paid for by the rate payers," Mr. Sullivan said. After losing about $200,000 a year, Coin Link sold its phones to various other independent operators for $2,000 to $3,000 each in 1998. By that time, Mr. Sullivan had already turned his attention back to Texas, starting ComChoice in 1997 and buying 535 phones from a company in Houston.
But Coin Link had not completely given up on Oklahoma. There, it and eight other companies had sued Southwestern Bell, accusing it of violating state and federal antitrust laws by saturating the market and using restrictive long-term contracts and other measures to deter competition.
In its defense, Southwestern Bell argued that it was easy to enter the pay phone market in Oklahoma, that more than 50 competitors had done so and in fact were winning away some of the most profitable locations. But last May, the jury in the case ordered Southwestern Bell to pay more than $7.4 million, an amount later trebled by the state. Southwestern Bell has filed to appeal the decision. 
In Texas, meanwhile, a group of plaintiffs including Mr. Sullivan has made similar antitrust accusations against Southwestern Bell. In a state court in Johnson County, near Dallas, the plaintiffs contend that Southwestern Bell used unfair tactics to secure long-term pay phone contracts with property owners and destroyed the concrete pads left behind when property owners tried to switch pay phone companies.
"We strongly deny the allegations and intend to vigorously defend our position," said Mr. Izbrand, the SBC spokesman. Southwestern Bell recently made its formal denial in a court filing.
As the lawsuits progress, Mr. Sullivan keeps looking for profitable places to put pay phones. 
These days, in a good month, his phones gross $161 apiece on average: $107 in change, $22 from the operator-assisted calls and $32 from the various other coinless calls. Convenience stores with gas pumps in poor neighborhoods do well. And Mr. Sullivan just recently won the bidding in Austin for a prime spot on Cesar Chavez Street, which a lot of folks still call East First Street.
"Everybody keeps going back to this thing that all of our business is being lost to cell phones," Mr. Sullivan said. "That's simply not true. But it's pushing everybody to fight for these good locations."

HEADLINE: Stay-at-Home Instinct Fosters Flush Times At 'Shelter' Magazines 

BYLINE:  By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
Before Marian McEvoy arrived with her trademark stiletto heels and red lipstick to take over as editor in chief of House Beautiful, the interior design magazine, the featured cover lines were often the likes of "Classics With a Twist." Photo spreads eschewed people in favor of table legs and draperies, and articles in the 105-year-old magazine focused on practical decorating matters. 
 As of February, Ms. McEvoy's House Beautiful began to feature headlines like "Exotic Romance" and articles about apartments for "budding rock stars." Actual human beings -- even celebrities -- scampered through the photo spreads with naked infants and posed barefoot on the cover. Paint hues were described with phrases like "the color equivalents of deep, long kisses." 
 "The category has loosened up a lot," Ms. McEvoy, the former editor of Elle Decor, said in her Hearst Magazines office. "It's cool to decorate. Retail stores like Crate and Barrel and Ikea have opened middle America's imagination." 
Ms. McEvoy pursed her lips, as glossed and red as an antique Ming Dynasty lacquer cabinet, and confided an important point. 
"Look, even guys don't think it's sissy any more to think about what kind of sheets they sleep on," she said.
The magazine world, hard hit by the economic downturn, is worried about disappearing advertising, but magazines about interior decorating -- known in the magazine industry as shelter magazines -- are thriving, a testament to their skill at evoking fantasy and enticing advertisers.
And whether you think the magazines are sissy or not, their field is among the most swiftly changing in the magazine industry and is bitterly -- even nastily -- competitive. Over the last 10 months, a domino effect has toppled editors at all of the major shelter magazines. Others are scrambling for their jobs, have resigned and taken coveted projects and staff members with them or remain locked in Oedipal struggles with former mentors.
All of this dynamism comes at a time when there are more shelter magazines than ever before, from Architectural Digest, with its celebrity fantasies, to small-circulation magazines as eclectic as Nest, which has featured articles about how prison inmates decorate their cells and how some sexual fetishists dress in diapers and decorate their homes with adult-size cribs and strollers. 
Architectural Digest, at 81 years old, is considered by most of the industry to be at the top of the heap. Because it has a relatively small staff and generates as much advertising as Vanity Fair, it is one of the most profitable magazines at Advance Publications' Conde Nast. House & Garden, apart from a two-year hiatus, is 100 this year, and combines high- and low-brow sensibilities -- the Baccarat and Crate and Barrel aesthetic, according to its editor. House Beautiful, 105, has long been considered the middle-brow read for middle America, but Ms. McEvoy -- is bringing it to a much more sophisticated level. And Homestyle -- a magazine hemorrhaging money from its parent company, Gruner & Jahr -- has also hired a new editor from House & Garden to make it less about chicken recipes and more about Chippendale, less franks-and-beans and more Frank Lloyd Wright. 
"There are so many shelter magazines now, and they're all struggling to get their piece of the American audience," said Jeffrey Bilhuber, an interior decorator whose clients include Peter Jennings and David Bowie. "I call it bohemians at the gate." 
One reason there are so many magazines is that those interior design-obsessed bohemians buy a lot, no matter what the economy is up to. The advertisers that appears in most shelter magazines -- food, furniture, pharmaceuticals -- are part of categories that do not go away during a depressed market, so they are generally considered recession-proof by publishers. For example, home furnishings advertisers have spent $236 million advertising in magazines this year, according to the Publishers Information Bureau, an increase of 11.4 percent.
"What do you do when you don't have money?" Ms. McEvoy said. "You stay home. You look at the dining room chairs. You notice they're dingy. You think about paint." 
Valerie Muller, senior vice president and director for print services at MediaCom in New York, the media agency owned by the Grey Global Group, said Americans are thinking more about their homes than in previous decades.
"It's that whole feng shui, simplify your life, beautify your home thing," Ms. Muller said. "Advertisers love that environment." 
And advertising pages and revenue at most of the shelter magazines are up. At a time when ad pages for the magazine industry over all are down 6.9 percent for the year to date, according to the Publishers Information Bureau, Architectural Digest's pages are up 12 percent; Elle Decor's, 8 percent; House & Garden's, 6 percent; and Homestyle's, 7 percent. Last November, The New York Times Magazine introduced a special Style & Entertaining magazine, published twice a year, to capture the overflow of advertising in the special Home Design issues, also published twice a year.
The continued success of the shelter magazines may have something to do with the fact that like fashion magazines they are mostly about fantasy. Even in a magazine that purports to offer practical decorating solutions, like Hearst's House Beautiful, there are lavish photo spreads of impossibly tidy and luxurious rooms the likes of which most Americans will never set foot in, let alone be able to afford to decorate. The half-acre of Brunschwig & Fils fabric decorating the bedroom of Gayfryd and Saul Steinberg's Long Island bedroom -- featured in House Beautiful -- cost at least as much as most Americans make in a year.
David Brooks, the author of "Bobos in Paradise: The New Upper Class and How They Got There" (Simon & Schuster, 2000), said the shelter magazines are about the American yearning for utopia. 
"They are about the desire to build a perfect world," he said. "They are totally unrelated to the lives anybody leads. No one is that neat. And no one has that much carefully arranged bric-a-brac."
Of course, whose version of utopia is better is the subject of much speculation among decorators and editors. Some interior decorators and architects complain that the magazines are all, in the uniform quest for high-end sophistication, becoming indistinguishable from one another -- with the exception of Architectural Digest. 
Lee F. Mindel, of the design firm Shelton, Mindel & Associates, said: "There are so many of them now, they cancel each other out. They are so superficial that most of them have just become about fashion. It's a hemline mentality. Pink is back. Beige is the new black. Traditional is back. More is more. Less is more. Less is less. So then you get a pack mentality. It's boring." 
One reason the magazines may resemble one another is that there is such a small and slightly inbred pool of editors qualified to run them. So when Ms. McEvoy left Elle Decor, her longtime deputy, Margaret Russell, took over. When Homestyle needed a new editor, it took Dominique Browning's longtime deputy at House & Garden, Suzanne Slesin. Ms. Slesin's remade magazine is supposed to go head to head with House Beautiful and her former employer, House & Garden. 
Mr. Bilhuber, the decorator, described it as "a merry-go-round of editrixes." 
In the last five years, magazine companies have started a host of new, smaller shelter magazines, making the competition for ad dollars more intense than ever before. Readers suspicious of cozy arrangements have long questioned whether the relationship between the editorial content of the magazines is too closely linked to advertisers' desires.
"No one will come out and say it," said Martin S. Walker, a consultant to the magazine industry. "But it has been happening since time immemorial." 
Two years ago, This Old House -- published by Time Inc. -- included in several issues an editorial insert poster that read at the bottom, "This poster is brought to you by Ace Hardware, the source for all your hardware needs." The magazine was stripped of a nomination for a National Magazine Award because of the use of an advertisers' logo on an editorial page. At the time, the president of the magazine explained that because Ace was a major sponsor of the magazine's companion television show, he felt that it deserved special treatment.
For almost two decades, Architectural Digest has had a policy of mentioning only advertisers in the magazine's captions, said Robert Pini, a spokesman for the magazine.
And at Elle Decor, Ms. Russell said she fends advertisers off daily. "You have to be very careful," she said. "Advertisers ask me for editorial coverage all the time. I get dozens of e-mails every day." Ms. Russell said that she always reminds advertisers that legitimate magazines do not have to resort to anything that looks like editorial payola. 
There have been instances of ethical tinkering at other magazines. In 1997, Home magazine, published by the Lagardere unit Hachette Filipacchi, featured a three-page editorial spread about painting a cottage in New Orleans and mentioned Benjamin Moore paints a dozen times. Benjamin Moore, an advertiser, had provided both the paint and the photographs on the spread for the magazine. The Wall Street Journal reported the incident, and the editor, Gail Steves, acknowledged that it was a joint project and said, "It's as much their story as it is ours." 
Ms. Browning at House & Garden said editorial and advertising remain separate at her magazines but explained what often seems like overly nice treatment to advertisers. "There's not really a hard-hitting investigative way to look at interior design," she said. "Would we write about decorators who overcharge? Maybe. Would we write a story about why a teacup costs $150? Sure." 
Ms. Browning also added that readers of shelter magazines tend to read the advertisements as avidly as they do the editorial matter, so their expectations of dirt-digging are fairly low. 
Mr. Brooks said that no matter how fantastical they may be, there will always be a market for the shelter books.
"One of my rules is that shallow people are greedy for money, and that profound people are greedy for real estate," Mr. Brooks said. He said that he had spoken to builders who reported that clients arrive at their architecture office with large boxes of pages ripped from the shelter magazines over the years. 
"Affluent people invest years in renovating their homes," he said. "They don't go to war. They renovate. It is the major psychological trauma of their lives, and they need guidance. There will always be a market for that kind of therapy."

HEADLINE: Contract Talks With Actors Move to Front 

BYLINE:  By RICK LYMAN 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 6 

 BODY:
When William Daniels was running for president of the Screen Actors Guild in 1999, he liked to do his interviews at Art's Delicatessen in Studio City, "where every sandwich is a work of Art," surrounded by some of the insurgents who helped him unseat the previous union leadership.
 Although always earnest and intense, Mr. Daniels grew most voluble when the subject turned to longtime actors who were paid basic scale for guest appearances on television programs or supporting roles in films. 
 What was happening, Mr. Daniels said, was that as many Hollywood studios and networks became corporate cogs in huge media conglomerates and pressure to cut costs intensified, producers were spending through the roof to get top-name lead actors while nickel-and-diming everyone else, including the supporting performers. 
"It's a real shame, an outrage," Mr. Daniels said at the time. "And I hope we're able to do something about it."
Now is his chance.
When the Writers Guild of America settled late last week on a tentative three-year contract with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers, a coalition representing the major studios and networks, attention shifted to the coming talks on a new contract covering the 135,000 actors represented by the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists.
Gone is the threat of dual strikes this summer by writers and actors -- assuming that, as expected, the 11,000 members of the writers' union vote to approve the tentative pact -- but still hanging out there is a potential strike by actors that could shut down film production as well as the making of such scripted television programs as sit-coms, hourlong dramas and made-for-television movies.
The actors' contract with the production companies expires at midnight on June 30, and talks have yet to begin. 
Union officials said they had wanted to give the writers' union time to settle its talks, and it was only a couple of weeks ago that the leaders of the huge and fractious actors' union agreed on their goals in this year's talks, which are expected to begin in the next 10 days.
The consensus over the weekend was that the settlement by the writers' union -- which had seemed more militant and outspoken than the actors going into this year's round of talks -- helped make it much less likely that there would be any Hollywood strike this summer. 
One official with another Hollywood union said that with the settlement by writers, "the odds of there being an actors' strike now have fallen to under 20 percent."
Neil Begley, an analyst for Moody's Investors Service, argued that unlike the writers' union, which had not been on strike since 1988, the Screen Actors Guild was coming off a bruising five-month strike last year for a contract covering work in commercials and might be less eager to hit the streets again. 
At the same time, Mr. Daniels and other union leaders have gone out of their way to quiet talk of a strike and to stress their belief that an agreement is possible. And with the settlement by writers in place, many of its provisions could be used in cobbling together a contract for actors.
News of the settlement by writers was greeted with something close to ecstasy throughout Hollywood, which had been almost frantic over the prospect of dual strikes this summer. Indeed, the entire country seemed to respond to the upbeat mood. The first of the big summer popcorn movies, "The Mummy Returns," opened on Friday, the same day the writers settled, and estimates today had it earning $70.1 million this weekend, the largest three-day opening ever for a movie on a nonholiday weekend, beating the $64.9 million earned in 1998 by "Star Wars: Episode 1 -- The Phantom Menace."
The economic portion of the tentative pact -- the only part that would have any correlation to an agreement for actors -- included a 3.5 percent increase in basic minimums plus a roster of improvements in a variety of formulas used to calculate payments for the use of film and television programs after their initial release, or residuals. Most significant seemed to be the removal of a cap on residuals for the sale of programs in foreign markets, which was expected to increase residuals for writers by $1.3 million over the life of the contract.
Mr. Daniels and other officials for the actors' union -- including Brian Walton, the chief negotiator, who had held a similar position for the writers until he was ousted two years ago -- declined to be interviewed in advance of the opening of their negotiations. Instead, they issued a statement congratulating the writers' union for its "careful effort to come to a new agreement without a work stoppage." 
Still, there may have been a hint of irritation in the statement at the frequently cited implication that the settlement by writers on matters like residual payments could simply be transplanted to a contract for actors. 
Mr. Daniels and other SAG officials said they would be spending the next several days studying the writers' deal "to see if it will be helpful in finding a way to address the specific needs of actors in our upcoming negotiations."
In other words, while there may be some crossover, the concerns of actors do not entirely match those of writers.
"Everybody is telling us that the writers' agreement is template for us, but we're trying to back away from that somewhat," said Greg Krizman, the chief spokesman for the actors.
Some feel there is also a danger in letting the euphoria over a settlement by writers distract from the potential danger of a walkout by actors. While it would have taken several months of a strike by writers before the impact would have been felt in the entertainment industry, a walkout by actors has the potential of shutting down business from Day 1.
And it is worth remembering, many caution, that the SAG leadership came to power by promising to take a tougher line with the production companies, much like the leaders of the writers' guild. Mr. Daniels and the union leaders may feel the need to address issues like diminishing pay for journeymen performers.
Also, the actors' union is a notoriously recalcitrant and fractious group. The bitter election two years ago that allowed Mr. Daniels and his supporters to oust the previous regime, headed by the actor Richard Masur, is still sending waves through the union. For example, it took the union much longer than many anticipated to hire Mr. Walton as its chief negotiator and to assemble its list of demands.
Still, on the positive side, the actors' union has by all reports assembled a roster of demands that is shorter and more focused than in previous talks, when negotiations sometimes bogged down on discussions of relatively minor work rules.
"The key question, if there is an actors' strike, which doesn't seem likely, is whether the union will decide to throw up picket lines," said Jack Kyser, chief economist for the Los Angeles County Development Corporation. "If they do strike and they do throw up picket lines and try to disrupt activity, the end result would be the same sort of shutdown that everyone has been fearing."

HEADLINE: Nuclear Power's New Day 

BYLINE:  By Richard Rhodes; Richard Rhodes is the author of "Nuclear Renewal" and "The Making of the Atomic Bomb."

DATELINE: MADISON, Conn. 

 BODY:
Technologies are born, grow, thrive and decline, much as living organisms do. That should not be surprising. Since they derive from human knowledge, their effective application must be learned, and they compete for social and economic territory.
 Nuclear power, a product of naval propulsion research, emerged in the United States in the 1950's. Its first use as a commercial energy source came about because it had obvious benefits for pollution control. A Pennsylvania utility, Duquesne Light, built the first commercial nuclear power reactor at Shippingport, Pa., in 1954. The utility had planned to build a coal-fired power plant. When the public objected to further smoke pollution around smoky Pittsburgh, Duquesne switched to nuclear power. 
 Public acceptance of a new technology is essential to its growth. Nuclear power, associated in the public's mind with nuclear weapons, was probably commercialized prematurely, while its complexities were still being worked out. Its environmental benefits were not fully appreciated in the early decades because air pollution was abating under government regulation in the 1960's and 1970's, and global warming had not yet emerged as the ultimate environmental challenge. When conservation slowed electricity demand after the Arab oil embargo of 1973 and 1974, utilities canceled orders for new power plants, both nuclear and coal. Almost all new plants built since then have been fueled with natural gas. 
But the population of the United States is growing, adding the equivalent of one California every 10 years. Demand has caught up with supply even with significant improvements in energy efficiency and conservation, and the United States has become the world's leading greenhouse gas emitter. These factors make a renewal of nuclear power likely.
The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has begun carefully extending licenses for existing reactors for an additional 20 years; eventually all 104 operating United States power reactors will probably be relicensed. Since they produce no air pollution or greenhouse gases, that's good news. The nuclear industry is consolidating, focusing experience and expertise. Several reactors that have been shut down will probably be restored to operation. Several others that were left unfinished when demand slowed will probably be completed. Two or three new advanced light-water reactors, designs the N.R.C. has already pre-licensed, will probably be built at sites that already have construction permits. One company, Exelon, is considering seeking licensing of a simpler reactor, designed so that it cannot melt down, that uses a bed of billiard-ball-sized "pebbles" of compacted uranium oxide and graphite as its fuel and helium as its coolant and working fluid, passing the fission-heated helium directly into a turbine to generate electricity even more cheaply than burning natural gas. If the pebble-bed modular reactor wins approval from the N.R.C., other utilities may decide to use this technology as well.
Americans are beginning to understand one of the unique benefits of nuclear technology. A majority now say they approve of nuclear power, a shift that appears to indicate awareness that nuclear power does not produce greenhouse gases that lead to global warming. There is less evidence of public understanding of radiation and nuclear waste. Antinuclear activism began in the 1960's with concerns about the disposal of nuclear waste, and disposal continues to be the nuclear industry's Number 1 public-relations problem.
The disposal debate is likely to move to center stage later this year, when the scientists and engineers evaluating Yucca Mountain, north of Las Vegas, as a possible permanent waste repository expect to deliver their final report.
All energy technologies produce waste. Burning fossil fuels -- even relatively clean fuel like natural gas -- generates waste that cannot be contained within the power plant, as nuclear waste is, but must be released into the environment as air pollution and toxic waste. In the case of coal, burning releases ash that is mildly radioactive, because radioactive uranium and thorium are ubiquitous in the earth's crust, including coal seams. Even renewable technologies like wind power and solar photovoltaics produce waste: manufacturing the materials for the multitude of collectors necessary to gather up such diffuse sources as wind and sunlight requires burning fossil fuels. Thus wind or solar power systems release far more greenhouse gases across their life cycles than does a nuclear system of equivalent output.
The great advantage of nuclear power is its ability to wrest enormous energy from a small volume of fuel. One metric ton of nuclear fuel produces energy equivalent to two million to three million tons of fossil fuel. Waste volumes are comparably scaled: fossil fuel systems generate hundreds of thousands of metric tons of gaseous, particulate and solid wastes, but nuclear systems produce less than 1,000 metric tons of high- and low-level waste per plant per year. The high-level waste is intensely radioactive at first, but its small volume means it can be and is effectively isolated and contained. When a nuclear plant is dismantled (few have been so far), the several hundred thousand tons of concrete, which is mildly radioactive, is buried in the same sort of commercial waste site used for radioactive medical and industrial wastes.
Spent nuclear fuel loses radioactivity steadily; after 500 years it is no more radioactive than high-grade uranium ore. The risk of radioactive waste's seeping past multiple barriers would be small compared to health risks posed by air pollution from burning fossil fuels, which the World Health Organization estimates causes three million deaths a year, with 15,000 deaths annually in the United States from coal particulates alone. Substituting small, sequestered volumes of nuclear waste for vast, dispersed volumes of toxic wastes from fossil fuels could provide an enormous improvement in public health.
The other risk that nuclear power supposedly raises is nuclear proliferation. In fact, no nation has developed nuclear weapons using plutonium from spent power reactor fuel. It's much easier to make weapons from plutonium bred specifically for that purpose. Inspection and proper accounting and control of nuclear materials are the answer to proliferation, not limits to nuclear power.
France once burned coal; that nation's electricity is now 80 percent nuclear, with five times less air pollution and with carbon dioxide emissions 10 times lower than Germany's and 13 times lower than Denmark's. At a conference recently in Japan (another nuclear leader, with 36 percent nuclear electricity), French nuclear industry executive Anne Lanvergeon proposed improving the debate about nuclear power by creating an authoritative world database that would assess the advantages and disadvantages of each type of energy in terms of use of resources and economic, environmental and health impact. Measured against other energy sources, nuclear power would emerge at the top of such a list.
Energy needs in the United States will grow in the coming decades, even with improved efficiency and more strenuous conservation. Nuclear energy needs to be a major component of our energy supply if we hope both to reduce air pollution and limit global warming.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
