HEADLINE: Dragon Systems Sputters After Belgian Suitor Fails 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER 8. LEE 

DATELINE: WEST NEWTON, Mass. 

 BODY:
The courtship began in the unlikely setting of the Grand Hungaria hotel in Budapest in September 1999, where a speech recognition conference was under way. Over dinner, Jo Lernout and Pol Hauspie, founders of the highflying speech recognition software company that bears their names, tried to persuade Janet Baker, who with her husband, James, had founded and nurtured Dragon Systems over 18 years, to combine their resources into one company.
 It was a highly reasoned proposition. The acquisition would combine some of the world's most advanced speech technologies under one company. In a field where Microsoft and I.B.M. were players, Lernout & Hauspie and Dragon would be better off working together than competing against each other. 
 Lernout & Hauspie had approached the Bakers several times over the years about acquiring Dragon, a small but highly respected technology company that had recent success. But this time the circumstances were different: in the preceding two years, Dragon had been through two failed attempts at taking the company public, and its board was strongly considering selling it to a larger company. 
Lernout & Hauspie was not, in fact, Dragon's suitor of choice. Visteon, a Ford Motor Company spinoff with $18 billion in annual revenue, seemed more attractive. But Visteon left Dragon at the corporate altar in February 2000; Visteon would later argue in court papers that it did so at the urging of Lernout & Hauspie. Mrs. Baker then picked up the phone and called Lernout & Hauspie to resume their talks. Within weeks, the deal was done; Dragon was wed to Lernout & Hauspie last June for stock then valued at about $600 million.
But within 60 days, things began to unravel. Unusual spikes in sales from Lernout & Hauspie's Asian division raised questions about the company's finances. Hundreds of millions of dollars in either missing or fictional revenues eventually forced Lernout & Hauspie to file for bankruptcy protection in Belgium and the United States.
Less than a year after the merger, Mr. Lernout and Mr. Hauspie are detained in Belgium, charged with stock manipulation and falsifying documents. The company has become the subject of numerous investigations, and its stock price has dropped more than 99 percent from its record of $72.50; it closed at 63 cents on Friday. It has been an embarrassing episode for the Belgian government and major investors like Microsoft.
The Bakers' tale has become a dramatic side plot to Lernout & Hauspie's financial travails. For the couple, it is not only about the hundreds of millions of dollars lost, but the pain of watching the disintegration of a company that represents two decades of their emotional, intellectual and financial investment. Since the acquisition, more than two-thirds of the 300 or so Dragon employees have left or have been laid off, including the vast majority of its engineers and researchers, who were considered the company's most valuable assets. 
Parts of Dragon's technology have already been sold to help pay Lernout & Hauspie's debts and settle disputes, including a sale of voice recognition technology to Visteon for $13 million -- far less than Mrs. Baker said it was worth. And two weeks ago, Lernout & Hauspie's current chief executive, Philippe Bodson, announced that the company would probably be forced to sell its assets, including the former Dragon, to pay its creditors.
"It's like being caught in the middle of a soap opera, and I've never liked soap operas," said Mrs. Baker, who, like her husband, seems more like a seasoned academic than an archetypal technology entrepreneur. "The idea of being trapped in one is very surreal."
Today, the Bakers spend 30 to 40 hours a week trying to extricate Dragon from Lernout & Hauspie. They have enlisted the law firm of David Boies, who represented the government in the Microsoft antitrust suit and Al Gore in the Florida election recount. The couple has tried to get the bankruptcy court to appoint a separate trustee for Dragon in the bankruptcy proceedings and has spent days testifying in court. The Bakers have expressed their desire to reacquire Dragon, or what is left of it.
But it may be too late to divorce Dragon from Lernout & Hauspie. "Dragon no longer exists," said John Shagoury, a former president of Dragon, who now heads a division of Lernout & Hauspie. "The Dragon technology is part of the business unit within Lernout & Hauspie."
The Bakers remain determined to reclaim their legacy. "If it was put back in the hands of the shareholders of Dragon, it could be rebuilt," Mrs. Baker said. "Surely it's a very strong setback -- you need to have more people and so forth -- but the technology is still at the top of its field."
The Lernout & Hauspie debacle is a sour patch for a 30-year-long speech technology love story. The Bakers built their marriage and lives around speech recognition, having met at Rockefeller University when they were graduate students in the early 1970's.
They worked together in a variety of speech research posts, and when they found themselves unemployed in 1982, they formed their own company in the nascent speech recognition industry, with no venture capital financing and no business plan.
What they did have were two young children, enough savings to last them about a year and a half, and a large mortgage on their white Victorian house, which also served as the company's first headquarters. The company's name came from Mrs. Baker's longtime passion for dragons, which her husband came to share. 
Today, their Victorian house is still filled with hundreds of dragons from all around the world -- ceramic, wooden, plush, metal, miniature, large, fierce and adorable. A wooden plaque that reads "Dragons' Lair" is on the front door. Even the wallpaper in the bathroom has dragons. 
It is from this house that the Bakers handle most of their legal battles. "The year of the dragon has been horrible for the company," said Mrs. Baker, referring to the Chinese zodiac designation for the year 2000.
The financial scandal that engulfed Lernout & Hauspie is a bitter irony for Dragon, a company that had followed a conservative fiscal course throughout its existence.
Speech technology is an exciting field that has always operated largely on its potential, promise and promotion. But Dragon Systems did not act like an explosive technological start-up. For its first 12 years, Dragon accepted no outside financing, subsisting on a modest diet of government contracts and special projects until a quarter of the company was sold to Seagate Technologies in 1994.
Mr. Baker immersed himself in the research, and Mrs. Baker, who has been dubbed the "Dragon Lady" by some in the industry for her ferocious negotiating, took charge of the business side.
After 15 years of modest success, the company finally had a big payoff in 1997 with Dragon NaturallySpeaking, inexpensive desktop software that recognized nearly continuous, almost natural speech. It became a top-selling software package, the salvation of bad typists and those suffering pain from the stress of keyboard use. The company won dozens of industry awards and was portrayed as a technological David battling the Goliath I.B.M. In one year, Dragon's revenues tripled.
By all accounts, the sudden growth spurt strained Dragon's ability to manage itself, which pushed it down the path of acquisition. There was a certain amount of financial naivete within the company, former and current employees say. The tight controls that helped Dragon through its early, lean years may have hindered it as it grew. For example, Janet Baker, as chief executive, personally had to authorize any purchase over $500 -- in a company with revenue that had by then reached $60 million.
Even in hindsight, the Bakers say there were no visible signs of Lernout & Hauspie's problems. For the deal, Dragon hired a premier crop of advisers -- Goldman, Sachs; Arthur Andersen; and the Boston law firm of Hale & Dorr -- all of whom approved the transaction. "We didn't cut any corners," Mrs. Baker said. "I don't know what we could have done differently."
Former executives at Dragon still defend the value of the acquisition, fraud charges aside. "The integration of the two technologies has gone even better than we hoped it would," said Jeanne McCann, a former vice president for development at Dragon who now works for Lernout & Hauspie. She pointed to the introduction of software that allows police officers to dictate their notes directly to a computer as a successful integration of the two technologies. 
In addition, other speech technology companies, like Speechworks and Nuance, have also had drops in their stock prices of more than 95 percent in the overall market downturn. "I don't know how much difference their fate would have been as shareholders, had there not been fraud," Ms. McCann said.
The speech technology industry, analysts say, will eventually recover from these setbacks. And people involved with Dragon agree that for the Bakers, the money is largely beside the point. The real tragedy for them is the loss of an innovative company's culture and the scattering of Dragon's concentration of talented engineers and researchers to other companies. 
Lernout & Hauspie's announcement that it would sell assets has created some hope for the Bakers, but it is so far unrealized. "If the Bakers found a financial backer with the right financial offer, the company and the creditors would certainly consider it," Mr. Shagoury of Lernout & Hauspie said.
But the Bakers say they have not yet received a warm reception to their overtures, although they remain upbeat as their legal battles continue. "Maybe this is the natural evolution of the dragon," Mrs. Baker said. "Dragons have a history of making themselves over."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Chief Financial Officer Is Dismissed at Lucent
Lucent Technologies, the troubled maker of communications equipment, dismissed its chief financial officer, Deborah C. Hopkins, in an effort to revamp the company's leadership.
 Ms. Hopkins, who had been chief financial officer for a little more than a year, will be succeeded by Frank D'Amelio, president of Lucent's switching solutions group. The departure of Ms. Hopkins comes after nearly a year of turmoil at Lucent, which is trying to raise cash by selling parts of its business and is restructuring after large losses. Page C2. 

Virgin Mobile in Talks on Venture
Virgin Mobile of Britain is in talks with Sprint to create a joint venture that would be the British company's first foray into the United States telecommunications market, people close to the discussions said. C2.

No Epitaph Yet for Pay Phones
Charlie Sullivan, president of ComChoice, a private pay phone company in Texas, disputes the widespread notion that cell phones are pushing pay phones off the American landscape. Mr. Sullivan is competing with the large phone companies by putting his phones in places where other phones, including wireless ones, are scarce and where people tend to make calls using coins instead of credit cards. "This whole idea that cell phone technology has killed the pay phone business is really not the case," he said. Industry data would seem to support his point. C4.

British Telecom Nears Revamp Plan
The board of British Telecommunications is scheduled to meet tomorrow to put the final touches on a restructuring plan that includes spinning off its wireless operations. The board is also expected to vote on a proposal to raise $7 billion by issuing equity to existing shareholders in what would be the largest rights issue in Britain's corporate history. C2.

Privacy Concerns for Google Archive
By reviving an archive of more than 650 million messages posted on electronic bulletin boards, known as Usenet newsgroups, Google has raised questions about the privacy implications of increasingly sophisticated search technology. New Economy. C4.

An Online Vintage, Still Unproved
After buying the assets of Wine.com, eVineyard has become the king of the category. The question now is whether eVineyard can hold onto that crown -- and whether enough consumers will warm to the idea of buying wine online to make the crown worth keeping. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C9.

No Code of Silence for Mafia Site
GangLandNews.com, created in 1996 and written by Jerry Capeci, the former organized-crime columnist at The Daily News, has become the equivalent of an online chat room for mobsters. It is the place where those interested in the Mafia, including current members, go for news on the latest underworld figures ranging from John Gotti to Leroy Barnes, above. C10.

Microsoft to Add Digital ID
Microsoft plans to incorporate a user-identification approach into its operating systems and software, and the company says the change could speed up business-to-business transactions and increase the level of confidence in those online transactions. C4.

Atlantic Monthly to Combine Issues
The Atlantic Monthly may soon have to change its name to The Atlantic 11-Times-a-Year. Starting this summer, it will combine the July and August issues. C10.

HEADLINE: America the Roughneck (Through Europe's Eyes) 

BYLINE:  By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: BERLIN, May 6 

 BODY:
Before becoming president, George W. Bush seemed acutely aware of the need for a country as powerful as the United States to show restraint. "If we are an arrogant nation, they will resent us," he said. "If we're a humble nation, but strong, they'll welcome us."
 The words appear to have been forgotten. A torrent of hostile articles in Europe has greeted Mr. Bush's first three months in office. Their chief theme has been the arrogance of what the German weekly Der Spiegel recently called "the snarling, ugly Americans." 
 On its Web site, the respected Munich daily Suddeutsche Zeitung lists seven articles summing up the themes of Mr. Bush's first 100 days. They are not unrepresentative of widespread European views. 
The titles include: "Selling Weapons to Taiwan: Bush Throws His Weight Around in the Pacific"; "North Korea: Bush Irritates the Asians"; "World Court: No Support From United States"; "Iraq: Bombing Instead of Diplomacy"; and "Climate Agreement: The United States Abandons the Kyoto Protocol."
There can be little doubt that it was irritation over those and other issues that lay behind the vote last week that ousted the United States from the United Nations Human Rights Commission for the first time, while leaving countries like Algeria and Libya as elected members.
Speaking in Berlin today, Richard C. Holbrooke, the former United States ambassador to the United Nations, described the administration's foreign policy as "unsmooth" and the handling of environmental issues as "disastrous." But he noted that the Bush team is still taking shape and that transitions always involve difficulties.
Certainly, Mr. Bush's predecessor had problems. In their current irritation, European officials appear to have forgotten that the president whose absence they now seem to rue -- Bill Clinton -- infuriated them in his first year in office by appearing to pay scant attention to the Continent, dithering over Bosnia, and long delaying his first visit.
Those officials, and particularly the French, also seem inclined to overlook the fact that discomfort or irritation with the extent of post-cold-war American power -- military, political, economic and cultural -- has been running high for some time.
Well before Mr. Bush's arrival in office, France began referring to the United States as a "hyper-power." Other countries, from Russia to China, have also made much of the need for "counterbalances" to American power. In this sense, any missteps by the Republican administration have provided ammunition for a gun already partly loaded.
But Mr. Bush's apparent insensitivity to European concerns on a broad range of issues -- he has never visited London or Paris or Berlin -- has clearly opened the way for a season of America bashing.
Celebrating the record number of votes -- 52 of a possible 53 -- won by France in the election that ousted the United States, Jean-David Levitte, the French ambassador to the United Nations, attributed his country's success to a French foreign policy "founded on dialogue and respect."
The message was clear: the embarrassing snub to the United States could be attributed to a seeming absence of "dialogue and respect" in the Bush administration's approach to the outside world.
In their glee at America's discomfort in the vote, the Chinese used language similar to that used by the French. The ousting, for China, showed that the United States had "undermined the atmosphere for dialogue."
The time has arrived for the United States "to enter into dialogue on equal footing with other countries, rich or poor, strong or weak" and to stop using "human rights issues as a tool to pursue its power politics and hegemonism," China said.
Instructions from China on human rights seem certain to raise as many eyebrows in Washington as French tips on diplomacy do. But there is little doubt that Mr. Bush's generally more confrontational stance on Russia and China, his apparently slow learning curve on how much the environment matters to Europeans and his lukewarm support for South Korea's so-called sunshine policy for improving relations with the North have reinforced a European sense that the United States is a power more inclined than before to ride roughshod over its allies.
When Michael Steiner, the chief diplomatic aide to Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany, visited Washington earlier this year, he was surprised to find Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, telling him that he must be aware that the only way to get results from the Russians was to be tough with them.
That was one small example of the ways in which the Bush administration seems to be out of step in its thinking with a European Union disinclined to reopen divisions on the Continent and generally more concerned about the quality of food and the environment than possible security threats from Moscow or North Korea.
But Karl Kaiser, a German foreign policy analyst, said he thought that awareness of those differences was growing in the Bush administration and he questioned whether there was any deep justification for European anxieties.
He noted that Mr. Bush's recent policy speech on a possible missile defense shield was marked by extreme sensitivity to allied and Russian concerns. The antimissile project, Mr. Kaiser went on, is no longer "national" but intended to help all friendly countries; it will be built only after thorough consultation.
"Through this speech, Mr. Bush clearly differentiated himself from the Republican right wing and marked a return to the mainstream of multilateralism," Mr. Kaiser said. 
How far such a "return" will go remains to be seen; currents of unilateralism seem far stronger in this administration than in any for some time. But it does seem clear that the speech reflected the concern of Colin L. Powell's State Department -- the one office of the Bush administration that has been spared the harsh criticism reserved in Europe for the Pentagon and the White House.
One particular target of European criticism has been President Bush's policy toward China, and particularly his strong expressions of support for Taiwan that have been widely viewed as unnecessarily provocative. Europe, like Russia, has been concerned that America is throwing its weight around in a reckless manner. 
But James R. Lilley, a former United States ambassador to China, said that while it was fair to say that, "Until you get your act together, you are going to cause some concern," the Europeans had overstated the dangers.
"The fact is China and Taiwan are moving together economically," he said. "The compelling fact of making money together undercuts the notion of estrangement." No American weapons sales to Taiwan would alter that reality, he said. 
In the end, it may be style as much as substance that is causing the growing hostility to the United States. The revival of some cold war language under Mr. Bush and the emergence into clearer view of another America more concerned with itself and quite at ease with the death penalty has come as a shock to many outside the country.
In Britain the other day, The Guardian described America's position on the death penalty as "morally untenable." Of course, that position may be many things, but it is scarcely "untenable," just as America's human-rights record may have blemishes but is hardly comparable to that of Algeria.
That, however, is not the point. The fact is Mr. Bush has contrived to prove his own theory that arrogance provokes resentment for a country that, long before his arrival, was already the world's most conspicuous and convenient target.

An article yesterday about European irritation with the Bush administration misstated the sparseness of President Bush's travels in Western Europe. While he has never been to Berlin, The White House says he indeed visited London and Paris, in the 1980's.

HEADLINE: 4 Democrats Spar Cordially In Mayor Race 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
The four major Democrats who are seeking to be New York's next mayor strode out on the public stage for their first televised debate yesterday, gently jousting over such subjects as cutting taxes, disciplining the four officers in the Amadou Diallo case, and whether the city should help finance the construction of stadiums for the Mets and Yankees.
 But for the most part, the four offered a fairly uniform view of where they would take the city once Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani leaves office at the end of the year, as well as similar judgments of how Mr. Giuliani, a Republican, succeeded and failed over the last eight years. 
 The hourlong debate -- with Fernando Ferrer, Mark Green, Alan G. Hevesi and Peter F. Vallone -- marked the start of a presumably more vibrant chapter in what has to date been a fairly low-flying contest for the Democratic nomination to succeed Mr. Giuliani. Excerpts, Page B3. 
That said, a viewer who stumbled across the 9 a.m. telecast on WNBC, Channel 4, which sponsored the debate with The Daily News, would find little evidence of just how close the candidates believe their competition to be.
To a person, they were cordial and deferential, and more likely to go after their questioners than their opponents. The men who would follow Mr. Giuliani, at times, even raised their hands like schoolchildren as they sought to be recognized by their questioners.
"I'm sorry, Mark, do you want to go first?" Mr. Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, inquired gently of Mr. Green, the public advocate, touching his arm as the two men sought to respond at the same time to a question. On the other side of the set at Rockefeller Center, Mr. Vallone, the City Council speaker, kept smiling and praising Mr. Hevesi as "my friend," even as he sought to diminish the importance of the job Mr. Hevesi holds as the city comptroller.
Still, the debate provided the four major candidates on the Sept. 11 Democratic primary ballot a chance to lay out their appeals to a viewing audience that was, presumably, far larger than any they had faced over months of appearances at union halls, churches, community meetings and on the steps of City Hall.
For Mr. Vallone, that meant claiming credit for what he said were the city's advances over the last eight years -- "We've made the city a lot better" -- while saying that he was the only one who would not need on-the-job training.
Mr. Ferrer lamented what he saw as the huge disparity between those who had prospered under Mr. Giuliani and those who had not, particularly when it came to public spending on education and housing.
Mr. Green presented himself as "a fighter and a problem solver," pledging to reduce class sizes in lower grades in school and to push to create new jobs in the city economy.
And Mr. Hevesi repeatedly raised concerns about the budget proposal made by Mr. Giuliani for 2002. He described it as a "time bomb that will detonate the city's fiscal health" in future years, and he repeatedly challenged his panel of questioners to raise the issue.
"Hanging in the air is the question that I posed about the attitude of all of us and the Council about the dangers of this budget in the out years," Mr. Hevesi said at one point. "Should we just leave it hanging there? Because the fiscal monitors are going to be commenting on this. This is deadly serious."
At times, the exchanges among these four longtime figures in New York government sounded a bit like an accounting seminar, particularly when Mr. Hevesi and Mr. Vallone fell into rather arcane discussions about the budget proposal.
One of the hosts, Gabe Pressman of WNBC, kept jumping in to offer definitions of such phrases as out years and debt service for an audience that might not be as well versed on the subject.
Even in this clubby atmosphere, the candidates drew some distinctions among them.
Both Mr. Ferrer and Mr. Hevesi said the four police officers who fatally shot Mr. Diallo, an unarmed immigrant, should be dismissed from the Police Department for what Mr. Ferrer described as "a demonstration of manifestly awful and tragic judgment," even though the officers had been cleared by a jury in State Supreme Court and after an internal police investigation. When one of the hosts, Michael Kramer of The Daily News, asked whether Mr. Ferrer was trying to make scapegoats of the officers, Mr. Ferrer vigorously disagreed.
"It's not about making scapegoats," Mr. Ferrer responded. "This is about, Michael, accountability."
Mr. Hevesi, who has been criticized by some Democrats for being reticent about police misconduct before he began campaigning, took a notably harsh line. "My attitude is that they have not been exonerated and shouldn't be serving as police officers now."
By contrast, Mr. Vallone and Mr. Green, who has historically been one of the Police Department's vocal critics, said they should not be fired. "The killing of Amadou Diallo was a great tragedy, but a court said it was not a crime," Mr. Green said. "As a lawyer who believes in due process, I think it is very inadvisable for a politician like the mayor or a candidate for mayor to intervene in an individual proceeding and say, 'Off with their heads,' before we know the evidence and we know the result."
Mr. Vallone said that the responsibility "is not with those four police officers, it's with the training and procedure that led to that."
All four candidates seemed surprised when Mr. Kramer asked them whom they would vote for in a hypothetical contest with Mr. Giuliani and two former Democratic mayors, David N. Dinkins and Edward I. Koch.
Mr. Vallone instantly responded, saying Mr. Koch. That drew appreciative, if slightly cynical, laughter from the other candidates, aware that Mr. Koch has endorsed Mr. Vallone. Mr. Green said Mr. Dinkins, a response that was not surprising considering that Mr. Green has been actively seeking the support of Mr. Dinkins, the city's first black mayor.
By contrast, Mr. Ferrer, who has also been seeking Mr. Dinkins's support, seemed to be caught off guard. Rather than using the opportunity to continue his courtship of Mr. Dinkins, he offered such an equivocal answer that Mr. Kramer cut him off, saying, "Right, O.K., we get it, you want to dodge it."
Mr. Hevesi did not answer the question at all. Instead, sounding like the college professor that he was, he scolded Mr. Kramer for even asking it. "That's the kind of question that's intended to get less information and more contention, which comports to a journalistic culture," Mr. Hevesi said sternly. "So I'm not sure I need to offend any of these distinguished New Yorkers by selecting one as against the other."
Of the four, Mr. Green was the only candidate who ruled out using city money to finance the construction of new sports stadiums, saying it would drain money from other city programs. Mr. Hevesi said the city should do it, if it could afford it, and Mr. Vallone argued that such an investment would spur economic growth. Mr. Ferrer said he supported only a minimal public investment in stadium building.
"This is again about choices," Mr. Ferrer said. "That mayoral plan to build a billion-dollar stadium on the West Side of Manhattan was an allegory about choices. Are we all going mad as a city when we're prepared to empty our pockets of more than a billion dollars when we need to build schools, affordable housing, libraries and health care?"
The four candidates also suggested that teacher salaries should be raised to make New York more competitive with the suburbs. Mr. Ferrer reiterated his call for a 30 percent increase, tied to concessions on work rules from teachers. That promise drew an arch response from his rivals, who suggested he should not be negotiating from the platform of a mayoral campaign.
"You don't talk about percentage increase, certainly not as a mayor or a mayoral candidate," Mr. Vallone said. Mr. Green said he supported "higher pay -- but you don't give away 30 percent on a TV show." 
Both Mr. Green and Mr. Ferrer criticized Mr. Giuliani's call for more tax cuts. Mr. Green said that given the city's economy, "neither a tax hike or cut, I think, would be prudent right now." Mr. Ferrer called the mayor's proposed cut in personal income taxes "trivial," and he said it would inevitably force cuts in education and housing spending.
By contrast, Mr. Hevesi said he was prepared, if the city's fiscal situation grew worse, to support a temporary city income tax surcharge, similar to the one that had been used to finance the hiring of police officers, to make "sure we didn't have a teacher shortage, that we had equipment in the classroom, longer school day and an extended curriculum, a core curriculum and all the other reforms that have to be made."
But Mr. Vallone, who is positioning himself to run on the final budget he negotiates with Mr. Giuliani, with at least some tax cuts, scolded Mr. Hevesi. "There's no necessity to be talking about taxes now," Mr. Vallone said. "That's an outrage."
The four candidates all declared that they would put an end to one of the more visible legacies of Mr. Giuliani's tenure: the police checkpoints that prevent New Yorkers from going near City Hall, as well as what some civic groups and journalists have complained is the difficulty of getting information from City Hall.
"I would open up the park, open up the government," Mr. Green said.
Mr. Ferrer put it more bluntly: "My answer is -- with a front-end loader. The first day I'm mayor."

HEADLINE: Dream Prize Draws Closer For Murdoch 

BYLINE:  By JIM RUTENBERG and GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
As Rupert Murdoch's dream of owning a satellite television system in the United States came a big step closer to reality last week, rival media companies began bracing for Mr. Murdoch to become an even fiercer competitor in the American TV industry. 
 After months of tentative discussions, the board of General Motors agreed on Tuesday to begin negotiating in earnest to sell control of G.M.'s Hughes Electronics division to Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation. 
 Hughes contains several businesses. But the prize is DirecTV, the fast-growing satellite television service now in nearly 10 million American households. As the nation's third-largest provider of subscription TV, it ranks behind only AT&T (with more than 15 million subscribers) and Time Warner Cable (13 million), and has become a force in an arena once fully controlled by the cable industry. 
The general consensus is that DirecTV would give new leverage to the News Corporation -- already a TV power with its Fox broadcasting network, 33 local stations and cable holdings like the Fox News Channel and a clutch of regional Fox Sports networks.
Barry Diller, chairman of the cable and broadcasting company USA Networks, said he would regard a Murdoch-owned DirecTV as "the first real competition to cable."
"He will cut the prices," Mr. Diller said, "and use every competitive strategy to create a winning path for satellite."
News Corporation, citing the negotiations, said it had no official comment on the possible deal, which the companies said they hoped to complete within a few weeks. 
Despite building DirecTV's growth from a mere 1.5 million subscribers in 1996, Hughes under G.M. has not been in a position to bring the media muscle to the business that News Corporation could. 
Mr. Murdoch has said that his company could double the DirecTV subscriber base, to nearly 20 million, by significantly lowering prices and aggressively marketing the product through his Fox TV outlets. He could also eliminate Hughes's middleman status and reap the revenues directly each time a DirecTV viewer watches one of News Corporation's 20th Century Fox films on pay-per-view.
And because News Corporation already owns satellite networks serving more than 100 million households around the world -- with heavy concentrations in Britain, China and India -- Mr. Murdoch has the power to buy consumer receiving equipment in bulk. That could enable DirecTV to lower substantially the average cost -- now estimated at more than $500 a household -- of acquiring each new customer.
"The rationale for Hughes to align itself with News Corporation is to effectively drive down the cost of acquiring customers," said Christopher Dixon, a media analyst at UBS Warburg.
Analysts, meanwhile, say DirecTV would allow Mr. Murdoch to start new channels on his own without an initial reliance on cable companies.
All pieces of Hughes, though, would not be an ideal fit for News Corporation. One operation, Hughes Network Systems, which provides private business satellite networks for companies like Wal-Mart, would bring no clear synergies. Selling it might be an option, analysts said.
Hughes also owns 81 percent of PanAmSat, a major relayer of programming for networks that span the cable dial, including CNN from AOL Time Warner, ESPN from Walt Disney and MTV from Viacom. 
While control of PanAmSat might seem to give Mr. Murdoch awesome power over his media rivals, analysts note that it is primarily a common carrier already locked into long-term contracts that would be difficult to change. Besides, any attempt to coerce customers could drive them to PanAmSat's successful rival, GE Americom, and draw objections from regulators.
People inside and outside News Corporation say that if it does gain control of Hughes, the company may consider selling the PanAmSat stake, which has a current market value of $4.3 billion, to help finance the Hughes purchase, expected to cost around $7.2 billion. Finding a buyer, particularly in the current economic climate, may not be easy, though.
"There are not a lot of people looking to buy PanAmSat," said William Kidd, a satellite analyst at C. S. Unterberg, Towbin.
More complementary to the News Corporation empire is the DirecTV Latin America unit, whose only rival in the region is Mr. Murdoch's Sky Latin America. Hughes has a 78 percent stake in DirecTV Latin America, with the Cisneros Group, a Venezuelan media giant, as a minority investor. The service has slightly more than 1.4 million subscribers, compared with about 1.5 million subscribers for Sky Latin America, which News Corporation owns in a partnership with Grupo Televisa of Mexico and Rede Globo of Brazil.
Both of the Latin services are losing money. And although the losses are declining, Larry Haverty, an analyst at State Street Research, said that satellite TV was a luxury product in Latin America, and as such its market was limited. In the past, the two Latin America satellite services have explored a merger to save costs, and consolidating the operations under News Corporation could increase the likelihood of eventually turning a profit, Mr. Haverty said.
For Mr. Murdoch, though, a potentially bigger lure for the Hughes deal is the various benefits it would bring to his media operations in the United States, where News Corporation has tended to operate in the shadow of companies like AOL Time Warner.
DirecTV, for example, offers viewers an interactive programming guide that lists the schedules of the various channels. To view any program on the schedule, a user need only highlight the program's listing with the remote control, then push a button. Mr. Murdoch could replace this DirecTV guide with the Gemstar TV Guide interactive guide, a business of which News Corporation already owns 43 percent. Consumer advocates have raised concerns that television providers might use such guides to favor their own programming. The News Corporation has said it does not intend to use its guide unfairly.
One top executive at a major cable company said he was more worried that News Corporation could use DirecTV to force cable operators to pay higher rates to carry the popular regional Fox Sports networks, under the threat of otherwise distributing them only on the satellite service. But one News Corporation executive, speaking on condition of anonymity, called this an unfounded fear. It would not be in New Corporation's interests to alienate cable companies that it will have to continue to rely on for distribution of its cable channels.
Certainly, though, DirecTV could give Mr. Murdoch new leverage in persuading companies like AOL Time Warner to carry new Fox cable channel offerings in return for placing their new offerings on DirecTV.
At least one big rival said last week he had no fear of a News Corporation-DirecTV deal. Speaking at a Credit Suisse First Boston conference last week, Gerald M. Levin, AOL Time Warner's chief executive, said he believed that digital cable systems were ultimately far better positioned than satellite TV to offer high-speed Internet and interactive services like movies on demand and the ability to purchase goods through interactive TV. That is because cable allows for more efficient two-way communication, while satellite television has no built-in return path. (Satellite users are typically forced to use cumbersome phone connections to communicate with the system operator.)
But Jack Myers, chief economist of the Myers Reports, which publishes media and research newsletters, said in an interview that the News Corporation's BSkyB satellite service in Britain, which depends on phone lines for the return path, was already offering the sorts of interactive services that are still experiments for American cable companies. BSkyB has five million British customers who can use their satellite television systems to do banking, purchase Domino's pizzas and even gamble on sports events.
A News Corporation executive said the company believed it could offer similar services here in relatively short order with DirecTV -- especially with the help of Microsoft, which has agreed to be a minority partner in the Hughes deal, kicking in $3 billion. 
Of course, all this assumes a deal can be completed. On Thursday, Charles Ergen, chief executive of DirecTV's smaller rival, EchoStar Communications, said during a conference call with analysts that he thought his company would be a better partner for DirecTV. His comments prompted speculation that he might make his own bid for Hughes. EchoStar did not refute that speculation, although executives at Hughes and News Corporation said on Friday that they thought it was unlikely such a bid would succeed.
Those who have watched Mr. Murdoch closely over the years say he has a way of succeeding when he puts his mind to things, and he certainly has put his mind to controlling DirecTV.
"People have always underestimated Rupert Murdoch," said Mr. Myers, who pointed to Mr. Murdoch's earlier ventures, Fox and Fox News Channel, which have succeeded despite early skepticism. "And he continues to operate in a marketplace where expectations are low though performance is high."

HEADLINE: Debt Offerings Scheduled for This Week 

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financings this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, joined by note auctions of a five-year maturity tomorrow and a 10-year on Wednesday.
 By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 3.63 percent and a six-month bill was 3.64 percent. In when-issued trading ahead of the note auctions, the five-year was trading at a price to yield 4.70 percent and the 10-year, 5.21 percent.

HEADLINE: In Surprise, Novartis Gets A 20% Stake In Roche 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, May 7 

 BODY:
Novartis startled investors today by announcing that it had bought a 20 percent stake in Roche Holding for $2.8 billion in cash, raising the prospect that the two drug makers might later merge.
 Each company is a global pharmaceutical giant, and both are based in Basel, Switzerland. In recent years Novartis, with a strong crop of new drugs, has grown faster than Roche and has overtaken it in size. Sluggish sales of Xenical, Roche's flagship anti-obesity drug, and a thin pipeline of new products have diminished the prospects for the company, once the world's biggest and most profitable drug maker. 
 The announcement of the Novartis move ignited a storm of takeover speculation in the Swiss drug industry, a crucial part of the country's economy. A combination would create a company with more than $20 billion in pharmaceutical sales a year, a more formidable rival to the biggest companies in the industry, Pfizer and GlaxoSmithKline. Novartis is itself the product of a blockbuster 1996 merger combining two Swiss drug and chemical makers, Sandoz and Ciba-Geigy. It now employs 69,000 people and operates in 142 countries; Roche has 65,000 workers in 150 countries.
Novartis said it had acquired 32 million Roche "bearer" shares, whose ownership is not registered by the company, for $87 apiece, about 5 percent more than their closing price of $83.20 a share on Friday.
"This is a long-term financial investment, which is also strategic in nature," said Daniel Vasella, chairman and chief executive of Novartis. In a telephone interview, Mr. Vasella said his company's purchase "came as a surprise" to Roche.
"No collaboration has been discussed with Roche management," he said, "although we hope over time we will be able to explore areas of collaboration, as Roche has good long-term business prospects."
Novartis has no timeline for a merger, Mr. Vasella said, adding that such a move would have to be preceded by a look at the product lines. A merger, he said, "is not a must, but it would be great."
Many analysts had thought the best way for Roche to secure its future was by buying a company with some late-stage drugs ready to bring to market. The company had been mentioned as a potential bidder for the United States pharmaceutical operations of DuPont.
Critics of the Novartis purchase questioned the wisdom of investing in a rival in relatively staid Europe when drug sales in the United States are growing at twice the pace -- 15 percent in the year ended Feb. 28.
Roche sought to dampen speculation of a merger with Novartis, saying that the two companies would merely cooperate when it made sense commercially. 
Michel Venanzi, an analyst at Darier Hentsch, agreed. While Roche's short-term prospects are wobbly, he said, "Roche has a lot of hidden value, including its stake in Genentech, which has a 25 percent sales growth on average." Roche has majority control of Genentech, an American biotechnology company. 
"This purchase clearly has a strategic touch, and is more than just an investment," said Mattias Fehr of Lombard Odier & Cie. "Once everything settles down, it may be clearer what they plan to do."
Roche's shares have slumped because its drug sales rose only 1 percent last year, while competitors were chalking up double-digit gains. Roche has said it is considering layoffs of up to 12 percent of its worldwide staff to cut costs. But Roche officials see a brighter future in the 63 drugs in its development pipeline, and in the Genentech products it markets outside the United States.
Roche management reportedly learned of the Novartis move over the weekend, ending uncertainty over what would become of the block of stock, which had been put up for sale by the Swiss financier Martin Ebner. As Roche's biggest shareholder after the Hoffman and Oeri families, who founded the company's predecessor concerns, Mr. Ebner had campaigned to open up the company's structure, and had accused Roche directors of misleading investors about the company's condition and outlook, especially in last year's annual report. Mr. Ebner wanted the company to name more independent directors and had tried unsuccessfully to win a seat of his own last year.
Unhappy with the 105-year-old company's recent performance and unable to force it to revamp itself, he and his investment company, the BZ Group, decided to sell out instead.
